DOC.HEAD: Voice-Activated Typewriter Unveiled
LaserPhoto BX3
DOC.TEXT: A new, voice-activated ``typewriter'' is a science-fiction dream-turned-reality that promises to boost productivity and open a world of opportunity for the handicapped. The DragonDictate Voice-Typewriter, which was being formally unveiled today by Dragon Systems Inc., is billed as the first of its kind in the world. ``My only regret is that your product didn't come out 20 years ago,'' Frank Whitney, a quadriplegic Maryland computer scientist, told the company in a letter written on the system. Whitney has used the system for the past year. The ``typewriter,'' which consists of software and a speech-recognition circuit board for personal computers, allows users to create memos, manuscripts and other documents by speaking instead of typing. Users speak into a microphone and see text appear on a video screen at the rate of 35 words a minute. The $9,000 system can recognize 30,000 words and adapt itself to individual speakers. Until now, voice-activated systems had not been able to recognize more than 5,000 words. The commands are simple. To turn off the system, one says, ``Voice Console: Go to Sleep.'' To turn it on, the command is ``Voice Console: Wake Up.'' A mistake is corrected by saying ``oops'' and repeating the correct word. Many functions can be operated manually as well. ``The technology can address all segments of the workplace,'' says Janet Baker, who founded the company with her husband, James, in 1982 after stints in speech-recognition product development at IBM Corp. and Exxon Corp. The system is designed for professionals who don't type well or who want to write reports and letters that otherwise would be dictated to a secretary, then transcribed. ``The only people who are really good typists are journalists, computer programmers and secretaries,'' said Baker. ``Doctors, lawyers and a lot of other people often just hunt and peck or they rely on handing notes to someone to type up.'' DragonDictate is also seen as a great boon to the disabled. Whitney and others with disabilities have used the system in test marketing around the country for the past year. Laura Harris, a 19-year-old sophomore at Harvard University, was born without fingers on her left hand. She taught herself to type with her right hand, but did so much typing as a freshman government major, she injured her hand. She was forced to dictate her papers into a tape recorder and give it to another student to transcribe. Since January, Harris has used DragonDictate. ``It was so hard to dictate before because I couldn't actually see what I was writing, so I couldn't edit. I often ended up trying to write longhand and that was painful,'' said Harris. ``DragonDictate is just amazing. It allows me to go back to typing and editing my work.'' The system adjusts to each user's voice and vocabulary because individual voices can vary widely. DragonDictate is compatible with an IBM personal computer with a 386 microprocessor.

DOC.HEAD: Change in Eastern Europe Spurs Activity At U.S. Think Tanks
DOC.TEXT: These are heady days at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, where scholars surrounded by the largest collection of Soviet papers outside the Kremlin hope to close the book on communism. They are scouring Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, sweeping up papers, posters and other artifacts to add to the 25 miles of library shelves that house everything from the first editions of Pravda to the latest speeches by Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. The late President Hoover, a lifelong foe of communism, founded the library with his own World War I collection two years after the 1917 Soviet revolution. Today, more than merely collecting, Hoover economists, historians and political scientists are analyzing and playing a role in the transition of the Soviet bloc by meeting with leaders of the new governments and U.S. officials. Former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, an honorary fellow at Hoover, and U.S. Ambassador to Czechoslovakia Shirley Temple Black, a former member of Hoover's board of overseers, are helping set up some of the meetings. ``We are in a new era that is revolutionary,'' Shultz said in an interview in his office at Hoover, in the center of the Stanford University campus. ``It is fascinating to think about the problems of transition from one kind of system to another kind, how you manage that. Some people here will be thinking about that and studying that and trying to be helpful to people doing that through this period. I want to be part of that process of change.'' Other think tanks are similarly abuzz with scholars looking at upheavals overseas. The Center for Strategic and International Studies, based in Washington, sees its mission now as helping America cope with a radically different world, said Robert E. Hunter, vice president of the center's regional programs. Some of the academic cold warriors have even taken to gloating about the changes in the Soviet bloc, which they believe were pushed along by their policy recommendations. ``We absolutely feel vindicated,'' said Burton Yales Pines, senior vice president of the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington. ``It's a nice feeling. It's not often that it's given to people to feel victory the way we've felt it the last year and a half.'' But the general consensus among scholars that communism is dying out, four months after the Berlin Wall began coming down, ``is still based in some optimism,'' said Hoover acting Director John Raisian. ``We're hopeful there won't be any fallbacks. It's not quite over, but it's proceeding along those lines.'' Recently retired Hoover director W. Glenn Campbell warns that ``communism is far from dead yet. ``No one has said communism is dead in China, North Korea or Cuba. And there are enormous problems in privatizing all the economies in the countries wrecked, getting a price system, getting a foreign exchange. There are a whole host of problems and anything can happen.'' But there is a pervasive sense among some scholars that communism has been exposed as a failed experiment. ``I think the idea that you can run a society or an economy effectively by centrally placed authoritarian or dictatorial means has been proven bankrupt,'' Shultz said.

DOC.HEAD: Glorious Color and Creativity at Lacroix
DOC.TEXT: Sparkling with color, luxury and youthful abandon, Christian Lacroix's show of ready-to-wear and Luxe lines was a winner for women who want to have fun looking feminine. The lean pants, minis, tunics and fitted or smocky tops of the ready-to-wear line shown Sunday melded right into the more expensive Luxe. ``I love it,'' said John Fairchild, publisher of Women's Wear Daily and W. ``It's highly decorative. He gives the clothes personality more than any other designer, and it's never boring.'' Looking pale but happy, Lacroix took a bow after the intimate show in his shop on a sunny day. He still is recovering from two back operations and walked stiffly. The eye-catching clothes went from reversible shocking pink and orange shortie trapeze toppers over pink tights and orange suede over-the-knee boots to little burgundy-yellow-black bicycle tights with pullovers or V-necked mini-tunics in chartreuse and rust with ribbed tights. Lacroix also worked with a wealth of fabrics. Typical was an outfit featuring a jewel-buttoned burgundy and yellow jacket in a patchwork of little hearts and geometrics over a flowered tapestry miniskirt. Lacroix's favorite folklore themes were in both collections, like the opulent fortuneteller or gypsy skirts with velvet star and baroque embroideries on jackets and full multicolored silk skirts. He also made a hit with his bright pink suits, elaborately embroidered and piped with lush black velvet. When presented with boleros, these ``suits of light'' were a dashing salute to the bull rings of Spain and Lacroix's native Arles. From the simple black crepe sheath with its split skirt topped by a jeweled flower, to the little white satin collared navy georgette and chiffon numbers with flippy godet flares, the clothes were showy, fun and luxurious. ``Totally wearable and saleable,'' said Ellin Saltzman, vice president and creative director of R.H. Macy. Lynn Manulis of Martha's boutiques, another American who adored the show, said: ``I'd like to buy the whole collection. It's varied and cohesive; he has a kind of genius. I think finally the public is ready for him. This seems to point the way we're going.'' Another winner for color was Italian Enrico Coveri. He drew inspiration from the ski slopes, showing brightly flowered long pullovers paired with stretch tights, plus some hot numbers based on ski suits appliqued with starfish designs. His plaid suits with long tweed jackets, matching brimmed hats and shortie sarong-split skirts were fetching for daytime. And the gym-suit body stocking worn with lame boots and a cape of multicolored outsized mirror sequins would knock them dead on the ski scene. Meanwhile, Italian Romeo Gigli's Saturday night show drew kudos for artistry. Gigli went on his usual exotic trip of fabrics, producing heart-shaped coats in luxurious silks and velvets of brown and bordeaux. The coats, worn over narrow stretch pants, often had shawl collars so huge they completely engulfed necks and shoulders _ the neckless, shoulderless look all part of the heart-shaped silhouette. In shades of bordeaux, rust and fuchsia, Gigli played around with the big-collared shortie coats crackling with flame-shaped hems over the leanest striped pants. That outfit was topped by a gold-embroidered red velvet wimple.

DOC.HEAD: What Do Heart Doctors Eat In The Cholesterol Capital Of America?
DOC.TEXT: In New Orleans, it seems almost every other recipe begins, ``Take a stick of butter ...'' What isn't cooked with butter is likely to be deep-fried or seasoned with fat pork. So what will 24,000 heart doctors eat during the American College of Cardiology's convention this week? ``At all the official events, we serve heart-healthy foods so `60 Minutes' doesn't end up at our convention and show that there's a contradiction of terms going on,'' said Linda Karson, director of meeting services for the American College of Cardiology. That means cereal, muffins, yogurt and fruit for breakfast, rather than eggs Sardou or any of the other cholesterol-laden local breakfast favorites. Lunches and dinner menus are heavy on fish and chicken, with vegetables and lots of green and pasta salads. One of the biggest challenges, Karson said, was working up a menu for Tuesday night's ``Sights, Sounds, Music, Food and Culture of New Orleans.'' ``Doing heart-healthy food in New Orleans is kind of a contradiction in terms,'' she acknowledged. Tuesday night's menu includes ``Cajun potpourri gumbo'' with chicken and fish but without cholesterol-laden shellfish _ an essential ingredient of seafood gumbo _ or sausage, which is almost always included with chicken. The red beans and rice will not have any salt pork or ham hocks, and the po-boy sandwiches will have lean meat and low-cholesterol mayo. The andouille sausage will be made with turkey, and the jambalaya with chicken. ``We'll give them the atmosphere of it, more than the actual food,'' said Karson. But even heart doctors are likely to splurge on their diets in New Orleans. In November, Mother's restaurant, which specializes in po-boys, sausage-and-chicken jambalaya and pork-seasoned red beans, was full of conventioneers wearing American Heart Association nametags. Doctors could be seen in tonier restaurants at dinner, chowing down on red meat, chicken and fish with buttery sauces, and New Orleans-style barbecued shrimp, which comes to the table swimming in spicy butter. ``I think the majority of people, when they hit New Orleans, kind of say `Well, throw it to the winds,''' said Kermit Cosse, associate general manager at Antoine's. ``We're known for so many restaurants in New Orleans, and we're known for food.'' But Lally Brennan, one of the workers at Commander's Palace, said the restaurant includes light entrees on the menu and finds many heart doctors take advantage of them. ``Whenever we have cardiologists in town, they always want lighter-type foods,'' she said. ``We put lots of fish on the menu with light sauces because we know they'll ask for it. We still have our other goodies if they want to splurge. But we expect them to order a lot of the lighter things.'' The food vendors at the New Orleans Convention Center will offer some healthy foods as well as their standard hot dogs, hamburgers and sandwiches, Karson said. ``They did offer a whole lot of heart-healthy food during the American Heart Association meeting,'' she said. ``The big joke is they've got caseloads of turkey dogs left. They didn't really go.'' Karson acknowledged that meeting organizers can't stop private concessionaires from selling _ nor doctors from eating _ what they want at the convention. ``We won't say everyone's real concerned about heart-healthy food,'' she said. ``But at least we can say we've made a real effort to provide it.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Prisons Making it Easier for Mothers Behind Bars
LaserPhoto HF1
DOC.TEXT: Sylvia Jenkins is matter-of-fact about the drug conviction that landed her in federal prison, but mention her two young grandchildren and tears trickle down her cheeks. ``It's very hard,'' said Jenkins, who won't let the children visit her because she hates to watch them leave. ``Every time they want to come up, I say, `Not this weekend.''' Jenkins, 52, is pulling a five-year stretch at the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury. She has a running track, a view of gentle hills and a job as a tutor. And now, there are also innovative programs to help people like her deal with the emotions of being a mother or grandmother behind bars _ and the reunion when she finishes her time. There are more than 2,000 mothers in federal prisons across the country. The system is providing such things as parenting classes and special visitation days. The government wants female inmates to be better prepared when they leave prison to deal with their families, said Ann Bartolo, chief of the female offender section of the federal Bureau of Prisons. Bartolo's latest project is a program allowing pregnant inmates to stay at halfway houses three months after giving birth so they can keep the babies with them. Mothers now can keep their babies only two days before giving them to relatives or foster families. About 3,150 women live in eight permanent and five temporary facilities in the federal prison system. About 75 percent have children, ranging in age from 6 months to 45 years. Fifty inmates are pregnant. Danbury is considered one of the better prisons. It's a minimum-security camp on the fringe of a men's penitentiary. There are no bars, and pictures of loved ones are allowed atop short metal lockers where inmates keep their clothes. The prison started a special family day last year, allowing children inside for a day to see where mother eats and sleeps. ``It's fairly relaxed. There's nothing up there that gives you a prison atmosphere,'' said superintendent John Sullivan, a father of seven who oversees 170 women in the camp and 1,100 men in the penitentiary. Children also attend events like graduations, where they see their mothers in caps and gowns accepting high school diplomas. Another of the federal system's programs has playrooms in women's prisons and sets up a counseling service for family emergencies, such as drug arrests or bad grades in school, Bartolo said. A parenting class is so popular in Danbury it even draws inmates without children. The program helps women understand their relationship with their own parents while teaching them to deal with their children. ``It's training the inmate in parenting skills _ what does it mean now that they're going to be in for X amount of years and this child most likely will be attached to a foster parent,'' Bartolo said. ``It helps the mother (after she's released) to slowly walk into this child's life and also to deal with her skills as a parent, how to deal with discipline and anger the child feels that she wasn't with her all the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Linking School Attendance to Welfare Benefits Ineffective
DOC.TEXT: A program aimed at keeping students in school by cutting welfare payments to families whose children have poor attendance has been ineffective, according to a study by the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Only 28 percent of Milwaukee County teen-agers affected by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson's welfare reform measure returned to school and were still there after two months, according to the university's Employment & Training Institute. Payments from Aid to Families with Dependent Children were reduced by $3.4 million because of penalties assessed by the program, the study showed. More than 3,700 teens in the county are subject to the Learnfare program. The university study was conducted by John Pawasarat and Lois Quinn, who examined more than 4 million records from the Milwaukee County Department of Social Services. The new study proves Learnfare is not effective, Michael Soika, associate director of the Office of Social Concerns for the Milwaukee Catholic Archdiocese, said this weekend. ``Under the pretext of helping them, we are exacerbating their problem by taking money away from them, and I would suspect, creating more turmoil and tension in their lives,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Renewed Emphasis on Wetlands Could Hamper Delta Development
DOC.TEXT: Guidelines to protect the wetlands along the lower Mississippi River are slowing development and could reverse the economic revival sought by Congress for this poverty-stricken region, some officials say. Farmers' plans to dig ditches, build dikes or ponds and clear land have been put on hold. And as the construction season approaches, developers fear delays, paperwork, and the mitigation of land will increase building costs. ``We're just about going to miss the work season,'' said Dennis Sorrell of Bond Engineering in West Memphis. Sorrel said he has residential subdivisions, a county health building, apartment complexes and other industrial projects on hold. ``When developers don't develop, engineers don't work, lumber companies don't sell lumber, carpenters don't work,'' he said. Under new federal guidelines, developers and farmers must obtain a permit issued by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers before turning a spade of dirt in the wetlands. Yet no Section 404 permits have been issued in Arkansas, and a Corps spokesman said none would be issued for ``some time.'' The new ``no net loss'' policy, spurred by Bush administration efforts to comply with environmental laws, states wetlands that have been taken over must be replaced. Also, the amount of lands defined as wetlands has increased. Roughly three-fourths of the region now meets the new definition, instead of about 20 percent previously classified as wetlands, according to the Lower Mississippi Delta Development Commission. Ron Murphy, a natural resources specialist with the Memphis-based commission, said the new definition does not distinguish between different land. ``We've got to identify that high quality wetland, and then there needs to be some balance struck,'' he said. ``We're looking into it as a major problem. The wetlands policy is going to have a significant impact'' on economic development in the delta, he said. The development commission has scheduled meetings this week with members of Congress from Arkansas and other states on possible legislative remedies to the new wetlands policy. Wetlands regulations changed to become more uniform, said Furcy Zeringue, a Corps of Engineers project manager. ``There is a lack of certainty as to the amount and type of mitigation that will be acceptable or will be needed for certain types of projects,'' he said. People who change the use of wetlands could be forced to replace that acreage with new wetlands, and costs eventually would be passed on to consumers, developers said. Another problem is the time needed to get a permit, which can take up to 90 days. Bruce Blackall, executive director of the Arkansas Home Builders Association, said that while wetlands must be protected, ``it may be the pendulum swung too far.''

DOC.HEAD: Germans Meet in Border Town: `We Belong Together' ^With PM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germans from both sides of the border turned this decaying industrial town into a symbol of unity, celebrating the East German elections as the prelude to a merger. Crowds filled the dusty, cobblestone streets and squares. A huge traffic jam paralyzed the city as thousands of West Germans crossed the border to join the celebration. Many believed East Germany's first free elections were also the formerly Communist country's last as a separate state and reunification with the West was the inevitable next step. ``The pressure right now for unification is immense,'' said Rolf Bode, 29, a building manager in this city of 50,000 about 10 miles from the border. Eisenach is home to the country's second-largest automaker, the VEB Automobile Werk Eisenach, which employs about 10,000 people. ``Of course we want a united Germany,'' said Peter Voigt, 40, a technician. ``We speak the same language. We have a long shared tradition. And we belong together.'' Cornelia Bode, 30, a nurse who says she has often thought about emigrating to the West said: ``The people want the unification above everything ... occupation powers here as well as over there have to go now.'' Erhardt Jung, a 35-year-old metal worker, said he voted for the Christian Democrats because the party has drawn the clearest and quickest line for unification. ``I'm looking forward to a true free market here,'' he said. ``The central economy was a farce. It has to go forwards from here: unification as quickly as possible.'' Wilhelm Guenther, a 62-year-old accountant, said plans for a rapid unification and immediate investment from the ``big German brother'' to the West were the only ways to prevent more East Germans from leaving the country. An estimated 2,500 East Germans have left the country each day since the start of the year. ``The overwhelming majority are for a speedy unification,' he said. ``If there's a unification, there will be no reason to leave. It has to happen fast.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kidnap Campaign Workers, Killing At Least One
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path guerrillas kidnapped three adults and two children who were campaigning for the governing party's presidential candidate near a provincial city, and killed at least one, police said. The body of campaign activist Jose Bardon, 28, was found near a public market Saturday night in Huanuco with at least 40 bullet wounds, police said. Manuel Hernandez, a 26-year-old colleague, was found near Bardon's body, gravely wounded. Police said both men showed signs of torture. The other adult and the two children, a boy and a girl, were still missing after being seized Saturday by the Maoist-inspired rebels in a village three miles north of Huanuco. The candidate, Luis Alva Castro, held a rally Saturday night in Huanuco is 165 miles northeast of the capital, Lima. When they were abducted, the campaign workers were driving in a pickup truck equipped with loudspeakers and broadcasting messages urging people to attend the rally. Alva Castro is candidate for the center-left Aprista party of President Alan Garcia in presidential elections scheduled for April 8. He is currently a distant second in public opinion polls to center-right candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, an acclaimed novelist. In a statement issued Sunday condemning the murder, Alva Castro said, ``This has been a terrifying situation.'' The statement said: ``Bardon was savagely tortured during more than eight hours.'' The Shining Path began its armed insurgency against Peru's elected governments 10 years ago. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Anxiety Over Interests Rates Sends Market Into Nosedive; Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo market's anxiety about a possible interest rate hike and the yen's decline against the dollar sent the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeting to a 14-month low today. The dollar, meanwhile, rose sharply against the yen to a mark a three-year high, fueled by the currency's bullishness in overseas markets and Tokyo's poor performance. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which fell 55.20 points on Friday, plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, today. Its closing of 31,263.24 was the lowest since it closed at 31,170.38 on Jan. 20, 1989. The Nikkei's decline today was the third biggest single-day decline for the index. It plunged 3,836.48, or 14.9 percent, on Oct. 20, 1987, in the worldwide ``Black Monday'' stock market crash, and 1,569.10 points, or 4.50 percent, on Feb. 26. In today's early trading, the index rose 105 points as investors were encouraged by Friday's gains on Wall Street. But early optimism was followed by a sharp late morning decline as institutional investors began cashing in their trust funds. ``The anxiety about the interest rate hike, coupled with the weak yen against the dollar are the main causes of today's fall,'' said Ichitaro Watanabe, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. ``The market as a whole appears very pessimistic about the current situation and I have heard that there was some panic selling.'' He added that a sharp fall in index future prices also triggered massive selling on the spot market. ``There was not one outstanding reason for the Nikkei's fall today,'' said Keiichi Nishida of Kidder Peabody Securities. ``But, rather, while the market as a whole lacks buying incentives entirely, a series of bad news such as the interest rate hike and unstable exchange rates hit the market, triggering the sharp fall.'' Nishida warned that ``because Monday's drop was not the result of panic selling, there is a widely shared fear in the market that share prices may fall even further until they really hit the bottom.'' ``But at this point, no one knows where the bottom really is,'' he added. A share of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., which once was the driving force of the affluent Tokyo exchange, declined 20,000 yen from the previous day's close to finish at 1.8 million yen, the lowest since it was released in the market in April 1986. In the currency market, the dollar closed at 153.55 yen, up 1.05 yen from Friday's close of 152.50 yen. After opening at 152.48 yen, it seesawed in a wide range of 152.35-153.80 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar was firm against the Japanese yen even though the American currency was sold against the West German mark because of the conservatives' impressive showing Sunday in East Germany's elections. The Nikkei's sharp drop in the stock market prompted the market players' selling of the yen for the dollar, giving a stronger upward push to the American currency, they said. ``The market players were expecting to see a stronger yen today as the speculation about a possible interest rate hike on Tuesday swirled around the market,'' said a dealer with Daiichi Kangyo Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``But after seeing the unexpectedly bullish dollar Monday morning, players began buying the dollar almost one-sidedly,'' he added. ``I would not be surprised to see the dollar surpass the 154-yen mark before the interest rate hike actually happens.'' Dealers said the Bank of Japan made ``large-scale interventions'' throughout today to stem the yen's fall. One dealer with Daiichi Kangyo Bank said the central bank bought at least $1 billion worth of the Japanese yen today. But Masaaki Tanahashi, a dealer with the Mitsui Bank, said some market players were hesitating to buy the yen until the Bank of Japan decides to raise its official discount rate from the current 4.25 percent. Japanese media have speculated for weeks that the Bank of Japan will raise its key lending rate, charged for loans to commercial banks, by as much as one percentage point. This would affect other domestic interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Socialist Party Congress Ends In Division
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES to CORRECT that Mitterand not party leader, ADD details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The French Socialist Party congress ended in failure Sunday with the struggle for the leadership unresolved and the party unable to agree on a basic political program. The power struggle between major personalities that has rent the party in recent months went down to the wire and all-night attempts to work out a compromise in committee ultimately failed. There was virtually no debate during the four-day congress on the major issues facing the country, such as unemployment or the future of Europe. Throughout the congress, the party's top figures declared they wanted to compromise and merge their various agendas into a single political program for the next three years. But none budged from the position he came with. The next national legislative elections are not scheduled until 1993, and the presidential election is set for 1995. But jockeying for power and support already is in full swing. There were seven motions, or platforms, put forth for party members to choose from. Pre-congress voting among the 7,200 party militants from the various local federations put the motions of party First Secretary Pierre Mauroy, allied with former First Secretary Lionel Jospin, in a dead heat with former Premier Laurent Fabius, protege of President Francois Mitterrand and possessor of clear ambitions for the Elysee Palace. The official count _ contested by Fabius and his followers _ gave the Mauroy forces 28.9 percent of the vote, a hair ahead of Fabius with 28.8 percent. In third place was Premier Michel Rocard with 24.3 percent but Rocard, a presidential hopeful who controls only a minority in the party, refused to choose sides. Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement, who won 8.5 percent of the vote and has made no secret of his interest in the presidency, threw his support behind the Mauroy-Jospin motion, and Jean Poperen, minister for relations with Parliament in the Rocard government, who won 7.2 percent, backed Fabius. Two other motions won a total of 2 percent of the vote. Leaders of the various factions scheduled a meeting for Tuesday in Paris to try to write a program that will rally the party around a single platform and work out a deal on who gets the top leadership positions. If that fails, the matter will be decided by the party's board of directors, scheduled to meet on Wednesday. The makeup of the board of directors, named last week, is proportional to the votes received by the various motions. Thus the scramble will be on to forge alliances with smaller factions. This was the first congress in the history of the party that was unable to find a clear majority faction to rally and lead a unified party. The fight essentially involved two figures who both claim to be the inheritors of the mantle of Mitterrand _ Jospin, the man who followed Mitterrand as the head of the party, and Fabius, once France's youngest premier, who has made a career on Mitterrand's coattails.

DOC.HEAD: Pepsi Founder Dies at 94
DOC.TEXT: Walter S. Mack, who rescued a largely unknown Pepsi-Cola Co. during the Depression and turned it into the country's No. 2 soft drink maker, has died after a lengthy illness. He was 94. Mack died in his sleep early Sunday at his Manhattan home, where he had been recuperating from a December bout with pneumonia and heart disease, said his son, Walter S. Mack Jr. During the 1930s, Mack tackled the job of reviving troubled but promising companies. It was while trying to save the New York-based Loft's candy chain that he took a special interest in its Pepsi syrup division. Pepsi was spun off and Mack became its president in 1938. Loft's had sold the syrup formulated by a North Carolina druggist in 1893 only to candy stores. It made little headway in the market until Mack broke Coca-Cola's control of the name ``cola'' in a historic fight with Coke chief Robert Woodruff. Mack also bought what he called ``the first commercial jingle ever heard on the air.'' The jingle played in the first 30- and 60-second network spots: ``Pepsi-Cola hits the spot, ``Twelve full ounces, that's a lot, ``Twice as much for a nickel, too, ``Pepsi-Cola is the drink for you.'' By the early 1940s, Pepsi was an international giant second only to Coca-Cola in sales. After stepping down as Pepsi president in 1951, he ran the Nedick's hot dog chain and headed several other companies. Mack graduated from Harvard in 1917 and volunteered for war service. He later won a commission to the U.S. Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md. He started the Young Republican Club in the Democratic bastion of New York City. He ran unsuccessfully for the state Senate in 1932 and worked on Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia's mayoral campaigns. He also served as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee. ``He was an extraordinarily energetic and creative man,'' said Republican state Sen. Roy M. Goodman. In 1978, at 82, Mack brought together a group of former cola company executives to launch King-Cola Corp. It filed for bankruptcy three years later. ``Work keeps me alive, as it does a great many people,'' he testified before the House Select Committee on Aging in 1981. Mack remained active until about two years ago, his son said. ``As he aged he came more to believe that you do your best and keep trying and if things don't work out you keep going,'' Walter Jr. said. ``That's probably what kept him young.'' His wife, Ruth, died in 1986. He is survived by two sons, Walter Jr., an assistant U.S. attorney in Manhattan, and Anthony of Los Angeles; and two daughters, Alice M. Sawyer of Wilmington, Del., and Florence Ann Kelly of Manhattan. A memorial service was planned for Thursday at the Beth-El Chapel at Temple Emanu-El, where Mack was treasurer for 56 years.

DOC.HEAD: Contender for Premier Led Party Beyond Tainted Past
With PM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lothar de Maiziere, the favorite to become East Germany's first popularly elected premier, dealt with his party's past as a supporter of the ousted hard-line Communists by openly acknowledging mistakes. The conservative alliance that won East Germany's first free elections Sunday is led by de Maiziere's Christian Democrats, putting the 50-year-old former head of the country's Luthern Church Council in an excellent position to head a new government. At a frenzied celebration at party headquarters Sunday night, the lawyer who took charge of the Christian Democratic Union after last fall's peaceful popular revolution sidestepped questions about being chosen premier. ``We have an enormously large responsibility,'' he said of his party. De Maiziere is a fervent supporter of quick unification with West Germany and now embarks on forging a governing coalition because his party fell just short of a majority in the balloting. ``I don't want to talk about personnel questions tonight. I don't want to burden the coalition negotiations,'' he said. ``I just want to celebrate.'' Until last fall, de Maiziere's party was one of the four that had seats in a puppet Parliament and was controlled by the hard-line Communists. De Maiziere has acknowledged his party was financed by the Communists in exchange for giving parliamentary support. He has also admitted that some Christian Democratic leaders, like ousted Communists, stole party funds. The party leader has also said his party's past will hinder a fresh start in a democratic East Germany. Many East Germans now openly despise people who supported the ousted hard-line Communist regime. De Maiziere, who is married and has three daughters, rose to prominence after the popular revolution last fall as deputy premier in the caretaker government of reformist Communist Premier Hans Modrow. In the election, however, his party embraced support from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats. De Maiziere has strong personal ties to West Germany. His uncle, Ulrich de Maiziere, held a top post in the West German army. His cousin, Thomas de Maiziere, is the West Berlin spokesman for West Germany's Christian Democrats. De Maiziere is descended from a prominent Huguenot family. He is married, has three daughters and is a talented viola player.

DOC.HEAD: Ronald and Nancy Reagan Visit Burned Youth
DOC.TEXT: Ronald and Nancy Reagan are the latest in a string of notables to come to the hospital bedside of David Opont, the 12-year-old boy fighting back from a nightmarish attack by a bully who set him afire. The Reagans visited the severely burned boy Sunday evening at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, just hours after the youth had had a visit from actor Bill Cosby. The outpouring of sympathy and good wishes from around the country, most of it from people he's never met, began after the March 7 attack by a 13-year-old boy from David's neighborhood. More than 400 cards and letters arrived in a single day, along with an assortment of stuffed animals, posters and baseball caps. He also received numerous gifts, flowers and balloons on his 12th birthday, the day after the brutal attack. ``You not only can have a great feeling for him and his recovery, but down deep there is a resentment that these things can happen,'' the former president said after spending a few minutes with Opont. If his recovery goes perfectly, David could be out of the hospital in June. If there are any complications, he could die. His chances of making a full recovery remain only 50-50, doctors said. A fund set up to cover David's massive medical expenses received between 15,000 and 20,000 donations in five days, said Opont family lawyer Michael Prieto, who is overseeing the contributions. About two dozen local clergy are holding a week-long prayer vigil at the hospital, where David will probably spend the next 12 weeks. In addition, skin banks run by the Vietnam Veterans of America and the New York Firefighters Skin Bank have offered to assist the youth. ``The horror of the crime, the heinous nature of this crime, and the ages of the people involved have helped produce this response,'' said Prieto. Diana Goldin, a hospital spokeswoman, said the heavily bandaged boy was delighted with the visit from Cosby. ``David recognized him and was very pleased. He (Cosby) joked around with him,'' she said. The Reagans, who flew in from California Sunday for an award ceremony Monday night, asked to visit Opont after reading about his plight. Naomi Opont, David's sister, said David brightened up and gave a small smile when he saw the Reagans, but did not speak. He can't smile a lot because it hurts, she said. Others who have donned hospital garb to offer their support include Mayor David Dinkins and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. His optimism and spirit have won over the hospital staff. ``He's a fighter. If you ask him does it hurt, he says `no,' even during procedures we know are uncomfortable,'' said Dr. Cleon Goodwin, head of the hospital burn unit. ``He's tough.'' David's attacker, a 13-year-old whose name is being withheld because of his age, allegedly admitted torching the youth after tying him to a railing inside an abandoned garage. In chilling testimony, Detective George Klingberg quoted the suspect's account of the incident: ``I walked over to him. I lit a match. I held it up to his shirt. His shirt caught on fire, and I got scared and ran off.'' Opont originally told relatives he was torched because he refused to smoke crack but no drug charges were filed against the suspect. David wound up with second- and third-degree burns over 55 percent of his body. The attack nearly ended the dream David brought with him when he arrived in New York 18 months ago from Port-au-Prince, Haiti. He came over with his sister, Naomi, and was reunited with their father, Luther, who had immigrated in 1981. While David initially spoke his native Creole and very little English, he became a good student and applied himself in school. A school photo of David, shows the boy, in a jacket and tie, looking seriously into the camera. His sister said the 12-year-old's goal was to become a doctor and support their mother, Premese, who works as a seamstress. On the morning he was beaten, bound and burned, David was walking with friends to the Walt Whitman Intermediate School. ``All the teachers like him at school because he's fun,'' his sister said. ``He always has a story to tell them, but he's well-behaved.'' David's passions were like those of any other 12-year-old: He enjoys rap music, Nintendo games and ``The Cosby Show.'' His first Saturday in the hospital, the boy asked to watch cartoons. But the scars will remain with him for life, both physically and emotionally, doctors said. The boy will need many years of psychological after-care, said Goodwin. The effect on David's family is harder to assess. In the days after the burning, his parents and other family members were stunned by the viciousness of the attack and shaken by the severity of David's condition. ``I cannot believe a guy would do that,'' said an anguished Odridge Opont, a cousin of the burned youth. ``This family cannot believe what happened to David.'' Seated nearby in the hospital lobby, the boy's father sobbed and shook, his head in his hands. ``He's not OK yet,'' Luther Opont said softly before walking away.
The address for the fund:
David Opont Fund c-o Scheinfeld & Mayer 30 E. 42nd St. Suite 401 New York, N.Y. 10017

DOC.HEAD: Report: Hacker Entered Once-Plagued Internet Computer System
DOC.TEXT: A rogue computer program that steals electronic documents and covers its own tracks has invaded dozens of computers in a nationwide computer network, a published report said. The program has infiltrated the computers of corporations, non-classified military installations, government laboratories and several universities, The New York Times reported in today's editions. Los Alamos National Laboratory, Digital Equipment Corporation, Harvard University, Boston University and the University of Texas are among the affected institutions, unidentified investigators told the Times. The computer network is Internet, a worldwide collection of computer systems that links corporations, government projects and universities together. Government computer security teams have been unable to trace the source of the illegal program. Their job has been especially difficult because the program automatically erases computer files that would help them trace break-ins, the newspaper said. No classified military computers have been affected and damage has been slight to the Internet system, unidentified government officials told the newspaper. The computer attack is being run through a single hidden location. But in order to avoid detection, the hacker is connecting to Internet through a series of computers. The program is designed to find a file containing the system's passwords and copy the file into another computer for decoding. Some of the break-ins were traced to Texas and New Mexico before investigators lost the trail. Internet was thrown into chaos in November 1988 when a program written by Robert Tappan Morris, a graduate student at Cornell University, jammed the system. The new program is not the same as one that Morris used. That program, called a worm, copied itself from computer to computer, as a computer virus does. ``The computer virus frenzy is not the real problem,'' said Peter Neumann, a computer security expert at SRI International, a research center in Menlo Park, Calif. ``The real problem is the fact that the computers are so vulnerable, and whether the attack is by one person at a computer or a program like a worm or virus, they're all exploiting the same problem _ the vulnerability of our computer systems.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: It was standing room only at the wedding of Kevin Lerch and Vanessa LaClair. Standing room for the bride, the groom, six guests and the town justice. Even then, the church was crowded. Lerch, 24, and LaClair, 23, Saturday became the first couple married in the world's smallest church _ Cross Island Chapel, measuring 3{ by 6 feet. The chapel was built last December on an island in a two-acre pond in the upstate New York town of Verona, 20 miles east of Syracuse. Chandler Mason said he built the chapel both to honor God and to draw tourists to the rural town. Mason received a letter from Guinness Book of World Records confirming the chapel's title as world's smallest church. It will replace the Union Church in Wiscasset, Maine, in the book's next printing. The chapel has white aluminum siding, three cathedral-shaped windows, and a 5-foot steeple. The wedding party _ Lerch, LaClair, their parents, two attendants and town justice David Reed _ rowed to the island in two small boats. About 40 guests stood in a downpour to watch from shore. Lerch said he and LaClair, both of nearby Oneida, visited the church in December when the pond was frozen. ``We got engaged to be married in October. We came out here on the ice and we thought it would be fun. It would be different,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Showers in Northwest; More Rain in South
DOC.TEXT: Showers fell across the Northwest today, and more rain was falling in the South along a low front that hugged the Appalachians. Flurries were predicted for the Ohio Valley through New York as temperatures cooled after last week's bout of unseasonable warmth. Extensive flooding was reported Sunday on the Chattahoochee River in Georgia as it neared its crest at Tailwater and George Dam, its highest level since 1929. The Kinchafoonee Creek crested at Peston, Ga., the National Weather Service reported Sunday. Along the Oostanaula River, there has been widespread flooding at Rome and Resaca, Ga. The Etowah River crested at Canton, Ga., but the river level was falling slowly and flooding continued. Flooding in Alabama left 3,700 homeless and 10 dead over the weekend. Sunday evening, rain stretched from northeast Oklahoma across southwest Missouri to northwest Kentucky and central Illinois. The front moved slowly eastward, past central Indiana and west-central Ohio. Snow showers were scattered over Michigan, Wisconsin and eastern Minnesota. Flurries also were expected today in the Northeast. The high temperature for the nation Sunday was 95 degrees in California at Palm Springs, Thermal and Death Valley. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Little Changed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar kicked off the European trading week mixed. Currency dealers said today the markets want to assess the significance of East Germany's elections and the Tokyo stock market's sharp overnight drop. Gold prices were little changed. ``I don't expect much movement in the dollar,'' said one trader in Milan, Italy. ``The market is essentially trendless with the dollar slightly bid.'' Sunday's landslide victory for East Germany's conservative parties is expected to lead to solid gains by the Deutsche mark. But lingering concerns about the exchange rate to be adopted by the two Germanys ahead of unification could continue to temper some investors' enthusiasm in the longer term. ``I don't want to be on the trading desk the day the monetary union comes,'' said one dealer at a European bank in Frankfurt. ``We just don't know what will happen.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose to a three-year high, closing at 153.55 yen. That, plus anxiety about a possible interest rate increase, sent the key Nikkei Stock Average plummeting to a 14-month low. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 153.54 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.6873 West German marks, down from 1.6945 _1.5085 Swiss francs, up from 1.5080 _5.7025 French francs, down from 5.7245 _1.9005 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9077 _1,245.50 Italian lire, down from 1,251.00 _1.1855 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1802 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at 1.6140 dollars, compared with 1.6235 dollars late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $401.50 a troy ounce, up from $400.50 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $401.25. In Zurich, the bid price was $401.00, unchanged from late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.15 to close at a bid $402.04. Silver was quoted in London at a bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Three Shrines in Tokyo Razed, Arson Suspected
DOC.TEXT: Three Shinto shrines in Tokyo were burned to the ground before dawn today, and police said they suspected ultra-leftist extremists. No one was hurt in the three separate fires at the shrines of Japan's native religion, said an official of the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department. The official, who requested anonymity, said investigators believed it was arson because batteries and electric cords such as those used in detonators were found near two of the shrines. He identified the three wooden shrines as the Hikawa Shrine, Shinmei Shrine and Shirahige Shrine, each several miles apart. The fires occurred at around 3 a.m. On Feb. 3, 1989, Togo Shrine in central Tokyo was damaged by a predawn explosion that shattered more than a dozen windows and burned a covered passageway. The ultra-leftist Kakurokyo, or Revolutionary Workers' Association, claimed responsibility for that attack, and a leader of the group was later arrested. Radical groups in Japan strongly oppose the monarchy and its traditionally close relationship with Shinto. The official said radical involvement in Monday's fires was being investigated, but refused further comment. Also Monday, 5,500 riot police were mobilized to remove a tower built illegally on the site of planned expansion of Tokyo's New International Airport. A 150-ton steel cage was lowered over the 50-foot tower as six anti-airport radicals atop hurled firebombs, the official said. Riot police countered with water cannon. There were no reports of injuries on either side, the official said. Since last December, riot police have removed two similar structures where a new runway for the New Tokyo International Airport at Narita, 40 miles northwest of Tokyo, is under construction. Eight more huts remain, according to airport authorities. Anti-government radical groups, backing local farmers, have opposed the government's plans to expropriate farmland for the additional runway.

DOC.HEAD: Woody Allen, Alfred Uhry Take Writers Guild Awards
DOC.TEXT: Woody Allen's ``Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' and Alfred Uhry's ``Driving Miss Daisy'' won the best screenplay awards from the Writers Guild of America, giving them a leg up in the Oscar derby. Allen was honored for best original screenplay at the 42nd annual WGA awards presentation Sunday for his story of a murderous philanderer tormented by his conscience. The film stars Allen, Martin Landau and Anjelica Huston. Uhry's own adaptation of his Pulitzer Prize-winning play won for best screenplay based on material from another medium. The film, featuring Jessica Tandy as a Southern widow and Morgan Freeman as her chauffeur, is nominated for nine Oscars. The two films now become favorites in their respective screenplay categories at the 62nd Annual Academy Awards next Monday. In the television awards presented in dinner ceremonies in Beverly Hills and New York, Bill Wittliff won for adapted long form prize for CBS' ``Lonesome Dove, Part 1.'' T.S. Cook, the writer of the TNT cable network movie ``Nightbreaker,'' took the award for original long form. In series television, Karl Schaefer took the drama prize for the ``Rolling'' episode of CBS' ``TV 101.'' Todd W. Langen was selected for best comedy writing for the ``Coda'' episode of ABC's ``The Wonder Years.'' The winner of the Paul Selvin Award for the script that ``best embodies the spirit of constitutional liberties and civil rights'' is Alison Cross for the NBC made-for-TV movie ``Roe vs. Wade.'' Other television winners were: Anthology Episode, Single Program: ``The Closed Set'' from PBS' ``Tales from the Hollywood Hills,'' Ellen M. Violett.
