DOC.HEAD: Mother Keeps Media At Bay While Guarding Daughter
DOC.TEXT: An American woman who was jailed two years for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of her daughter was reunited with the girl over the weekend, then spent today guarding her from the media. Dr. Elizabeth Morgan drove her daughter, 7-year-old Hilary Foretich, the 200 yards to her school this morning after learning that photographers and reporters were outside the hotel where Hilary lives. She took a different route when she drove Hilary back to the Diplomat Motel. Hilary has lived there with her maternal grandparents since mid-1988. Morgan refused to speak to the media or allow herself to be photographed with Hilary. She would not say how long she expected to stay in Christchurch. Morgan, a plastic surgeon from Washington D.C., has accused her ex-husband, Eric Foretich, of sexually abusing Hilary. She was jailed 25 months in 1987 for refusing to reveal Hilary's whereabouts. The girl and her grandparents came to live in New Zealand 18 months ago after living on the run in Canada and Europe. Foretich saw his daughter last week for the first time in more than two years and has since returned to his Falls Church, Va., home where he works as a dental surgeon. He found Hilary in Christchurch three weeks ago. The New Zealand Family Court is to rule on the custody issue and has barred reporters from covering the proceedings. No date has been announced for the hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Fashion Designer Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Yves Saint Laurent, one of the world's best-known couturiers, has been hospitalized to recuperate from exhaustion, his fashion house said today. Saint Laurent, 53, will not attend the presentation of his ready-to-wear spring collection on Wednesday, and his doctor advised him to abandon his business activities for several weeks to rest, a statement said. The hospitalization was ordered Saturday by Dr. Michael Prendeville after Saint Laurent underwent a thorough medical examination that disclosed no signs of any infectious diseases, the statement said. The Saint Laurent empire, estimated at some $2 billion, in 1988 had a turnover of about $450 million in couture, ready-to-wear clothing for women and men, perfume and accessories through licenses.

DOC.HEAD: Independence Activists in Latvia Miss Two-Thirds Majority
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with former political prisoner defeating KGB official in race; Picks up 4th graf, `Communist Party ...' ^By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY
DOC.TEXT: Latvia's People's Front emerged victorious today after the Baltic republic's first free elections in 50 years, but initial results showed it failed to achieve the majority needed to press for independence. Meanwhile, reformers claimed victories in crucial runoff elections Sunday in Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine, the Slavic heartland that accounts for 80 percent of the Soviet Union's territory and two-thirds of its population. In Moscow's Proletarsky district, former political prisoner Victor Bulgakov defeated Yuri Gorbachev, a local KGB official, and became a member of the city council. And in Leningrad, pro-democracy activists claimed many victories in individual races and estimated they would control at least 65 percent of the city council, said Elena Zelinskaya of the Northwest Information Agency. Communist Party officials scored some victories, she said, mostly in the ``closed'' electoral districts such as army bases, where campaigning is not allowed. Activists had hoped Sunday's elections to parliaments in the Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia, annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, would follow the lead of nearby Lithuania and bring independence supporters to power. Estonia has not yet reported any election results. Lithuania's parliament was taken by independence activists in February and early March elections, and legislators declared the republic independent on March 13. The Soviet Congress declared the move illegal and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday gave the republic three days to respond. He later offered to meet with Lithuanian lawmakers and a delegation arrived in Moscow for talks today, just as the deadline was expiring. Latvia followed Lithuania in legalizing political parties several months ago. No such move was made in Estonia but several parties put forward candidates without interference. The Soviet Parliament legalized multiple political parties for the entire country last Tuesday. In Latvia, People's Front supporters won 108 mandates to the 201-seat parliament, a large majority among the 170 legislators elected, according to initial results cited by the Soviet news agency Tass. But independence activists needed a two-thirds majority to change Latvia's constitution. Among the newly elected lawmakers were 97 Commmunist Party members, 34 of whom were supporters of the People's Front. Party officials lost badly in the countryside but were victorious in Latvia's capital of Riga, Tass reported. Voter turnout in Latvia was 70 percent, Tass said. Thousands of Popular Front supporters rallied in the Latvian capital of Riga Sunday, urging voters to support their movement. At least five other parties, including the Green or environmental party, competed in the Latvian elections, Tass said. In Estonia, local journalist Michael Taro predicted the People's Front would win about 35 of the 105 seats in the republic's parliament, with 15 or 20 more going to other pro-independence groups. Throughout the Slavic republics, from Moscow to Vorkuta in northern Russia, reformers ran against Communist Party and government officials. Voters chose among candidates in some 1,610 runoffs, held after no candidate gained 50 percent of the vote in the main round on March 4. In Moscow city council races, the pro-democracy bloc claimed 10 of 14 contested seats, said Irina Boganseva of the Voters' Club.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Claims Eddie Murphy Stole Screenplay Has Criminal Record
DOC.TEXT: A city councilman's aide who claims comedian Eddie Murphy stole his idea for a movie has a criminal record that includes convictions for fraud, drug possession and theft, according to published reports. Hafiz Farid, 37, sued Murphy earlier this month for allegedly using a version of a screenplay he had written for the movie ``Harlem Nights.'' Farid, whose given name is Darryl Anderson, served time in federal prisons in Danbury, Conn., and Morgantown, W.Va., for two offenses, including a scheme to steal tens of thousands of dollars from federal student loan programs, according to the Sunday Star-Ledger of Newark. Farid legally changed his name and works for Newark City Councilman Ralph T. Grant Jr. He refused to discuss his criminal record, but told the paper he has reformed. Grant said he is aware of Farid's criminal record but doesn't believes it interferes with his ability to perform his job, which involves representing the councilman at community functions. Farid's lawsuit against Murphy came a week after a New York writer filed a suit accusing Murphy of stealing a story idea used in the making of ``Harlem Nights.'' Both lawsuits came just months after columnist Art Buchwald won a judgment against Paramount Pictures, the parent company of Eddie Murphy Productions, for using Buchwald's story, ``King For A Day,'' as the basis for the Murphy movie, ``Coming to America.''

DOC.HEAD: Carter Criticizes Human Rights Violations in Occupied Territories
LaserPhoto JRL3
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter today accused Israel of violating the human rights of Palestinians in the occupied territories and said such harsh treatment helps fuel the Palestinian uprising. Carter, on a three-day visit to Israel as part of a Middle East tour, cited as abuses Israeli detention of Palestinian activists without trial, house demolitions as punishment and what he termed ``excessive use of firearms'' against Arab demonstrators. ``What we are talking about is an authoritative government that is in charge that is depriving the people under its control of their basic human rights,'' Carter told reporters. He added: ``I think the intefadeh is being perpetuated partially by the abuse of the Palestinians.'' Intefadeh is the Arabic word used by Palestinians for their 27-month revolt against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel captured the West Bank and east Jerusalem from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel annexed east Jerusalem as part of its capital and rules the territories through a military government. Israelie soldiers or civilians have killed 665 Palestinians since the uprising began in December 1987. An additional 198 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence. Israel has said force is necessary to put down Palestinian violence and that actions such as detentions and house demolitions deter anti-Israeli activities. Carter made his comments to reporters after a half-hour meeting with the board of the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories. The group, founded by liberal Israeli politicians and academics, monitors activities in the territories. He also met with 13 Palestinian leaders from the occupied territories and representatives of Al Haq-Law in the Service of Man, a Palestinian human rights group. Carter cited figures from the Israeli center indicating that ``almost one in four, 25 percent, of all the adult males among the Palestinians have been arrested'' at one time or another since the uprising began. He was also critical of Israel's ``administrative detention'' procedures, which allow the jailing of Palestinians without charges or trial for up to a year. ``In addition, there have been about 650 Palestinians killed by excessive use of firearms by the military that are not under life-threatening situations,'' Carter said. ``A lot of these are little children who have been killed. These things are very disturbing to me and to the rest of the world.'' Faisal Husseini, one of the Palestinian leaders who met with Carter, said the former president ``was very concerned about human rights and has a deep understanding of this problem.'' Carter earlier visited Egypt, Jordan and Syria. He is to stop in Tunis for talks with PLO leader Yasser Arafat before returning to the United States. Carter said Sunday he believes Syrian leader Hafez Assad is ready to negotiate peace with Israel. Carter told The Associated Press that after talks with the Syrian president Thursday, he felt that Assad is ``ready to make peace, under the framework of an international conference.'' Syria, as well as nearly all Arab countries in the Middle East, has refused to officially recognize Israel and has remained in a technical state of war with the Jewish state since its establishment in 1948.

DOC.HEAD: Jane's: Soviet Army Hit by Unprecedented Wave of Murders
DOC.TEXT: In an unprecedented wave of murders, 59 Soviet military officers ranging in rank from lieutenant to general were slain last year, a military affairs newsletter said today. The newsletter, published by the respected Jane's Information Group, said the murders ``appear to be part of the current move of antipathy felt toward the armed forces, particularly among younger age groups in ethnic regions.'' In 1988 two officers were murdered, and in 1987 just one, it said. ``Very few (of the murders) have been solved,'' and Soviet authorities are disturbed that local law enforcement agencies ``are either incapable of or not interested in carrying out any proper line of inquiry,'' the newsletter said. It cited the case of Lt. Igor Kholostyakov, stabbed 14 times while returning to his unit one night. ``In the case of Lt. Kholostyakov, the police official arrived to `survey the scene,' while his dog promptly fell asleep. That was nine months ago; since then nothing further has been done to bring the murderer(s) to justice,'' the report said. It said a special section has been set up in the top military prosecutor's office to work with local police and law offices. New security guidelines are being drawn up to protect military personnel. The murders come against a backdrop of rapidly rising crime in the Soviet Union and ethnic unrest in various republics. Military troops at times have been sent in to quell unrest. This year, they became the target of Azerbaijani nationalists' anger when they were deployed to stop ethnic violence in the Azerbaijani capital. The deaths listed in the newsletter did not include officers killed in battle. In most cases, the place where the crime occurred was not stated in Soviet accounts, said Richard Woff, who wrote the report. He said this made it difficult to establish any geographic pattern to the killings.

DOC.HEAD: 1 Killed, 7 Wounded in Bomb Blast
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a shopping district today, killing one person and wounding seven others, fire brigade officials said. The explosion occurred in front of a shop in the Subzi Mandi district of northwest New Delhi, said the officials who cannot be identified under briefing regulations. The shops were closed when the bomb exploded, one official said. The cause of the blast and the identities of the victims were not immediately known. The offcials said firemen had started rescue work and the police had cordoned the area.

DOC.HEAD: Thief Who Swallowed Evidence Burned to Death
DOC.TEXT: A suspected thief who reportedly swallowed a necklace he snatched was burned to death by angry witnesses, News Agency of Nigeria reported today. The official agency quoted witnesses as saying the man snatched the necklace off a woman in a taxi and was captured by passers-by who responded to the victim's cries. ``When finally cornered, the suspect allegedly turned down all appeals to return the jewelry to the owner but rather swallowed it in a desperate effort to escape justice,'' the agency said. A crowd that had gathered poured gasoline over the man and set him ablaze, the report said. Mob justice is common in Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation.

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Prime Minister Withdraws Resignation
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal has withdrawn his resignation, averting a crisis that had threatened to shatter the tenuous unity of India's 3-month-old government. Prime Minister V.P. Singh refused to accept his deputy's resignation and Devi Lal withdrew it on Sunday, senior Janata Dal party leader Chimanbhai Patel said. Patel said Singh sent a letter to Devi Lal, saying ``the people will never excuse us if we fail them.'' ``Taking all this into account, Devi Lal decided to withdraw the resignation,'' Patel told reporters. Devi Lal, a top Janata Dal leader, submitted his resignation from the Cabinet on Friday after ferocious political and press criticism of his son, whose bid for a state legislative seat last month was marked by widespread violence and at least 13 deaths. ``There were no conditions attached to the withdrawal and this is a result of positive approach by senior (party) leaders,'' Patel said. Devi Lal, 75, was the chief minister, or top elected official, of Haryana state before resigning to join the federal Cabinet. His son, Om Prakash Chautala, was appointed to succeed him as chief minister of the predominantly agricultural state adjacent to New Delhi. Under Indian law, Chautala had to win an election to the Haryana state assembly within six months to keep the chief minister's job. Chautala ran on a Janata Dal ticket in a Feb. 27 by-election that subsequently was countermanded because of the violence and widespread allegations of vote-rigging by Chautala's supporters in the Meham constituency. Amid newspaper condemnations of Chautala's election tactics, federal Industries Minister Ajit Singh visited the Meham district and demanded Chautala resign as chief minister on ``moral grounds.'' Ajit Singh, who is unrelated to the prime minister, is a strong rival of Devi Lal within the Janata Dal party. The Janata Dal has been marked by almost continuous internal bickering since its founding in 1988, and the latest flap prompted a weekend flurry of consultations within the party. A semblance of unity is crucial for the Janata Dal, since it attained national leadership with a minority government. Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party took the most votes of any single party in the November national elections, but the 192 parliamentary seats it captured fell far short of the 263 needed to form a majority. The National Front coalition, in which the Janata Dal is the major component, won only 144 seats. But unlike the Congress Party, it was able to muster the tacit support of right-wing and left-wing parties and form a government in December. An outright split within the Janata Dal could topple V.P. Singh from the prime minister's job.

DOC.HEAD: Students Demonstrate to Demand Democratic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 university students demonstrated in heavy rain today to demand that the elderly politicians who dominate Taiwan's electoral college step down and be replaced by direct presidential elections. The protest came two days before the electoral college meets to select the next president. The only candidate is President Lee Teng-hui of the ruling Nationalist Party. The students boycotted classes from about a dozen universities to participate in the first major student demonstration since Taiwan lifted martial law in 1987 after 38 years. Wearing yellow headbands, they linked arms and sang ``United We Have Strength, As Students We Have Strength.'' They met in the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park, named after the strongman Nationalist leader who moved his government to Taiwan after losing a civil war to Communist forces on the Chinese mainland in 1949. There was little police presence at the park. Several hundred students vowed to continue their pro-democracy demonstration until after the presidential election and a dozen classmates began a three-day hunger strike to demand reforms. A student circular demanded the dissolution of the 752-seat electoral college, known as the National Assembly, which is dominated by elderly Nationalist politicians elected in mainland China before 1949. The deputies, many in their 80s and 90s, were frozen in office to support the ruling Nationalist Party's claim to still be the sole legitimate ruler of all of China. The students rejected a call by Lee to end their occupation of the park, which started Friday when 200 students began a sit-in. Education Minister Mao Kao-wen arrived at the park before dawn with a letter from Lee asking the students staging the sit-in to return home. ``I know well what you are concerned about,'' Lee said in the letter. ``I assure you that the government will give you specific answers soon.'' The students said they were disappointed at the vague promise and want Lee to present a specific timetable for democratic change. Almost all of Taiwan's 20 million people are ethnic Chinese and last spring's Beijing student movement received wide sympathy here. ``If people in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and Beijing dare to demand reforms, so do we,'' said a poster at the site of the park sit-in.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Hear Appeal of Antitrust Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to hear appeals stemming from a $200 million settlement of price-fixing charges against the nation's leading manufacturers of folding cartons. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that redistributed a $6 million surplus from the settlement in one of the biggest antitrust cases ever. The manufacturers were accused of criminal antitrust violations in 1975 by the Justice Department. In the wake of that successful prosecution, the manufacturers were sued by 2,700 customers. That suit was settled in 1979 when a $200 million fund was created to pay off all claims. In an unusual twist, some $6 million was left over in unclaimed money _ triggering a decade-long battle that led to the appeals acted on today. Two federal judges in Illinois, Hubert L. Will and the late Edwin A. Robson, ordered creation of a foundation to spend the surplus for research on complex antitrust and class-action lawsuits. But the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1984 overruled the judges' order, calling it a ``miscarriage of justice and an abuse of discretion.'' The appeals court instead ordered the money turned over to the federal government. But before the order was carried out, the manufacturers and their customers worked out a new agreement that would let law schools apply for some of the funds. Judges Will and Robson approved that agreement. Loyola University in Chicago was awarded $1.2 million and the University of Chicago $156,000. The 7th Circuit court, acting on an appeal by the federal government, ruled in 1989 that the universities must return the money. The appeals court then sent the case to another federal judge to come up with a new solution for distributing the excess money. The appeals court suggested the money be distributed on a nationwide basis _ perhaps by giving it to the Federal Judicial Center Foundation that helps educate and train court personnel and does research to improve the federal courts. The appeals court ruling was challenged in separate appeals by Will and the customers who sued the folding carton manufacturers. In a third appeal, a committee Will and Robson appointed to distribute the surplus funds asked the high court to award it lawyer fees denied by the 7th Circuit court. Bush administration lawyers, in yet another appeal, said the high court should not disturb the appeals court ruling. If the justices agreed to review the case, the government appeal said, they should consider giving the surplus money to the federal government. The cases are In Re Will, 89-927; In Re Folding Carton Litigation, 89-992; Folding Carton Administration Committee vs. Folding Carton Reserve Fund, 89-1081; and U.S. vs. Folding Carton Reserve Fund., 89-1097.

DOC.HEAD: Guam Governor Signs Most Restricted Abortion Law in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Joseph F. Ada today signed into law a bill containing the most restrictive abortion legislation in the United States, and opponents pledged to fight to measure all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``The question for me really boils down to one simple point,'' Ada said. ``In my heart, I believe a fetus is a human being.'' The law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. The law makes it a third-degree felony to perform an abortion or aid in the procedure, a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion and a misdemeanor for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. Although the bill is now law, it contains a clause calling for a referendum on abortion during the Nov. 6 general election, allowing voters to decide whether they want to retain the law. Ada signed the bill before a room packed with dozens of abortion rights supporters and opponents. ``My personal views on the subject of abortion have been stated many times and should be, by now, fairly well known,'' Ada said. ``I do not agree with the practice of abortion, except in the case of rape, incest and where the life of the mother may be threatened.'' ``It was outrageous that the bill was signed,'' said Janet Benshoof, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Reproductive Freedom Project, based in New York. Benshoof arrived Sunday in this U.S. territory in the western Pacific Ocean, hoping to meet with Ada to discuss the implications of the bill. The meeting never took place. ``I was devastated he was making a personal opinion,'' Benshoof said. ``We all have a conscience. I believe he should be making the decision for the people of Guam.'' Benshoof said she will remain on Guam for ``as long as it takes'' and said she has no immediate plans to return to New York. The unicameral Guam Legislature unanimously approved the bill March 8 despite an opinion from Attorney General Elizabeth Barrett-Anderson that it is unconstitutional. It was amended before approval to provide the public referendum on the abortion issue. The vote came after Archbishop Anthony Apuron threatened to excommunicate any Roman Catholic senator who voted against the measure. All but one of the 21 senators are Catholic, as is Ada. However, not all senators were aware of Apuron's threat before the vote. Rachael Pine, staff attorney for the ACLU's Reproductive Freedom Project, had said the Guam law, if approved, would give the U.S. Supreme Court the opportunity to decide the core issue of the right to abortion. In a letter sent to Ada before the signing, Benshoof said the case would be ultimately appealed to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Prison Overcrowding Appeal From Puerto Rico
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by Puerto Rico officials fined more than $30 million for failing to move quickly enough to relieve prison overcrowding. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that the commonwealth's belated efforts to ease the problem is not reason enough to cancel the fines. Officials from 31 states joined in urging the justices to hear the commonwealth's appeal. The states are Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Delaware, Florida, Hawaii, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Vermont, Utah, Virginia, West Virginia and Wyoming. State officials said strict enforcement of such federal court penalties could delay voluntary prison reforms. The Puerto Rico case stems from a 1979 lawsuit by inmates. A federal judge ruled the following year that each prisoner must be provided at least 35 square feet of cell space temporarily, and ultimately 55 square feet in dormitories and 70 square feet in individual cells. Commonwealth officials in 1986 agreed to comply with the court order and began to expand prison capacity. But in July 1987 the officials were fined $50,000 plus $10 per day per inmate for failing to provide 35 square feet of space per prisoner. The fines were increased in August 1988 so that by November 1989 they approached a total of $30 million. Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon and other officials said tropical rains and an unexpected increase in the prison population prevented them from meeting their own deadlines for easing overcrowding. They said they inherited the problem from a previous administration, and had more than tripled the commonwealth's prison budget. Prison capacity was increased from 5,400 in 1985 to 10,295 last year, they said. But the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the fines last September. ``The relevant harm, confinement in an area smaller than five by seven feet, is significant,'' the appeals court said. ``The number of prisoners suffering that harm, seven to 10 percent, is large. And the time since entry of the remedial decree is long.'' The appeals court said officials have not shown that meeting their own deadline for providing the minimum space was ``overwhelmingly difficult or anywhere near impossible.'' The appeals court added that U.S. District Court Judge Juan M. Perez-Giminez, who has presided over the case, could decide to use the fines to pay for prison expansion. Puerto Rico officials said if other appeals courts adopted the 1st Circuit court's approach it could mean that states and the federal government would have to pay billions of dollars a year in fines for failing to expand prisons quickly enough. The states that supported Puerto Rico's appeal said nearly every state in the nation is under a court order to improve prison conditions. The case is Hernandez Colon vs. Feliciano, 89-1016.

DOC.HEAD: Students Undergoing Military Training Rave About the Experience
DOC.TEXT: Beijing University's freshmen class, ordered to undergo a year of military training after last year's pro-democracy uprising, wrote glowingly of the experience in a letter published today. ``Your visit and that of other leading officers helped us to better understand that our military training certainly is not the `punishment' that others have said,'' the students wrote to the education minister. ``Rather it indeed shows the preferential treatment ... the solicitude and loving care given to our generation of college students,'' they said. The letter was published on the front page of the Communist Party newspaper, the People's Daily, less than three weeks before the anniversary of the start of the student-led pro-democracy movement. Its publication also coincided with the convening this week of the annual session of China's parliament, the National People's Congress. The lengthy letter to Education Minister Li Tieying was written Jan. 14. Last year, as part of the crackdown on dissent following the spring protests, the government cut the incoming freshmen class at all major universities. At Beijing University, the freshmen class was ordered to undergo a year of military training before starting their course work. The university's students were among the leaders of the 1989 movement. The approximately 700 students were sent to train at an army base in Shijiazhuang, about 185 miles south of Beijing. Reporters were not allowed to visit the site. Sources on Beijing university campuses said they did not expect any activities to mark last year's uprising, which was crushed by the military in June. ``Everyone wants there to be trouble, but no one wants to be the one to start it,'' said one Beijing University student. But the school's freshman class adopted a very different tone in its letter. ``Finally we understand ... that although last April and May our nation experienced very serious turmoil and although the international situation is changing unpredictably, the great flag of socialism will never fall,'' they wrote. The students said the masses would never stand for the overthrow of socialism because they are the ones who would suffer the most. The letter gave few details about the students' living conditions and training but boasted about their ``harvest'' of new political awareness. They have become living examples of the Chinese socialist maxim of ``serving the people,'' the students said. They said they had learned that ``without the People's Army the people would have nothing,'' and vowed to ``train ourselves into a new model of socialist college students.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Hear Administration Appeal on Freedom of Information
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at making it costlier for an organization called the National Security Archive to compile information. The archive is a non-profit organization that collects information on national security and foreign policy and makes it available to the public in various ways. It has filed thousands of FOIA requests for government records. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that gives the archive the same preferential status under the Freedom of Information Act that other news media enjoy. The administration claimed the archive should not have the status of a news organization for purposes of FOIA requests. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last year that the archive should be treated as a news media representative under the FOIA because it publishes some of the information it gathers itself. News media representatives that make FOIA requests reimburse the government for the cost of copying the documents, but not for the major additional cost of searching for the records. If the archive did not have the status of a news organization, it would have to reimburse the government for search costs. The archive is headed by Scott Armstrong, a former Washington Post reporter and co-author of ``The Brethren,'' a 1979 book that provided a behind-the-scenes look at the Supreme Court. The organization published a book entitled ``The Chronology: The Documented Day-by-Day Account of the Secret Military Assistance to Iran and the Contras'' and another called ``El Salvador _ The Making of U.S. Policy, 1977-1984.'' A federal judge ruled in favor of the Pentagon when it sought to force the archive to pay more for government documents. In reversing that decision, the appeals court here said, ``Congress intended that an organization like the archive qualify as a representative of the news media.'' The appeals court added, however, ``If the archive's intention to publish works derived from the documents it requests does not pan out, it will be open to the Department of Defense to argue that the archive is no longer a representative of the news media.'' The case is U.S. vs. National Security Archive, 89-1204.

DOC.HEAD: County Commissioner Arrested for Whitewashing Billboard
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested a Dallas County commissioner who whitewashed a billboard depicting a black woman as part of a protest against cigarette and alcohol advertising aimed at black consumers. Commissioner John Wiley Price was released Sunday from Lew Sterrett Justice Center after paying $52 of a $200 bond. He was arrested two hours earlier on a charge of criminal mischief over $400, a class A misdemeanor. ``We are the target of adverse advertising. We are the victims,'' said Price, who is black. He led two dozen people who whitewashed between 25 and 30 billboards Sunday. All the billboards contained advertising for alcohol or tobacco products. ``I didn't paint but one sign, but I was the only one arrested,'' Price said. Police confirmed that Price was the only person arrested in the protest. While he was handcuffed in front of several dozen people at the gates to Fair Park, Price said he would continue to do ``whatever it takes'' to stop tobacco and alcohol advertising targeted at minorities. ``We'll be back out again next Sunday,'' he said. Last week, similar demonstrations took place in New York, Chicago and Detroit. George Reynolds, president of the Dallas Outdoor Advertising Association, said sign owners and advertisers were upset by the action because they had been asked by minorities in the past to use minority models in their ads and were now criticized for putting up the billboards at all. ``We can't win either way,'' Reynolds said.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Win Big, Bolstering Push For Rapid Reunification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 1 graf after lead, and SUB grafs 9-13, `The Social...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Social Democrats refusing to enter coalition with alliance or communists. Pickup 14th pvs, `The Communists...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,5, XBER5
DOC.TEXT: A conservative alliance that favors speedy unification with West Germany today proposed a broad coalition government after being swept to a surprise victory in East Germany's first free elections. But one of the parties invited to join the Cabinet immediately refused, making it much more difficult for the conservatives to achieve a two-thirds majority in Parliament. Such a majority would allow Parliament to simply declare a merger with the West. Sunday's vote culminated a peaceful democratic revolution that toppled hard-line Communists five months ago. About 93 percent of the 12.2 million eligible voters cast ballots, and the results reflected sentiment that the faster East Germany is joined with its prosperous neighbor, the better. Lothar de Maiziere, who is likely to become premier, said today the remainder of the Berlin Wall must be torn down ``as soon as possible as a clear sign of the merging of the two German states.'' De Maiziere, chairman of the top-ranking Christian Democratic Party, also said in a post-election news conference that talks with the West German government on monetary, economic and social union must be accelerated. The Christian Democrats received more votes than any party in Sunday's election. They are the leading party in the three-party Alliance for Germany, which won 48.2 percent of the vote and 193 of the 400 parliamentary seats. That was more than pre-election polls predicted. The vote marked the first time East Germans were given a free choice at polls after a decade of the Nazis and 41 years of Communist dictatorship. De Maiziere, reading a statement by the alliance, said the group ``wanted to build a possible grand coalition.'' ``Therefore, we are inviting the Social Democrats and the Union of Free Democrats to coalition talks,'' he said. Social Democratic leader Ibrahim Boehme said his party, which favors reunification at a slower pace than the alliance, had decided against entering a coalition with the conservatives. The Social Democrats were early pre-election favorites but fell behind in polls after the alliance received massive backing from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Like the alliance, Kohl supports speedy unification. The Social Democrats placed a distant second, with 21.8 percent and 87 seats. The Union of Free Democrats, a centrist party that also supports slower reunification, won 5.3 percent, or 21 seats. Boehme said the Social Democrats had also decided against entering a coalition with the communist party, which sought their support to prevent conservatives from achieving the two-thirds parliamentry majority. The Communists, who ruled the nation with an iron fist before being toppled in October, won 16.3 percent of the votes and 65 seats. The party, renamed the Party of Democratic Socialism, cautioned that rapid reunification would hurt East Germany. The rest of the vote was divided among 20 smaller parties and groupings, including such diverse contenders as the Beer Drinkers' Party. It won just .02 percent of the vote, not enough to have a seat in parliament. Interestingly, the vanguard of the pro-democracy revolution that made the election possible fared poorly. New Forum, in an alliance with two other groups, ended with just 2.9 percent of the vote. It will have 12 seats in Parliament. The United States and Britain praised the orderly election. The campaigning was harsh, but no irregularities were reported in voting. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called the election a new beginning for East Germany and another step in the spread of democracy through central and eastern Europe. The White House called it a ``historic occasion.'' There was no immediate comment from Washington on the final results. According to East German law, the new parliament must constitute itself within 30 days of the election. The new government will take part in unification talks with West Germany and the four World War II Allies _ Britain, France, the Soviet Union, and the United States. A major issue is the military strength and alignment of a unified Germany. The Western powers want West Germany to remain part of the NATO military alliance. The Soviets and East German Communists have called for a neutral single state. Citing the outcome, Kohl and de Maiziere urged East Germans to halt the exodus to West Germany, which sparked the fall uprising but has crippled the East's economy and put enormous strains on the West. ``The German citizens have decided against every form of extremism,'' Kohl told a news conference. ``Most important, they want to follow a path, together with West Germany, that will lead to unification.'' ``My message at this hour is: Stay home,'' Kohl said. ``Work with us in your villages, cities and communities, in your factories and in your local administrations to build up this beautiful country.'' As one way of persuading people to stay in East Germany, the countries are negotiating a monetary union in which West Germany's powerful mark would become East Germany's currency as well. In an interview with the Cologne newspaper Express, de Maiziere raised the prospects of the two German states forming their planned monetary union ``perhaps as early as June.'' As the results poured in Sunday night, about 2,000 ecstatic supporters of the Christian Democrats gathered at a victory party and chanted ``Helmut! Helmut!'' Germans from both sides of the border turned the decaying industrial town of Eisensach into a symbol of unity, celebrating the East German elections as the prelude to a merger. Erhardt Jung, a 35-year-old metal worker, said he voted for the Christian Democrats because the party has drawn the clearest and quickest line for unification. ``I'm looking forward to a true free market here,'' he said. ``The central economy was a farce. It has to go forwards from here: unification as quickly as possible.''

DOC.HEAD: West Virginia Teachers Return to Classrooms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with teachers returning, number of counties officially accepting settlement to 43, give detail. Picks up 11th graf, `On Saturday...'.
DOC.TEXT: Teachers throughout West Virginia returned to their classrooms today after voting overwhelmingly to end an 11-day strike. ``They're back,'' said Jackie Goodwin, a spokeswoman for the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Association, the main teachers union in the state. Unions in 43 of the state's 55 counties voted by large majorities Sunday or early today to accept a back-to-school agreement reached by union leaders and state legislative leaders on Saturday. ``We've made our point. We won a lot of respect, unity and strength through this,'' Goodwin said. ``The teachers have shown they mean business.'' In Morgantown, school started an hour later than usual at North Elementary School to allow teachers time to prepare for their pupils who seemed happy to be back. ``I feel good,'' said Jorja Smith, a counselor at the school. ``We made the public aware of the problems the schools were having and the problems we were having with the governor.'' Teachers in two counties, Jackson and Greenbrier, voted to return before the settlement was announced. Marion County teachers voted to ``suspend'' rather than settle their strike, pending the outcome of a special session promised by legislative leaders. ``If the Legislature doesn't come through with what we want, we're back out,'' said Kathy Jacquez, president of the Marion County Education Association. Teachers, upset over the state's refusal to grant pay raises, walked out March 7. Educators in just nine of the state's 55 counties voted not to support the strike. On Saturday, legislative leaders promised leaders of the state's two teachers unions they would ask Gov. Gaston Caperton to call a special session to address long-term education needs. The settlement does not specifically address salaries _ which, averaging $21,904 in 1988-89, were ranked nearly last among the 50 states _ but calls for lawmakers and union leaders to work out a plan for improved pay and benefits. ``That's all we ever wanted, an education summit to get something done so we don't have to keep going to Charleston banging our heads against the House and Senate doors,'' said Joseph Suriano, president of the Ohio County Education Association. ``I think we've done a heck of a job,'' said Marie Hamrick, president of the Raleigh County Education Association. ``We're glad to be going back to our schools,'' she said. ``Of course, there are some people who are going to be unhappy unless we have $5,000 across the board and Gaston hanging from a pole.'' Caperton's proposals to teachers were either withdrawn by the administration or were rejected by the education association and the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers. Both unions endorsed Caperton in his bid for governor in 1988. However, union representatives say Caperton has lost his credibility and teachers will have more faith in promises of action made by House Speaker Chuck Chambers and Senate President Keith Burdette. Teachers ``would much rather trust the legislators than Governor Caperton,'' said Janet Zevnik, president of the Tyler County Education Association. ``We have tried three times to negotiate with Governor Caperton and three times he has let us down.'' Caperton and legislative leaders offered teachers a 5 percent raise before the strike began, but the offer was dropped when the WVEA continued to threaten a walkout. The WVEA rejected a second offer, saying the governor reneged on a promise to call a special session. The third offer fell through when the unions rejected a seven-point plan from Caperton they said contained nothing new. WVFT Executive Director Bob Brown said the tentative settlement reached Saturday is better than the previous offers because lawmakers agreed to work out a plan to raise revenue for salaries by next fall.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Jet Crashes; 2 Crewmen Safe
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force F4-G Phantom jet fighter taking part in joint U.S.-South Korea military exercises crashed south of Seoul today but the two crewmen aboard ejected safely, authorities said. The jet from Clark Air Base in the Philippines crashed near Chongju, 60 miles south of Seoul, shortly after 1 p.m., U.S. military officials said. The pilot and weapon systems officer on board the aircraft ejected safely but were admitted to a military hospital for checkup, it said. The announcement did not identify the crewmen. Military officials were investigating the cause of the accident. The South Korean news agency, Yonhap, said the jet exploded after crashing into a mountainside near a reservoir. About 200 pine trees in the area were burned in a fire that followed the explosion, it said. It was the second accident involving U.S. military aircraft in this year's joint U.S.-South Korea ``Team Spirit'' exercises under way since last week. On Thursday, a U.S. army helicopter on a night flying mission crashed after hitting a power line south of Seoul. No one was killed. About 190,000 U.S. and South Korean troops are taking part in this year's ``Team Spirit'' exercises. The maneuvers have been held annually since 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Extremists Kill 26 in Punjab
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE death toll, CORRECT that Talwandi attack was today, add details and conflicting death toll. Pickup last graf, `Sikhs are...'
DOC.TEXT: Sikh extremists fighting for secession of Punjab state raided a farm and fatally shot five members of a family accused of being police informers, police said today. Elsewhere in Punjab state, Sikh militants killed 21 people in a 24-hour period that ended today, according to police and news reports. Two militants barged into a farm in Guru-ka-Khu village late Sunday and started shooting in the courtyard, killing the owner, Mahenderpal Singh, his three sons and a brother-in-law, a senior police officer, R.P. Singh said. A note claiming responsibility for the killings was found near the bodies, Singh said. The note was signed by a group called Khalistan Commando Force, one of several militant organizations fighting to set up an independent nation in Punjab, he said. The militants call the proposed nation ``Khalistan,'' or the Land of the Pure. Gunmen crouching in trenches dug along a road near the Punjab town of Talwandi halted three trucks early today and opened fire on the drivers and passengers, police said. Senior Police Superintendent Surjit Singh initially put the death toll at 11, but United News of India later reported it was 14. Talwandi is about 45 miles south of Amritsar, the holiest Sikh city and the center of the 8-year-old campaign for secession from Hindu-dominated India. Other police officials said militants killed a Sikh clergyman, his bodyguard and a relative Sunday in Faridkot district. Police did not say why they were killed but the extremists are known to attack fellow Sikhs who do not support their cause. The officials also said on condition of anonymity that a Hindu politician and a Sikh farmer were gunned down by extremists Sunday night in separate shootings. Details of the other deaths were not given. The latest deaths brought to 397 the number of people killed this year by Sikh militants in their quest for Khalistan. The separatists claim the Hindu- dominated government discriminates against them. Sikhs are a slight majority in Punjab, a rich farming state bordering Pakistan. Natiowide, Sikhs comprise 2 percent of India's 880 million population while Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide if Anti-Counterfeiting Law Can Be Used in Phony Mileage Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether a federal anti-counterfeiting law may be used to crack down on the sale of used cars with phony mileage readings. The court said it will hear an appeal by the manager of a Pennsylvania car dealership sentenced under the law to six months in prison. The manager, Raymond J. Moskal, was convicted last year of taking part in a scheme in which car odometers were turned back and ownership titles listing the lower mileages were obtained in Virginia. Also convicted were Al Davis, owner of the wholesale car dealership in Manheim, Pa., where Moskal worked, and Dennis Smith, owner of a dealership in Chesapeake, Va. Davis and Smith did not appeal to the Supreme Court. All three were convicted under a federal law that makes it a crime to transport falsely made securities across state lines or to make counterfeit state securities. Prosecutors said the ownership certificates from Davis' dealership were shipped to contacts in Virginia who applied for titles in that state with the phony lower mileage figures. The Virginia titles then were sent back to Davis and he distributed them to area dealers to sell with the used cars. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the convictions of the thee defendants. The appeals court said a bonafide car title issued by a state qualifies as a falsely made security when the title contains false information. ``Stated mileage is a material part of a title certificate,'' the appeals court said. ``The fact that valid title is transferred by the certificate does not vitiate the fraud that is foisted on the unsuspecting customer when the falsely made document is introduced into commerce.'' Federal appeals courts elsewhere in the nation have disagreed with the 3rd Circuit court's interpretation. The Justice Department urged the high court to resolve the conflict. The department said the court should intercede to ``promote the fair and efficient operation of the federal criminal justice system.'' The case is Moskal vs. U.S., 89-964.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Brennan Out With `Flu-Related' Illness
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan is suffering from ``flu-related'' stomach trouble and could not report for work today, his secretary said. ``He's got the flu, actually some stomach problems that are flu-related,'' secretary Mary Elmore said. ``We hope he will be back soon. These things can lay you low but he's not very patient.'' Brennan, 82, was not on the bench as the court returned from a two-week recess this morning. Asked about his absence, court spokeswoman Toni House said he was at his doctor's office. She said Brennan became ill Thursday while at work, and was taken to a physician at the Capitol across the street. No word of Brennan's condition was released last week. Today, Ms. House said, ``We really don't know very much.''

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Brings Message of New Morality to France
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel arrived today for talks with French leaders on the future shape of a Europe quickly shedding distinctions between East and West. ``I'm persuaded that we will understand each other,'' Havel told President Francois Mitterrand after landing at Orly Airport. The two-day trip is the playwright-turned-president's first to France since becoming Czechoslovakia's leader in December after the breakdown of four decades of Communist rule. Havel predicted that his talks with Mitterrand this afternoon and again at a state dinner would be ``intensive,'' covering bilateral relations and ``the accelerating course of history.'' In an interview published in the Sunday edition of the newspaper Le Monde, Havel expressed support for Mitterrand's concept of a new European security order involving the 35 countries that signed the 1975 Helsinki accords. ``At the end of the trail, we will see a new Europe as President Mitterrand imagines,'' Havel was quoted as saying. ``It's necessary, however, to look at intermediate steps that will permit us to reach this ideal.'' Havel rejected neutrality for a unified Germany and envisioned a common European security system free of both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. ``The future European system shoud be founded on the principle of multipolarity ... a system where the Lithuanians and the Irish, as well as the Germans and the French, will feel secure,'' Havel said.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Kill 14, Leave Thousands Homeless in Two States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with military police mobilized, temperatures falling and new storm predicted, picks up 5th graf, `Elba Mayor ...'. INSERTS 3 grafs after 15th graf, `It hurts...' to UPDATE with comment from resident, pcks up 16th graf, `Col. Larry ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Military police guarded against looters today in flood-ravaged southern Alabama, where a weekend of sunny weather did little to diminish the devastation from two days of torrential rains. The deluge and flooding killed 10 and left at least 3,700 people homeless in Alabama, and the town of Elba remained a muddy hole two days after an earthen levee ruptured along the Pea River. More than 150 Alabama National Guard police patrolled the town to enforce curfews and guard against looting in the devastated business district. Spokesman Maj. David Bosarge said that in all, about 300 guardsmen were dispatched to 24 locations in southeast Alabama to assist with flood control, evacuations and security. Water from nearly non-stop rain Thursday and Friday also swelled rivers and streams in Georgia, where authorities blamed flooding for four deaths in auto accidents. Some Alabama rivers were expected to crest at 20 feet or more above flood level today or Tuesday, while some rivers in southern Georgia were not expected to crest until Friday, the National Weather Service said. After a sunny, dry weekend, temperatures dropped. The National Weather Service warned that a new storm front would bring freezing temperatures and possibly snow to Alabama's northern tip and near-freezing temperatures and light rain to south Alabama. Though the Pea River was one of the few starting to recede in the state Sunday, water still nipped at Elba's downtown rooftops, 1,500 of the 4,400 residents were homeless and roads, homes, schools and businesses were paralyzed. As much as 16 inches of rain fell in southern Alabama last week. Elba Mayor Fred Moore estimated the cleanup would cost millions of dollars. ``I've never seen anything like it,'' said U.S. Rep. Bill Dickinson, who toured the devastated area by helicopter Sunday. ``I cannot begin to imagine everything that's been lost or damaged.'' Most southern Alabama rivers continued rising today as flood waters drained toward the Gulf of Mexico, a National Weather Service official said. Authorities reported about 500 people were forced from their homes in the Montgomery area as the muddy Alabama River rose to 19 feet above flood stage. In Selma, about 200 people fled their homes as the river headed toward the level reached in a record 1961 flood. Hundreds more could be evacuated by Tuesday afternoon, when the river is expected to crest 13 feet above flood level, said emergency management director Warren Rhoades. The Choctawhatchee River was 21 feet above flood stage in the southeast Alabama town of Newton, about 30 miles east of Elba. Sheriff's deputies said some 500 people had been forced from their homes since Friday in Newton and surrounding Dale County. Evacuations in five other counties brought the total number of evacuations to more than 3,700, authorities said. The waters in Elba appeared to have receded perhaps a foot or two on Sunday, but a swift current continued to flow swiftly through a 100-foot hole on the north side of the levee and back into the Pea River through a large crack on the south side. The water was up to the windows of Lela Wilson's one-story home, which she moved into about a week ago. ``It hurts. It honestly hurts. It seems like everything you work for you wind up losing,'' she said. For older Elba residents, the deluge brought back memories of a ``great flood'' that devastated the town on March 14, 1929. Fleetwood Carnley, 71, recalled that his family had to seek refuge in their loft. But now, their home is submerged. ``We didn't get anything out but what we wore,'' Carnley said. ``I just couldn't conceive it happening.'' Col. Larry Bonine, the district engineer for the Army Corps of Engineers in Mobile, said it was too early to determine what caused the levee to rupture. About 45 miles downstream in Geneva, emergency workers shored up another levee and continued evacuating residents. At least 450 people were forced out there. Margaret Mixon, emergency management director for Geneva County, said officials believed the Geneva levee would hold. But she added, ``I guess Elba was pretty confident, too.'' State troopers said six people drowned Friday night in Covington County when a car fell into a rain-swollen creek where a bridge had washed out. Two more people met a similar fate Saturday night in neighboring Escambia County, and a third man died there when he walked into a flooded area to check on his parents. Another man was found dead in his car in Prichard on Sunday morning on a road that had been barricaded since Friday due to 7-foot-deep water, police said. In Georgia, authorities expected the Ocmulgee River to crest at 12 feet above flood level today in Macon. The Flint River is expected to crest at about 11 feet above flood level by Friday in Albany. The Georgia State Patrol blamed the heavy rain and floods for car crashes that killed three people near Lumpkin on Saturday and one woman in Henry County late Friday night.

DOC.HEAD: India Boosts Defense Spending; Cites Pakistani Threat
DOC.TEXT: The government today announced a 10.5 percent increase in military spending and officials said the boost was necessary due to growing tensions with Pakistan along a disputed northwestern border. Finance Minister Madhu Dandavate presented the $9.3 billion defense budget to parliament as part of the government's budget for 1990-91. ``This increase in defense expenditure is not of our choice,'' Dandavate said. ``It is a direct result of the situation on our borders.'' The hike in defense spending follows two months of fighting between Moslem miliants and government troops in the northern Jammu-Kashmir state where Moslems want to secede from predominantly Hindu India. At least 184 people have been killed in the latest round of violence that flared up Jan. 20 following a government crackdown. Pakistan controls the western part of Kashmir and has claimed the larger Indian-controlled area because of its predominantly Moslem population. Pakistan has openly pledged support for the militants. The secession movement has been alternately simmering and flaring since 1947 when the old princely state of Kashmir, then governed by a Hindu ruler, opted to merge with India instead of mostly Moslem Pakistan. Pakistan and India have fought three wars since independence. India, with a population of 880 million, has an armed force of 1.36 million men, smaller only than those of the Soviet Union, China and the United States. The budget, the first by Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government, which came to power 3{ months ago, calls for $55 billion in spending and revenues of $51 billion. The budget calls for a debt of $4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: One Brother Named in Drug Case Arrested in Bombing; Other Sought
DOC.TEXT: A man described as having a ``soldier-of-fortune mentality'' was being sought today for questioning in the bombing of a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration office. Local, state and federal officials were hunting for Jeffrey A. Matthews, 23, formerly named Jeff Ciganek, in connection with the Saturday morning firebombing of the local DEA office. Matthews' brother, John Lewis Ciganek, 22, was arrested Sunday morning in the Florida Keys for questioning in the same case. The bombing took place two days after the brothers were indicted on two counts of conspiracy to distribute cocaine and a month after federal drug agents told local sheriff's deputies that Matthews had threatened DEA property during a drug investigation. The search for the brothers began when they were declared fugitives after their indictment Thursday, but picked up after the bombing. Ciganek was arrested in Tavernier, just south of Key Largo, on the drug charges, Lee County Sheriff John McDougall said Sunday. Florida Highway Patrol officers turned Ciganek over to FBI agents, who returned him to the Lee County Jail. Earlier in the day, FBI agent Brian Kensel, a spokesman for the FBI team leading the investigation into the bombing, said no charges had been filed against Ciganek over the bombing. Kensel said the FBI wanted to question the brothers about the bombing. But he declined to label them _ or anyone else _ as prime suspects. The search for Matthews has involved officers of the FBI, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, among other agencies. McDougall also summoned 50 deputies from six other Florida counties to help provide protection for at least 13 prosecutors, judges and law enforcement officials who took part in a joint task force investigating and prosecuting drug dealers in the southwestern Florida county. ``We're certainly prepared for a showdown with him,'' McDougall said of Matthews. ``The ball is in his court now. If he wants to surrender, that's fine. But if he wants to engage in other options, we'll accommodate him.'' McDougall described Matthews as elusive, saying he always has been proud of the fact that nobody knew exactly where he lived. ``I think he has a fixation with being a Mafia don,'' the sheriff said. ``He's into that neo-Nazi philosophic bent. He's into that neo-Nazi-type, soldier-of-fortune mentality.'' At the DEA office, an FBI forensic team continued searching through the charred rubble and was expected to finish its investigation at the site today, according to Kensel. The blast appeared to have been triggered by a pipe bomb that ignited some kind of ``liquid accelerant,'' probably gasoline, he said. No one was injured in the bombing, but the blast and resultant fire destroyed the one-story building, causing damage estimated at $4 million. Last month, DEA agents told sheriff's deputies that Matthews had threatened to damage DEA property and cars, the Fort Myers News-Press reported Sunday. That report was filed after a DEA vehicle parked outside the office was vandalized Feb. 24.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Judges' Authority to Rule in Some Labor Disputes
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide how much authority federal judges have to rule in some labor disputes. The court said it will hear an appeal by two workers fired by a Michigan company, Ring Screw Works. Arthur Groves was fired for allegedly excessive unexcused absences from work. Bobby Evans was dismissed for allegedly falsifying company records. Both men denied the charges but lost grievance complaints against the company. They then sued the firm for firing them without due cause in violation of the federal Labor Relations Management Act. The United Automobile Workers Union joined the lawsuits on the side of the employees. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year upheld a ruling by a federal judge who threw out the suits. The appeals court said the UAW contract with Ring Screw Works provides that a strike is the union's only recourse when workers lose grievances. The appeals court said the only exception that would permit the workers to sue would be if they accused the union of breaching its duty to represent them fairly. The fired workers made no such accusation. The union members had voted against striking after Groves and Evans lost their grievances. Groves, Evans and the UAW said in their appeals to the Supreme Court that federal appeals courts elsewhere have disagreed with the 6th Circuit court and ruled that federal judges have authority to rule in such suits. They asked the justices to resolve the conflict. The case is Groves vs. Ring Screw Works, 89-1166.

DOC.HEAD: Network Says Hardliners Win Struggle; Means No Early Hostage Release
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 9, Stephan Strain, to remove ``In Iran.''
DOC.TEXT: Iranian hardliners have derailed moderates' efforts for the release of Western hostages in the Mideast, according to ABC News. But a senior Iranian official says prospects for the hostages' release have never been better. Leaders of groups holding hostages in Lebanon were summoned to Tehran for meetings last week, ABC's Pierre Salinger reported from Paris on Sunday, quoting sources within the Hezbollah movement in Lebanon. ``There, the current plan to release the hostages was sabotaged by Iranian hardliners opposed to (Iranian President Hashemi) Rafsanjani,'' Salinger reported. ``The hostage leaders returned to Lebanon three days ago and one of the organizations, Islamic Jihad, issued a statement saying the hostages wouldn't be released,'' he said. ``This position was confirmed at a secret meeting in Lebanon 48 hours ago.'' The statement mentioned by Salinger was issued by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. Spokeswoman Alixe Glen said there would be no White House reaction to the report on Sunday. In an interview with Tehran Times newspaper in Iran on Sunday, Ali Mohammad Besharati, first deputy foreign minister, said, ``I can say that all the hostages may be released by 16.00-18.00. DOC.HEAD: Thieves Steal Old Master Paintings From Boston Museum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 25th graf, `The Gardner..', to CORRECT that museum had two security guards on duty sted employs two guards total.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: Two thieves with a talent for disguise and a taste for Rembrandt and Degas stole 11 paintings valued at upwards of $100 million in a daring theft from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. But experts say the paintings are so priceless, in one sense they're worthless. Any legitimate collector or dealer would recognize them and wouldn't pay a penny, they say. ``People make pilgrimages to see these paintings. Scholars and art lovers know where they belong,'' Constance Lowenthal, executive director of the International Foundation for Art Research, said Sunday. The theft occurred around 1 a.m. Sunday, when two men apparently convinced museum guards they were police, then bound them with tape and made their way to the museum's Dutch room. It was seven hours before a cleaning crew discovered the theft. The heist was ``a professional job,'' said FBI agent Paul Cavanagh. ``This is one of those thefts where people actually spent some time researching and took specific things.'' He said the investigation would not be limited to the United States. ``It is the biggest Old Master theft in this country, by far,'' said Ms. Lowenthal, whose organization tracks art thefts. ``The Gardner Museum is a treasure house,'' she said. ``Everything in it is exceedingly valuable and first-rate and superb.'' The value of the missing works, which included an ancient Chinese beaker, was in the hundreds of millions of dollars, said Karen Haas, the museum's curator. The police report gave the value as at least $100 million. ``It's not overstating the case to say that these are priceless works,'' said William Robinson, curator of drawings for Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum. ``A loss of any of these works is significant.'' But their true value cannot be determined because they have not been on the market for nearly a century. The works taken were: _ ``The Concert'' by Jan Vermeer. _ ``A Lady and A Gentleman in Black,'' ``The Storm on the Sea of Galilee,'' and a self-portrait by Rembrandt. _ ``Landscape with an Obelisk,'' by Govaert Flinck, another 17th-century Dutchman. _ ``Leaving the Paddock,'' ``Procession Outside Florence,'' ``Three Mounted Jockeys,'' ``Program for an Artistic Soiree,'' and another, less complete work by the same name, by Edgar Degas. _ ``At Tortoni's,'' by Edouard Manet. _ A Chinese bronze beaker from the Shang Dynasty, 1,200-1,100 B.C. The Rembrandt self-portrait and ``The Storm on the Sea of Galilee,'' the artist's only seascape, were especially important, Robinson said. He said the theft of the Vermeer also was a major loss because only about 35 of his works are known to exist. Experts said the motive for stealing such well-known pieces could be ransom or acquisitiveness by a selfish, wealthy art lover. ``You hear legends of deranged collectors. But, mostly, I think it's the stuff of spy novels,'' said Peter Sutton, curator of European paintings at the nearby Museum of Fine Arts. Gardner Museum spokesman Corey Cronin refused to say whether the works were insured. The Gardner Museum, which sits along the graceful green parkway called the Fenway, has a state-of-the-art security system, and had two security guards on duty at the time of the theft, Cronin said. He said no apparent damage was done to the museum, a four-story building with a courtyard and a skylight. The museum was built to house the collection of the woman whose name it bears, the widow of John Lowell Gardner, the wealthy son of the last of Boston's East India merchants. Mrs. Gardner lived on the top floor of the mansion until her death in 1924 at age 85. But she opened her home and its collection to the public long before then, in 1903. The museum collection contains 290 paintings, 280 pieces of sculpture and various religious objects, period furniture, textiles, ceramics and documents and books by famous writers and political figures. The last major reported theft involving a musuem occurred in Paris on June 1, when a Georges Braque worth an estimated $3 million was taken from the National Museum of Modern Art at the Pompidou Center.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Hear Tennessee Prosecutors' Appeal in Abuse Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to hear an unusual appeal by Tennessee prosecutors in the case of a man convicted of sexually abusing his 5-year-old nephew. The justices, without comment, let stand a Tennessee Supreme Court ruling that upheld Sam Pilkey's 1986 conviction and 25-year prison sentence. The state court ruled against Pilkey, who was 21 when he stood trial, even though it found that his constitutional right to confront all adverse witnesses was violated because jurors were shown a videotaped statement by the young boy. Prosecutors introduced the videotape as evidence. The boy did not testify in person, but apparently was available to be called by Pilkey's lawyer for cross-examination. He was not. The state Supreme Court last August ruled that Pilkey's right was violated but that the violation represented ``harmless error.'' Even though Pilkey's conviction had been upheld, Tennessee Attorney General Charles W. Burson appealed the state court's ruling. He urged the justices to rule that showing the videotape did not violate Pilkey's rights. The Supreme Court last January agreed to decide in cases from Maryland and Idaho whether people accused of child abuse have the right to at least one face-to-face confrontation with their young accusers. A decision is expected by July. The case acted on today is Tennessee vs. Pilkey, 89-773.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal by Owners of North Carolina Adult Film and Book Store
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by owners of a North Carolina adult film and book store who hired a college professor to help them rebut obscenity charges. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that had the effect of exposing the professor to an obscenity prosecution if he surveyed people about their reactions to sexually explicit material. Cinema Blue of Charlotte, N.C., and its owners, Jim St. John and Curtis Renee Peterson, were charged in 1988 with disseminating obscenity. St. John and Peterson were convicted last year, and each was sentenced to six years in prison. Their store was fined $250,000. Prior to their trial, the two men hired Ohio State University sociology professor Joseph E. Scott as an expert witness. Scott planned to show the allegedly obscene material to randomly selected groups of adults in Mecklenburg County. He also planned to conduct telephone surveys aimed at determining community attitudes toward the material. The North Carolina obscenity law bans sexually explicit material lacking ``serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value'' if it also is ``patently offensive`` and ``appeals to the prurient interest in sex'' as judged by contemporary community standards. Peter S. Gilchrist III, the local district attorney, warned the Cinema Blue owners that Scott could be prosecuted if he conductted the surveys. A state judge refused to shield Scott from prosecution, and St. John and Peterson turned to the federal courts for help. U.S. District Judge James B. McMillan ruled in their favor, issuing an injunction that barred Gilchrist from prosecuting the professor for conducting the surveys. But the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year overruled the judge. ``In the unique circumstances present here,'' the appeals court said, the judge should not have interfered in a pending state prosecution. Scott ``was not immediately threatened with any irremediable harm, for his remedy for avoiding state prosecution lay entirely within his hands and could be invoked with no sacrifice of any federal rights personal to him,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court also rejected charges that the adult book store's proprietors were victims of unlawful discrimination by Gilchrist. The store owners said Gilchrist permitted anti-pornography groups and others to conduct surveys similar to the one Scott wanted to undertake. The case is Cinema Blue vs. Gilchrist, 89-1213.

DOC.HEAD: Police Seize Nearly Two Tons of Cocaine, Arrest 13
DOC.TEXT: Police raided a drug laboratory in southern Colombia, seized 3,960 pounds of pure cocaine and arrested 13 people, police said Monday. The cocaine, packaged and ready to be shipped to the United States, was seized Saturday in the raid on the lab near the town of Bolivar, 145 miles southwest of Bogota, police said. Police aso found an airstrip used by small planes bringing coca paste from Bolivia and Peru and carrying cocaine to the United States. On Sunday, police raided another lab capable of processing more than 100 pounds of cocaine daily. Police seized coca base, chemicals used to process cocaine and several vehicles at the lab near the town of Candelaria in the southern state of Valle.

DOC.HEAD: China's Legislature Meets Tuesday; No Controversy Expected
DOC.TEXT: China's national legislature meets Tuesday in an annual session expected to be devoid of controversy and laden with shows of loyalty to government political and economic policies. Unlike previous sessions of the National People's Congress, when mild debate and scatterings of negative votes were taken as signs of emerging democracy, the emphasis at the first meeting since the June 1989 crackdown on demonstrators will be on political stability and obedience. Wan Li, chairman of the Congress' Standing Committee, has called on the nearly 3,000 deputies to the 15-day national meeting to follow the guidance of the ruling Communist Party and ``make correct policies'' for the good of all Chinese people. Communist Party members, who make up about two-thirds of the delegates, reportedly have been told to refrain from making controversial statements or proposals at the plenum. The Congress in recent years has tried to shake off its rubber-stamp image by openly debating and sometimes amending legislation, but the party still holds ultimate authority to initiate and decide policy. Tuesday's highlight will be a state-of-the-nation address by Premier Li Peng in which he is expected to hail the suppression of the pro-democracy student movement and reassert China's commitment to Communist Party rule and socialism. Li also will pledge to continue an austerity program that has brought inflation under control, but may announce some concessions, such as the easing of tight money policies, to pull the economy out of a serious slump. Li, a political hard-liner and economic conservative, is unlikely to reveal plans for new economic reforms. Instead of market-oriented price reforms, now politically inexpedient, he may call for tighter management of prices. On foreign policy matters, Li is expected to express China's interest in good relations with all countries, including the Soviet Union and the United States, but stress that China will not be influenced by rapid changes in other socialist countries or bow to U.S. Demands for human rights reforms. The deputies also will hear a report from the finance minister on the government's precarious financial state and approve the 1990 budget. Attempts to balance the budget have been made more difficult by intense competition for limited funds. Bureaucrats seeking money for struggling education, social welfare and infrastructure programs are vying with the military, which carries more clout since the army put down the demonstrations and wants to reverse the trend of falling defense budgets. The deputies are expected to pass with little debate a basic law to govern Hong Kong after the British colony reverts to Chinese rule in 1997, and an amendment to the joint venture law guaranteeing that foreign enterprises in China will not be nationalized. The Congress will approve several government personnel changes, but the Standing Committee spokesman Yao Guang on Monday dampened speculation about major displacements, including the removal of Li. The scheduled changes, he said, ``do not correspond with the rumors and guesses and reports of some newspapers in Hong Kong,'' he said. Li is widely disliked because of his key role in the violent military suppression of the pro-democracy movement and his economic policies that have led to factory closures and unemployment. There has been speculation the party would demote him to shore up its shaky reputation among the populace. Hong Kong and foreign reports also have suggested the party would have a non-party member named vice premier as part of its recent pledges to give those outside the party a greater voice in the government. Yao said the Congress would take up the request by senior leader Deng Xiaoping to step down as chairman of the state Central Military Commission. Deng, still regarded as the most powerful person in China, resigned in November as head of the largely overlapping party Central Military Commission, ending his official party duties. Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin, who succeeded Deng in the party post, is expected to get the state job as well. Yao said Jiang's predecessor Zhao Ziyang, who was purged form all party posts in June for allegedly supporting the democracy movement, would not attend the Congress. Zhao, a deputy from Sichuan province, has ``asked for leave,'' Yao said. He has not been seen in public since a tearful meeting with hunger strikers on Tiananmen Square on May 19, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Says It's Working to Resolve Space Station Maintenance Problem
Precede NEW YORK
DOC.TEXT: NASA said today that its engineers have worried for years that astronauts will have to spend too much time in the harsh environment of open space to repair and maintain the space station that is set for construction in the mid-90s.
