Agency officials were preparing a response to a front-page article in the New York Times today that said the station can't be built as designed ``because its vast array of parts would start to break down before the station was completed.'' The first elements of the $30 billion station are to be carried into orbit beginning early in 1995 and completion is scheduled for 1999. The Times said NASA investigators found that construction would be only 60 percent to 70 percent complete before preventive maintenance would have to begin. The Times said investigators concluded that, if built according to plan, the space station would have more than 5,500 external parts that would need to be replaced if they failed. That would require space walks, or what NASA calls EVAs, short for extra-vehicular activity. ``In terms of the program addressing EVAs, that is not a new thing; it's not a new problem that has suddenly been discovered,'' said space station spokesman Mark Hess. The Times said such space walks would total 2,200 hours for maintenance, but Hess said that estimate includes a lot of time in which astronauts would not actually be outside of the relative safety of the station. Anther spokesman, James McCulla, said EVA time ``is a matter that space station designers have been working on for years.'' He said that working out methods to cut down the EVA time is an integral part of design review activities ``and therefore will be an important matter to be worked on for days to come.''

DOC.HEAD: Large Jade Boulder Reportedly Found in China
DOC.TEXT: A piece of jade weighing 260 tons was found in northeastern China, the official People's Daily said Monday. The paper said the jade, measuring 16{ feet tall, 23.1 feet long and 19.8 feet wide, was the world's largest, but gave no basis for the claim. The Guinness Book of World Records lists a 157.65-ton boulder of jade, also found in China, as the world's largest. It said the brightly colored green jade with areas of red, blue and yellow was found in Liaoning province's Xiuyan Manchu Autonomous County. The report did not say how or when the jade was discovered or give any other details.

DOC.HEAD: Counting the Homeless, A First-Time Effort
DOC.TEXT: Census Bureau workers will head for flophouses, missions and cheap hotels Tuesday night. Then they'll look for people in the streets and alleyways, and as the sun comes up they'll be outside abandoned buildings to see who comes out. It will be the most ambitious effort ever to count the homeless and the first in which the government tries to count people living in the streets. ``The government needs to know about everyone and this is a chance for the homeless to say, `Look, we exist, we're part of this country,''' Cynthia Taeuber, special assistant for selected populations at the Census Bureau, said Monday. Although most Americans will receive census forms asking from a dozen to a few dozen questions, the main effort for the homeless will be just to get them counted, explained Taeuber. The new effort reflects a change in American society, with the homeless more numerous and more visible than ever. Dealing with the problem, though, has been muddled by the scarcity of information on how many people have no homes. Estimates have ranged from 250,000 to 3 million or more. Narrowing down that difference will involve an estimated 15,000 census workers and cost $2.7 million, Taeuber said. Census officials are looking for homeless in every city of at least 50,000 people. In addition, Census asked smaller communities if they had a homeless population and ``if they sent in the information to us, we're there,'' said Taeuber. A decade ago the Census Bureau sent workers to flophouses and shelters, and this special count is still known as S-Night. Originally that stood for shelter night, now it's expanded to shelter and street night. ``There are a lot of people that are homeless that don't even come to a shelter. I stayed on the streets ... for days before I came here,'' said Toylce Cheatham in a recent interview at a Salvation Army shelter in Detroit. Workers will try to ask the homeless some questions. But they will simply observe and estimate answers for those sleeping or who are ``not in a state of mind to answer questions, or who refuse,'' Taeuber explained. Advocates for the homeless are cooperating with the census in many cities, but a few are resisting the effort, claiming the count will be too low. Because of problems in finding all the homeless, and concerns about worker safety, Taeuber admits she expects the tally to be conservative. But it will at least provide the first formal count of people in the streets. In the end, however, the Census Bureau won't announce any specific number of homeless, since officials decline to try and define that term. Instead, the bureau will simply report that it's special count found so many people in shelters, so many in missions, so many in flophouses, so many walking or sleeping on the streets, and so forth. Beginning Tuesday at 6 p.m. workers will visit public and private emergency shelters, hotels and motels used to shelter the homeless and other hotels costing less than $12 per night. This effort is expected to last until about midnight, covering a period when people are generally settled for the night. Then, from 2 a.m. to 4 a.m. census workers will travel the streets, checking places not intended for habitation but where homeless people may be found. After that, until about 8 a.m., workers will be outside abandoned buildings where they believe some homeless people may live. Michael Alakel, who said he has been homeless for three years in Hartford, Conn., thinks census workers will have problems finding people living in dumpsters, cars, graveyards and under bridges, among other places. ``You have to know where to find these people. They are not going to come out of their hiding places so they can be counted,'' said Alakel. Census officials concede they will miss some, but they have been working with with municipal officials and local groups that assist the homeless in order to identify the most likely places to look during the special count. In New York City alone some 2,100 sites have been identified as likely locations for the homeless, including more than 300 public and private shelters. Security can be a problem for workers taking to streets and shelters in the middle of the night, and they will be dispatched in groups of two or three. They have been told to leave any area where problems develop, said Taeuber. Because of safety questions, she explained, the decision was made not to enter abandoned buildings even though people may be sleeping in them. In Tompkins Square Park, on New York's lower east side, a homeless man who declined to give his name said the early morning hours are ``not a good time to ask people questions around here. I think that's stupid.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Optimistic About Chances For German Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl's comments today; Picks up 4th graf, `West Germany ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today vowed to keep his promises of economic help to the East German people, a day after his conservative East German allies were elected in their nation's first free vote. Kohl also said he sees ``outstanding chances'' for his party when elections for a united German government finally come, but he doesn't expect that to happen until after West Germany's own elections in December. During numerous campaign appearances in East Germany, Kohl promised East Germans quick steps toward German unification, and to protect them from possible economic and social shocks during the process. Kohl told reporters he will not break his pledge. ``We will keep our promises to the people of the GDR (East Germany),'' he said. Kohl campaigned vigorously for the three-party East German alliance that placed first in Sunday's vote. West German newspapers today heralded the results as a clear vote for quick unification. West Germany faces its own elections Dec. 2, and Social Democrat Oskar Lafontaine today formally announced he would challenge Kohl. It has been assumed for weeks that Lafontaine, the sharp-tongued governor of Saarland state, would enter the race. Like the leaders of their sister parties in East Germany, Lafontaine and Kohl disagree on the pace and course of German unification. Kohl wants it done quickly, but Lafontaine says it must be a measured process and include creation of a new constitution. Alfred Dregger, parliamentary chief of Kohl's Christian Democrats, predicted in an interview with the Deutschlandfunk radio station in Cologne that elections for a unified Germany would occur next year. Dregger urged the newly elected allies in the East to undertake economic and social reforms ``as soon as possible'' to lay the groundwork for unification. The East German results could speed up negotiations between the German states on making West Germany's mark East Germany's currency. That would be a giant stride toward unification. The Alliance for Germany, however, did not win a majority and must now build a coalition. Kohl said he had advised his East German allies to include the East German Social Democrats in a ``grand coalition.'' However, the leader of the East German Social Democrats today rejected such an invitation. Kohl repeated his opinion that talks with East Germany on creating a common currency should be taken up immediately after a new government in East Berlin is created. The chancellor was asked when he foresaw all-German elections taking place. He replied many steps should be taken first, such as East Germany's local elections slated for May, and the reconstitution of East Germany's states. Under Kohl's plans for unification, East German states could join West Germany under a provision of the West German constitution. Kohl added, ``We'll have our federal elections in December in any case, and then we'll see what happens.''

DOC.HEAD: White House Hails `Historic' East German Voting
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with White House reaction
DOC.TEXT: The White House today hailed the free elections held in East Germany and said the march toward a united Germany is ``inexorable.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the strong showing by the conservative alliance linked with West Germany Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party also ``would seem to lend support'' for U.S.-backed efforts to keep the new Germany inside NATO. ``We are pleased to note that East Germany yesterday joined the growing list of nations that have held free and fair elections,'' Fitzwater said. ``This is a victory not only for the people of the German Democratic Republic, but for all Germans and all who support democratic values,'' he said in a statement. ``We have long supported the aspirations of the people of East Germany in deciding their own future. We join them and the people of the Federal Republic in celebrating this historic occasion.'' Asked about possible obstacles to unification, Fitzwater replied, ``it does appear that the march towards reunification is inexorable. It seems clear that the elections have sent that message.'' Asked if the large plurality for the Alliance for Germany, the three-party conservative bloc tied to Kohl's Christian Democrats, would make it easier to keep the new Germany within NATO, Fitzwater said, ``I think that's difficult to say.'' But he added, ``This victory ... would seem to lend support for that direction as well.'' He said, ``I don't think there's much question about their intention.'' The Soviet Union has said a united Germany cannot belong to the Western military alliance. Bush and Kohl met at Camp David, Md., last month to discuss the fast-moving changes leading to what could be a single Germany by the end of this year. West Germans vote in their own parliamentary elections this fall. The United States and the three other World War II victors, the Soviet Union, Great Britain and France, have approved a process for talks with the two Germanys on unification. Fitzwater said of unification, ``President Bush's discussions with Chancellor Kohl all point in that direction and we have a process in place now that hopefully will help manage that reunification and make it a peaceful and orderly process.'' The White House earlier had hailed the results of East Germany's first free election in 57 years as a ``historic occasion.'' White House deputy press secretary Alixe Glen, commenting on Sunday after East Germans finished their balloting, said: ``The U.S. welcomes today's parliamentary elections in the German Democratic Republic. We have long supported the aspirations of the people of East Germany to decide their own future through a freely elected parliament and government. We join them and the people of the Federal Republic of Germany in celebrating this historic occasion.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises State Efforts in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told attorneys general from around the nation today that aggressive state efforts were responsible in part for a ``certain turning around'' of public opinion on drug abuse. But the state legal officers said what they really needed was more money from Washington. Speaking at the White House to attorneys general from 37 states, Bush cited some frustration that Congress hadn't moved more quickly on parts of his drug and anti-crime package. ``We've gotten some of what we have asked for _ new agents, new prosecutors, new prison space,'' he said. ``We are getting some good support already on certain parts of the package. But I must confess to a certain frustration. ``I would ask your support, this much horsepower in town, to work ... with us on getting this crime package through.'' He voiced strong opposition to efforts in Congress to retroactively overturn state death sentences. ``We are not sympathetic to that,'' Bush said. Bush said he sensed ``a certain turning around, at least in terms of public opinion,'' on the issue of drugs, mentioning that anti-drug messages are being worked into some Saturday morning cartoon shows. ``Twenty million kids watch cartoons every Saturday,'' Bush said. ``Now, that couldn't have happened if it hadn't been from April 1 through March 31, 1991. All athletes who qualify may compete in the U.S. Senior Sports Classic, held June 28-July 3, 1991, in Syracuse, N.Y. Events include archery, badminton, basketball, bowling, cycling, golf, horseshoes, race walking, shuffleboard, softball, swimming, table tennis, tennis, track and field, triathlon and volleyball. To participate in the biennial national even, an athlete must be 55 or older, and for most events have place in the top three at USNSO-sanctioned local senior games, or meet minimum performance standards. Former U.S. Olympians and national record-holders are exempt from qualifying in their sports, as are all 1987 and 1989 USNSO gold medalists. The not-for-profit USNSO, former the U.S. National Senior Olympics, was established in 1987 after the first U.S. National Senior Olympics.
For more information, contact local games coordinators or the USNSO, 14323 South Outer Forty Rd., Suite N300, Chesterfield, Mo. 63017, 314-878-4900.

DOC.HEAD: Swallows Make Official Return To San Juan Capistrano
DOC.TEXT: Swallows made their traditional St. Joseph's Day appearance in this old mission town today as hundreds of residents and visitors cheered the fork-tailed birds' return. From the mission church courtyard, Paul Arbiso, 96, and Frank Velasquez, 68, spotted a small group of swallows flying above the 214-year-old mission. The two hometown residents pulled ropes to ring the four church bells to formally celebrate the birds' migratory return from Argentina. A handful of swallows and dozens of pigeons flew from the mission eaves to nearby treetops during the two-minute ringing of the bells. ``It's fun. It's like playing _ pulling the ropes and all,'' said Arbiso, who has sighted the swallows' return for several decades. Swallows had been seen earlier this morning, but by tradition, Arbiso's sighting signals their official return. The swallow watch began in a thick fog shortly after dawn, kicking off a series of celebrations that end with the Fiesta de las Golondrinas Parade on Saturday. The morning fog slowly burned off to reveal a clear blue sky. Arbiso, like others present, said the numbers of swallows were decreasing. ``Twenty or thirty years ago, they were all over, flocks of them coming in and out. I'd sure like to see those days again,'' he said. First accounts of the swallows coming to San Juan Capistrano date back to 1776. That was the year Father Junipero Serra founded the mission as part of Spain's effort to spread the Roman Catholic faith in the New World. The traditional belief that the birds return every St. Joseph's Day gained widespread fame because of a hit 1939 song, ``When the Swallows Come Back to Capistrano.'' According to legend, the swallows failed to arrive in Capistrano only once, in 1935, when they were held up by a storm. In the fall, the swallows migrate to Goya, Argentina, about 5,000 miles to the south.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Warns Against New Technology Becoming an `Idol'
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, visiting one of Italy's most important technical centers, warned Monday about making technology the idol of modern times. The pope said the dignity of human beings can not be ``sacrificed to the machine'' and that unemployment resulting from advanced technology ``can't be morally accepted.'' ``It's necessary to resist the temptation to make technology a new idol ... technology and its products are not all ... how can we forget, for example, the polluting effects linked to technological development ... and questions about the destination of technological products?'' the pope asked workers during a visit to the Olivetti and Fiat-Lancia plants. The pope visited the Olivetti computer factory in Ivrea and the Fiat-Lancia auto plant in nearby Chivasso in northern Italy to mark the feast day of St. Joseph, considered the patron of workers. The pontiff frequently has met with groups of workers and spoken of his own experiences as an employee in a quarry in his native Poland before he became a priest. ``The pope has come here to acknowledge and pay homage to the dignity of each worker,'' John Paul said in his address to Olivetti employees. John Paul II conceded that technology can be an ally of humans and said that technological advancement is irreversible. But he stressed that the principle of ``man's pre-eminence over technology'' must be remembered. ``Automation and sophisticated equipment are causing not a few problems for workers, their families and society,'' he added, speaking in Italian. In Ivrea, the pope was welcomed by Carlo De Benedetti, who heads a financial empire including the Olivetti corporation. Fiat's chairman, Gianni Agnelli, stood at the pope's side in an open van during the visit to Lancia. Production at the Lancia plant, which employs 5,000 workers and makes more than 500 cars a day, was suspended during the pope's speech in a huge tent. The pope called on the Lancia workers to show solidarity with immigrants, who have been streaming into Italy by the thousands in recent years from northern Africa and other impoverished areas. ``Each man must have the right to seek working opportunities ... also beyond national and continental borders,'' he said. ``Humanity by now lives in a single village ... because of the growing interdependence among humans and nations.''

DOC.HEAD: One Person's Castle: Ransacked Museum Reflects Patron's Eccentricities
With AM-Museum Theft, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Isabella Stewart Gardner, founder and lone patron of the Gardner Museum, assembled an art collection unique among American galleries and a museum stamped with her own incorrigible, eccentric personality. Extravagant, selfish, ambitious and daring to the point of imprudence, Mrs. Gardner, as she was always called, was known for her ability to swig beer and heft an ax like the men of the day. She was a woman who did everything a proper Boston woman of the late 19th and early 20th centuries would not do. In taking a priceless cache of art from her former home on Sunday, two thieves violated Mrs. Gardner's cardinal rule by moving her paintings from their assigned locations. ``She was an amazing character,'' said Cleveland Amory, author of ``The Proper Bostonians,'' an account of the city's ``Brahmins.'' ``She was a very individual person.'' Tales of Mrs. Gardner's exploits abound. She was known to walk down the city's Tremont Street with her pet lion, Rex, on a leash. When she gave parties at her Beacon Street home she greeted her guests not from the door, but perched on a branch in a tree. Wealth was never novel to Mrs. Gardner. She was the daughter of a successful New York dry goods merchant and married John Lowell Gardner, son of the last of Boston's East India merchants, in 1860. But while other turn-of-the-century Boston bluebloods played down their riches, Mrs. Gardner flaunted hers. Warned by other high-society Boston women that she should keep her jewels tucked away in a safe deposit box, she had two of her largest diamonds set on gold wires so she could wear them like antennae. In 1898, shortly after her husband died, she had a nervous breakdown. When she recovered, doctors suggested she take up a hobby, which became her museum. A 15th century Venetian palace was dismantled and brought to Boston, where Mrs. Gardner supervised its incorporation into her home and museum. The museum is frozen in time: Nothing may be altered, nothing may be moved from its assigned place, nothing may be loaned, nothing may be sold and nothing may be added to the collection. Peter Sutton, curator of Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, called the Gardner Museum one of three great art collections assembled by turn-of-the-century aristocrats. He said the others are those of the Frick in New York and of attorney John G. Johnson, now at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. ``The Gardner is a testament to another era,'' Sutton said. ``It's not only important because of the works it houses, but important to the history of American art collecting. It's a great tribute to old style, blue-chip collecting.'' While Mrs. Gardner footed the bill for the museum's construction, she wasn't afraid to get her hands dirty. She personally supervised the building, to the point of climbing on scaffolds to mix paint to the precise color she sought. Whenever she worked, a trumpeter stood nearby to summon workmen, one note for the architect, another for the plumber, and so on. ``She was there every damn day,'' Amory said. ``Once, she grabbed an ax to hew a heavy beam to show workmen how it should be done.'' The official opening of the museum was celebrated with a gala on Jan. 1, 1903. Only workmen had seen the inside of the palace. Confronted with the problem of testing the acoustics in the music room before the ball, Mrs. Gardner had a characteristic solution. She contacted the Perkins Institute for the Blind and gathered an audience of blind children for an afternoon concert and test run. Mrs. Gardner lived in the top floor of the mansion until her death in 1924 at age 85. But she opened her home and its collection to the public long before then. She built the collection with the help of a young Lithuanian immigrant named Bernard Berenson, who became one of the most respected art historians. On her own, Gardner convinced T. Jefferson Coolidge to loan her Sargent's ``El Jaleo,'' and then never gave it back. To protect her stolen prize, she built a cloister around the work, making it nearly impossible to remove. The collection contains 290 paintings and 280 pieces of sculpture, as well as religious objects, period furniture, textiles, ceramics and documents and books by famous writers and political figures. Amory said the museum is unique because it bore the indelible stamp of Mrs. Gardner's personality. ``Others, like Frick, had more money and bigger collections,'' Amory said. ``But the personality of the Gardner Museum is hers. It's one person's taste and one person's castle.''

DOC.HEAD: Clashes Flare in Both Christian and Shiite Feuds
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces traded mortar and gunfire in east Beirut Monday, while Shiite Moslem militias pounded each other with artillery and tank fire in south Lebanon, police reported. They said one soldier of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's army was wounded in gun battles with Lebanese Forces militiamen of Christian warlord Samir Geagea in east Beirut's Sin el-Fil residential district. The hostilities threatened a cease-fire called March 3 to halt the bloodiest Christian power struggle since Lebanon's civil war started 15 years ago. By police count, 762 people were killed and 2,116 wounded since Aoun's fight with Geagea for control of the 310-square-mile enclave started Jan. 30. Police said no casualties were reported from the fighting in south Lebanon between the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the pro-Syran mainstream Amal militia. A Hezbollah communique accused Amal of launching a surprise attack with tanks to recapture two strategic villages in Iqlim al-Tuffah, the Apple Province, southeast of the port city of Sidon. The communique said Hezbollah's fighters repulsed Amal's onslaught on the villages of Kfar Hatta and Kfar Melki after heavy fighting with tanks, mortars and 106mm recoilless guns from dusk Sunday to dawn Monday. Amal withheld comment on Hezbollah's communique. But police described the fighting as the heaviest in the region since a cease-fire brokered by Iran silenced the guns in Iqlim al-Tuffah in early February. The two factions have been locked in a power struggle since 1987, for control of the 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect. Their mini-wars erupt periodically in south Lebanon and Beirut's Shiite-populated southern slums. In a separate event, Lebanon's Central Bank employees Monday called off an open-ended strike that was staged to protest an attempt to arrest the bank's governor. A statement issued in the name of the bank's 700 employees said they hoped such an incident will not happen again. Interior Minister Elias Khazen on Thursday sent a police patrol to arrest Gov. Edmond Naim, but the attempt was foiled by bank guards. A bank administrator was wounded in the brief shootout.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Suffering From Hay Fever
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of cameras whirred as a sniffling President Bush coughed and blew his nose. ``It's news: a little hay fever in the air around here,'' the president apologized to his audience. Then, looking straight at the now-quieted cameras, Bush raised his handkerchief with a flourish for an exagerrated honk of his nose. Flashes lit the room like lightning and electric camera motors hummed in unison. ``They've got their job to do and I got mine,'' the president told a gathering of state attorneys general in the White House's Roosevelt Room. Then he rubbed his nose again. The cameras again came to life. ``Come on, you guys,'' Bush scolded. The president, who suffers from allergies, said he ``got hit'' with the bout of hay fever Sunday. He spent the weekend at the well-foliated presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland. Tom Miller, attorney general of Iowa and president of the National Association of Attorneys General, told Bush: ``Thank you for being with us, and thank you for the education in Washington that, when the president sneezes, it makes news.'' ``They like to needle me a little bit,'' Bush said of the camera operators and photographers. ``I'll get even.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Reiterate Demand that Unified Germany Stay Out of NATO
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Membership of a unified Germany in NATO would upset the balance of power in Europe and should not be allowed, a Soviet spokesman said Monday. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said at a news briefing that the Soviet Union respected the will of the people of East Germany, but added that they must in turn respect the rights of others. A conservative coalition that swept to victory in East German elections Sunday strongly favors speedy reunification with West Germany. ``We respect the expressed will of the citizens of East Germany, an allied sovereign state,'' Gerasimov said. ``Respecting this right of choice, we proceed from the premise that in turn, they will respect the legitimate interests of the Soviet Union and other countries.'' Gerasimov said Germans had the right of unification, but he repeated the Soviet position that a unified Germany could not become a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He said the process of unification should come about in carefully planned stages, with cooperation between the East and West. ``It should not be a member of NATO,'' Gerasimov said. ``That would upset the balance of Europe.'' Gerasimov said the Soviets wanted both parts of a unified Germany to be demilitarized and the problems of European security should be approached with a view of overcoming the ``inertia of bloc approaches.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Burlington Mayor Announces Congressional Bid
DOC.TEXT: Former Burlington Mayor Bernard Sanders, hoping to build upon his strong showing in the 1988 race, said today that he would run again for Congress this year. Sanders, who gained wide attention as the nation's only socialist mayor during his eight years as Burlington mayor, said he opted for Congress instead of running for governor, as he had considered doing, because of concerns over national and international issues. ``I can honestly say that there is no race that I have ever run in which I feel more enthusiastic, more confident, and which has, for me, a greater sense of urgency,'' he said in his announcement. Sanders came in second in the 1988 race for Vermont's only seat in the U.S. House. The race was won by Republican Peter Smith, with 41 percent. Sanders, running as an independent, gained 38 percent, while the Democratic nominee, former Vermont House Majority Leader Paul Poirier received only 19 percent. Sanders, who was Burlington mayor from 1981-89, considers himself a socialist but runs as an independent and said he would do so again this year. It appears at this time, however, that the Democrats will not put up a strong candidate, and perhaps will not put up any candidate at all against Smith, giving Sanders something he has never had in a statewide race: a head-to-head contest. But a race against Smith, now an incumbent with support among Democrats as well as Republicans, will not be easy. The League for Conservation Voters has already endorsed Smith, even without knowing who he would have as an opponent. Sanders began his political career in Vermont with the Liberty Union, a third political party that is unique to the state. But he left that party and statewide politics to run for mayor of Burlington in 1981. He ousted the incumbent and went on to serve eight years. In 1986 he returned to statewide politics, with a gubernatorial run, in which he finished third, behind Gov. Madeleine Kunin and Smith, then the lieutenant governor.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Arista Records drew on some of the hottest names in the recording industry in marking its 15th anniversary with a concert billed as the largest single event to benefit AIDS victims. Hall & Oates belted out their latest single, ``Starting All Over Again,'' Whitney Houston delighted the crowd with a charged rendition of ``The Greatest Love of All'' and Patti Smith sang a moody version of ``A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall'' at Saturday's five-hour concert in Radio City Music Hall. Artists and guest hosts repeatedly reminded the enthusiastic crowd of their reason for attending, with Jennifer Holliday dedicating a song to Broadway director and playwright Michael Bennett who died of AIDS in 1987. In a solo skit portraying an 8-year-old AIDS victim, Whoopi Goldberg drew laughs, sighs and tears as she demonstrated the numerous misconceptions of the fatal disease. Even the ever-silly Chevy Chase switched gears and solemnly intoned that such events can help eradicate the bigotry and hatred confronting AIDS sufferers. ``It's everyone's job to stop the panic,'' he said. Organizers said the ``That's What Friends Are For'' concert raised more than $2 million and is to be broadcast on CBS in April. Proceeds went to the Gay Men's Health Crisis and other AIDS organizations. Virtually every major artist on the Arista label performed, including Dionne Warwick, Bob Weir, Melissa Manchester, Lisa Stansfield, Jermaine Jackson, the Jeff Healey Band and Anderson Bruford Wakeman Howe. At the finale, Warwick sang ``That's What Friends Are For'' accompanied by Burt Bacharach, and most of the night's performers joined in. Warwick recorded the chart-topping single in 1986 with Elton John, Stevie Wonder and Gladys Knight, raising more than $1 million in royalties for the American Foundation for AIDS Research.

Dolly Parton plans to buy the radio station where she taped her first songs. She wants to move it to her Dollywood theme park in nearby Pigeon Forge. The country music queen announced Monday she is buying WSEV-AM and FM, pending Federal Communications Commission approval. No price was disclosed. ``The planned relocation to Dollywood will better serve the hometown listeners as well as the millions of visitors to the Smoky Mountains,'' she said in a statement. At age 9, Ms. Parton went with her uncle, Bill Owens, to WSEV to tape two songs they had written together, ``Puppy Love'' and ``Girl Left Alone.'' It was their first single for Gold Band Records. ``The quality of the recording would be considered substandard compared to today's technology because it was recorded through a single microphone,'' former WSEV co-managers Mary Sue Poe and Skip Trotter said in a statement. The theme park plans to display the original microphone and other equipment Ms. Parton used to tape the two songs. Visitors also will be able to see the modern station in operation.

Former auto racing champion Stirling Moss suffered a broken thigh when he was hit by a car while driving a motor scooter in central London, and should take six months to recover, doctors said. Doctors inserted three metal pins in the 60-year-old former Grand Prix driver's thigh bone after Monday's accident, said publicist Linda Patterson. The car allegedly ran a yield sign and hit Moss, who was going 20 mph on an errand to buy coriander, Ms. Patterson said. Police were investigating, she added. ``I have been told the recovery process will be a slow one _ about six months,'' Moss said in a statement. ``In all my racing career, in which I have had quite a few shunts, I have never been kept from behind the wheel for even half that length of time, apart from my 1962 accident.'' Moss crashed at 90 mph during a race at Britain's Goodwood track in 1962. He was dragged unconscious from his car, remained in a coma for three days and was paralyzed for six months. Since his career began in 1950, Moss has competed in 494 races or speed records, winning 222, including 16 Grand Prix. He won the British national championships nine times.

Paula Zahn, the new co-anchor of ``CBS This Morning,'' rejects the notion that she is in a beauty contest with two other network blondes, ABC's Joan Lunden and NBC's Deborah Norville. ``I find that very insulting,'' Zahn told TV Guide in its March 24 issue. ``I've been in the news business for 13 years. I'm bringing to this broadcast a lot of experience working in different parts of the country covering many different types of stories. ``I've interviewed world leaders. To reduce it to that kind of battle, I find it very offensive.'' Zahn, 34, is the latest in a line of female co-anchors on CBS's third-place morning show, following Phyllis George, Mariette Hartley and Kathleen Sullivan. She knows there are no guarantees of job security. ``There are bound to be changes if a program isn't producing the kinds of audiences that executives want,'' she told the magazine. ``There will be constant tinkering to deliver the best product, and the most profitable product, that we can. Those changes are an everday reality.''

Yves Saint Laurent, one of the world's best-known couturiers, has temporarily abandoned his fashion house activities to recuperate in a hospital because of exhaustion. Saint Laurent, 53, will not attend Wednesday's presentation of his ready-to-wear spring collection, his fashion house said in a statement. His doctor, Michael Prendeville, ordered St. Laurent hospitalized Saturday for several weeks after examining him but finding no signs of infectious disease, the statement said. The Saint Laurent empire is estimated to be worth $2 billion. In 1988, it had a turnover of about $450 million in couture, ready-to-wear clothing for women and men, perfume and accessories through licenses.

DOC.HEAD: Precedes WASHINGTON
Baker Arrives in Namibia; Plans South African, Angolan Peace Moves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Baker arrival; Picks up 5th graf, `Baker will ...'
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III arrived today in Namibia, where he aims to mix celebration with negotiations to end apartheid in South Africa and to achieve a cease-fire in Angola. In six fast-paced days, Baker plans to visit three countries, including South Africa _ the first secretary of state to go there since 1978. He will fly to Cape Town on Thursday to show U.S. appreciation for the preliminary steps taken by President F.W. de Klerk and to try to drive him to go faster. To underscore U.S. support for the black movement Baker will go on Friday to Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg, for talks there with Desmond Tutu, the black Anglican archbishop, and other black leaders. Soweto has been the cradle of the anti-apartheid movement. Baker joined world leaders gathered in Windhoek, the capital, for independence ceremonies. Namibia was pried from South Africa's control with the help of U.S. diplomacy that is now shifting its focus to Pretoria, where a white minority government is being urged to dismantle racial segregation. Baker made no comment on arriving at the airport and he and his party were whisked away in a convoy of cars. Baker will meet in Windhoek with Nelson Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress, and then in Cape Town with de Klerk and Foreign Minister R.F. Botha. ``The purpose of our seeing these gentlemen is to encourage negotiations, to move as rapidly as possible, and to see what we can do to contribute to that,'' a senior U.S. official said. Baker also will hold talks in Windhoek with Jose Eduoardo dos Santos, the president of Angola, a potentially rich African nation with which the United States has no diplomatic relations. Baker intends to urge him to negotiate for a share of the government with Jonas Savimbi, the U.S.-backed leader of the UNITA insurgents in a 14-year war. He will see Savimbi in Kinshasa, Zaire, before flying home on Saturday. Baker's aides made clear before his departure that the Bush administration would not yield to Mandela's demands for stiffer sanctions against South Africa and would not recognize Angola until the Luanda government settles with the rebels. But Baker also is ready to assure Mandela that the administration would keep pressuring de Klerk, who will hold preliminary negotiations April 11 with black leaders, to free all political prisoners and end a 3{-year state of emergency. In Angola, a military standoff since December in Navinga, a Savimbi stronghold, encourages Baker to promote a cease-fire. The country has developed a private economy and ships 75 percent of its oil to the United States through Chevron and Conoco. But the United States, alone among major Western countries, has withheld recognition. Soviet support for Angola and Cuban troops in the country were the biggest reasons. About half of the 50,000 Cubans have left under a complex agreement that also ended South African control over Namibia. The rest are supposed to depart by next year. But Soviet aid, even though it is decreasing, ``continues to be humongous,'' a senior U.S. official said, insisting on anonymity. ``We're talking about a decrease from about a billion dollars a year to $600 million.'' ``We're not asking for the overthrow of the government,'' the official said. ``We are not asking for any type of regime. We're not asking that Jonas Savimbi be made president of Angola. ``All we're asking for is for the government of Angola to reconcile with a major dissident organization which represents a significant number of Angolan people,'' the official said. In the event of ``a new political order, we will be very happy to bow out.''

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Coming to United States
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki is coming to the United States to seek support for the Solidarity-led government's demand that a treaty guaranteeing Poland's western border be signed before Germany unifies. The former Solidarity editor and political prisoner leaves Warsaw on Tuesday for a six-day visit to the United States, with a one-day stop in Canada. It will be Mazowiecki's longest abroad since he was elected in August to lead the first non-Communist government in the East bloc. ``I don't need to stress the significance of the visit for Poland to a country which is the world's No. 1 superpower,'' government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said recently, outlining the goals of the visit. Mazowiecki achieved one aim of his trip when the four victorious World War II allies and the two Germanys last week decided to allow Poland to take part in sessions of ``two-plus-four'' talks that concern Poland's security. Now, Mazowiecki will be pushing for U.S. backing of his government's demand that a treaty guaranteeing Poland's western border be initialed by East Germany and West Germany before unification and then ratified by a unified Germany. Treaties commit the Germanys to respect the Oder and Neisse rivers as Poland's western border, but a unified Germany is not bound by those terms. Poles are concerned by some in Germany who urge reunification be sought within the 1937 borders that included about one-third of present-day Poland. Warsaw has not been satisfied by a resolution backed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl asking parliaments in West Germany and East Germany to adopt declarations saying a united Germany should sign a treaty affirming the Poles' right to live in secure borders. ``We would like the U.S. to act towards stabilization of transformations taking place in Europe and to support, as it has always done, the Polish interests, particularly those concerning the process of German unification,'' Janusz Onyszkiewicz, former Solidarity spokesman and now a deputy to parliament, told the PAP news agency Monday. Germany unity, developments in central Europe, security and defense issues, and economic cooperation are expected to be the topics of talks between Mazowiecki and President Bush. ``Prospects for Polish-American cooperation are better today than at any time since the end of World War II. This new attitude results from what happened and is happening in Poland, and that Washington has appreciated the importance of Polish events,'' said a commentary Monday in the Zycie Warszawy newspaper. Mazowiecki also is to meet with U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, members of Congress and other top U.S. officials. Mazowiecki, a lawyer, practicing Roman Catholic and top adviser to Solidarity leader Lech Walesa for a decade, is expected to focus on talks rather than the public appearances that characterized Walesa's trip to the United States in November. Niezabitowska said Mazowiecki is to address the Council on Foreign Relations, and meet with representatives of Jewish organizations and groups of American Poles. Mazowiecki also will be pursuing increased financial aid and cooperation for his radical economic reform program. With the blessing of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the Solidarity-led government introduced a pro-market reform plan Jan. 1 that lifted most price controls, ended many government subsidies to industry and made the zloty a convertible currency. Niezabitowska said Mazowiecki plans to extend Poland's thanks for the help it has received from the United States in direct aid and in dealings with the Paris Club, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Further assistance in restructuring Poland's $41 billion debt _ $3.1 billion of which is owed to the United States _ also is expected to be discussed. Mazowiecki also will be seeking a reduction of restrictions on technology imports, a broadening of U.S. business investment in Poland, and expansion of credit guarantees. Warsaw would like Washington to lift travel restrictions placed on Polish diplomats following the 1981 martial-law crackdown to crush Solidarity. It also would like to open a consulate in California, where many Polish emigres have settled, as well as an easing of U.S. restrictions on issuing visas to Poles. Niezabitowska said more than 60 percent of all Polish applications for U.S. visas are rejected. Mazowiecki will travel to Canada for one day after his U.S. trip for talks with Canadian officials.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Leaves Fines Against Puerto Rico Intact
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court rejected the advice of 31 states Monday as it left intact $30 million in fines against Puerto Rico for failing to relieve prison overcrowding. The justices, without comment, refused to disturb rulings that the government of the island commonwealth failed to respond fast enough to a federal judge's order that the overcrowding cease. Most states are under similar court orders to improve prison conditions. Officials for 31 states told the high court that such strict enforcement of federal court penalties could delay voluntary prison reforms. The states are Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Delaware, Florida, Hawaii, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Vermont, Utah, Virginia, West Virginia and Wyoming. The court issued orders in more than 200 cases Monday as it returned from a two-week recess. Justice William J. Brennan was missing from the bench, reportedly suffering from a stomach flu since Thursday. In other matters, the court: _Rejected arguments that a college professor hired to help the two owners of a North Carolina adult movie and book store fight obscenity charges wrongly was inhibited from surveying Charlotte area residents about their opinions of sexually explicit materials. _Agreed to decide in a case from Pennsylvania whether a federal anti-counterfeiting law may be used to crack down on the sale of cars with falsified mileage readings. _Refused to become embroiled in the continuing fight between environmentalists and the Bush administration over Oregon timber and the northern spotted owl. _Heard arguments over the obligation of U.S. banks with branch offices overseas to pay depositors after foreign governments seize or freeze those accounts. Robert H. Bork, the former federal judge whose Supreme Court nomination was rejected by the Senate in 1987, represented Citibank in that case _ marking what was believed to be the first time a failed Supreme Court nominee subsequently appeared before the high court. The Puerto Rico case stems from a 1979 lawsuit. A federal judge ruled the next year that each inmate initially must be provided at least 35 square feet of cell space, and ultimately 55 square feet in dormitories and 70 square feet in individual cells. Commonwealth officials in 1986 agreed to comply with the court order, and began to expand prison capacity. But in July 1987 the officials were fined for failing to provide 35 square feet of space per prisoner. By November, the fines approached a total of $30 million. Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon and other officials said tropical rains and an unexpected increase in the prison population prevented them from meeting their own deadlines for easing overcrowding. They said they inherited the problem from a previous administration and had more than tripled the commonwealth's prison budget. Prison capacity was increased from 5,400 in 1985 to 10,295 last year, they said. But the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the fines in September. ``The relevant harm, confinement in an area smaller than 5-by-7 feet, is significant,'' the appeals court said. ``The number of prisoners suffering that harm, 7 to 10 percent, is large. And the time since entry of the remedial decree is long.''

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota's Eccentric Labor Commissioner Under Fire
DOC.TEXT: The state labor commissioner, known for his bib overalls and frugality, is running for a second term against a field of unknowns. His critics say he's incompetent. ``I'm alive and ready to go punching,'' said Byron Knutson, 60, a Democrat whose eccentricities and penchant for beating party-endorsed candidates in primary elections have won him a reputation as a political maverick. Knutson, dismissing his critics as politically motivated and Lt. Gov. Lloyd Omdahl as a ``snothead'' and ``meddling nincompoop,'' says he'll be in office when his enemies ``are pushing up daisies from their political graves.'' He certainly is better known than his seven declared opponents, who include a retired Navy man, a diesel mechanic, a 24-year-old rancher and two state senators, one of whom once introduced legislation to abolish the labor job. The only declared Democratic candidate, a former labor union official, pleaded guilty to drunken driving days after his announcement. ``It would be tough ... to pick out a good candidate in the field,'' the Grand Forks Herald said in an editorial. ``Still, the incompetent incumbent makes the seven other candidates attractive in comparison.'' Knutson's office handles wage claims, discrimination allegations, firing disputes and other job-related matters. His office has seven workers, including Knutson, whose annual salary is $49,300. Tales of Knutson's quirks and frugality have bolstered his popularity. He occasionally shows up for work in striped bib overalls during North Dakota's freezing winters. He attended his 1976 inauguration as insurance commissioner in a suit he bought at a thrift store for 35 cents. ``I was in school at the time. You have to adjust expenditures to income,'' he said. ``They just happened to have something that fit me.'' His critics, including Democrats Gov. George Sinner and Attorney General Nicholas Spaeth, want Knutson to resign, but he has ignored them. The Labor Department's average time for handling a wage claim has doubled since Knutson took office, and his backlog of cases has ballooned, says state auditor Gordy Smith. Knutson, who often works nights on cases with help from his wife, Bernice, says his own audits show his backlog is considerably less than state auditors say. Omdahl, saying he has ``never seen such a mess in state government in my life,'' concedes state officials are powerless over Knutson, who is independently elected. The dispute over his management led to a recent confrontation with Omdahl, who heads a legislative oversight committee that is looking into the Labor Department. Knutson bumped Omdahl as the lieutenant governor tried to leave during a recess, and later referred to Omdahl as a ``snothead'' and a ``meddling nincompoop.'' Mrs. Knutson poked the lieutenant governor in the chest as she protested his opinion of her husband. ``I need a manager,'' Omdahl joked later, and an editorial cartoon pictured Knutson in a boxing robe. ``Give and take is part of the way the public business ... is conducted,'' Knutson said. ``Sometimes it's more refined than other ways.'' A former state legislator, Knutson served four years as state insurance commissioner and ran unsuccessfully for secretary of state and the Public Service Commission before winning the labor office from a Republican in 1986. In three of his six statewide races, Knutson defeated the Democrats' endorsed candidate in the primary. Knutson is a gregarious campaigner with a ready handshake and knack for remembering names, and his Norwegian surname helps in a state where 15 percent of the population has Norwegian ancestry. Sinner says voters in the June 12 primary will have to judge the situation, and Knutson says he's perfectly content to let them. ``I'm not going to take anything for granted and say it's a cinch,'' Knutson said. ``We work as if we need every last contact. I like to be out amidst it. I need to have a certain amount of the chin sticking out.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Treaty Dispute Near Resolution
DOC.TEXT: A dispute between the Soviet Union and the United States over the use of X-ray equipment to inspect Soviet missile canisters is close to being resolved, the State Department said Monday. Productive talks have been held between U.S. and Soviet technical teams about the use of the Cargoscan inspection system to probe canisters emerging from the Soviet missile plant at Votkinsk, the department said. Asked if Soviet objections to the use of the system are on the way to being settled, department spokesman Richard Boucher replied: ``I think that's fair.'' ``But I don't want to say it's over,'' Boucher added, noting that talks are continuing. American inspectors at the Votkinsk facility, about 700 miles east of Moscow, filed an unprecedented complaint last week after the Soviets objected to the use of Cargospan to verify the contents of at least three missile canisters. The objective is to make sure canisters leaving the plant don't contain medium-range missiles banned under the 1987 U.S.-Soviet Intermediate Nuclear Forces or INF treaty. Secretary of State James A. Baker III lodged an official protest over the incident with his counterpart, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, and technical teams were dispatched to Votkinsk to attempt to thresh out the matter. Cargospan is a key element in verifying Soviet compliance with the terms of the INF treaty, and some U.S. officials fear that continued Soviet objections to its use could give a new weapon to arms-control critics on Capitol Hill who see the incident as proof that such treaties are not adequately verifiable. They also are concerned about the potential adverse impact on negotiations in Geneva aimed at sharply reducing the numbers of long-range, intercontinental missiles. Other officials argue that chances for successfully negotiating a Strategic Arms Reduction, or START, treaty are enhanced when the United States recognizes in advance the technical issues that can arise after a treaty has been signed. They note that the Bush administration has emphasized in START and other arms-control negotiations experiments and measures to test the technical means of verification before a treaty is signed. An array of verification measures proposed by the United States has been under discussion at the START talks since July.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Evokes Reference To Poindexter's Immunized Testimony
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS year in 3rd graf to 1987
DOC.TEXT: An Iran-Contra prosecutor today inadvertently brought out John Poindexter's immunized congressional testimony about destroying a politically embarrassing presidential document. With Rep. Lee Hamilton on the witness stand, prosecutor Dan Webb asked whether Poindexter ever reported destroying the document, called a finding. ``He did,'' Hamilton said in front of the jury. The congressman was referring to Poindexter's July 1987 testimony in which the former national security adviser admitted tearing up the document. No part of a prosecutor's case may be derived from a defendant's immunized testimony. As soon as Hamilton answered, another prosecutor, Howard Pearl, stood up. Webb quickly said, ``I see the problem.'' Webb rephrased the question, but Poindexter lawyer Richard Beckler said that ``I will made an argument on this,'' indicating that the defense may move for a mistrial. Hamilton also testified that he had no indication the National Security Council was lying to him in 1985 when it denied assisting the Contras. Hamilton, who was chairman of the House intelligence committee in 1985 and 1986, testified for the prosecution as it began wrapping up its case against Poindexter, onetime national security adviser to President Reagan. Poindexter is accused of covering up Oliver North's military assistance to the Contras and the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Hamilton told the court today that Congress approved the Boland Amendment cutting off U.S. military aid to the Contras in order to stop the war in Nicaragua. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb told Hamilton that ``Oliver North has testified'' that written answers denying the NSC was assisting the Contras ``were all false.'' Did Hamilton have any idea the answers were false? asked Webb. ``I had no such indications,'' said the Indiana Democrat. Poindexter embraced the denials in 1986 as Congress continued to inquire into whether the NSC was assisting the Contras. Also scheduled to testify for the prosecution was Eric Newsome, a former Senate intelligence committee staffer who attended a meeting on the Hawk missiles with Poindexter. The heart of the government's case is North's testimony, given reluctantly against his former boss. The former White House aide testified that he didn't want to meet with Hamilton, then chairman of the House intelligence committee, to discuss whether North was giving military assistance to the Contras. North told Poindexter he might be asked questions about matters which he was supposed to keep secret. Poindexter sent him to the meeting anyway, telling him ``you can handle it or you can take care of it,'' North testified. North lied at the meeting, saying he hadn't met with Contra supporter John Singlaub for 20 months, had only casual contact with Contra liaison Robert Owen and wasn't giving military advice to the rebels. Hamilton also attended the Nov. 21, 1986, meeting with Poindexter, who told the intelligence committee he didn't learn of the Hawks shipment until January 1986. Poindexter made a similar statement the same day to the Senate intelligence committee. The prosecution says Poindexter's motive for concealing the U.S. role in the shipment was the existence of a politically embarrassing presidential finding that depicted the Hawks shipment as a straight arms-for-hostages deal. Poindexter tore up the finding the same day he testified before the committees. North testified that he watched Poindexter destroy the finding in the national security adviser's office. Poindexter's lawyers begin presenting their case next and are expected to replay former President Reagan's videotaped testimony. The former president made a number of comments favorable to Poindexter, including a suggestion that it might have been acceptable to destroy documents in the affair to protect national security.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Asks For Postponement of Game 7
DOC.TEXT: Former world champion Anatoli Karpov on Monday requested a postponement of his seventh game against Jan Timman in the World Chess Championship Candidates Final Match. On Sunday, Karpov failed to win the sixth game in a much superior position. Entering the endgame, the Soviet grandmaster, playing white, was a pawn up with a rook and knight against Timman's rook and bishop. Karpov, however, could not make any headway without giving up his extra pawn and exchanging his knight. The seventh game will be played Wednesday. Karpov leads the 12-game series by four points to Timman's two having won the first and fourth games with the rest drawn. The first player to amass 6{ points will be declared the winner and advance to face Garri Kasparov for the world title in Lyons, France, in October. Timman, 39, of the Netherlands, needs to win a game to bolster his morale. In their 55 meetings so far, Karpov also 39, has triumphed 18 times compared to Timman's three with the rest drawn. Timman has not beaten Karpov since 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets Prison for Conviction of Starving Death of Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A woman was sentenced Monday to 15 years-to-life in prison for the starvation death of her 2-month-old daughter. Tonnette Rae Lee, 29, and her husband, James Lowell Lee, 38, were convicted of second-degree murder after an autopsy revealed that the baby, Janelle, had no food in her system when she died Dec. 8, 1988. Judge Roger Randall delayed sentencing of Lee until April 16. Deputy District Attorney Terry P. Pelton said the infant's weight fell from 5 pounds, 6 ounces at birth on Oct. 1, 1988, to 3 pounds, 5 ounces when she died nine weeks later. ``It was an extreme case of malnutrition,'' Pelton said. The defense argued that although a forensic pathologist testified that the baby died of malnutrition, he could not be sure whether something else contributed to the death, such as digestive problems or a birth defect. Mrs. Lee said the couple could not afford to take the baby to a doctor. The couple's two sons are under protective custody of Kern County officials.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Issues Warning to Lithuania; Legislators Travel to Moscow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Moscow warning to Lithuania; Picks up 3rd graf, `On Sunday ...'; SUBS last 7 grafs with 1 graf to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government today issued a harsh warning that it would not allow Lithuania to put up its own customs posts, introduce its own currency or take over Moscow-run factories without permission. The warning represented the first concrete steps taken by the government to counter Lithuania's March 13 declaration of independence, which President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called invalid. However, the warning did not specify what measures the Kremlin would take to protect its interests. The government announcement, read on Soviet TV, accused Lithuanian leaders of planning to turn over national factories to private owners, bring in a separate currency and put up customs posts on the Soviet border. The government was especially concerned about nuclear power plants in the Baltic republic, it said. The announcement came as a delegation of Lithuanian legislators arrived in Moscow seeking talks with Gorbachev on their declaration of independence. In the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, President Vytautus Landsbergis said Soviet military maneuvers in Lithuania were increasing tensions in the region. On Sunday, Soviet military jets buzzed Vilnius in what many Lithuanians considered an intimidation tactic, and Soviet troops held maneuvers in the countryside. ``The military exercises of Soviet troops in Lithuania now underway are intensifying tensions,'' Landsbergis told Lithuania's legislature, according to Lithuanian television editor Eduardas Potashinkis, who monitored the meeting. The Lithuanian leader said he was told in a meeting with high-ranking Soviet officers on Sunday that the maneuvers had been planned long in advance. Landsbergis asked if he would be notified in advance of future maneuvers and one of the officers replied that he could not make any guarantees. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said he was told by the Defense Ministry that ``no major military maneuvers are under way in Lithuania. The armed forces are acting in accordance with training plans.'' The six-member delegation that arrived in Moscow was headed by Egidius Bickauskas, a lawyer who recently resigned from the Lithuanian Communist Party. It was empowered by Lithuania's parliament to meet with Gorbachev and propose a start of negotiations on independence, said a spokesman for the Lithuanian nationalist movement, Sajudis. The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies on Thursday declared Lithuania's Feb. 11 declaration of independence illegal and directed Gorbachev to defend Soviet interests and citizens in the Baltic republic of 3.8 million. On Friday, the Soviet leader sent a cable to Landsbergis, giving him three days to respond to the decree. However, Gorbachev struck a conciliatory tone Sunday, saying he still planned to talk with Lithuanians about returning to the Soviet fold. He said no ultimatums had been issued and that he also wanted negotiations on the question of independence. ``I think we shall receive a reply from the authorities of present-day Lithuania and, depending on what it is, everything will become clear. The character and content of the answer will define our next steps,'' he said. Gorbachev said earlier this month that before allowing independence he would demand $34 billion in hard currency _ money Lithuania would be hard-pressed to obtain _ in compensation for Soviet investments in the republic. If it wishes to exert economic pressure, the Kremlin also has the option of cutting off supplies of cheap energy and raw materials. Landsbergis drafted a reply to Gorbachev's message over the weekend and a Sajudis spokesman, Andreas Ajubalis, said it declared that Lithuania's parliament ``has the mandate to enter negotiations with the U.S.S.R. government.'' ``The main thing now is to reach an agreement in principle in starting the negotiating process,'' he said. Bickauskas, who is also a deputy in the national Supreme Soviet, said at today's Kremlin session that the situation in the republic was normal and ``the Lithuanian government is in control.'' He said the Lithuanian legislature on Saturday confirmed its decision to declare independence and urged the Soviet Union ``to solve the issue through inter-state talks.'' Lithuania, along with the other Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia, was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Gorbachev, speaking to reporters after voting in local runoff elections in Moscow on Monday, continued to insist the Lithuanian break was illegal and must be decided by the entire Soviet Union. He said economic, political, cultural and technical ties were too strong to tear apart, and ``human contacts have become particularly deep. So it is a futile attempt to destroy them.'' He expressed concern for Lithuania's ethnic minorities _ mainly Russians and Poles. Nikolai Medvedev, a member of the Lithuanian delegation and a deputy in the national Congress, said in an interview at the Congress today that they hoped to meet with Gorbachev today, but no appointment had been set. ``We are here and waiting to be called,'' he said. ``We will stay here as long as it takes.'' He said he did not expect an immediate start to negotiations. ``There will be some delay as the issues are contemplated, then, negotiations will start at the official level, and eventually, actual negotiations.'' On Saturday, Landsbergis appealed to democratic nations for official recognition of his new government. So far, no country has recognized Lithuanian independence.

DOC.HEAD: History of Famed Naturalist Disappearing Along With Indian Murals
DOC.TEXT: In a crumbling Navajo hogan on a rise dotted with pinon and juniper, colorful wall paintings of Kiowa rituals and Hopi Kachina figures are washing into the red dirt. Rain and snow fall through what once was a conical roof, eating away the Indian murals: A brave raises his arms toward a buffalo, another beats a drum, dancers chant and hold prayer wands, a funeral procession makes its way. Vanishing with them is part of the history of naturalist Ernest Thompson Seton, who founded the Woodcraft Indians organization at the turn of the century, championed Indians when many saw them as red devils, and who built the Navajo hogan as part of his College of Indian Wisdom in the 1930s. The British-born, Canadian-raised Seton was 70 in 1930 when he bought 2,500 acres of land near Santa Fe to build Seton Village, an artist colony and cultural center. A national historic landmark since 1966, Seton Village includes the 30-room, stone Seton Castle; a kiva, or ceremonial chamber, decorated with the plumed serpent of the San Ildefonso Indian pueblo; and the circular Navajo hogan with the damaged murals. ``It was painted by a Kiowa Indian named Jack Hokeah, who was at the Indian School'' in Santa Fe, said Dee Seton Barber, Seton's daughter. ``The hogan was for public ceremonies _ a campfire and stories, a dance demonstration or whatever, a Woodcraft council.'' Mrs. Barber, who still lives in Seton Castle, said she had the hogan re-roofed 18 years ago, but can't afford to do it again. Time, weather and vandals have nearly destroyed it. Seton built his rambling mansion after a lifetime as an author, illustrator, naturalist and lecturer. It was designed to house his library of 40,000 books, nearly 3,000 paintings and drawings, and 3,000 bird and animal skins. He wrote hundreds of books and articles, including ``Wild Animals I Have Known,'' ``Two Little Savages,'' and the first Boy Scout manual. He hobnobbed with Teddy Roosevelt and Mark Twain, helped found the American Boy Scouts and was named their first Chief Scout. But he fell out with Roosevelt and scouting leaders because he believed the movement had turned too militaristic in World War I. He urged the government to give back Indian hunting grounds, helped Southwestern Indians support themselves through tradition-based pottery, textiles and jewelry rather than cheap tourist knickknacks, and brought Indians to Seton Village to share their traditions, songs, stories and art. He adopted his daughter in 1938, when he was 78. At its height, the village had a zoo, a museum, a craft shop, dining hall, log cabins, and adobe houses. Up to 150 people could gather: youngsters studying Indian lore, Seton lecturing to adults on the virtues of outdoor life, his wife, Julia, beating a drum and singing an evening chant at lights out. Snapshots taken in the 1930s and 1940s show intricate wood carvings over entrances to dorms and the dining hall, long rows of tepees, a thriving vegetable garden. Many adobe houses remain, some rebuilt and expanded. Other buildings, including the dining hall, dorms and dance lodge, are gone and the hogan nearly so. The National Park Service oversees national historic landmarks, but has no repair money for them. It reported in 1986 that the outside of the hogan could be patched for $6,000. It also recommended spending $2,800 to have an art conservator evaluate the paintings inside before restoring them. The kiva, with the plumed serpent painting circling its inner wall, at that time needed $5,450 in exterior work, plus interior repairs, evaluation and outside grading costing an estimated $2,300. Those findings were made in a ``landmarks at risk'' report soliciting donations to the National Park Foundation, which administers private contributions for the Park Service. But ``we were unsuccessful with Seton Village,'' said Gregory D. Kendrick, chief of the history unit at the Park Service's Rocky Mountain Regional Office. Now the weather and vandal damage to the hogan is far more severe, and it's unclear whether any of the murals can be saved. ``I don't even go out there anymore,'' said Mrs. Barber. ``It just makes me sick.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Are you a husky, square-faced Texan born and bred? If you have a yellowish coat, white stocking feet and a white polecat streak down your back, the heifers of the LBJ Ranch are looking for a handsome Texas Hereford bull like you. The National Park Service is searching for an especially handsome bull to maintain the cattle bloodlines on this ranch that was the pride of President Johnson. At LBJ's request, the ranch was given to the government in 1973 so that visitors could see what the ranch was like when he was chief executive. Despite the U.S. beef industry's drive to produce taller, leaner cattle, the ranch wants to maintain a squatty, short herd of Herefords descended from those that roamed the Pedernales pastureland in LBJ's time. In those days, said Buddy Hodges, chief of ranching, the preferred Hereford build was ``short-legged, dumpy and plump.'' Ranch foreman Edward Meier, who began working here when LBJ was president, said Johnson didn't want his home to become a relic of the past. However, Meier said, rebuilding ranch houses to make them historically accurate would be easier than breeding cows in a fight against advancing genetics. Every three years, a new bull must be introduced to avoid inbreeding, but brings the risk of producing a herd that looks a little less like the one LBJ admired. Texas A&M University has been assisting the ranch in plans to preserve its genetic pool, Meier said. The historically accurate breeders are attended to daily, and are admired by thousands who snap their pictures and applaud the antics of their offspring. At present, 23 babies cling to their mamas along the winding route of the tourist tram. ``The visitors get all excited,'' said Meier. ``You gotta admit, they are pretty little buggers.''

You might as well call Scarlett O'Hara a Yankee as call a Soviet Georgian a Russian. And don't, please, circle your thumb and forefinger to tell a Soviet Georgian that it's OK with you. Those were among the tips for 300 U.S. Georgians who are participating in the Friendship Force's largest single exchange of citizens between the United States and the Soviet Union, a Georgia-to-Georgia exchange April 17 to May 1. The U.S. participants in their first meeting Sunday at Clark Atlanta University learned that it's the little things that count. For example, the circled thumb and forefinger gesture, which means ``OK'' to a U.S. Georgian, is an obscene gesture in the Soviet republic where Atlanta's sister city, Tbilisi, is the capital. Women in slacks are frowned upon. The group also was told to expect much more hospitality from their hosts than they are used to, especially in drinking and making toasts. If they admire someone's painting or jewelry, it may be given to them on the spot. Friendship Force officials reassured the group that the political situation seems to be stable in Soviet Georgia, which is one of several republics agitating for independence. Among noted U.S. Georgians participating are Rosalynn Carter's mother, Allie Smith, Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson's daughter, Valerie Amanda Jackson, and Atlanta entertainers Liz Spraggins and Michael Cloud.

DOC.HEAD: Sewage Dumped at Sea Poses Health Risks to Swimmers, Seafood Lovers
DOC.TEXT: Sewage dumped at sea poses a significant health risk to seafood lovers and swimmers who can pick up bacteria and viruses, said an international report on the world's oceans released Monday. The contaminated sewage can cause hepatitis, cholera, polio, gastrointestinal illnesses and possibly AIDS, it said. Contrary to public fears, however, radioactive contamination of the oceans remains ``extremely low'' and the oceans are not threatened by oil pollution except at the sites of major spills, the report said. The United Nations-sponsored report said coastal waters are the most vulnerable and abused. They are threatened by contaminated sewage, runaway coastal development and excess nutrients such as phosphates and nitrates which are killing fish and altering plant life. Professor Alasdair McIntyre of the University of Aberdeen in Scotland, chairman of the 20-member panel that prepared the report, rejected the theory that sunlight and waves quickly destroy dangerous organisms in sewage. ``It used to be thought that a very short time in the sea killed off these organisms, but we are having to recognize this is not the case,'' he told a news conference. The report said eating contaminated seafood is firmly linked with serious illness, including viral hepatitis and cholera and that bathing in contaminated water could also cause illness. ``There are records of people contracting polio from swimming in contaminated water,'' McIntyre said. He said a U.S. study showed the polio virus could survive for 17 months in sewage-polluted marine waters. Epidemiological studies in the United States and the Mediterranean have also provided ``unequivocal evidence'' that swimmers in sea water polluted with micro-organisms from feces have a higher incidence of gastric disorders, the report said. ``The fact that viruses are known to survive for surprisingly long periods is a significant development,'' he said. Asked about the AIDS virus, McIntyre said: ``Although the chance of an AIDS virus surviving would be very slight, nevertheless it could survive.'' Last week, Patrick Gowen, a British marine biologist formerly at the University of East Anglia, told a parliamentary committee that new research showed the AIDS virus could live for more than 24 hours in sea water. He warned that swimmers could catch it through cuts, sunburn sores and shingle scuffs. The World Health Organization dismissed the claim as ``total nonsense.'' The report by the Group of Experts on the Scientific Aspects of Marine Pollution said human pollution was evident in the oceans ``from the poles to the tropics and from beaches to abyssal depths.'' The scientists said ``the open sea is still relatively clean'' but marine habitats and resources along the oceans' coasts were being damaged irretrievably by harbor developments, industrial installations, tourist facilities and saltwater fish farming. ``Although difficult to quantify, destruction of beaches, coral reefs and wetlands, including mangrove forests, as well as increasing erosion of the shore, are evident all over the world,'' the report said. The increasing flow of nitrates and phosphates to coastal waters, mainly from sewage disposal and agricultural run-off, has resulted in excessive plant growth which is choking some coastal waters and killing fish, the report said. Without immediate international action, McIntyre said, ``there is good reason to fear a significant deterioration in the marine environment in the next decade.'' The report said nuclear installations, fallout from weapons-testing and more recently, from the accident at Chernobyl in the Soviet Union, have added to radioactivity levels naturally occurring in sea water. But it said the levels remain ``extremely low'' and ``these additions have had insignificant effects on man and other organisms.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Burlington Mayor Announces Congressional Bid
DOC.TEXT: The former socialist mayor of Burlington on Monday announced a new bid for Congress, and pledged not to soften his rhetoric. ``I am what I am and what I have been for 20 years,'' Bernard Sanders told reporters. Sanders, an independent hoping to improve his strong second-place showing in the 1988 House race, said he decided to run again for Congress rather than governor because of concern about national and international issues. ``I can honestly say that there is no race that I have ever run in which I feel more enthusiastic, more confident, and which has, for me, a greater sense of urgency,'' said Sanders, who stepped down in April after running Vermont's largest city for eight years. The 1988 race was won by Republican Peter Smith with 41 percent of the vote. Sanders drew 38 percent, twice that for Democratic nominee Paul Poirier. Sanders said he considers himself a socialist, but will again run as an independent in the November election. Analysts say the Democrats might not field a candidate, giving Sanders a head-on contest against Smith.
