If elected, Sanders said he would strive to create a national health care system, shift the burden of taxes away from workers and the middle classes, cut in half defense spending in five years to acknowledge radical changes in the Soviet bloc, and halt the destruction of the environment. ``Politically, we need the courage to put the environment first and corporate profits last,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: United States Sees Election Bolstering NATO Membership for Germany
With AM-Germany Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Monday the victory of East German conservatives in Sunday's elections bolsters the case for keeping a united Germany in NATO. Press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the elections were ``a victory not only for the people'' of East Germany, ``but for all Germans and all who support democratic values.'' ``It does appear the march towards reunification is inexorable,'' said the presidential spokesman. A conservative alliance linked with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats won a large plurality on a platform favoring rapid unification with West Germany. The United States has insisted that a reunited Germany remain in the West's military alliance and Fitzwater said the balloting showed support for the Western approach. ``Our policy, clearly, is that a reunified Germany would be in NATO. Chancellor Kohl has indicated that,'' he said. ``This victory ... would seem to lend support for that direction as well.'' The Soviet Union wants Germany to be neutral and reiterated Monday that the new Germany must not be in NATO. ``That would upset the balance of Europe,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said in Moscow. ``We respect the expressed will of the citizens of East Germany, an allied sovereign state,'' Gerasimov said. ``Respecting this right of choice, we proceed from the premise that in turn, they will respect the legitimate interests of the Soviet Union and other countries.'' Fitzwater, in a statement, said, ``We are pleased to note that East Germany yesterday joined the growing list of nations that have held free and fair elections. This is a victory not only for the people of the German Democratic Republic, but for all Germans and all who support democratic values. ``We have long supported the aspirations of the people of East Germany in deciding their own future. We join them and the people of the Federal Republic in celebrating this historic occasion.'' Fitzwater, asked about possible obstacles to unification, said, ``It does appear that the march towards reunification is inexorable. It seems clear that the elections have sent that message.'' The United States says NATO membership for Germany would help safeguard the security of both East and West in Europe. Bush and Kohl met at Camp David, Md., Feb. 10-11 to discuss the fast-moving changes that could lead to a single Germany by the end of this year. West Germans vote in their own federal elections in December. The conservative Alliance for Germany won 48.2 percent of the vote and 193 of the 400 parliamentary seats in East Germans' first free election since 1933. The Communists, who had ruled under a dictatorship for the past 41 years, won just 16.3 percent of the votes and 65 seats. The new government that forms in the next 30 days will take part in unification talks with West Germany and the four chief World War II victors, Britain, France, the Soviet Union, and the United States. NATO is the 16-nation Western military alliance forged in the 1950s as a united defense against communist aggression. Its rival Warsaw Pact has been shaken by the collapse of communist rule in most East Bloc nations over the past year.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Reinstate Award to Texas Couple in Bendectin Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Merrell-Dow to Merrell Dow throughout. Also subs graf 10, Bendectin was, to note that Merrell Dow merged with Marion Laboratories.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate a $550,000 award won, and then lost, by a Texas couple whose daughter was born with deformities after her mother took the anti-nausea drug Bendectin. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that overturned a jury award against Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, the drug's manufacturer. Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Brock of Moscow, Texas, sued Merrell Dow after their daughter, Rachel, was born with deformed limbs in 1982. A three-member panel of the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year threw out the $550,000 judgment a federal trial jury had awarded the Brocks. The appeals court said there is no definitive scientific proof that Bendectin causes birth defects, and said the jury award was based on speculation. ``Speculation unconfirmed by ... proof cannot form the basis for causation in a court of law,'' the appeals court said. The full 5th Circuit court, by a 8-6 vote, refused to review the three-member panel's ruling. The dissenters noted that six experts testified for the Brocks that Bendectin is capable of causing birth defects, and that three testified they believed the drug caused Rachel's deformities. The dissenting judges said appellate courts should not substitute their understanding of the facts for that of a jury merely because medical experts disagree. Bendectin was marketed by Richardson-Merrell Inc. between 1957 and 1983. More than 30 million women used the drug during pregnancy. Richardson-Merrell later became Merrell Dow, which last July merged with Marion Laboratories Inc. and became Marion Merrell Dow Inc., based in Kansas City. The company stopped selling Bendectin 1983, although the Federal Drug Administration never has rescinded approval of it. Merrell Dow in 1984 agreed to pay $120 million to more than 800 families to compensate children with birth defects allegedly caused by Bendectin. As part of the settlement, the corporation did not admit that the drug caused the defects. The settlement was rejected by a federal appeals court, and the lawsuits then went to a consolidated trial in Ohio, where Merrell Dow has its headquarters in Hamilton County. After a 22-day trial in 1985, an Ohio jury found that Bendectin did not cause birth defects when taken in prescribed doses. The case acted on today is Brock vs. Merrell Dow, 89-1189.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Become Embroiled in Fight Over Northern Spotted Owl
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Merrell-Dow to Merrell Dow in graf 10, The justices.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to become embroiled in a fight between environmentalists and the Bush administration over Oregon timber and the northern spotted owl. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out part of a lawsuit seeking to protect the owl from the asserted threat posed by logging operations in the old forests of westalership sentenced under the law to six months in prison. _ Refused to hear appeals stemming from a $200 million settlement of price-fixing charges against the nation's leading manufacturers of folding cartons. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that redistributed a $6 million surplus from the settlement in one of the biggest antitrust cases ever. _ Refused to hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at making it costlier for an organization called the National Security Archive to compile information. The archive is a non-profit organization that collects information on national security and foreign policy and makes it available to the public in various ways. It has filed thousands of FOIA requests for government records. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that gives the archive the same preferential status under the Freedom of Information Act that other news media enjoy. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service estimates that about 1,500 breeding pairs of northern spotted owls remain, and that without protection their numbers could be cut in half by the year 2050. The owl is being considered for inclusion on the federal government's endangered species list. A coalition of environmental groups, including the various Audubon Society chapters, the Wilderness Society, the Sierra Club and the Natural Resources Defense Council, sued the Interior Department in 1987 over timber-management plans for the western Oregon forests. The lawsuit alleged that the department's Bureau of Land Management had decided to continue logging old-growth timber without adequately considering the detrimental effects to the spotted owl population. The government's decision therefore was made in violation of four federal laws _ the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), the Oregon and California Lands Act, the Federal Land Policy and Management Act and the Migratory Bird Treaty Act. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last September dismissed that portion of the lawsuit alleging a NEPA violation, ruling that Congress had precluded such a court challenge when it passed a 1988 appropriations bill for the Interior Department. The appeal acted on today argued that the appeals court wrongly interpreted the 1988 legislation. The 9th Circuit court sent the lawsuit back to U.S. District Judge Helen J. Frye in Oregon for consideration of the claims raised under the three other environmental laws. While the case was pending before Frye, Congress last October passed a 1990 appropriations bill dealing with timber production on federal lands and protecting the northern spotted owl. The bill specifically states that the Bureau of Land Management's consideration of logging effects on the owl ``is adequate ... for the purpose of meeting the statutory requirements that are the basis for'' the 1987 lawsuit. Judge Frey last Dec. 21 dismissed the lawsuit's remaining claims ``without prejudice to the filing of any new action challenging the BLM owl management activities after fiscal year 1990.'' An appeal in which the environmental groups are mounting a constitutional attack against the 1990 appropriations bill is pending in the 9th Circuit court. The case acted on today is Portland Audubon Society vs. Lujan, 89-931.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Merrell-Dow to Merrell Dow in 3rd item.
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
SPOTTED OWL
The court refused to become embroiled in a fight between environmentalists and the Bush administration over Oregon timber and the northern spotted owl. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out part of a lawsuit seeking to protect the owl from the asserted threat posed by logging operations in the old forests of western Oregon. The case is Portland Audubon Society vs. Lujan, 89-931.
PRISON CROWDING
The court rejected an appeal by Puerto Rico officials fined more than $30 million for failing to move quickly enough to relieve prison overcrowding. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that the commonwealth's belated efforts to ease the problem are not reason enough to cancel the fines. The case is Hernandez Colon vs. Feliciano, 89-1016.
BENDECTIN
The court refused to reinstate a $550,000 award won, and then lost, by a Texas couple whose daughter was born with deformities after her mother took the anti-nausea drug Bendectin. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that overturned a jury award against Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, the drug's manufacturer. The case is Brock vs. Merrell Dow, 89-1189.
PORNOGRAPHY
The court rejected an appeal by owners of a North Carolina adult film and book store who hired a college professor to help them rebut obscenity charges. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that had the effect of exposing the professor to an obscenity prosecution if he surveyed people about their reactions to sexually explicit material. The case is Cinema Blue vs. Gilchrist, 89-1213.
ODOMETERS
The court agreed to decide whether a federal anti-counterfeiting law may be used to crack down on the sale of used cars with phony mileage readings. The court said it will hear an appeal by the manager of a Pennsylvania car dealership sentenced under the law to six months in prison. The case is Moskal vs. U.S., 89-964.
CARTONS
The court refused to hear appeals stemming from a $200 million settlement of price-fixing charges against the nation's leading manufacturers of folding cartons. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that redistributed a $6 million surplus from the settlement in one of the biggest antitrust cases ever. The cases are In Re Will, 89-927; In Re Folding Carton Litigation, 89-992; Folding Carton Administration Committee vs. Folding Carton Reserve Fund, 89-1081; and U.S. vs. Folding Carton Reserve Fund., 89-1097.
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION
The court refused to hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at making it costlier for an organization called the National Security Archive to compile information. The archive is a non-profit organization that collects information on national security and foreign policy and makes it available to the public in various ways. It has filed thousands of FOIA requests for government records. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that gives the archive the same preferential status under the Freedom of Information Act that other news media enjoy. The case is U.S. vs. National Security Archive, 89-1204.

DOC.HEAD: Question for Chicago Suburb's Voters: Art or Junk?
With AM-Illinois Primary
DOC.TEXT: Voters in this Chicago suburb have a chance to play art critics: They're being asked to give the thumbs up or thumbs down to a 50-foot-tall stainless-steel shish kebab of eight automobiles. A special referendum on Tuesday's ballot asks voters to decide whether the massive $100,000 ``artistic construction,'' titled ``Spindle,'' and one known as ``Bil-Bored'' should be removed from its display in a shopping plaza. The plaza's owner, David Bermant, says he's placed similar works in the 20 shopping plazas he owns around the country, without any of the fuss ``Spindle'' and ``Bil-Bored'' raised in Berwyn. Bermant, who splits his time between the East and West coasts, acknowledges having been warned that his tastes in art might clash with those of the conservative, middle-class suburb. But he nonetheless professes astonishment at the criticism. ``I've just about had it with Berwyn,'' he said. ``I mean, I'm really discouraged about Berwyn. Don't they have any sense of aesthetics in Berwyn?'' If they do, it apparently was offended by ``Spindle,'' erected last year, and the 9-year-old ``Bil-Bored,'' an equally massive assemblage of household goods, appliances and concrete. ```Bil-Bored' looks like a big pork chop filled with garbage ... and `Spindle' is just more junk up our gazoos,'' state Republican Sen. Judy Baar Topinka said at a recent hearing. Despite such caustic reviews, local officials lamented that their options were limited. ``There is no law covering it,'' said Lawrence Zdarsky, Berwyn's administrative coordinator. ``Building ordinances simply do not forsee eight autos being piled on top of one another. ``What do you do? Ticket them?'' Bermant and Berwyn officials eventually negotiated a solution _ an advisory referendum, along with some private polling by Bermant, to determine just what residents think of the city's most prominent works of art. Bermant cried foul after the ballots were printed because they solicit a ``yes'' or ``no'' on the future of ``Spindle'' as well as ``Bil-Bored,'' though the tower of skewered automobiles has been in place for only a few months. He also said he thought the vote would come next fall, not this spring. ``You need 10 years to gain an understanding of art like this,'' he protested. ``But if the vote and my polls show the worst, that they really hate it, then that's that, I've had it, I'll rip all the art out and sell the whole damned shopping center,'' he said. ``It's really quite saleable, you know.''

DOC.HEAD: UPI to Ask Appeals Court For Order in Picture Exchange Suit
DOC.TEXT: United Press International will ask an appeals court on Tuesday to stop Reuters from backing out of a picture exchange agreement between the two news services. UPI is seeking an injunction that was denied last week by U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure, who ruled that UPI would not be irreparably harmed if the contract were discontinued. Reuters had been ordered to continue the exchange until 5 p.m. Monday. However, it said it would keep supplying UPI with pictures from overseas until Tuesday's hearing before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The injunction request stems from a UPI counterclaim to a Reuters' federal lawsuit that seeks to void the picture exchange. Reuters says the agreement was not living up to expectations. The contract was entered into in 1984. It called for UPI to supply Reuters with pictures from the United States, while Reuters provided UPI with pictures from other countries. It was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. UPI says it will lose clients if Reuters ends the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys General Suggest to Bush He Spend More on Drug War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush claimed progress Monday in the war on drugs and asked a group of state attorneys general for suggestions on how to do better. Some suggested he send more money. Bush agreed there was a need for additional federal support but blamed Congress for dragging its feet on his anti-crime and anti-drug efforts. ``We've gotten some of what we've asked for _ new agents, new prosecutors, new prison space. ... But I must confess to a certain frustration,'' he said. He told the National Association of Attorneys General that recognition was important ``that this problem is national and that nobody's going to make it by dealing just at the federal level.'' ``I would ask your support, this much horsepower in town, to work ... with us on getting this crime package through,'' Bush said, speaking to attorneys general from 37 states. Bush said he sensed ``a certain turning around, at least in terms of public opinion,'' on the issue of drugs, mentioning that anti-drug messages are being worked into some Saturday morning cartoon shows. ``Twenty million kids watch cartoons every Saturday,'' Bush said. ``Now, that couldn't have happened if it hadn't been for the focus that you all are putting on the drug problem.'' Some of the attorneys general made a plea for more federal funds. Pennsylvania Attorney General Ernest D. Preate Jr. told reporters that the money earmarked to help the states was not enough. ``You can't fight a war against drugs unless you have the kind of financial commitment that's necessary to put troops into the field,'' Preate said. But national drug policy director William J. Bennett argued that if Congress accepts the administration's proposal for spending $10.6 billion on the drug effort in fiscal 1991 it will represent a 70 percent increase in funds over the 1989 level of $6 billion. ``No other federal program has seen that kind of increase,'' Bennett said. ``That's real money and it's going to make a difference.'' ``I don't object to people coming here and saying they need more,'' Bennett added. ``They're going to get more. We'll be back in future years for more. But let's not ignore what's been done. What's been done is significant and substantial.'' For one thing, Bennett said, ``there was a lot more drugs coming into this country than previously thought.'' Tom Miller, attorney general of Iowa and president of the National Association of Attorneys General, said Bennett had arranged to meet with state officials on the drug problem at a June conference in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: One-time Nominee for High Court Argues Case Before Justices
DOC.TEXT: Robert H. Bork, who once hoped for a Supreme Court seat, instead stood before the nation's highest court Monday. He was there in the capacity of a lawyer _ apparently making him the first defeated Supreme Court nominee ever to argue before the justices. Representing Citibank in a big-stakes battle, Bork argued that U.S. banks with branch offices overseas should not be required to pay depositors after foreign governments seize or freeze those accounts. The Senate rejected Bork's nomination to the high court in 1987 after a bitter political battle. He was branded a conservative extremist by opponents. Bork, nominated by then-President Reagan, has said he was the victim of a campaign of lies and distortions led by liberals. There were no references to that fight Monday as Bork engaged in debate with the justices and opposing lawyers over the complexities of federal banking law and related matters. Bork was treated much the same as any attorney who appears before the justices. They questioned him vigorously, occasionally interrupting him for clarification and elaboration. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who occupies the seat that eluded Bork, directed a few questions at Bork. Bork, 63, a former federal appeals court judge, is a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and will begin teaching constitutional law in the fall at the George Mason University law school in Arlington, Va. He will be paid $25,000 a year to teach one course each semester as a part-time professor. Bork was only the sixth man this century to be denied a Supreme Court seat by the Senate and the 26th in its history.

DOC.HEAD: East German Winners Urge Acceleration of Unification
LaserPhoto BER5
DOC.TEXT: The victorious Alliance for Germany said Monday the German states must move more quickly to reunify, but its leader was rebuffed as he began trying to form a coalition government to move the process along. A more left-leaning party, the Social Democrats, turned down an invitation to join the coalition, thus blocking the Alliance from having a two-thirds majority in Parliment. Such a majority would allow East Germany to simply declare a merger with the West. The three-party Alliance swept to victory Sunday in East Germany's first free elections but did not win a majority in the 400-seat Parliament. The Alliance got a boost Monday from perhaps its biggest supporter, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who promised financial aid for East Germany. The chancellor had refused such aid to the Communists, who have governed since hard-liner Erich Honecker was overthrown in the fall. Lothar de Maiziere, likely to be the next East German premier, invited the Social Democrats and the Union of Free Democrats to discuss forming a ``grand coalition'' to guide the nation toward unification with the broadest possible consensus. He clearly was disappointed when Social Democratic leader Ibrahim Boehme refused. ``Mr. Boehme must certainly have to ask himself what he meant in the last few weeks when he repeatedly said our country's problems are so big they must be carried on the broadest possible shoulders,'' de Maiziere said. However, an alliance of centrist, liberal parties, which won 21 seats, was ready to negotiate joining in a coalition with the Alliance, West Germany's ARD television said. That would give a de Maiziere-led government 214 seats in Parliament. De Maiziere's Christian Democratic Union is one of three parties comprising the Alliance. The party stresses traditional Christian values and less government control of the economy, and traditionally has been at odds with the Social Democrats, who follow a leftist, socialist-oriented path. The Social Democrats said moving quickly to reunify could result in a loss of East Germany's cradle-to-grave social services and allow the country to be swallowed up by its wealthy neighbor. The party placed second in the vote, with 21.8 percent and 87 seats in Parliament. The Alliance won 48.2 percent and 193 seats. The Party of Democratic Socialism _ the former Communist Party _ placed third with 16.3 percent. It will have 12 seats in Parliament. De Maiziere held a round of meetings Monday with the goals of forming a government and uniting with the West. ``Here, we will carry forward and step up the pace of the already started negotiations,'' he said. He urged ``rapid introduction of a monetary, economic and social union'' with West Germany. In a largely symbolic move, he said the Berlin Wall should be torn down ``as soon as possible, as a clear sign of the merging of the two German states.'' The wall was opened Nov. 9 during the height of the pro-democracy movement that made Sunday's vote possible. Large pieces of it already have come down. The balloting marked the first free elections in East German history and capped the country's transition to democracy after four decades of iron-fisted Communist rule. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the vote was ``a victory not only for the people'' of East Germany, ``but for all Germans and all who support democratic values.'' ``It does appear the march toward reunification is inexorable,'' he said. The new government will take part in unification talks with West Germany and the four World War II Allies _ Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. A major obstacle is the military alignment of a unified Germany. The Western powers want Germany to be part of NATO. The Soviets and East German Communists have called for a neutral single state. Both sides made clear Monday they have not changed their attitudes. ``Our policy, clearly, is that a reunified Germany would be in NATO. Chancellor Kohl has indicated that. This victory ... would seem to lend support for that direction as well,'' Fitzwater said. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said putting the new Germany in NATO would upset the military balance of Europe. ``We respect the expressed will of the citizens of East Germany, an allied sovereign state,'' Gerasimov said. ``Respecting this right of choice, we proceed from the premise that in turn, they will respect the legitimate interests of the Soviet Union and other countries.'' Kohl's government is scheduled to decide Tuesday on ways to halt the immigration of East Germans to his country. The exodus sparked the fall revolution and has come to strain West Germany's social services while crippling the East's economy. At a news conference in Bonn, Kohl said he stands behind his promises of a financial bailout now that a democratically elected government is about to take over. He did not give specifics.

DOC.HEAD: Show Biz Friends Celebrate Dance Teacher's 65th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: They borrowed a Broadway theater to celebrate the 65th birthday of Luigi Faccuito, a long-time performer and dance teacher whose students have included some of the top names of the stage and screen. Several hundred friends and associates gathered for Sunday night's tribute at the Helen Hayes Theater. Faccuito, known simply as Luigi, was lured to the theater on the pretext of attending a reading. Dozens of his students were on stage to greet him, playing out the jazz dances that he is largely credited with developing. Actor Robert Morse, currently starring on Broadway in ``Tru,'' and Loni Ackerman of ``Cats,'' were co-hosts of the show. Performers included actor Tony Roberts, opera singer Clamma Dale and stage stars Gretchen Wyler, Donna McKechnie and Yvonne Constant. Roberts read a Happy Birthday letter. Gene Kelly, Joel Grey, Liza Minnelli and Mayor David Dinkins sent messages. The office of the president of the New York borough of Manhattan proclaimed March 21 ``Luigi Day'' in the borough. A deluge of congratulatory messages came from England, France, Japan, Brazil, South Africa, West Germany, Canada and Mexico. The tribute took place three days before Luigi's actual birthday. Born Luigino Faccuito in Steubenville, Ohio, Luigi was involved in a car crash while starting out his career in Hollywood in the late 1940s, and was left partially paralyzed. Old photos, film clips and videotapes projected on a screen traced his life from his early days when he displaced fellow Steubenville native Dean Martin as a band singer through naval service in World War II to his arrival in New York in 1965. The gathering saw clips of several films in which he danced, mainly as an associate of Gene Kelly, including ``Gotta Dance,'' ``Singin' In The Rain,'' and ``On The Town.'' Miriam Fond, one of the organizers, said the hardest part was keeping the party a secret from Luigi. The catch-phrase of the evening was ``never stop movin,''' Luigi's constant exhortation to students in class. In response to the accolades, Luigi told the gathering that his mother had always said she prayed every day for her son and his students, ``so if some of you made it, it's because of her.''

DOC.HEAD: Namibia Makes Final Preparations For Independence
LaserPhoto WDH2
DOC.TEXT: Laborers hurried to finish platforms and bleachers Monday as foreign dignitaries began arriving for the celebrations to mark Namibia's passage from being Africa's last colony to its youngest nation. About 5,000 foreign visitors, mostly diplomats and journalists, are expected to join tens of thousands of Namibians to watch the South African flag lowered in favor of Namibia's red, green and blue banner. The event, which begins Tuesday and continues into Wednesday, will end 75 years of South African rule. South Africa captured the former German colony during World War I and for decades imposed the same apartheid laws that separate blacks and whites in South Africa. United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will be present at Namibia's birth, along with South African President F.W. de Klerk, South African blac leader Nelson Mandela, at least 10 African heads of state, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. On his arrival, de Cuellar said Namibian independence was a major achievement for the United Nations. ``The world now speaks of the Namibian model, in praise of the determination, restraint, tolerance and political maturity of the Namibian people,'' he said at the airport. Baker made no comment on arriving at the airport and he and his party were whisked away in a convoy of cars. Wednesday's independence date was selected to mark the 30th anniversary of the ``Sharpeville Massacre,'' when 69 unarmed demonstrators were shot to death in South Africa while protesting apartheid laws in a black township south of Johannesburg. ``March 21, 1960, is a day that people rose up against apartheid,'' said Hifikepunye Pohamba, who will become the home affairs minister in the new government. ``The day was chosen as a sign of solidarity not only for the people of Namibia, but also with the people of South Africa.'' Pohamba is a member of the South-West Africa People's Organization, the group that waged a 23-year war against South African rule and captured 57 percent of the vote in November's elections. SWAPO's long-time leader Sam Nujoma will become Namibia's first president. South Africa agreed in December 1988 to grant independence to Namibia under a regional peace treaty that also calls for Cuba to witldraw its 50,000 soldiers from Marxist-ruled Angoa by mid-1991. Namibia for many years had the same laws of racial segregation as South Africa, although most were scrapped in recent years and the huge, arid territory of 1.3 million people has a more relaxed atmosphere than South Africa. Pohamba said the new government intends to remove ``symbols of colonial brutality'' such as the old police uniforms. ``We feel it an urgent necessity that all old uniforms be taken off and all new uniforms be put on,'' Pohamba said. However, he said the new outfits for police and prison guards were not ready yet. ``Circumstances beyond our control,'' he said without elaborating. Laborers at several sites rushed to finish platforms and bleachers, and foreign dignitaries began arriving for the celebrations. Windhoek, Namibia's modern capital and largest city with 120,000 residents, has only a few hotels and is able to accommodate only a fraction of the visitors. Private homes, apartments and railway sleeper cars all have been rented out, although some visitors were still searching for places to stay. The Windhoek airport, which usually handles about six flights a day, must cope with some 200 planes Tuesday and Wednesday. Because of a lack of space, the planes of visiting leaders have to be parked in the neighboring countries of South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe and Zambia. Preparations for independence have gone relatively smoothly so far, but the new government could face its first political headache the day it takes over. In the dusty central town of Rehoboth, where virtually all of the residents are of mixed-race, leaders have refused to relinquish the extensive local autonomy granted by South Africa under its policy of ethnic-based governments. The new Constitution calls for a strong central government and does not provide for local authority along racial or ethnic lines. Pohamba said SWAPO would be willing to negotiate, but that Namibians ``will not tolerate anyone who wants to dismember the territory of Namibia.'' SWAPO, which was committed to socialism while in exile, speaks more often of working with the white business community that controls the mining, farming and fishing industries. Those industries, along wih South African aid, have made Namibia one of the few African countries to achieve an annual per capita income of $1,000. However, the country's wealth is disproportionately in the hands of the 75,000 whites, who make up only 6 percent of the population, and South African aid is ending.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Sends $22 Billion Plan To Congress
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration Monday sent Congress a $22 billion, five-year plan for commercial aviation to be funded by a new airport tax of up to $12 per roundtrip and 25 percent increases in other aviation taxes. Federal Aviation Administrator James B. Busey said the reauthorization bill would help meet the growing demand for aviation, allow modernization of the FAA's air traffic control system and increase aviation safety. Overall, it would boost federal funding for aviation projects 73 percent in the next five years, compared with the amount available during the current five-year period. In addition to the plan for improvements, FAA expects to spend between $22 billion and $24 billion on operations and maintenance over the next five years, including salaries of air traffic controllers, FAA budget officials said. The FAA reauthorization, which covers proposed capital expenditures through fiscal 1995, is the first major legislation proposed under the national transportation policy unveiled by President Bush and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner earlier this month. The transportation policy asks users to pay more of the cost of air, land and sea transportation systems and would shift some taxing responsibilities away from the federal government to state and local governments. The aviation plan calls for increases in some federal aviation taxes, as well, although the administration makes a distinction between ``user fees'' and taxes Bush has promised not to increase. A federal trust fund, which is collected from passenger and shipper taxes, would pay 85 percent of FAA costs compared with 57 percent now. The fund would be bolstered by an increase in the passenger ticket tax from 8 percent to 10 percent. Freight way bill fees would be increased from 5 percent to 6 percent. The tax on aviation gasoline would increase from 12 cents to 15 cents and on jet fuel from 14 cents to 18 cents. ``I believe this administration has put forward a comprehensive proposal to deal with aviation in the 1990s,'' Busey told a meeting of airport officials after the plan was sent to Capitol Hill. If approved by Congress, the plan would allow airport taxes for the first time since the early 1970s. The maximum initial tax would be $3 per departure, with travelers who make connecting flights paying at no more than one additional airport each way. The legislation would give the transportation secretary power to increase the maximum tax after fiscal 1991. After the first year, collection of the tax would automatically decrease other federal funding available to airports, and some smaller regional airports might elect not to levy the fee so it would not reduce funding under the federal Airport Improvement Program, said Mike Moffet, an FAA assistant administrator. Improvement funds that were freed up as a result of the ticket tax _ each $1 in collections would reduce federal funds available to an airport by 50 cents _ would go into a discretionary fund to help airports that need additional money, Moffet said. If the nation's largest 45 airports impose the ticket tax, collections are expected to total $1 billion a year, he said, adding that the collections could be used to obtain bonds for about $10 billion in airport projects over the five years. Federal funding for airport improvements would total $7.7 billion over five years _ a 28 percent increase over amounts made available during the past five years. Other funds under the reauthorization program would include $13.5 billion for facilities and equipment programs, a 130 percent increase over the previous five years, and $970 million for research and development, a 13 percent increase. The administration proposes to fund the programs primarily from the trust fund, which is expected to have a $7.6 billion balance by the end of fiscal 1990 on Sept. 30. The spending plan would decrease funds in the aviation trust fund to about $3 billion by the end of the five-year period, officials said. Officials in the aviation industry and some members of Congress have criticized the build up of money in the trust fund, which they say has been used to offset the federal deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Private Economists Predict Interest Rates Should Begin Falling
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates have peaked and should start falling during the spring, a group of private economists predicted Monday. Members of the Shadow Open Market Committee said they believed a variety of consumer and business loans would decline in coming months, reflecting a sluggish economy and declining inflationary pressures. The economists forecast that banks' prime lending rate, the benchmark for many business and consumer loans, should drop from 10 percent to 9.5 percent or perhaps as low as 9 percent by summer. Fixed-rate mortgages, which are about 10.25 percent, will fall to 9.8 percent by mid-year and remain below 10 percent for the rest of 1990, the outlook predicted. Jerry Jordan, senior economist at First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles who compiled the group's forecast, said that weakness in the economy would encourage the Federal Reserve to loosen its grip on credit in coming months. The panel forecast that the federal funds rate, a bellwether interest rate for judging the impact of Fed actions, will dip from 8.25 percent down to 7.5 percent by mid-year. Various business and consumer rates have been rising since the first of the year with the government's 30-year bond jumping from an average of 7.9 percent in November and December to around 8.5 percent currently. Those rates should fall back to 8 percent, the economists forecast, and remain there through 1991. The shadow committee was upbeat on the prospects that the economy will be able to avoid a recession this year although the forecast called for economic growth to remain sluggish, reflecting previous credit-tightening on the part of the Federal Reserve. Inflation, which jumped sharply early in the year because of severe winter weather, will begin moderating with consumer prices expected to rise at a slower pace than in 1989. ``A soft landing has been achieved,'' Jordan said. ``The economy is going to muddle through as inflation continues to unwind.'' The shadow committee meets twice a year to assess actions of the Federal Reserve whose chief policy-setting body, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet next week. The shadow committee is composed of monetary economists who focus on the Fed's control over the money supply as a determining factor in the economy's health.

DOC.HEAD: Savings Bond Sales $652 Million in February
DOC.TEXT: Sales of U.S. savings bonds totaled $652 million in February, bringing to $118.85 billion the value of bonds including accrued interest held by the public, the Treasury Department said Monday. Savings bond sales totaled $3.2 billion for the first five months of fiscal 1990 _ a 6 percent decline from February 1989. Savings bonds earn interest at a rate of 6.98 percent when held five years or longer.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Calls For Unified East-West European Economy
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Monday a unified European economy should include the Soviet bloc and a new system for settling potential military conflicts. Kohl's comments came at the opening of an East-West security conference that is to focus on the economic recovery of Eastern European nations that have overthrown their Communist regimes in the past year. The conference is the biggest gathering of East and West nations since the opening of the Berlin Wall, and it came one day after East Germans, in their first free elections, chose a government that is likely to embrace Kohl's plan for a swift reunification of the Germanys. Kohl called for European nations to form a security agency that would mediate conflicts and another agency to verify arms control agreements. ``We need an instrument that makes it possible to prevent conflicts while they are still in the bud,'' Kohl told the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The 35-nation group includes the United States, Canada and all Eastern and Western European nations except Albania. ``A European conflict center and a center for verifying arms control agreements could be the first steps toward building up comprehensive security structures in Europe,'' he said. He gave few details of the new security agencies, but said they should be ``within the framework'' of the conference, which includes the Soviet Union. Kohl, however, reiterated his opposition to neutrality for a unified Germany and said the merged nation should continue to belong to NATO. The Soviet Union is seeking neutrality for a united Germany. Kohl also urged the West to help stabilize Eastern Europe's new attempts at free-market economies and promote their integration with the rest of Europe. He said he supports the idea of forging ``treaties of association'' that would tighten economic ties between East and West Europe. He also said the West should help create conditions for a ``pan-European economic area'' that would bring the economies of Europe closer together. The East-West meeting in Bonn, which runs until April 11, will include the participation of more than 600 business and government officials from Eastern and Western Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Poland to Get Corn Instead of Butter
DOC.TEXT: Poland will get U.S. corn instead of butter as initially announced under President Bush's $100 million food-aid package, the Agriculture Department said Monday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said 173,225 metric tons of surplus corn will be donated to Poland instead of the 10,000 tons of butter originally specified. After the original agreement was approved, the Poles found themselves with an exportable supply of butter, he said. So the switch was made. ``The corn will be sold and the proceeds used to enhance economic development, with an emphasis on the Polish agricultural sector,'' Dickerson said. The 173,225 tons of corn _ equal to about 6.8 million bushels _ is owned by the department's Commodity Credit Corp. At recent prices, the corn would have a U.S. farm value of about $16 million.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Says Several People Detained in Chemical Plant Fire
DOC.TEXT: Libya has detained several people suspected of setting fire to a chemical plant that U.S. officials said produced poison gas, Libya's ambassador to Italy said Monday. Ambassador Rahman Shalgam said the blaze was apparently set by ``a member of the technical staff at the factory,'' the Italian news agency ANSA reported. He said the person responsible will be ``executed in the same place where the fire took place.'' Shalgam did not say how many people were detained or give their nationalities. He said the blaze caused ``damage of great proportions,'' and U.S. officials said the plant is inoperable. But a French company disclosed Monday that photographs taken by the European satellite Spot I show the plant was not destroyed. ``The principal structures of the Libyan chemical factory at Rabta don't seem to have been touched, and there are no traces on the ground ... of the existence of a fire,'' said Christian Bernard, a spokesman for Spot Image. Except for black traces on the small buildings apparently used for storage, ``it's like nothing happened at Rabta,'' said Bernard. He said the small buildings appear to be 800 yards from the main plant. The photographs were taken Sunday. The blaze broke out Wednesday in the plant in Rabta, about 60 miles southwest of Tripoli. Libya said the factory produces medicines, but the United States and West Germany have alleged it produces poison gas. Libya has said it suspects that Israel, the United States and West Germany were behind the fire. All three countries have denied involvement. Shalgam said West Germany is under suspicion because West German firms helped build the plant and would have its techncial plans, Italian news agencies reported. ``It was a very dangerous attack which perhaps is part of a program of sabotage, of which we don't even know the dimensions,'' he was quoted as saying. The blaze occurred shortly after the United States and West Germany called for the Rabta plant to be shut down. Before the fire, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater had refused to rule out a U.S. military strike to close it.

DOC.HEAD: Police on Alert as Brazil's Banks Reopen
DOC.TEXT: Riot police guarded banks and supermarkets Monday as Brazilians began to adjust to radical economic reforms that included a new currency and an 18-month partial freeze on savings accounts. The measures were announced Friday by President Fernando Collor de Mello to fight rampant inflation that has soared as high as 2,700 percent. Across the country, most banks opened two hours late to adapt to the new rules, and Brazil's stock market, which also opened late, reported no transactions during its half-day of trading. In Rio, state police in riot gear kept order in the downtown financial district as huge lines formed at banks opening for the first time since a three-day enforced holiday was declared. The banks were closed Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. Under the vigilance of federal police, supermarkets began to lower prices to meet government limits. Prices shot up by as much as 200 percent last week in anticipation of a freeze, but the new economic plan rolled back prices to last Monday's levels and set maximum prices for 103 staples, ranging from beef and eggs to matches and toothpaste. Looters attacked five supermarkets in Rio's poor northern zone over the weekend, but no violence was reported Monday. Brazil's radical economic plan was designed to stabilize the economy and bring down inflation that reached 2,700 percent in the past year. ``Our hope was being taken from us,'' Collor de Mello said Sunday night. ``This is our last chance.'' Collor de Mello, 40, took office Thursday as Brazil's first democratically elected president in 29 years. The most severe measure was a freeze on bank deposits that totaled $115 billion _ the size of Brazil's foreign debt, the Third World's largest. Savers can withdraw the equivalent of $1,200. Brazilians with deposits in the $60 billion short term financial market can take out half that amount after paying a tax. The rest will be frozen for 18 months, receiving corrections for inflation and 6 percent yearly interest. ``The government has confiscated the money of the people after promising that it would not alter the rules of the game regarding savings accounts,'' said Francisco Gugael, a Sao Paulo lawyer, as he stood in line outside a bank. ``Collor and his economy minister have lost all their credibility.'' The new president defended his package and said it wouldn't hurt the poor. ``In the study we made, 90 percent of savings accounts are under that limit.'' Collor de Mello said. ``We had to hit those accounts because the big speculators were turning there.'' Other measures included the elimination of federal subsidies, a lowering of trade barriers and import restrictions, sharp increases in taxes and utility rates, a floating exchange rate and the abolition of 24 state companies and agencies. On Sunday, Collor de Mello said courts won't be allowed to issue restraining orders to block the reforms. Opposition parties were to discuss the reforms Monday. Most of the measures must be approved by Congress with 30 days, although the president can submit a new 30-day decree.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Officers Join in Calling for Women-in-Combat Trial
DOC.TEXT: A retired Army brigadier general and a former Air Force colonel joined with the National Organization for Women on Monday in supporting a bill to open Army combat jobs to women for a four-year trial period. ``If we do have a test within the Army, I think finally there will be documentation to prove that women can perform as competently as men in the infantry and other combat areas,'' retired Brig. Gen. Evelyn Foote told reporters at a Capitol Hill news conference. The Combat Exclusion Act, approved by Congress in 1948, bars women in the Air Force, the Marines Corps and the Navy from serving in combat positions. The Army has regulations similar to the law. Women comprise about 11 percent of the total armed forces of 2.1 million. The call for a reexamination of the policy has grown louder since Army Capt. Linda Bray led troops into combat with Panamanian forces during the U.S. invasion last December. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. and a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, proposed legislation in January that directs the Army to conduct a test study allowing women assignment to combat positions. The legislation faces an uphill fight in Congress, where many members still oppose opening combat jobs to women. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis. and chairman of the House Armed Services panel, has said the measure will not be part of the overall defense bill. Nevertheless, officials of NOW, Foote and retired Col. Diane Ordes called for a change in policy starting with passage of Schroeder's legislation. Standing in front of a photo of enlisted men marching down the capital's Constitution Avenue, Foote described her nearly three decades of military service and how close she came to combat in Vietnam in 1967. Ordes noted that eight women died in the Vietnam War and that their names are engraved on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial a few blocks from the Capitol. ``Women have been in combat ... since this nation was born. Women have not been called combatants but they have been in combat,'' Ordes said. Molly Yard, president of NOW, said the exclusion of women from combat ``is based on archaic ideas of what women and men should and should not do.'' Yard, who is scheduled to testify Tuesday at hearings on the issue, said the inability of women in the military to accept combat positions limits their advancement in the service.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nears 100th Point of Light
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Monday that the roster of President Bush's ``thousand points of light'' is approaching the hundred mark. The White House on Monday named Bush's 94th daily ``point of light'' _ Jesse Sanchez Berain of Boise, Idaho, honored for helping migrant workers and their children. Bush began naming points of light Nov. 22 to encourage volunteerism. He intends to name 1,000 _ reflecting the ``thousand points of light'' theme first struck in his acceptance speech in August 1988 at the Republican convention. The White House Office of National Service released advance copies Monday of a booklet with thumbnail sketches of Berain and his 99 fellow points of light. Asked if it was an attempt to generate more publicity, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``Actually, we're getting very good publicity. ... We have stacks of clippings from around the country.'' ``Citizens and communities are starting to pick up on this program, developing private organizations. So it's working very well. We're very proud of it,'' he said. Bush has asked Congress for $25 million for a quasi-private Points of Light Foundation that Bush would chair to spearhead further voluntary activities. Berain, himself a farm worker as a child, helped found groups called IMAGE de Idaho and CAMP, College Assistance for Migrant People, to encourage Hispanic youths to stay in school and avoid drugs. The daily point of light get a signed letter from Bush.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. May Grant Soviets Favored Trading Status By Summer
DOC.TEXT: President Bush could grant the Soviet Union ``most-favored nation'' trading status at the July economic summit in Houston if the Soviets enact legislation permitting free emigration, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said Monday. Bush announced at his Malta summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last December the United States would begin negotiating a trade agreement with the Soviets wiping away nearly half a century of trade friction. The package would include granting most-favored nation trading status, qualifying the Soviet Union for the lowest tariffs available to American trading partners. Soviet exports into the United States currently bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other nations. However, Bush first must waive the Jackson-Vanik Amendment barring such status, which Congress passed in 1974 because of Soviet refusal to allow free emigration. A waiver would require Bush to certify to Congress that free emigration was being allowed. In a speech to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, Mosbacher said Soviet enactment and implementation of free-emigration legislation is expected this spring. ``Passage and implementation of such a law would mean that a Jackson-Vanik waiver could be signed sometime this summer _ in July, in Houston, Texas,'' Mosbacher said. Bush and other leaders of the Group of Seven plan to hold their next economic summit July 9-11 in Houston. Other members are Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan and West Germany. The economic meeting will follow the next summit meeting between Bush and Gorbachev, probably in Washington during the last two weeks in June. The exact dates have not been announced. U.S.-Soviet negotiators hope to reach agreement on the overall trade package in time for the Bush-Gorbachev summit. The first round of talks were held last month and both sides expressed satisfaction with their progress. A second round was held later in February in London and a third round is scheduled this month in Vienna.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti's Provisional President Names All-Civilian Cabinet
With AM-Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Haiti's new civilian government swore in 13 Cabinet ministers Monday, including human rights activist Joseph Maxi as interior minister and retired army Col. Jean Thomas as defense chief, independent Radio Haiti Inter reported. Under the military regime of deposed ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, defense and interior were combined into one ministry. The caretaker government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot split the ministry to avoid a concentration of power. Maxi was in hiding until recently after being implicated by the Avril government last November in an alleged plot to overthrow it. He has been president of the Human Rights League since the group's previous president, Joseph Lafontant, was assassinated in July 1988. Thomas, a former diplomat, retired from the army last year. He was regarded as an opponent of Avril even while serving in the military. No current army officers are represented in the government. Pierre Labissiere, president of the Haiti Bar Association and a prominent liberal, is the new justice minister. Haiti Inter identified the 10 other ministers as: Kessler Clermont, foreign relations; Charles Tardieu, education; Lionel Richard, agriculture; Carlo Desinor, information; Leslie Goutier, finance; Jean-Pierre Moise, public works; Claudette Werleigh, social affairs; Maurice Lafortune, commerce; Ludovic Pierre, planning; and Serge Fils-Aime, health. The ministers were appointed by Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot and approved by a civilian State Council that has veto power over her decisions. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a Supreme Court judge and Haiti's first woman president, was inaugurated on March 13, one day after Avril fled into exile in the United States following a popular uprising. She is to govern until elections can be held, possibly within three to six months.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official Confident About Reopening Angolan Talks
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet foreign minister said Monday he is confident that Angola's Marxist government can soon reopen peace talks with the U.S.-backed rebels it has been battling for 15 years. Eduard A. Shevardnadze made his comments before ending a 24-hour visit to this country during the first trip to sub-Saharan Africa by a Soviet chief of diplomacy. ``Given the dynamic and rapid changes'' in the world recently, ``it shouldn't be impossible'' to start renewed direct peace negotiations in the coming months, Shevardnadze told reporters after a two-hour meeting with President Jose Eduardo dos Santos. He said a final peace accord could be signed by the time Cuba completes the scheduled withdrawal of its estimated 50,000 troops from Angola by July 1, 1991. Despite Shevardnadze's remarks, hopes for a quick peace seem faint. Earlier peace talks and a June truce have collapsed, and fighting has intensified since the government launched an offensive in December. Western diplomats here, noting the recent warming of U.S.-Soviet relations, are expecting the superpowers to put more pressure on the Angolan adversaries to come to peace. Shevardnadze left Angola later Monday for the Zambian capital, Lusaka. The official Angolan news agency ANGOP reported he will also visit Zimbabwe, Namibia, Tanzania and Nigeria. The Soviet diplomat stressed the Kremlin supports dos Santos' attempts to negotiate with Jonas Savimbi, the rebel leader. Shevardnadze said he was confident a new nine-point plan drawn up by the Luanda government would open the way to new direct talks with the rebels. He gave no further details on that plan. But he said the Angolan question would be high on the agenda at a planned meeting with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III at Namibian independence celebrations Tuesday. Namibia has been controlled by neighboring South Africa. Late Sunday, Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro van Dunem of Angola launched another attack on continued U.S. aid to the rebels. UNITA, or the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, reportedly receives $50 million or more in annual U.S. aid. The rebels have been fighting to force a power-sharing agreement since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. U.S. officials have pledged support as long as Moscow supplies arms to the Marxist government.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Income Prospects Improved
DOC.TEXT: Prospects for farm income have improved from earlier 1990 economic forecasts, an Agriculture Department report showed Monday. ``Combined with continuing strong demand for agricultural products, currently higher prices due to tighter corn stocks and smaller hog inventories have brightened the outlook,'' the report said. Analysts also said that the bulk of federal payments, which figure prominently in annual farm income statistics, continue to go to a relative handful of larger farming operations. Overall, the net cash income of farmers was forecast at $54 billion to $58 billion this year, up from $53 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. Previously, the department's Economic Research Service had put 1990 income in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion. As used by the agency, net cash income ``measures the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less out-of-pocket costs.'' Commodities sold may actually have been produced in earlier years and stored until marketed. In another method of accounting, the report said net farm income is expected to be in the range of $45 billion to $49 billion, steady to down 8 percent from last year's $49 billion. Previously, it was forecast at $44 billion to $49 billion. Economists use net farm income to measure the value of agricultural production _ whether sold or stored _ in a calendar year plus government payments, minus all costs, including depreciation and other factors. ``Net farm income may drop as feed grain prices ease from the spikes caused by the 1988 drought,'' the report said. ``The lower prices will dampen the value of the fall harvest. Much of the fall 1990 harvest will be sold in 1991.'' The report said an analysis of USDA's 1988 Farm Costs and Returns Survey showed that direct payments to farmers have been ``distributed on the basis of production'' as prescribed by current farm law. ``Of farms receiving direct government payments, 32 percent received 90 percent of the payments,'' the report said. ``Since 64 percent of all farm receive no direct payments, 90 percent of the payments go to only 12 percent of all farms.'' Greg Gajewski, senior editor of the report, said there was no surprise in the breakdown of federal subsidies and that the pattern fit the trend. Direct federal payments to farmers peaked at about $16.7 billion in 1987, according to the agency, then dropped to $14.5 billion in 1988 and to around $11 million in 1989 as market prices improved, thus reducing many of the subsidy rates. A further reduction to as low as $8 billion is expected this year. The report also said that ``improved weather has brightened prospects'' for the U.S. winter wheat crop. ``Early indicators in Western Europe, Canada and Australia point to wheat production gains there as well,'' the report said. ``Wheat prices are falling.'' In Asia, a bumper 1989-90 rice crop is being harvested, with record or near-record output forecast for China, Bangladesh, Vietnam, Thailand and India. ``But U.S. stocks are low, and the Thais are holding stocks back for sale later in the year,'' the report added. ``So, prices remain strong and U.S. exports are slowing.''

DOC.HEAD: OAU Cautions West Not to End South Africa Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Organization of African Unity met here Monday and urged African states not to resume diplomatic relations with South Africa until further reforms are made to end racial segregation. The 50-member Organization of African Unity's ad hoc committee on southern Africa also warned governments that easing their sanctions against South Africa would slow reforms. But the delegates agreed to encourage the black-led African National Congress to pursue power-sharing talks with the white-led government. South Africa's President F.W. de Klerk said he will hold talks with the ANC April 11 as a prelude to formal negotiations on power-sharing. De Klerk legalized the ANC and freed its leader, Nelson Mandela, in February to pave the way for talks. ``The euphoria that has developed ... has led some leaders in Africa and abroad to think that all is over in South Africa and they are entitled to re-establish contact with the regime,'' ANC secretary-general Alfred Nzo said. ``If this happens it is a signal to de Klerk to block any further progress,'' he added. Zambia's President Kenneth Kaunda welcomed the release of Mandela, but said Pretoria should do more to pave the way for formal constitutional talks. ``It is the Pretoria regime that should unlock the gates to negotiations,'' he said. It was the first summit meeting since the committee met in the Zimbabwe capital Harare last August to endorse an ANC plan for talks with South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Not Worried About Possible Shuttle Maintenance Problem
DOC.TEXT: The head of NASA's space flight program acknowledged Monday that repair and maintenance problems exist in the planned space station but said they can be fixed by design changes long before the station is built. ``I'm not worried about it,'' said Bill Lenoir, the space agency's associate administrator for space flight. ``It's one of many things at this point in the design that is inherently fuzzy.'' A report in Monday's New York Times said NASA discovered belatedly that the station, planned for assembly beginning in 1995, would require about 2,200 hours of maintenance each year by astronauts working in the hazardous open space environment. Lenoir said a more realistic _ but still inflated _ estimate is 550 hours, which he also considers too much. ``At this point, admittedly, we don't understand in depth the reliability of the subsystems and pieces of subsystems,'' he said in an interview. ``So we've made some unrealistic assumptions like `everything that can fail will fail' and it will fail once a year. ``Then we multiply it all together and say, `well, gee, that's 550 hours.' We know that's harsh and probably higher than realistic and that's what we'll be spending between now and December working on,'' Lenoir said. The figure is exaggerated even more, he said, by being multiplied by four to 2,200 hours. The Times said NASA investigators discovered ``the setback'' early this year, but Lenoir said it has been an issue that's been worked on for six months and part of a preliminary design process that will continue until a review in December. ``We've taken this quick and dirty bottoms-up assessment and now we are going to dig in item-by-item and say what's the real requirement and how will we deal with it,'' Lenoir said. ``I wouldn't say I'm not worried about it, but I'm worried about it no more than anything else. I'm paid to worry about everything.'' The newspaper's report said there were 5,578 parts outside the station's inhabited modules that could be replaced if they failed and that those calculations increased the work load by 30 percent. Lenoir said maintenance and repair of any such items can be planned in four ways: ``I can live with it, I can do it robotically, I can make it require less (maintenance) by upping its reliability, or I can move it inside (the pressurized living module) so it becomes an intravehicular rather than an extravehicular job.'' Lenoir said it would be wrong to think the space station has a major problem ``when in fact we have a minor problem, business as usual, we are working on it and we are on schedule for coping with it.''

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Unveils Plan to Cut Charges to Selected Area Code
DOC.TEXT: Customers will be able to save money on calls to their favorite out-of-state area code under a new long-distance plan announced Monday by AT&T. The company said customers will pay $1.90 a month plus discounted per-minute prices on all direct-dialed calls to whatever area code they choose under the SelectSaver plan. There is no sign-up fee under a special introductory offer. Prices on most SelectSaver calls will be 12 cents a minute during evening, night and weekend calling periods. AT&T said the rate is 23 percent less than usual evening prices. Daytime calls, between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m., will cost 20 cents a minute, or 13 percent less than usual. SelectSaver customers also will receive a 5 percent discount on all other direct-dialed, out-of-state calls, the company said. The new service is scheduled to start May 3.

DOC.HEAD: The Day the Rabbi Toppled the Israeli Government
With AM-Israel-Politics
DOC.TEXT: The man who may decide who will head Israel's new government is an unlikely kingmaker, a 69-year-old rabbi better known for his torah scholarship than foreign policy. Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, spiritual leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party, made his power felt earlier when he put aside his daily task of guiding his flock and advised Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to accept U.S.-backed peace proposals. Shamir said no, and Yosef then used his spiritual authority to topple Shamir's government by withholding the parliamentary votes of his Shas Party last Thursday. Yosef's views angered his mostly right-wing followers _ many of whom back Shamir's Likud party _ and a few ran into his Jerusalem synagogue shouting ``Traitor!'' A tug-of-war followed in Shas, and the pressure produced an apparent turnaround in the party's support for Labor. Still, Yosef's strong views on peace could decide whether Shas backs Labor or Likud. In a rare television appearance Sunday, Yosef argued that he toppled Shamir's government because it could not make peace. ``You are inviting war if you support such a government,'' Yosef said, dressed in traditional dark robes with gold embroidery and sunglasses he needs to wear to protect his sensitive eyes. He called Shamir's government ``the extremist of extremes'' and argued that ``it would not have been able to give a positive reply'' to the U.S. plan for the first open dialogue ever between an Israeli government and Palestinians. ``What would the nations of the world say then? `These Israelis don't want peace, they want war,''' Yosef said. ``And afterward, when, God forbid, all the Arab states will rise up and make war against us ... how many will be killed? Who will account for the spilled blood?'' Yosef is an Israeli former chief rabbi of Sephardic Jews, those of Middle East or North African origin who now constitute a majority in Israel. Born in Baghdad, Iraq's capital, he served as deputy chief rabbi of Egypt before moving to Israel. Here he was a religious court judge, author of studies of Jewish religious writings and founder in 1984 of Shas, an acronym for the Sephardic Torah Guardians. He created the party in reaction to what was perceived as discrimination against religious Sephardic Jews by the ultra-Orthodox religious establishment, which was dominated by Ashkenazis, or European Jews. Shas quickly gained support among secular Sephardis as well. Today, with six seats, it is the third largest party in the 120-seat Knesset, or parliament. Three other religious parties control 12 seats. Sephardic Jews comprise roughly 55 percent of Israel's Jewish population. They generally are poorer and more conservative than Ashkenazi Jews. Their overwhelming support enabled the Likud to end 29 years of rule by the center-left Labor Party in 1977. But since the 27-month-old intefadeh, or Palestinian uprising, has made peace a more urgent concern, Yosef and some other Sephardic leaders have surprised their flock with moderate statements. First Yosef, on a festive homecoming to Egypt last summer, declared that he believed the religious commandment to prevent bloodshed superseded Israel's right to the occupied territories. Then a few months ago, another Sephardic spiritual leader, ``Baba'' Baruch Abuhatzeira, went further and advocated talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel views as a terrorist organization. Both Sephardic and Ashkenazi spiritual leaders have generally exhibited concern primarily for matters of immediate interest to their flocks _ funding for religious schools and housing and demands to pass legislation favorable to religion. That is why it was surprising Yosef got involved in the larger political question of how Israel should make peace with the Arabs.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Plans $32 Million Aid to Contras Who Give Up Weapons
DOC.TEXT: U.S. aid to relocate Contra rebels into their Nicaraguan homeland will go only to fighters who agree to lay down their arms, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson said Monday. ``This package ... is meant to provide a new livelihood for unarmed resistance members who return peacefully to Nicaragua,'' Aronson said in testimony supporting President Bush's request for $300 million to aid Nicaragua this year. The aid package includes about $32 million to pay costs of moving rebel fighters and their families back into Nicaragua, and could cover the costs of items like seed, fertilizer and tools to get them started in farming. Rep. Matthew McHugh, D-N.Y., a member of the House Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee, voiced concern over reports that armed rebels have infiltrated into the country from their camps along the Honduran border and are demanding that enclaves be established where they can remain with their weapons. ``There is a certain degree of skepticism out in the country and in Congress'' over the intentions of the rebels, said McHugh, a consistent opponent of the past U.S. policy of financing the Contras. He called Contra demobilization ``the most serious potential problem for the transfer of power'' from the leftist Sandinista government to the opposition coalition led by Violeta Chamorro, who won the Feb. 25 election. Aronson said the administration believes ``it's time for the combatants to put their arms down and go back to civic life'' but added, ``There's no button to push ... and 10 years of fears on both sides.'' One option for easing the rebels back is to establish ``enclaves'' in the Nicaraguan countryside where the rebels could congregate, with United Nations peacekeeping troops around them as a buffer to separate them from Sandinista soldiers, Aronson said. The UN is contemplating expanding its peacekeeping force by as many as 800 men, he said. But it was unclear whether Contras would be required to forfeit their weapons before entering Nicaragua, or only after arriving in the enclaves, he added. ``There is jockeying on both sides,'' Aronson told the subcommittee. He said plans are also under consideration to establish a church-run verification network in rural Nicaragua which would report any instance of harassment or abuse of returning rebels. Relocation aid is an important element of the plan, he said. ``In exchange for having given up a weapon, we don't want to turn them loose in a devastated area with no way to support seven or eight kids,'' Aronson said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Groups Express Support for Batmonh
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Some Mongolians only use one name.
DOC.TEXT: The democratic opposition groups that successfully demanded the ouster of Communist Party chief Jambyn Batmonh put up posters on Monday supporting him as president. The posters urged Ulan Bator residents to rally Tuesday afternoon in Sukh-Bator square in the city center on the eve of a legislative session expected to replace Batmonh as president. The ruling Communist Party, meanwhile, said its Central Committee would meet Tuesday for a second time in two weeks to discuss restructuring the party in the face of growing popular pressure. The party has ruled since 1921, when it came to power in a Soviet-backed revolution. The sparsely populated Kremlin satellite, sandwiched between China and the Soviet Union, allows Red Army troops to be based on its soil. The opposition groups, which sprang up the past four months to end the Communists' monopoly on politics, won Batmonh's ouster as party general secretary last week after repeated demonstrations in the square. A veteran party member tied less closely to Mongolia's past dictatorial leadership, Gombogavyn Ochirbat, replaced him, and a new Politburo and Secretariat were named. The opposition said it wanted a new communist leadership because the old one had failed to keep promises to move toward democracy and shake up the inefficient planned economy. However, opposition activists said Batmonh was an honest man who they trusted to continue as president in what they consider as a transitional period to full democracy. ``If someone more conservative is elected ... he might stop the democracy movement,'' said a member of the opposition. In multiparty talks, which began nearly two weeks ago, the ruling Communist Party agreed Batmonh would resign as party chief but stay on as president. The opposition was surprised and upset when Batmonh offered his resignation as president last week. Delegates to the legislature, called the Great People's Hural, said they expect to accept Batmonh's resignation. ``Batmonh was replaced in his party post. It would not be suitable for such a person to be president,'' said Erdene, a 36-year-old worker and deputy from Darhan City. However, he and other delegates agreed that the new reformist notion of separating party and state should be observed and Ochirbat should not be chosen president. None of the delegates was able to suggest a replacement for Batmonh. They said they expected to retain Dumaagiyn Sodnom as prime minsiter. Sodman was a member of the ousted party Politburo and also offered to resign his state post. Delegates to the Communist-dominated 370-seat Hural began arriving in Ulan Bator on Monday for its annual session, which begins Wednesday and is expected to last four days. Many climbed off buses at the Hotel Ulan Bator wearing labor hero medals and small pins of the national flag on their traditional nomads' garb. ``This is the peak season in breeding livestock. They are giving birth and there is so much work waiting for us,'' said Ikhlas, a 55-year-old herdsmen from western Mongolia. But, he said, the session is important because it will debate and probably approve a law providing for multiparty elections. Legislative elections are not due until next year and the Communists say they are confident they will win. Hural delegates seemed unenthusiastic about the opposition demands for early elections this year. ``I support the current deputies,'' Ikhlas said. Dolgormaa, a woman teacher from southern Mongolia, said opposition parties should be allowed Hural seats if they work with the Communists. ``But if the opposition parties are in conflict with the ruling party and are demanding and aggressive, then I will not support it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Budget Cuts As Far As We Can Go
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf pvs, ``Our position, to CORRECT million to billion; picks up 5th graf, The New
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Monday the administration has cut the Pentagon budget ``as far as we can responsibly go,'' as the White House denied a report that President Bush could accept a major cut in military spending. Cheney said in a speech that the administration had made ``real cuts'' in its $307 billion military spending plan for 1991 that respond ``directly and rationally'' to the changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater rejected a report that the administration could accept cutting the Pentagon budget by $11 billion. ``Our position is that we have proposed a budget that calls for something like $3.9 billion in cuts. We intend to stick with that proposal,'' Fitzwater said. The New York Times reported Sunday the administration is willing to accept a $10 billion to $11 billion cut in fiscal 1991 military spending, in response to pressure from Capitol Hill for even more severe reductions. ``There is not a $10- or $12 billion cut ... that we are prepared to accept,'' Fitzwater said. However, the spokesman added, ``Every number's negotiable.'' ``We believe adequate national security is based on the $3.9 million cut. That's the one that we proposed,'' he said. For the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the administration has requested $307 billion in budget authority and $303 billion in outlays for the Defense Department, the Department of Energy and military construction projects. The administration's request, although higher than last year, is two percent below the level required to keep up with inflation. But some members of Congress, with an eye to the developments in the Soviet Union and Europe amid economic presssures at home, are pressing for heftier cuts.
