Cheney, in a speech to the American Defense Preparedness Association, acknowledged the relationship between the superpowers ``clearly has taken a turn for the better'' and ``the threat of a sudden, Soviet invasion of Western Europe clearly has receded.'' But he argued ``great uncertainty'' remains about the course of reform in the Soviet Union, and the Soviets retain ``enormous military capabilities,'' particularly in strategic nuclear weapons systems. Cheney's view has clashed with the more sanguine public view CIA Director William Webster has taken of the potential Soviet military threat. Cheney said Monday that ``my job calls for me to err on the side of caution.'' ``It would be irresponsible of me ... to run out and focus only on the good news,'' he said. Even so, Cheney said, the Pentagon has cut its projections for spending over the upcoming five-year period ``by $231 billion'' during his past year in office. ``By March of 1995, defense spending will be down to the lowest share of GNP since before World War II. These are real cuts, they are big, and they relate directly and rationally to the reduced threat. But these cuts are as far as we can responsibly go,'' Cheney said. The former congressman from Wyoming accused his former colleagues on Capitol Hill of having a ``memory lapse'' in demanding steep defense cuts, because they rejected his proposals for killing such programs as the V-22 Osprey tilt-roter plane and the F-14D jet fighter last year. ``The resistance (to cuts) we keep running into is right up there on Capitol Hill _ with those folks who say they want me to cut the defense budget. But of course they don't want me to close any bases, shut down any production lines, or do anything that maight have an impact on somebody's base back home on the district,'' Cheney said. In his speech, the defense secretary also said he and Bush ``want to keep moving forward as fast as we possibly can'' on the Strategic Defense Initiative.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Suspect Sought; DEA Says Security Has Limits
DOC.TEXT: The government offered a $100,000 reward Monday for the capture of the bomber who destroyed a Drug Enforcement Administration office in Fort Myers, Fla., but the agency concedes it can do little to prevent future attacks. The FBI has issued a nationwide alert for Jeffrey A. Matthews, 23, an elusive drug suspect who allegedly threatened the DEA after his indictment Thursday. ``There have been no warrants issued yet for anyone in the explosion, but we are following some good leads,'' FBI spokesman Brian Kenscel said. The DEA and FBI jointly announced the $100,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the bomber or bombers, but they did not name a suspect. Matthews' half-brother, John Lewis Ciganek, 22, surrendered to authorities Sunday in the Florida Keys and has been questioned about the bombing, the FBI spokesman said. He refused to say what, if anything, the suspect told agents. Ciganek was arraigned in Fort Myers federal court Monday on the drug indictment. ``I just want a fair trial,'' Ciganek said after declaring himself indigent and in need of a court-appointed attorney. He was ordered held without bond. Saturday's bombing destroyed the DEA office building in a quiet Fort Myers neighborhood. Remnants of the pipe bomb, which apparently used gasoline as a fire accelerant, have been sent to FBI laboratories in Washington for analysis. Washington DEA spokesman Bill Ruzzamenti said that although agency offices around the world have been informed about the bombing, there have been no new security measures taken. ``The situation in Fort Myers is an isolated incident,'' he said. But in Yakima, Wash. _ a key station on the Northwest drug route from Mexico _ head DEA agent Robert Dreisbach acknowledged security has been heightened, although he would not disclose details. ``We have taken certain security precautions as a result of Fort Myers and continuing threats to all DEA offices from drug-trafficking organizations,'' Dreisbach said. Jim Braseth, agent in charge in Minneapolis, says his office has not received any threats, nor has it inreased security because of the Fort Myers bombing. In Indianapolis, David H. McDougal, the resident agent in charge, said that although the bombing appears local, ``this just shows that it is a war.'' The bombing, along with threats from Colombian drug dealers and the slayings of agents around the world, points to the agency's limits in protecting itself, the DEA acknowledges. Ruzzamenti mentioned the kidnapping and murder of undercover investigator Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena in Mexico and the slaying of a DEA agent in the Bogota, Colombia, office. ``Over the last few years we have certainly become much more security-conscious than we were,'' Ruzzamenti said. ``The drug traffickers of today are much more violent and brutal than they used to be _ we have seen what happens to agents overseas.'' The bombing will likely make agents more careful, said Miami DEA spokesman John Fernandes. He said he still checks carefully before entering his car and follows different routes to and from his home, even though he no longer works in the streets. But surrounding DEA offices with armed guards, for instance, would make it difficult for the agency to function in a free society. ``We can't shut ourselves off behind an iron wall,'' Fernandes said. ``We work with the public.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Television Attacks British Royal Family
DOC.TEXT: State television attacked the British royal family on Monday as Iraq increased the tone of its attacks on London for its condemnation of the hanging of a London-based journalist. The television upbraided members of Queen Elizabeth II's family for alleged immorality, broadcasting segments of programs about the monarchy. ``Elizabeth does not feel any shame despite the fact that her family members are hanging out their dirty linen before the people,'' a TV announcer said. A Buckingham Palace spokesman, asked in London whether he had any comment on the Iraqi TV attack, replied Monday night, ``No, not at all.'' The television claimed that Prince Charles, heir to the throne, married Diana even though he knew there were many men in her life before him, including his brother Prince Andrew. The television announcer asked how Charles could marry such ``a playgirl,'' without giving the source of his comments on Diana or further details. Diana was a friend of the royal family before her marriage and knew Andrew, Charles and others from childhood, but London newspapers have not carried reports that such relationships were anything like those portrayed by Iraqi TV. For women, premarital love affairs are taboo in much of the Arab world and would bring deep shame upon their families. The television showed scenes of the royals in their leisure time and said they were living at the expense of millions of poor people in Britain. It said Andrew married Sarah Ferguson although he knew she had had a love affair with ``a businessman.'' Miss Ferguson, now known as the Duchess of York, dated several men before her marriage, including a romance with a motor-racing millionaire. There was no effort to conceal it. The state television broadcast other details on the life of the monarchy that it said showed bad behavior on the part of the royal family. Farzad Bazoft, 31, an Iranian-born reporter for the British weekly The Observer, was hanged Thursday after being convicted of spying for Britain and Israel. He was arrested while trying to investigate reports that an explosion at an Iraqi military complex killed hundreds of people. Bazoft and his newspaper denied he was a spy. Editor Donald Trelford said alleged confessions produced by the Iraqi authorities were clearly extracted under duress. The execution outraged Britain, which recalled its ambassador, expelled six Iraqi military trainees, canceled a trade mission and suspended visits by government ministers. London stopped short of breaking relations, however. Thousands of Iraqis demonstrated Saturday in Baghdad to protest the British actions. The television report on the British monarchy was clearly intended as part of a growing campaign against Britain and its leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Top Ceausescu Officials Win Appeal Postponement
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Ceausescu's henchmen Monday won a postponement of an appeal of their convictions for backing the Romanian dictator's order to fire on protesters during the December revolution. The defense attorneys argued that the convictions of complicity to commit genocide were the first ever in Romania and that they needed to do research outside the country to effectively defend their clients on appeal. Tudor Postelnicu, Emil Bobu, Manea Manescu and Ion Dinca pleaded guilty to the charges and were convicted last month. They are appealing their sentences, which range up to life in prison. Bobu, 62, was secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee and the third-ranking member of the Ceausescu hierarchy after the dictator and his wife, Elena. Ceausescu was toppled after the demonstrations grew into a violent revolution, and he and his wife were executed on Christmas Day following a secret military trial. Postelnicu, 59, was Ceausescu's interior minister; Manescu, 74, was vice president of the former State Council; and Dinca, 62, was a Politburo member, as were his co-defendants. ``I ask for a new period of time for the court appeal since I regard the charge of genocide against the four defendants as a premiere for us and for international judiciary practice,'' Virgil Rata, Postelnicu's attorney, told the military tribunal hearing the appeal. He noted that in 1973 Romania ratified the 1948 international convention on genocide, but said he knew very little about how it has been applied over the years. ``I personally am handicapped and I more or less improvised from the few pages of international law that I had at my disposal,'' Rata said. He also said ``political murder cannot be included within the charge of genocide.'' ``Crimes, murders and massacres existed before,'' Rata said, citing the mass killing of alleged Communists after the overthrow of Indonesian President Sukarno in 1965. ``No state, be it Western or Eastern, ever raised the issue of genocide then.'' The defense attorneys for the others agreed with the arguments, and court President Col. Cornel Badoiu postponed the appeal until April 23. The prosecution agreed with the delay on the grounds that the defense should have all necessary information to conduct the appeal. During the one-hour session at a former police training academy, the four defendants sat in a prisoner's dock, clad in the gray-striped wool tunics and trousers customarily worn by Romanian prison inmates. The four, whose hair had been closely cropped in prison, conferred with each other during the session and chatted with their guards during a break in the proceedings. Manescu wiped his eyes frequently, but the other three showed little emotion. Manescu's wife sat several rows from the prisoners' dock. ``I swear with my hand on the cross that he is not guilty,'' she said in an interview. ``He didn't give any orders (to shoot demonstrators). He only followed (them) and put into practice the measures that had been dictated to him,'' said Mrs. Manescu, who refused to give her first name. Central to the guilty verdict was a Dec. 17 Politburo meeting at which Ceausescu announced his intent to use deadly force against protesters to quell demonstrations that began in the Western city of Timisoara. Ceausescu offered to resign after several Politburo members protested his demand for the resignations of Postelnicu, Defense Minister Vasile Milea and Chief of Security Iulian Vlad for not carrying out his orders to shoot protesters in Timisoara. Ultimately, the Politburo members asked Ceausescu to remain on. The prosecution argued during the trial that the defendants could have prevented the slaughter of demonstrators by accepting Ceausescu's resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Candidates Head for Finish Line after Lackluster Race
DOC.TEXT: Candidates in an ideologically charged gubernatorial race and a pair of bitter congressional contests trudged toward the finish line Monday, but most voters were apparently ignoring them. Sunny skies and temperatures in the low 50s were forecast for Tuesday's primary, but state election officials predicted that little more than one-fourth of Illinois' 6 million registered voters would cast ballots. However, a 44 percent turnout was projected among Chicago's 1.4 million voters, partly because of a hotly contested, highly publicized four-way contest for county board president in Cook County, which includes Chicago. The gubernatorial race, the most-watched contest statewide, matched two-term Secretary of State Jim Edgar, the candidate backed by the state GOP hierarchy, against conservative political organizer Steven Baer. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday that President Bush and GOP National Chairman Lee Atwater both supported Edgar. Baer has attacked Edgar's support of abortion rights and extension of a temporary state income tax increase. He has dubbed Edgar ``Pinocchio'' for what he said were contradictory statements on taxes. Edgar aides have accused Baer of lying about Edgar's positions on abortion. Edgar says he supports the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. Edgar told a rally Monday in the state Capitol rotunda that a large turnout ``will be good for democracy ... and very good for Jim Edgar.'' Baer held out hope for an upset fueled by a get-out-the-vote effort targeting anti-abortion households and conservatives. ``I think we've done everything that's humanly possible, and I think there are going to be a lot of surprised faces tomorrow,'' he said at a campaign stop in Springfield. In one of the congressional races, Democratic Rep. Sidney Yates of Chicago faced a well-financed challenge from Chicago alderman Edwin Eisendrath, who claimed that a weekend canvass showed him leading the 20-term congressman. Yates, 80, complained that the 31-year-old Eisendrath had unfairly maligned him with a campaign pamphlet comparing Yates to an antique typewriter and an obsolete television set. Eisendrath rebuffed the accusation Monday at a meeting with campaign workers, saying, ``There's nothing wrong with pointing out that a man is out of touch.'' On the city's South Side, flamboyant and controversial five-term Democratic U.S. Rep. Gus Savage was locked in a rematch with educator Melvin Reynolds, who characterized Savage as ``totally ineffective.'' In the Cook County board race, there was last-minute barnstorming by front-runners Richard Phelan, who was special counsel in the House Ethics Committee's investigation of former House Speaker Jim Wright, and former state appellate Judge Eugene Pincham. Voters at a lunchtime Phelan appearance in downtown Chicago said the Cook County contests had overshadowed the other primaries for offices such as governor. ``Is that tomorrow? I didn't even know about it,'' said Richard Gutierrez, 25, of Cicero. ``It's all been about Cook County, that's where most of the media's been focused, not the governor's race.'' ``You just see them on TV and the names run together,'' added Jamie Mortellaro, 25, of Chicago. The statewide ballot was almost completely clear of contested races, the result of furious maneuvering last year by party leaders to ensure their top candidates a clear shot at the fall election. Two-term Democratic Attorney General Neil Hartigan was guaranteed a fall match with the winner of the GOP gubernatorial primary, while U.S. Sen. Paul Simon and his Republican challenger, U.S. Rep. Lynn Martin, were unopposed in their respective primaries. But party leaders' favorites were struggling in the handful of contested races. The Democrats' slated candidate for Cook County Board president, state Sen. Ted Lechowicz, was running last in the four-way race, according to independent polls. Cook County Clerk Stanley Kusper was also in the race. Slated candidates for state treasurer and comptroller were also locked in close races.

DOC.HEAD: No Quick End Forecast to Century's Worst Drought
DOC.TEXT: Weather forecasters broke more bad news Monday to parched Greece: There is no rain in sight for the nation, which is suffering from its worst drought in a century. The weather bureau said no rain had fallen in the agricultural north for 75 days, and bureau spokesman Andreas Lazanis said none was forecast for at least the next six days. The drought has endangered winter crops and spring planting, according to agricultural officials. Residents of Yiannitsa, a farming community near Salonica in northern Greece, prayed for rain at Sunday religious services. Rainfall also was very low last winter, and the government last week announced an emergency plan to drill for extra water because Athens' reservoirs reportedly contain only enough to last until November. No rainfall figures for the latest weeks were available. But figures released by the weather bureau indicated that January rainfall in the Athens area was less than a fifth of that month's average of 2 inches. In an interview with the newspaper Ta Nea on Monday, Environment Minister Costas Liaskas said $31 million had been allocated to drill for underground reserves near Athens. He said the main reason for the water shortage was the drought. ``But we must add that the water has not been managed correctly,'' Liaskas said. He said a lot of water had been lost because of leaking aquaducts.

DOC.HEAD: Students in Taiwan Hold Rally Demanding Political Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of students held an all-day rally Monday demanding that direct president elections replace the electoral college dominated by elderly Nationalist politicians elected in China before 1949. The protest came two days before the 752-seat electoral college, known as the National Assembly, meets to select the next president. The only candidate is President Lee Teng-hui of the ruling Nationalist Party. About 3,000 students boycotted classes at about a dozen universities throughout Taiwan to take part in the first major student demonstration here since this island nation lifted martial law in 1987 after 38 years. In heavy rain, they linked arms and sang ``United we have strength, as students we have strength'' in Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park, named after the Nationalist leader who moved his government to Taiwan after losing a civil war to Communist forces on the Chinese mainland in 1949. Students pledged to continue the protest until after the presidential election. About half those at the rally announced plans to stay in the park overnight. Sixteen classmates began a hunger strike they said would last until the government responded to their demands. The deputies in the National Assembly, many in their 80s and 90s, were allowed to remain indefinitely in office to support the Nationalist claim to still be the sole legitimate government of all of China. The students also asked the government to issue a timetable for democratic change. They rejected a call by Lee to end their occupation of the park, which began with a sit-in by 200 students last Friday. Students shunned political demonstrations under martial law and rarely participated in protests organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party the past three years. ``As the political situation deteriorated, students are coming out of their fears about participation in political movements,'' said Chang Chung-tung, history professor at National Taiwan University. University students in Beijing occupied Tiananmen Square for weeks last spring to press demands for a freer society in Communist China, and some demonstrators here acknowledged they were trying to recreate that spirit. Almost all of Taiwan's 20 million people are ethnic Chinese and the Beijing student movement _ crushed by troops _ received wide sympathy here.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Returns, Freezing Weather Reaches into Deep South
DOC.TEXT: Snow or rain fell across sections of the Midwest, the South and the Northeast on Monday, and floods continued to plague the Deep South. Flooding that began Thursday continued to keep thousands of people out of their homes in Georgia, Florida and Alabama. Snow extended from south-central Tennessee to eastern Kentucky and western West Virginia, Ohio, central Indiana, central Illinois and lower and central Upper Michigan. Rain reached from central and western New York state to much of Pennsylvania and northeastern West Virginia. Rain mixed with snow fell over southwest Pennsylvania, northwestern West Virginia and northeast Mississippi. Snow advisories were posted for the central and northern mountains of West Virginia, parts of western and south-central New York state and northeast ohio. A winter storm watch was posted for the upper Susquehanna Valley and the northern Poconos Mountains in Pennsylvania. Winter storm watches also were posted for Monday night and Tuesday across the Catskill Mountains of New York state, the Berkshires of Massachusetts and the northwest hills of Connecticut. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 0 degrees in Hibbing and International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 22 degrees at Houghton, Mich. to 90 degrees at Palm Springs and Thermal, Calif. and Yuma, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE JERUSALEM
Carter Criticizes Israelis During Visit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with Carter opposes settling Soviet Jews in Jerusalem, other. ADDS byline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Visiting former President Jimmy Carter on Monday accused Israel of violating Palestinian rights in the occupied lands and argued against settling Soviet Jews in Jerusalem, government officials said. His remarks came on a day when a 20-year-old Palestinian was shot and killed in a stone-throwing clash with Israeli troops in the occupied Gaza Strip, according to Arab reports. An 18-year-old died of a head wound suffered a day earlier. Carter met privately with officials during a visit to an absorption center for Israeli immigrants Monday in Mevasseret Zion, five miles west of Jerusalem. ``The settlement of Soviet immigrants in Jerusalem serves only to spark Palestinian protests and should be discouraged,'' an official, speaking anonymously, quoted Carter as saying during the meeting. On Sunday, Carter told Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek that Jerusalem should remain a united city. President Bush has equated Jewish neighborhoods in east Jerusalem with West Bank settlements. On a visit to Amman, Jordan, Carter called settlement of Soviet Jewish immigrants in the West Bank and Gaza Strip ``an impediment to peace.'' Israel captured the territories, along with Arab east Jerusalem, from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War. It annexed east Jerusalem as part of its capital, and the Jewish neighborhoods built around the city are not considered occupied territory by most of the Israeli public. Israel denies it directs immigrants to the occupied lands, saying they are free to choose where they want to live. About 200 Soviet immigrants have so far settled in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israeli leaders have said they expect thousands of Soviet immigrants in the next decade because of liberalized Soviet exit policies and U.S. visa restrictions. Children greeted the former U.S. president with flowers and kisses on his arrival at the absorption center, a temporary home where about 800 immigrants spend their first months here studying the Hebrew language. However, children from observant, right-wing families in the surrounding areas protested the visit, waving Israeli flags and holding a banner saying ``Jerusalem Not For Sale.'' The right-wing Tehiya party sent Carter a telegram saying he was ``not a wanted guest in our country,'' the national news agency Itim said. ``Your policy is not neutral. It represents PLO and Palestinian positions,'' the telegram reportedly said. The government and many Israelis consider the Palestine Liberation Organization a terrorist group. After a meeting earlier Monday with directors of the left-wing Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, Carter said he was distressed by reports that Palestinians were jailed without trial and that houses were demolished to punish Arab families. He also accused Israel of ``excessive use of firearms by the military that are not under life-threatening situations.'' ``What we are talking about is an authoritative government that is in charge that is depriving the people under its control of their basic human rights,'' Carter told reporters. ``I think the intefadeh (uprising) is being perpetuated partially by the abuse of the Palestinians.'' The latest fatality occurred in the Sheik Radwan neighborhood of Gaza City, when soldiers fired live ammunition to quell stone-throwing, Arab reports said. Arab hospital officials identified the victim as Osama El-Sharwish of Gaza City. Also Monday, Nafi Rafik Zakout of Jabaliya refugee camp died in Israel's Tel Hashomer Hospital. He was hit in the head with a plastic bullet fired by troops during a clash in Gaza City a day earlier. The army confirmed Zakout's death and said it was checking the report on El-Sharwish. The deaths raised to 666 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the territories. An additional 198 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Agent Says Government Used Bombs, Black Magic Against Foes
DOC.TEXT: A secret government security unit planned bombings and killings, and it once employed a witch doctor to put a spell on Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a former agent testified Monday. Abraham ``Snake'' Van Zyl told an inquiry hearing that agents of the secret Civilian Cooperation Bureau had conducted a major underground campaign against anti-apartheid activists. He said the main targets were the African National Congress, Nelson Mandela's group, and the South African Communist Party. ``Disruption of the enemy ranged from breaking windows to killing,'' he told the official inquiry. Van Zyl, a former police officer, said he and other agents tried to use ``muti,'' or magic, against Tutu, an anti-apartheid activist who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize. He said they hanged a monkey fetus prepared by a witch doctor in Tutu's driveway and drove magically treated nails into the driveway. He did not say exactly how this was supposed to affect Tutu. The government has ordered an investigation into the Cooperation Bureau, which was reportedly run by the South African Defense Forces to wage a secret war against groups fighting the white government's apartheid policies of racial discrimination. South African newspapers have reported that top generals were linked to the unit's activities. Opposition leaders contend the security forces are tied to the deaths or disappearance of dozens of anti-government activists in recent years. Several former police officers have admitted involvement in killings of government opponents and other illegal activities. Van Zyl, who said he was speaking because he wanted the truth to come out, also said the unit bombed a school in Cape Town in 1989 because it was reportedly used as a meeting place by anti-apartheid activists. He said it also planned to kill anti-apartheid leader Dullah Omar by inducing a heart attack by swapping medicine for poison. Van Zyl also said the unit planned to kill Gavin Evans, a journalist. Most of the schemes described by Van Zyl appeared to end in failure. Van Zyl recounted how he was recruited into the unit by military intelligence officers and given a salary and allowances that allowed him to buy a BMW car. He said he and other agents set up businesses with government funds to mask their activities and serve as front organizations.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. to Start Moving Relief Supplies in Early April
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations will start transporting about 104,000 tons of relief supplies to war-torn southern Sudan by early April, a U.N. spokeswoman said Monday. Pat Banks said in a statement the supplies will be ferried in from the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, and from neighboring Kenya and Uganda by helicopters, trains and barges. She said the effort is a resumption of Operation Lifeline, a relief project to aid people affected by southern Sudan's 7-year-old civil war. About 500,000 people are at risk of death as a result of war and starvation. A meeting of donors is scheduled for next Monday in Khartoum to plan the project in detail. Operation Lifeline succeeded in part last year until a cease-fire between Sudan's government and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army was broken in the fall.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Leader Welcomes Syrian Official
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria met with President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran on Monday and Rafsanjani stressed Iran's support for Syria in its confrontation with Israel, Tehran radio said. Sharaa emphasized the close relations between Syria and Iran. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Sharaa discussed Palestine, Lebanon and other subjects with Iranian officials during his visit to Iran. But it did not mention the issue of Western hostages in Lebanon. Both IRNA and Tehran radio were monitored in Nicosia. IRNA said Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati emphasized the need for even stronger ties between Persian Iran and Arab Syria in two hours of talks Sunday. The radio quoted Sharaa as saying Sunday that Syria doubted Israel would seek peace. ``Syria is very well aware of the fact that Israel does not want peace and security in the region and that it is thinking of increasing its sphere of influence _ in other words, of consolidating the occupation of Jerusalem and other Arab territories,'' Sharaa was quoted as saying. Syria is Iran's main Arab ally and supported it against Iraq in the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war. The Syrians, with 40,000 troops in Lebanon, have been instrumental in helping release Western hostages in the past. Last month, Sharaa told Peggy Say, sister of American hostage Terry Anderson, that he would raise the issue of Iranian help to free the 18 Westerners held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian groups. Rafsanjani has said he believes the hostage issue is moving toward solution. The radical faction that opposes him has argued against the hostages' release, however.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Defense Loses Battle Over A Word
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood's defense lost a legal battle Monday over a single word that could affect how jurors decide whether the Exxon Valdez skipper was drunk when his ship went aground. The word was ``noticeably,'' and was contained in a legal instruction that told jurors to decide whether Hazelwood was ``noticeably impaired'' on the night of the nation's largest oil spill. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone removed the word and said he would tell jurors they must only decide whether Hazelwood was impaired. ``There are a lot of people who can mask their impairment,'' he told lawyers in explaining his decision. Defense lawyer Dick Madson appeared stunned by the ruling, saying, ``This is the first time I've ever heard of this.'' Madson said in his years of defending drunken driving cases in Fairbanks, the term ``noticeably impaired'' always has been included in jury instructions. ``My gosh, it's been around for a long time,'' he told the judge. But Assistant District Attorney Sam Adams argued, ``All we have to prove is that he was impaired, not stumble-down drunk.'' Hazelwood is charged with one felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. His tanker ran aground on Bligh Reef last March 24, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil, wreaking devastation over hundreds of miles of shoreline rich with fish, birds and other wildlife. The question of whether Hazelwood showed signs of intoxication has been a key element in his trial, with numerous witnesses testifying that the skipper did not stagger, slur his words or show any other evidence that he was drunk. Three witnesses said they smelled alcohol on his breath. The judge's ruling came during a discussion of legal instructions which will be given to jurors after attorneys deliver their final arguments Tuesday. In other rulings, the judge said he would ``take judicial notice'' of the fact the U.S. Coast Guard had a regulation barring tanker crews from drinking alcohol less than four hours before sailing. But he refused to give an instruction on the point, because the regulation is not state law. He also refused a proposed prosecution instruction that would have told jurors the Coast Guard's blood alcohol limit for operating a commercial vessel is .04, well below the state level of .10 for drunken driving. Hazelwood's blood alcohol level was below the state limit, but violated the Coast Guard's. The judge noted the Coast Guard standard is a federal regulation, not a state law, and has not been admitted into evidence at the trial. He rejected a last-minute request by the defense to tell jurors that reckless driving and negligent driving are lesser included offenses of criminal mischief. The instruction would have given jurors the option of convicting Hazelwood on the reduced charges rather than the single felony.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed by Gunmen in Ice Cream Parlor
DOC.TEXT: Assailants strolled into an ice cream parlor in a northwestern town and sprayed it with gunfire, killing six people and wounding four, police said Monday. Authorities were trying to determine the identities of the gunmen and the motive for the shooting late Sunday in Apartado, 280 miles north of Bogota, a police statement said. It said most victims were workers on the banana plantations that cover the Uraba region on the border with Panama. The town has been wracked by violence recently. Mayor Diana Cardona was kidnapped and killed by a group of unidentified men on Feb. 26. Cardona was a member of the leftist Patriotic Union Party, whose leaders blamed her death on the region's right-wing death squads. Authorities have blamed the death squads for several massacres targeting union organizers and leftist leaders in Uraba in recent years. Also Monday, five leftist guerrillas belonging to the National Liberation Army were killed in a battle with the army on the country's northeastern border with Venezuela, an army statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Architect of Polish Reforms Says Soviets Can't Just Copy Them
With AM-Soviet-Economy
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's reported consideration of Polish-style radical economic reforms indicates an admission that perestroika so far has been insufficient, says one of the architects of Poland's plan. But the Soviet Union must not follow the Polish strategy too closely, because there are substantial differences between the countries' economies, said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University economist and one of Poland's main economic advisers since the country abandoned Communist rule last year. The Soviet news agency Interfax reported Monday that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is preparing to implement drastic changes effective July 1, including reforming the state-set pricing system, selling off state-owned industries and developing a plan to make the ruble convertible. The news agency said the strategy was developed by 60 Soviet economists, who modeled it after the Polish plan. Sachs, in a telephone interview, said that despite Soviet attempts at reforms during Gorbachev's five years in power, the country in some ways has more dire problems than Poland. For one, Soviets have ``terrible overhangs'' of money _ disproportionately high savings due to a lack of goods for consumers to purchase, he said. That means making the ruble convertible to foreign currencies could prompt high inflation. Poland, by comparison, had suffered years of rampant inflation that ate up savings and has started to subside under the reforms, Sachs said. He said the Soviet Union could lower the money supply by setting a limit on savings acount withdrawals, by doubling both wages and prices or even by confiscation. In addition, Poland is much further along in decentralizing control of industry, Sachs said, whereas the Soviet Union remains mired in inefficient central planning. And, he noted, Poland in previous years had been more concerned than the Soviet Union about developing trade with other countries. Sachs also pointed out that Poland's reforms are bolstered by substantial economic aid from other countries. The Soviet Union must be willing to accept similar aid, he said. The Soviet Union thus far has appeared to be offended by suggestions that it accept aid on the order of the Marshall Plan, the blueprint for European economic recovery after World War II. But Interfax quoted Gorbachev aide Nikolai Petrakov as saying such aid had not been ruled out. Sachs roughly estimated that the Soviet Union would need about $90 billion in foreign aid. Although Western countries might balk at coming up with that much in aid, it would be ``the deal of the century'' for opening up trade with the West and reducing Western defense expenditures through the reduction of military tension, Sachs said. Despite the differences between the Polish and Soviet economies, Sachs said the Soviet Union can expect to have one experience in common with Poland if it undertakes reforms that go beyond perestroika's so-far mild moves _ substantial unemployment. After decades of nearly full employment, about 150,000 Poles have become unemployed since the reforms were implemented. ``It is an inevitable offshoot,'' said Sachs, who added that he believed the unemployment would be short-term suffering for long-term gain. ``I would tell them to keep their perspective.''

DOC.HEAD: Blast Aboard Ship Shakes Quebec Town, Two Dead
DOC.TEXT: An explosion on a container ship loading aluminum at a wharf in this Quebec town Monday killed two people and injured at least seven, police and company sources said. Sgt. Maurice Girard of La Baie police said the afternoon blast rocked the town along the Saguenay River about 120 miles north of Quebec City. Some residents thought there had been an earthquake. Alcan Aluminium runs the wharf, which is used to service its local smelter. Alcan employee Fernard Leclerc said the two killed were members of the crew of the Pollux, a Norwegian ship. He said they were loading containers into the ship's hold, where the explosion occurred. Leclerc said seven Alcan employees were injured. He said he could only speculate about the cause of the explosion. He said the material in the containers _ spent linings from the smelting process of aluminum _ ``can, under certain conditions and if not properly handled, produce toxic gases, including methane.'' Girard said the ship wasn't seriously damaged.

DOC.HEAD: Masked Youths in Athens Firebomb Conservative Party Office
DOC.TEXT: Masked youths firebombed and destroyed a branch office of Greece's conservative New Democracy party on Monday, the latest in a rash of urban attacks before April 8 national elections. About 10 minutes later, a gang burned the nearby office of New Democracy parliamentary candidate Nontas Zafeiropoulos. Police speculated it was the same band. They reported no arrests. Witnesses said about 15 masked youths smashed the windows of the party's Exarheia branch and then hurled firebombs into the ground-floor offices. About 10 party workers escaped unharmed but the offices were destroyed, they said, speaking on condition of not being identified. The government pledged a crackdown Friday on anarchists firebombing police and party offices and planting bombs under police vehicles. A police officer was badly hurt early Sunday when youths firebombed his patrol car. The self-proclaimed anarchists are protesting the shooting deaths of two 15-year-old boys by police. A policeman was acquitted in January of the death of a youth involved in a firebomb attack on a police bus in 1985. Another officer is under investigation for killing a masked youth who broke into an arms store in Preveza this month.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Ordered to Court in Drug Plane Case
DOC.TEXT: A frustrated federal judge ordered Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to court to explain the government's abandonment of a settlement involving a drug-laden plane leased to U.S. agents and linked to the Contras. U.S. District Judge Patrick Kelly said the case involved criminal conduct by the United States. ``This case stinks to high heaven,'' Kelly said during a hearing on a lawsuit over the loss of the twin-engine Beech King Air, which was ditched in the Caribbean Sea on Jan. 3, 1983. The pilot, convicted smuggler Michael Toliver, later testified that he flew arms to Nicaragua's Contra rebels and illegal drugs back to the United States several times under the supervision of federal agents. Kelly had canceled a trial set for January after being told in November that the case had been settled through mediation. But on Friday, Richard Montague, an assistant U.S. attorney general from Washington, told Kelly that Justice Department officials never approved the settlement, and said the case should go to trial. Kelley ordered Thornburgh to appear at an April 2 hearing in Wichita to straighten out the lawsuit's status. Thornburgh aide Michael Robinson said Monday that the attorney general had not yet decided how to respond to the order. Kelly told Montague that the case ``involves the transport of drugs by agents of the United States or with the acquiescence of the United States.'' Montague objected, saying that Toliver was the only witness making such statements and that his credibility was questionable. The attorney said the insurance case had nothing to do with those statements. Kelly said he was frustrated by the government's lack of action in response to Toliver's disclosures. ``I have heard nothing,'' the judge said. ``Frankly, what I have had is stonewalling at the hands of the United States and I'm not going to have any more.'' Kelly had been so alarmed by Toliver's statements that he ordered transcripts of the testimony delivered to the FBI, CIA and to then-President Reagan at Bethesda Naval Hospital. ``The president of the United States advised me in spades that the attorney general was fully familiar with it, and I don't think you are,'' Kelly told Montague, who was representing the Justice Department. Montague said the question of whether a criminal investigation was warranted was up to the attorney general, not the judge. Toliver testified in Kelly's court in 1987 that he made two trips to Honduras and Colombia the previous year with arms for the Contras and returned to the United States with loads of cocaine and marijuana. He said he landed at Homestead Air Force Base, Fla., with one drug load and that he worked as an informant and contract employee under federal supervision. Toliver testified that he wasn't working for the government when he crashed the plane. He said he had disconnected a U.S. Customs Service homing device aboad the plane, and took off in another direction with a load of marijuana. He ditched the craft off Grand Cayman Island when he ran out of fuel trying to avoid storms. Toliver, who is serving a marijuana smuggling sentence in North Carolina, was granted immunity in exchange for his testimony. The lawsuit was filed by Midland National Bank of Newton, which said it had a $198,000 lien on the plane. The defendants included the plane's owner, Walter Conlogue, who said his company, American Aircraft Co. of Newton, leased the aircraft to U.S. Customs agents to help in an undercover drug investigation. Puritan Insurance Co. of Stamford, Conn. refused to pay a claim on the plane's $225,000 insurance policy, saying Conlogue lied about the plane's use. Conlogue said he was warned that if he did not do so, ``innocent people would suffer and be killed.'' The insurance company is both a defendant and a plaintiff in the lawsuit. The government is also a defendant. Friday's hearing was held to determine why the government had not paid the settlement negotiated in November. The terms of the agreement have not been revealed.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Withholds Judgment On Soviet Military Maneuvers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf: ``Also, Ms.,'' with three grafs bgng: ``A spokesman,'' _ Moscow troop report from a0682 and radio jamming.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration avoided criticizing Moscow over Lithuania on Monday but said it would keep an eye on Soviet military activities in the Baltic region. White House and State Department spokesmen called for a peaceful approach to secession and reminded Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev he had said force would not be used. ``There are discussions that need to be held with the USSR,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary. ``We want that to be a peaceful process.'' Fitzwater and State Department spokesman Richard Boucher declined to say whether the Soviets had engaged in coercion. ``I don't want to speculate, one way or another,'' Boucher said. The spoke as a delegation of Lithuanian legislators went to Moscow seeking talks on their declaration of independence. Gorbachev has condemned the move as illegal and demanded a renunciation. In Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, President Vytautus Landsbergis said Soviet military maneuvers were raising tensions in the region. On Sunday, Soviet military jets buzzed Vilnius and Soviet troops held maneuvers in the countryside. ``The military exercises of Soviet troops in Lithuania now under way are intensifying tensions,'' Landsbergis told Lithuania's legislature, according to Lithuanian television editor Eduardas Potashinkis, who monitored the meeting. In Arlington, Va., Asta Banionist of the Lithuanian American Community Inc., said she had received reports that 10 truckloads of Soviet paratroopers entered the northeast quadrant of Vilnius Monday afternoon. ``They are waiting for orders,'' she said. A spokesman for the Lithuanian nationalist movement Sajudis, Lionginas Vasiliauskas, said in Moscow that 10 truckloads of Soviet troops were moved Monday from Kaunas, about 60 miles from Vilnius, to a military post just outside the capital. Also, Ms. Banionist said she had reports that KGB agents had entered the atomic energy plant at Ignalina as well as television and radio stations, but without interrupting or altering broadcasts. A broadcast of Radio Vinius heard in Washington Monday night was heavily jammed. Her group says it has 100,000 members in 75 chapters across the United States. Mark Dillen, a State Department spokesman, said he no information about the matters Ms. Banionist discussed. Asked earlier about the maneuvers, Boucher at the State Department replied with what he called ``more general comments.'' They were, he said, ``that we've always stressed the importance to resolving the differences there peacefully. We have called for negotiations and discussions that take place without coercion or intimidation. Those discussions, in fact, are beginning today in Moscow. We are watching developments closely.'' Boucher then volunteered that both Gorbachev and Yegor Ligachev, secretary of the Communist Party's Central Committee, have said recently that force would not be used in the Baltic states. Asked whether he believed the Soviet was using coercion against Lithuania, Boucher said, ``Again, I don't want to speculate one way or the other or categorize what's been going on, other than to say that we're following it.'' Fitzwater repeated, meanwhile, that ``we want to see a peaceful resolution of the situation there.'' He said the United States continues to urge the Soviet government ``to respect the will of the citizens of Lithuania.'' And Fitzwater reiterated that the U.S. believes Lithuania was incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940 forcibly. The Bush administration has not established diplomatic relations with the breakaway republic. Fitzwater implied the step would be taken provided Lithuania clearly was in charge of its own affairs. ``We have a standard of control of one's territory which guides us in this matter,'' the White House spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Protesters Attack Hungarian Political Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: Romanians attacked an ethnic Hungarian political association headquarters on Monday and the government appealed to the military to help control the situation, a member of Parliament reported. He quoted interim President Ion Iliescu as saying ethnic Romanians from villages near Tirgu Mures went to that the ethnically mixed, northwestern city and attacked headquarters of the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania with axes. Mircea Dinescu, president of the Romanian Writers' Union, said Iliescu confirmed reports of the raid to him and that Iliescu asked the army for help. Dinescu belongs to the provisional parliament that is governing Romania until May 20 elections. He was in Budapest, the Hungarian capital, for a meeting of Hungarian and Romanian officials and intellectuals and spoke in a telephone interview. Tirgu Mures, 180 miles northwest of Bucharest, was reported calm late Monday. The city has a large ethnic Hungarian population and is considered a cradle of Hungarian culture and tradition in Transylvania. The ethnic Romanian demonstrators earlier Monday gathered before local headquarters of the National Salvation Front and demanded the resignation of its vice president, ethnic Hungarian Eloed Kincses, claiming he promoted separatism among the population. Kincses agreed to resign, army Maj. Vasily Tria told The Associated Press by telephone from Tirgu Mures. The Front took power in Romania in the December revolution that overthrew Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, later executed. It still dominates political life, but shares power with many other representatives in a Council of National Unity that acts as a makeshift parliament until elections. Under Ceausescu, Romanian-Hungarian ties were strained as Budapest charged Romania with mistreating its 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians _ Romania's largest ethnic minority _ and undermining their culture and traditions. Ceausescu's controlled media accused Hungary of wanting to change borders set by a 1920 treaty that granted Romania the territory of Transylvania. Most ethnic Hungarians live there. The area was long ruled by Hungary. After the headquarters attack, Hungarians gathered in protest Monday night in front of the local radio station, Sandor Gaspar, director of Tirgu Mures Radio, told The AP in a telephone interview. He said no injuries were reported. The attack followed a day of demonstrations by ethnic Romanians carrying the national flag through the city and demanding their rights. The area's ethnic Romanians have been complaining that Hungarians desecrated Romanian symbols. The conflict has its roots in ethnic Hungarian demands for political and cultural autonomy in Romania following the upheavals of the revolution. Ceausescu suppressed the ethnic Hungarians and closed Hungarian-language institutions. The Hungarian community claims discrimination continues.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Says Negotiations Won't Resume Until Violence Stops
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound said Monday it will not resume stalled talks with striking drivers until attacks on buses and replacement drivers stop, but a union leader pledged to meet ``any time'' with company negotiators. The first meeting between the two sides broke down Sunday when Dallas-based Greyhound accused union leaders of failing to negotiate and of stepping up violence walkout, now in its third week. ``A lot of the problem was the continuing intimidation and violence,'' said company spokeswoman Lyn Grayley. ``The company just does not feel that they will be intimidated into (accepting) a contract.'' ``Maybe if the violence and terrorism and intimidation and all that stopped ... (reopening talks) would be considered,'' she said. ``Our main concern at this point is the safety of our passengers and employees.'' There have been at least 14 shooting attacks on Greyhound buses, 46 bomb threats and numerous other incidents of vandalism or threats during the 18-day-old walkout, company officials say. Greyhound operates the only nationwide intercity bus service, and the strike has stranded many smaller communities for which buses are the only public transportation. Unions representing 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out March 2 over wages, job security and grievance procedures. In Denver, the Amalgamated Transit Union's vice president, Jim Hayes, said the union would return to talks ``any time, any place,'' but the sticking point is Greyhound's unwillingness to compromise. ``The company hasn't changed a thing,'' he said. ``The company makes one cent per mile for every passenger and that comes out to about $78 million. We're asking for $40 million over 3 years.'' The bus company last week began a nationwide radio advertising campaign to counter allegations by striking drivers that newly hired drivers were not properly trained. ``We've hired many new permanent drivers who are professionally qualified, thoroughly trained and committed to giving you the quality service you've come to expect from Greyhound,'' the radio spots say. Ms. Grayley, the company spokeswoman, said the new drivers must have two years experience driving a bus or truck, and are certified by the Department of Transportation. ``With so many of the violent episodes that have gone on, people are nervous,'' she said. ``And we don't want them to feel that's going to happen every time a bus goes out on the road. We want them to know we're doing everything in our power to make those buses safe,'' she said. Union leaders say they condemned the violence and Greyhound is the one balking in negotiations. ``We have continually called for our members to refrain from illegal activity,'' said Jeff Nelson, spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions in Washington. ``But, we are not police.'' ``This is simply an attempt by the company's so-called negotiator to stonewall the real issue, which is negotiating a contract,'' Nelson said. During talks in Tucson, Ariz. on Saturday, the union proposed a $40 million three-year package that included pay increases of 4 percent to 5 percent and the addition of new drivers to the pension plan. But the cost would be ``three times more than Greyhound could afford,'' Ms. Grayley said. A union spokesman said the company has offered a plan that included no guaranteed pay raises, but would have made raises contingent on increased profits and ridership. Negotiations broke off Sunday after about an hour, but both sides later met separately with federal mediators. ``I think we made some progress in the meetings,'' said Jim Power, spokesman for the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Would Curb US Aid to Drug Countries
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said on Monday he favors making U.S. aid to other countries conditional on their cooperation in curbing drug traffic after they get a chance to adopt needed laws. He pointed to an international pact on cooperation, signed by 89 governments. It will take effect when 20 of them have ratified it, as the United States has already done. ``There will come a time when those that have not ratified the convention will be questioned by those who have and who continue to be concerned about the drug problem,'' he told reporters. ``I would not rule out some action in this country at that time to indeed put that kind of restriction on U.S. aid.'' That would not happen in the foreseeable future, he added. He said that if he had his way, he would urge such a course after an interval during which countries had the opportunity to change their laws. He added that the process would take some time and that the 89 governments presumably support the goal of eradicating the drug traffic and money laundering. ``But that time is running and more and more nations are ratifying the convention,'' he said. ``And particularly when we've reached the point where 20 nations have ratified and the convention comes into force, then we'll be looking to every nation around the world to do its share in dealing with this problem.'' Thornburgh emphasized the need for international cooperation. He said there have been calls in Congress and the media for U.S. intervention but that President Bush had chosen a more restrained and measured response. Intervention would ultimately be counter-productive, he said. He said the indictment in this country of Khun Sa, the opium war lord in Burma, would step up the pressure on the international community and improve the chances of getting hold of him. The indictment was returned in December by a court in New York and disclosed in Washington last week. Thornburgh said then that someone in Khun Sa's own forces might betray him. Today he said that he knows there are substantial obstacles to an arrest. Khun Sa has an army estimated at 4,000 to 16,000 men. Thornburgh predicted that drug money will seek outlets in other banking systems as Switzerland and other countries tighten their cooperation on money laundering. ``I expect no nation with a credible banking system to be immune,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Convicted in Killing of of Pro-Solidarity Sociologist
DOC.TEXT: A court Monday convicted two men of the 1988 robbery and murder of a university sociologist who served as a Solidarity union adviser, the official news agency reported. Jan Strzelecki, 69, died nearly three weeks after he was found unconscious near the Vistula River in Warsaw, according to police reports, which said he had been dragged from his car, assaulted and thrown down an embankment. The Warsaw Provincial Court convicted and sentenced 20-year-old Marek Tomasz Marzec to the maximum of 25 years in prison for the June 1988 murder, the official PAP news agency said. The court also sentenced 26-year-old Krzysztof Chrobocinski to 14 years in prison. He had been charged with robbery and assault. The trial resumed Jan. 26 after being suspended so experts could carry out tests that determined a stick Marzec used to beat Strzelecki was capable of delivering a fatal blow. In its report, PAP did not suggest a motive for the crime. Strzelecki was not a prominent member of Solidarity, the once-banned labor movement that took control of the Polish government last year. However, he was an active supporter of Solidarity at the Institute of Philosophy and Sociology of the Polish Academy of Sciences, where he was an associate professor.

DOC.HEAD: Gift to Quayle of Jaguar Cubs Won't be Sent After All
DOC.TEXT: A pair of jaguar cubs given by President Gen. Andres Rodriguez to Vice President Dan Quayle won't be allowed to leave Paraguay after all, a government spokesman said. ``The cubs won't be allowed to travel to the United States because the legal requirements are very strict,'' an aide to Rodriguez said Sunday on condition of anonymity. Conservation groups consider the jaguar to be an endangered species in Latin America, and on Thursday Rodriguez was told Quayle would prefer that the cubs be released into the wilds of Paraguay. Rodriguez gave Quayle the jaguar cubs when the vice president visited Paraguay March 12-13 on a tour of several Latin nations. Quayle originally accepted the cubs to conform with diplomatic protocol, but had intended to try to give them to Washington's National Zoo. But the zoo would not take the jaguars because of their status as an endangered species, and an environmental group called the vice president's office to protest their being taken from the wild.

DOC.HEAD: Morocco Says It Expelled Rights Workers, but Others Welcome
DOC.TEXT: The government expelled two Amnesty International workers investigating alleged human rights abuses because they failed to make prior arrangements for their visit, officials said Monday. However, an Interior Ministry spokesman said delegates from the rights group could return to the North African country if they give authorities advance notice. Amnesty International, based in London, said Friday its envoys were told to leave Morocco after meeting last Tuesday with local rights activists. Amnesty issued a statement saying its delegates were visiting openly and had visited Morocco on a similar trip last month. The Interior Ministry spokesman, speaking on condition on anonymity, said the Amnesty envoys were not expected until this week and acknowledged they were asked to leave. ``We have no objections to Amnesty, and we will be happy to explain every case to them in detail,'' the spokesman said. ``But we insist that they show a minimum of respect for the host nation.'' Amnesty reports that Moroccan police torture and illegally detain suspects. The organization also has long-standing complaints over the imprisonment of some of King Hassan II's political opponents. Meanwhile Monday, the European Community's Fishing Commission opened talks with Morocco's ministries of Fisheries and Foreign Affairs. Morocco and Spain are at odds over fishing issues. The Spanish say Moroccan courts have imposed excessive fines on Spanish fishermen violating international rules. The Spanish have responded by blocking Moroccan ships from ports in southern Spain. But they suspended that blockade when the meeting with the Economic Community was announced.

DOC.HEAD: Four in Pickup Truck Burned to Death by Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path guerrillas poured gasoline on a pickup truck and set it ablaze Monday, killing four people inside, including two congressional candidates, police said. Also, a column of about 100 of the Maoist-inspired insurgents ambushed two army trucks carrying 50 soldiers on a main jungle highway Monday, killing three soldiers, according to police. The report said one rebel was killed in the firefight, along with two civilians in a truck passing near the scene. Another civilian in a car was wounded. Police said the civilians were hit by stray bullets. The morning battle took place near Las Vegas, a town 10 miles south of here. The report said police and army reinforcements were flown in by helicopters from bases in Tingo Maria, 200 miles northeast of Lima. In a separate incident, Shining Path rebels stopped a pickup truck carrying four people, doused it with gasoline and burned the occupants alive. Among the occupants of the vehicle were Marino Meza, a journalist, and Jose de la Torre, a doctor. Both were independent candidates for Congress in the April 8 elections. The four were returning home from a campaign meeting in Acomaya, a small town 30 miles southwest of here. The Mao-inspired group launched its armed insurgency 10 years ago in the southern highlands near Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima. The group now operates throughout the highlands and parts of the northeastern jungles. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Lituanian Radio Broadcasts Jammed Or Silenced
With AM-Lithuania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Broadcasts to North America by Radio Vilnius, voice of the Lithuanian capital, were either jammed or silenced Monday night, according to a frequent listener. The Radio Vilnius announcer suggested that the Soviet Ministry of Communications was doing the jamming, and asked listeners in Europe to tune to frequencies that are not relayed by Radio Moscow. Monday's broadcast, monitored in Washington, was barely audible beneath ``a superimposed droning sound, a classic jamming situation,'' said Paul Courson, amateur radio operator and anchor for AP Network News The short-wave broadcasts to North America normally are made on six different frequencies to ensure a good chance of reception in all areas of the continent. The broadcasts are normally relayed by Radio Moscow on its powerful transmitters. After the declaration of independence by the Lithuanian parliament on March 5, the English-language broadcasts were heard normally last week, said Courson. However, ``last night (Sunday night) they were missing altogether,'' and Monday night, were missing from five of the six scheduled frequencies, Courson said. The sixth frequency, 11.770 megahertz, carried the jammed broadcast. A Lithuanian-American group, the Lithuanian-American Community Inc., said in Arlington, Va., it had received reports that agents of the KGB, the Soviet secret police, entered radio and television stations in Lithuania but had not interfered with operations. Here is the transcript of Monday night's English broadcast, recorded by the AP. Though the annoucner begins by blaming Radio Moscow for the jamming, he later seems to blame the ministry. By custom in Lithuania and the Soviet Union, the announcer is not identified. ``For many years now, Radio Vilnius external service in Lithuanian and English languanges has been using the powerful system of relay stations in exterior parts of the Soviet Union. ``Thanks to these relay stations, our broadcasts could be heard in more than 50 countries of the world. ``Besides short-wave frequencies, Radio Vilnius programs in Lithuanian and English are also broadcast on medium wave, through relatively weak transmitters located in Lithuania. Their signal strength, however, is sufficient to be heard in northern Europe, West Germany, and Great Britain. As these transmitters are located in Lithuania, we advise all Radio Vilnius listeners in Europe to tune in to these medium-wave broadcasts. ``Today the leaders of the Lithuanian radio and TV networks and Radio Vilnius people have been getting in touch with high-level or ranking officials of Radio Moscow. It appears the blockade of Radio Vilnius broadcasts was a surprise to them, and they promised to clear up what the matter was. ``This suggests that perhaps the blockade of Radio Vilnius broadcasts abroad was not conducted by Radio Moscow, but rather by the Minister of Communications of the USSR. But so far, no answer from that ministry has been received.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Congressman Begins Prison Sentence in Wedtech Case
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Rep. Robert Garcia surrendered to a federal prison in Florida on Monday to begin serving a sentence for his role in the Wedtech Corp. scandal. On Jan. 19, a federal judge in New York sentenced Garcia, 58, to three years in prison, recommending his release on parole after six months. Garcia and his wife, Jane, were convicted Oct. 20 of extorting payoffs from Wedtech, a now-defunct defense contractor located in Garcia's former district in South Bronx. Mrs. Garcia was given the same sentence and is free pending an appeal. Garcia also is appealing, but decided to serve his sentence before the appeal, said his lawyer, Sarah Chapman. She said Garcia surrendered to the Eglin Federal Prison Camp at the Eglin Air Force Base near Pensacola. The prison warden's secretary, Donna Davis, confirmed that Garcia arrived at the prison Monday. Garcia, a six-term Democratic congressman, resigned after his conviction. A special election to fill his seat will be held Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Motion for Mistrial in Poindexter Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6th graf: ``In other,'' and grafs 18-20: ``Casey, who,'' with Casey's false denial that the document existed
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Monday denied a mistrial motion by John Poindexter that was triggered by a reference in open court to testimony Poindexter had given Congress under a grant of immunity. The information in the reference was ``not new at all,'' said the judge in Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial. With Rep. Lee Hamilton on the witness stand, prosecutor Dan Webb asked about a document, signed by then-President Reagan, indicating missiles had been sent to Iran in 1985 to try to win the release of Americans held in Lebanon. Had Poindexter ever reported destroying the document? Webb asked. ``He did,'' Hamilton said in front of the jury. In other testimony, Hamilton said the late CIA Director William Casey denied the very existence of the document in congressional testimony _ a denial that was not true and a denial that had not been known before. The congressman, co-chairman of a special congressional committee that investigated the Iran-Contra affair, was referring to Poindexter's July 1987 testimony to the committee, during which he said he tore up the document. No part of the case against Reagan's national security adviser may be derived from his testimony to Congress, given under a grant of immunity from prosecution. As soon as Hamilton answered the question on Monday, another prosecutor, Howard Pearl, stood up and Webb quickly said ``I see the problem.'' Webb rephrased the question, but Poindexter lawyer Richard Beckler later asked for a mistrial, saying that Hamilton had specifically been instructed not to refer to Poindexter's immunized testimony. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene denied the motion, saying that Oliver North testified last week that he watched Poindexter tear up the finding. Greene said Hamilton's testimony was ``cumulative rather than harmful.'' Beckler suggested the jury might not find North's testimony credible. But Greene also noted that ``both the government and the defense referred to tearing up of the finding'' in their opening statements to the jury. ``And you have great credibility,'' Greene told Beckler. The information about tearing up the finding ``is not new at all,'' Greene concluded. In November 1986, Hamilton had been chairman of the House Intelligence Committee that met with Poindexter to discuss U.S. arms sales to Iran. The congressman said the national security adviser made no mention of a U.S. role in the November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. The CIA-assisted delivery was authorized by the Reagan ``finding'' that Poindexter destroyed hours after testifying before the committee. Casey, who prepared the finding for Reagan, appeared with Poindexter before the committee. ``Do you remember Casey in that testimony actually telling you there was no finding for that 1985 shipment'' of Hawk missiles to Iran? Webb asked Hamilton. ``I do,'' replied Hamilton. Webb asked Hamilton, ``Do you recall whether Admiral Poindexter said he could reveal all the facts?'' ``Admiral Poindexter said ... President Reagan wanted to tell the full story,'' replied Hamilton. The finding that Poindexter destroyed depicted the U.S. role in Iran arms sales as a straight arms-for-hostages deal, the kind of arrangement the Reagan administration declared it would never allow. Poindexter told the Intelligence Committee members that the U.S. government didn't learn until January 1986 of the missile shipment, according to notes taken at the meeting by a congressional staffer. Hamilton said Poindexter read verbatim a January 1986 presidential finding that did not portray the Iran initiative as a straight trade of arms for hostages. Poindexter ``only told you about the January finding?'' asked Webb. Hamilton replied that had been the case. ``Did John Poindexter ever tell the committee that the U.S. government had been involved in Iran arms shipments before the date of this finding?'' asked Webb. ``No, he did not,'' answered Hamilton. ``John Poindexter, in the briefing session, did he ever tell about another presidential finding, one that was actually signed by the president in 1985 relating to U.S. involvement in another arms shipment?'' asked Webb. ``He did not,'' said Hamilton. Earlier, Hamilton testified that Poindexter endorsed false answers by his predecessor as national security adviser, Robert McFarlane, which denied that North was supplying the Contras with military advice or raising money for them. Poindexter sent a letter to Hamilton in the summer of 1986 referring to McFarlane's denials of the previous year. ``I understood that John Poindexter was ... restating the same denials we had from Mr. McFarlane ... there was no doubt in my mind about that,'' Hamilton said. Webb said North testified last week that McFarlane's answers were ``all false.'' Hamilton also testified that ``the system simply doesn't work'' if officials ``lie to one another.'' Asked by Webb whether ``John Poindexter or Oliver North ever had'' a right to lie to Congress, Hamilton replied, ``They did not.'' Does the system work if officials lie to Congress? asked Webb. ``The system simply doesn't work if we lie to one another in government,'' replied Hamilton.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Given Edge After Israeli Ultra-Orthodox Parties Split
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Shamir gain seen after tie shapes up over who will form new government. CHANGES byline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Israel TV said Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir holds the best chance of being tapped to form a new government after the ultra-Orthodox parties split Monday over backing his right-wing Likud bloc or the Labor Party. The religious parties hold the key votes on who will lead the government. The spiritual leaders of the ultra-Orthodox Shas, or Torah Guardians, and Torah Flag parties held a crucial meeting and decided to back Shamir, Israel radio said. Earlier Monday, leading rabbinical scholars of the small ultra-Orthodox party Agudat Israel decided to throw their support behind Shimon Peres' left-of-center Labor Party. Shas leader, Interior Minister Aryeh Deri, indicated Monday on army radio that Shas' support for Likud was conditional on acceptance of proposals of U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III for convening Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Likud's objections to Baker's proposals were what brought down Shamir's government last Thursday by a 60-55 no-confidence vote in the 120-seat Parliament. Israel TV said Monday's decisions by the ultra-Orthodox parties tied Likud and Labor with 60 seats each. It takes 61 to form a government. But the television said President Chaim Herzog now may well give Shamir the nod to form a government because he controls the largest faction in Parliament. Herzog is meeting with political leaders to chose who will form the next administration. He is expected to invite the Shas faction to his residence again Tuesday for clarification of who they support, an Israeli official said. Shas helped topple the government last Thursday. It said Sunday it was backing Likud, but did not recommend who should lead Likud in setting up a coalition. The Israeli official, who spoke on condition of not being identified, said Herzog could announce his decision by Tuesday night or early Wednesday. Herzog will base his decision on whoever has the best chance of forming a coalition government. Since a tie is reported, however, he could give the mandate to the leader of the largest faction in Parliament, which has been the practice in the past. Peres was initially expected to be Herzog's choice, but complications rose with growing splits and indecision in the religious camp over who to favor. Both large parties faced the difficulty of melding extreme right- or left-wing factions into an uneasy coalition with religious groups. Labor is Parliament's largest single faction with 39 seats. Likud has 35, but also controls a five-seat Liberal faction that it is trying to woo back into its ranks, making it the largest party. Transportation Minister Moshe Katzav of Likud maintained in remarks made on Israel TV that Likud remains the largest party since the Liberal breakaways still took part in all Likud functions. Rafi Edri, a former Labor minister, said on Israel TV that Labor still believes it will be able to win over Shas becaause only a Peres-led coalition could advance the peace process. Shas' spiritual leader, Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef, made a rare television appearance Sunday night and assailed Shamir's Middle East policies, saying they ``invited war and bloodshed upon Israel.'' ``How would I give an account standing in judgment before the Creator, for the blood spilled, without knowing I tried to avoid it?'' asked Yosef, who is also a former chief rabbi of Israel's Sephardic community _ Jews of Middle East origin. While its abstention in the Thursday vote gave victory to Labor, Shas has had a steady alliance with Likud since Shas was founded in 1984. Agudat Israel, a party founded as an anti-Zionist movement in Eastern Europe in the 19th century, is traditionally neutral on foreign policy. It usually backs the party that pledges more support for religious institutions. Apprehensions are growing in both Labor and Likud that a prolonged stalemate could force Parliament to move up national elections now scheduled for 1992. Shamir remains caretaker premier until a new government is formed or elections are held. Israeli law allows a maximum six weeks for whichever party leader is chosen to form a new government.

DOC.HEAD: British Press Ahead with War Crimes Probe
DOC.TEXT: The government said Monday it is setting up a special war crimes unit of police officers to investigate alleged World War II atrocities committed by people now living in Britain. Home Secretary David Waddington said the British police had never investigated war crimes before and the unit would work in the same way the police investigated ``any other criminal activities.'' He said police, legal authorities and the courts would have the responsibility for prosecutions, trials and convictions and the government would not interfere. Waddington made his announcement in the House of Commons, which voted 273-60 Monday to approve in principal legislation that would make prosecutions possible despite the long lapse of time since the war ended in 1945. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher backs the bill, which has to go through further procedures before it becomes law. When the legislation was introduced earlier this month, government officials said the first trial might be held before the end of this year. ``It is so long since the war and the instinctive wish of most of us is to get on with our lives in peace and not to rake over the past, let alone the pasts of men who have lived peacefully in this country since before some members of Parliament were born,'' Waddington said. ``But sometimes one is brought face to face with facts that cannot be buried, with deeds so terrible that they cannot be forgotten. And as long as one of those responsible survives, the world will cry out for justice.'' The Simon Wiesenthal Center, based in Los Angeles, gave lists of suspects to the British government in 1986 during controversy over the World War II role of Austrian President Kurt Waldheim when he was a German Army officer. A British inquiry last year exonerated Waldheim of complicity in the executions of British prisoners of war in the Balkans where he was serving. A separate government-ordered inquiry said there was sufficient evidence to prosecute three suspects living in Britain. It also urged the investigation of 124 others who came to Britain with thousands of displaced persons after the war. British news reports have said all the suspects in Britain are from the Soviet republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Ukraine, where the Nazis recruited killer squads and massacred thousands of people. New war crimes trials are opposed by Lord Shawcross, who as Sir Hartley Shawcross was British chief prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials of leading Nazi war criminals. ``To raise all these issues and spend an enormous amount of money to convict three or four old men and send them to die in a prison hospital is counter-productive and not worthwhile,'' he said in statement.
