DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for March 12-19:
DOC.HEAD: Family Appeals and Prayer Mark Fifth Anniversary of Anderson's Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: Friends and family of Terry Anderson marked the fifth anniversary of his Beirut kidnapping March 16 as Lebanese television stations played a poignant videotape of the daughter he's never seen. In the tape, Anderson's 4-year-old daughter, Sulome, shows off her ballet dancing and delivers a touching message for her father and his captors, saying, ``I love you, Daddy, come home. Please come home.'' The girl appears wearing a green coat and riding a bicycle given to her at Christmas in Anderson's name. ``I got the bike for Christmas, Daddy. Thank you,'' said Sulome. She was born 83 days after Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was seized by a pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem faction in Beirut. Anderson, 42, is the longest-held of the American hostages in Lebanon. All told, 18 Westerners are believed to be captives there. In a letter published by seven Beirut newspapers, Sulome's mother, Madeleine Bassil, told Anderson that she and the girl also feel like hostages. ``We are in as much captivity, Terry, only our living space is bigger here and it's shared by millions,'' the letter said. Relatives of the American hostages gathered for a commemorative ceremony in Lafayette Park, across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. In New York, friends and colleagues attended a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Yellow ribbons fluttered from trees, signs and poles in Anderson's hometown of Batavia, N.Y., and former hostages chained themselves to a tree in Paris to protest Anderson's captivity. In Tokyo, members of the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan raised symbolically empty glasses in a toast to Anderson. The worldwide commemorative schedule included similar salutes at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C., and at the Association de la Presse International in Brussels. Anderson was assigned to the AP Tokyo bureau from January 1977 to August 1981. He has been held in windowless rooms in the slums of Beirut, sometimes chained and blindfolded, former hostages say. During Anderson's five years of captivity, his father and brother have died. ``Who would have ever thought in their wildest nightmares that this would last so long?'' said his sister, Peggy Say, who has traveled to the Middle East and Europe trying to free her brother.
DOC.HEAD: No Basis for `Wave of Speculation,' Bush Says
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on March 16 tried to dampen speculation that the Western hostages in Lebanon might be released soon. Bush, after a private meeting with Terry Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, said he had no information about a release of the captives and didn't want to needlessly raise the hopes of their families. A day earlier he told the National Newspaper Association: ``I wish I could tell you that there was a serious immediate effort that would pay off, but that isn't the case.'' Bush said he was perplexed by the ``wave of speculation'' this month that hostages might be freed. Hopes were raised in part by statements attributed to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani that he would like to see the hostages freed.
DOC.HEAD: Iraq Hangs Reporter Accused of Spying
DOC.TEXT: Iraq ignored international appeals March 15 and hanged a London-based newspaper reporter who was arrested near a military complex and convicted of spying for Britain and Israel. Britain recalled its ambassador after the execution of 31-year-old Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian-born journalist who was working for the British weekly The Observer and traveling on British documents. Bazoft was arrested in September near a plant where ballistic missiles are reportedly being developed. He was investigating reports that hundreds of people had died in an explosion. Daphne Parish, a British nurse who drove him to the military complex, was also arrested and sentenced to 15 years in prison for complicity. Donald Trelford, the editor of The Observer, denied that Bazoft was a spy and called President Saddam Hussein a barbarian. The execution, which followed a secret trial, came despite pleas for clemency from Britain, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Amnesty International, the European Community and international press groups. After the execution, it was disclosed in Britain that Bazoft had been convicted of bank robbery there in 1981. But British officials said his criminal record did not diminish the London government's outrage over the execution.
DOC.HEAD: Report: Journalist Slayings Doubled in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Rising social and political unrest contributed to the killings of at least 53 journalists in 1989, more than double the number slain because of their work in the previous year, a study released March 15 says. Two-thirds of the killings occurred in Latin America, including 14 in El Salvador alone, the Committee to Protect Journalists reported. It labeled the slayings ``censorship by death.'' The report was released the same day Iraq hanged Farzad Bazoft, a London-based reporter accused of spying. Bazoft had been investigating reports of mass deaths in an explosion at a military complex. Another group, Freedom House, has put the number of journalists killed last year at 73. The two monitors could not explain the difference but noted that each uses its own sources of information and methods of confirmation.
DOC.HEAD: Official Daily Accuses Western Journalists of Biased Reporting
DOC.TEXT: China's leading daily newspaper on March 16 accused Western journalists of biased reporting and rejected their complaints that they have been followed and harassed by undercover police. The official People's Daily said some foreign reporters ``distort facts, spread rumors, maliciously attack the Chinese government and deliberately jeopardize the security of the country.'' Correspondents from nearly a dozen countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, said they have been followed by plainclothes police in recent weeks. They said police intimidation has interfered with their work and that their Chinese contacts have been questioned by security officials and told not to meet foreign reporters.
DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian News Agency Chief Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: The government fired Boyan Traikov from his longtime job as director general of the state news agency BTA on March 13 and also dismissed his deputy, Nencho Hranov. It named Georgi Todorov, 56, a veteran foreign correspondent and editor-in-chief of BTA's international news department, to succeed Traikov. Traikov was a trusted ally of Todor Zhivkov, ousted as Communist Party chief last November, and up to last year was also a member of the party's policy-making Central Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Steinle Resigns as UPI President
DOC.TEXT: Paul Steinle, president of United Press International, has resigned to form a broadcast production company, UPI Chairman Earl W. Brian announced March 16. The announcement said Steinle will form Steinle Communications, which will provide program development and production services with emphasis on news and information programming. The company will serve media and videocassette markets, Steinle said. Brian said UPI Vice Chairman Joseph K. Taussig will assume the duties of president until a successor is found. Steinle, 51, has directed restructuring of UPI operations since February 1988. He joined UPI management after serving as president of Financial News Network and its subsidiary, Data Broadcasting Corp. UPI is owned by Infotechnology Inc., an information and communications company, which also owns Financial News Network.
DOC.HEAD: Press Group Lists Administration Restrictions on Information
DOC.TEXT: A journalists' group marked Freedom of Information Day March 16 with a report listing almost 100 instances of what it said were Bush administration attempts to control news coverage. The statement by the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, a nonprofit research and service organization, is the group's first such study of the current administration. ``Our report illustrates the Bush administration's obsession with secrecy and leaks,'' Executive Director Jane E. Kirtley said. ``It chronicles the activities of a White House bent on orchestrating and controlling the presentation of news.'' The 42-page list included the exclusion of the press pool from early combat in Panama and the Pentagon's refusal to release combat footage shot by the military.
DOC.HEAD: Mozambique Expels Portuguese Reporter Over News Account
DOC.TEXT: A Portuguese journalist working for Voice of America was ordered to leave Mozambique on March 16 because of a story he wrote, and the VOA said he departed for France. The government had ordered Antonoio Mateus out of this southeast African country, a former Portuguese possession, within 24 hours for writing a story it said damaged Mozambique's image and constituted ``active disinformation.'' Information Minister Teodato Hunguana also said the story, filed to LUSA, the Portuguese news agency, and the U.S.-based radio network ``has no basis in fact.'' But other government departments acknowledged that elements of the story were true. According to Hunguana, Mateus filed a story March 12 saying military helicopters flew over the capital the previous Saturday and that on Monday special police units patrolled the city following ``rumors about the launching of a wave of protest against the cost of living.'' The Mozambican national news agency AIM quoted an official source as saying it is routine for air force helicopters to fly over the capital. Deputy VOA director Bob Coonrod said Mozambican authorities were offended because Mateus refused to divulge the name of a senior police officer he quoted anonymously in his account.
DOC.HEAD: Paper, Teamsters Resolve Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Pittsburgh Press Co. and its largest union resolved their dispute over terms of a new contract March 14, averting a possible disruption in delivery of the city's two major daily newspapers. An agreement between management and Teamsters Local 211 was reached after a nine-hour negotiating session at the offices of the National Labor Relations Board, said Gerald Kobell, NLRB district director. The agreement will result in the reduction by attrition and retirement of about 60 jobs, as the company had sought, Kobell said. Nearly all of the reductions will be in the transportation and circulation departments. No layoffs will occur. The agreement also permits union members to apply to the company's major medical insurer for reimbursement of out-of-pocket expenses for prescription drugs, as the union had asked, Kobell said. The labor dispute had threatened the delivery of both the afternoon Press and the morning Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. The Pittsburgh Press Co. publishes the afternoon paper and handles production and distribution of the separately owned Post-Gazette.
DOC.HEAD: Black Weekly Will Appeal to Entrepreneurs
DOC.TEXT: The founder of a new weekly newspaper for black entrepreneurs says he expects the paper to eventually do as well as a sister publication in Portland, Ore., that has a circulation of 20,000. Bernard Foster started the Skanner this month with a profile of Norm Rice, the city's first black mayor. Foster founded a newspaper with the same name in Portland 15 years ago and has been co-owner of the Northwest Dispatch in Tacoma, Wash., since 1985. In a city whose population is 12 percent black, Foster faces stiff competition for ad revenue from two other black weeklies, The Seattle Medium and The Facts, where he worked previously as an advertising salesman. Foster said he expects to lose money initially. Fitzgerald Beaver, owner of The Facts, said he wishes Foster well but questions whether the city can support three black papers.
DOC.HEAD: Multimedia Sells Its Two Florida Papers to Stauffer Communications
DOC.TEXT: Multimedia Inc. announced March 13 it will sell its two newspapers in Florida to Stauffer Communications Inc. for an undisclosed price. The purchase agreement for The News Chief of Winter Haven, a daily, and The Auburndale Star, a weekly, is expected to be completed by April 1, officials said. The News Chief is an afternoon paper with a circulation of about 20,000. Donald R. Hatley will stay as publisher until the transaction is completed and then will remain with Multimedia in a corporate role. Kenneth C. Bronson, vice president of newspapers for Stauffer, said he would announce a new publisher for each of the papers after the sale. He said no other personnel changes are planned.
DOC.HEAD: Chardon Newspaper Remaining with Thomson, Editor Says
DOC.TEXT: The Geauga Times Leader will remain under the ownership of the Thomson Newspaper Corp., Walt Fishon, managing editor for the newspaper, said March 12. In January, Ingersoll Publications Co. announced that it would acquire the Times Leader as part of a deal with Thomson. The agreement called for Thomson to transfer ownership of the Times Leader to Ingersoll and pay about $250 million for five daily papers and a chain of weeklies. While negotiations for the Times Leader have been called off, talks between the two companies over the sale of Ingersoll papers continue, the Chardon paper reported Friday.
DOC.HEAD: Telegram & Gazette Announces Move
DOC.TEXT: The Telegram & Gazette announced March 13 it is moving printing and distribution operations to a 28-acre site in the Millbury Industrial Park. The site just outside Worcester includes a 70,000-square-foot building. The newspaper hopes to begin publishing there within two years. Peter Thieriot, publisher of the Telegram & Gazette, said the newspaper tried to avoid moving out of Worcester and had considered 15 sites in the city during the past eight years, but none proved suitable. No decision has been made about whether to move editorial, advertising and other departments. The Telegram & Gazette is owned by The Chronicle Publishing Co. of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Sports Daily Plans To Increase Distribution
DOC.TEXT: The National says its circulation and ad sales are on target, and that it will boost distribution by 40 percent soon by expanding in its first three markets: New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Publisher Peter Price said on March 15 the sports daily is selling about 200,000 of the 250,000 copies it prints every day, matching the target set for the paper. The National is distributed Sunday through Friday and plans are to add six to 12 more cities by Dec. 31, when Price hopes a half-million copies will be distributed every day. Advertisers have been told it will start printing a second edition with a deadline three hours earlier than normal so papers can be distributed the next morning on newsstands farther away from the centers of its three markets. Media analysts say circulation confirmation from independent auditing agencies is not yet available, leaving advertisers to rely on the paper's word and anecdotal evidence of how things have been going. Andrew White, a spokesman for Philip Morris Inc., which advertises Marlboro and Parliament cigarettes in The National, said he wants to see if the paper is a truly national publication and whether circulation falls off on certain days of the week. ``The jury is still out on readership,'' said Joseph Ostrow, worldwide media director for the advertising agency Foote Cone Belding Communications. The number of advertising pages in the newspaper has been fairly light, dropping off from double digits in the first week to an average of four to five pages a day recently. But Price said that too was expected.
DOC.HEAD: Campaign Keeps Daily Tabloid in Business _ At Least for Now
DOC.TEXT: A daily newspaper that made a last-ditch effort to stay in business by appealing for suscribers and attacking its larger competitor has begun to attract new business, its publisher said March 12. Green Bay News-Chronicle Publisher Frank Wood said the campaign has attracted 900 new suscribers since last fall and may have pushed advertising up as much as 50 percent in one month. ``We are still alive. It is an honest-to-God newspaper war and we are badly outnumbered, but I think we still have a chance,'' he said. Wood said last November that his 11,000-circulation morning tabloid was doomed unless he found more subscribers and advertisers to offset losses growing to $500,000 a year. His appeal came with a front-page attack on the Green Bay Press-Gazette, the city's larger afternoon paper. Wood accused the Press-Gazette of ``trying to destroy us'' and turn Green Bay into a one-newspaper town. The publisher of the Press-Gazette, an afternoon broadsheet with about 56,000 circulation, called Wood's attack ``a very unique competitive move.'' Michael Gage, Press-Gazette publisher, said his paper had lost 94 subscriptions directly in the battle with the News-Chronicle. As for advertising, there has been a small impact, but ``I couldn't give a dollars- and-cents figure,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Residents Rally To Help Newspaper Down on Its Luck
DOC.TEXT: Faithful readers of the weekly Oak Cliff Tribune kicked in videocassette recorders, furniture and other items in a garage sale to benefit the newspaper after a fire destroyed all its publishing equipment. ``It's just a small weekly,'' Publisher Joseph Whitney said of the 86-year-old Dallas newspaper. ``But what the community has done to put it back on its feet makes us more appreciative of what we have.'' Area service clubs organized a sale at a YMCA branch March 10 that drew 200 people. ``We raised $800 in six hours, more than we ever dreamed of,'' said Robbie Hazelbaker, one of the organizers. ``We also sold 50 subscriptions to the Tribune.'' The newspaper's staff of eight has not missed an issue since the Jan. 31 fire, which destroyed the building where the paper had been produced. ``After the fire, we are more aware of its importance,'' Whitney said. ``People want a newspaper that has become almost an institution here.''
DOC.HEAD: Condoms in Paper Draw Only a Few Negative Responses
DOC.TEXT: A special issue of the University of Arkansas newspaper about AIDS that included a condom prompted the newspaper's faculty adviser to quit, but supporters outnumbered critics 10-1, the editor said March 15. Student Ray Minor, editor of The Traveler, said he had received five letters or other complaints, compared with 50 in support of the March 14 special edition, which addressed misconceptions about AIDS. Journalism professor Bob Douglas resigned as adviser to the paper and Managing Editor Anne Moreland had her name removed from the staff box of the special edition. Douglas, a former managing editor of the Arkansas Gazette, said he resigned to make an impact on the students. ``I'm opposed to this stunt journalism,'' he said. ``My feeling is (Minor) could have made a more effective statement without resorting to this gimmickry.''
DOC.HEAD: Promotional Campaign Includes Cash for Reporters
DOC.TEXT: Seeking to get the word out about its latest promotion _ soft drink cans stuffed with prizes _ Coca-Cola Co. on March 12 sent 200 reporters the real thing: samples containing $5 bills. Newsrooms are frequent recipients of promotional items sent from companies trying to get publicity. But cash from a major corporation is unusual. The ``Magic Summer'' campaign to promote Coca-Cola Classic will include 750,000 randomly distributed cans, which appear to be regular cans of Coke but when opened reveal a mechanism holding up to $200 in cash or a certificate for other prizes. Bob Bertini, a spokesman for Coca-Cola USA, said the company sent the reporters cans with $5 bills _ the smallest denomination in the campaign _ merely to demonstrate the promotion. ``We sent it to a very small group of national writers. The reporters can't write about it without seeing it,'' Bertini said. Many news organizations have policies against reporters receiving gifts of value from news sources. Bertini said the company is urging reporters to donate the money to charity.
DOC.HEAD: Photographer Gets Suspect _ and a Photo
DOC.TEXT: A photographer for The Clarion-Ledger helped police bag a suspect in three armed robberies _ and got pictures in the bargain _ after watching a man bolt from a convenience store who matched the description she heard on a police scanner. Photographer Michele Stapleton heard the report of two convenience store holdups as she drove to work March 12. She spotted a car matching the description of the getaway vehicle, followed it and called police when it stopped at another store, which was also robbed. James Dean Coker, 29, was arrested on three counts of armed robbery. ``When the policemen came, he was getting in his car, as if to leave,'' Stapleton said. ``The police just pulled up behind him and he took off running.'' Officers apprehended him about a block away, as Stapleton snapped photographs for the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Company Rejects Stock Request
DOC.TEXT: Directors of the parent of the St. Petersburg Times on March 14 rejected a demand from a minority investor group led by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass to call in the company's preferred stock. ``We decided not to take a course of action that would disadvantage the Poynter Institute and Nelson Poynter's widow, who are beneficiaries of the majority stock, for the sole advantage of a minority shareholder,'' said Andrew Barnes, chairman of the publishing company and editor of the newspaper. Bass' group has been trying to take over Times Publishing Co., owner of the daily St. Petersburg Times and Congressional Quarterly. The Poynter Institute controls a majority of the publishing company's stock and receives 83 percent of the dividends, which are used to run the non-profit journalism school. Disgruntled heirs of Nelson Poynter, who ran the Times for 30 years, sold their interest to Bass two years ago, saying they weren't getting a fair share of the dividends. A recall of preferred stock would increase that share for the Bass group.
DOC.HEAD: Court Hears Arguments in Case Against Twin Cities Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Supreme Court was asked March 13 to decide whether the state's two largest daily newspapers are liable for damages for publishing the name of a source who was promised anonymity by reporters. Attorneys for the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch and the Star Tribune of Minneapolis asked the justices to overturn a Hennepin County District Court jury's $200,000 damage award to Dan Cohen. An attorney for Cohen, meanwhile, asked the court to reinstate the jury's $500,000 punitive damage award, which was overturned last September by the Minnesota Court of Appeals. The dispute began in 1982 when Cohen gave reporters copies of court documents showing that Marlene Johnson, who then was seeking her first term as lieutenant governor, had been convicted of shoplifting 12 years earlier. Johnson's conviction was vacated in 1971 with no sentence. She was elected as Gov. Rudy Perpich's running mate in 1982, re-elected in 1986, and is running with Perpich again this year. Cohen was working for rival gubernatorial candidate Wheelock Whitney when he provided the information about Johnson on the condition that he not be identified. Reporters gave him that assurance, but newspaper editors decided to name Cohen as the source of the documents. Editors testified that they named Cohen because they believed the public had a right to know the information came from an Independent-Republican activist. Cohen's lawsuit said he lost his advertising agency job because of the resulting publicity. The Court of Appeals threw out the lower court's punitive damage award but held that the First Amendment does not bar a breach of contract claim in such circumstances. Attorney John Borger, representing the Minneapolis newspaper, told the Supreme Court that First Amendment free press considerations, not contract law, should govern the case. He said the newspapers had to identify Cohen. ``What the public had to understand was how close to the Whitney campaign the source of the information was,'' Borger said. The Supreme Court took the case under advisement and is expected to rule in a few months.
DOC.HEAD: Court Orders Hearing on Sealed Pre-Trial Records
DOC.TEXT: The Mississippi Supreme Court on March 14 ordered a trial court to hear complaints from two newspapers that they were improperly barred from pre-trial proceedings in a murder case. The Clarion-Ledger of Jackson and The Commercial Appeal of Memphis, Tenn., have sought to open court records and transcripts of a closed pre-trial hearing that was held March 9-10. The records were ordered sealed by a local judge before the case was assigned for trial. The Supreme Court referred the dispute over the sealing of records in the case to the trial court after lawyers for the papers asked that the trial be halted until they could fight the secrecy order. The court ordered Circuit Judge Elzy Smith of Marks to conduct a hearing ``as expeditiously as possible.'' Smith said the hearing would be held on March 26. Anthony Carr, 24, of Clarksdale and Robert Simon Jr., 26, of Memphis have pleaded innocent to charges they killed Carl Webster Parker, his wife, and two children on Feb. 2. Authorities said the family apparently walked in on a burglary and the family's home was set afire to cover up the killings.
DOC.HEAD: Guild Approves Agreement With Post-Dispatch
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper Guild members on March 19 overwhelmingly approved a three-year contract with the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and called off a 12-day-old byline strike. Members of Guild Local 47 had been working without a contract since the old one expired Feb. 28. The local, which represents reporters, some editors, photographers, adverstising sales personnel, business workers and clerks, voted 365 to 69 for the new agreement. Reporters and photographers had withheld bylines and photo credits since March 7 to protest an earlier, tougher offer from the company. The contract calls for a 4 percent pay raise each year, a drug-testing policy, a clause prohibiting strikes or lockouts, and a $600 contract-signing bonus for each member, payable by April 13. It also calls for 21 employees to be exempted from Guild jurisdiction, instead of the 26 exemptions the company asked for last week. The contract gives the paper the right to hire free-lancers to cover some news events and to hire advertising salespeople to sell ads on a commission-only basis for the paper's zoned editions. The Guild was the sixth union to reach an agreement with the Post-Dispatch. Five remain without a contract.
DOC.HEAD: Electricians Union Studying Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The electricians union at the Daily News is looking over a three-year contract proposal, labor and company officials said March 14. John T. Sloan, the newspaper's vice president for human resources, said Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers was not one of the unions the News targeted because of alleged featherbedding and overmanning. The contracts of all 10 unions at the paper expire March 30. The News says it wants revisions in order to become profitable and invest up to $500 million to build modern, color plants. The unions say the News wants to break them in order to become profitable enough for its parent in Chicago, the Tribune Co., to sell or close the paper. Christopher Erikson, a business representative for Local 3, said the union was studying the proposal and that the next bargaining session was not scheduled until March 22. In another development, a Daily News union leader said March 16 he will sue the newspaper for $5 million for what he described as a libelous personal attack by Sloan. George McDonald, president of both the mailers union and the Allied Printing Trades Council, accuses the executive of willful defamation. Sloan called the threat of a lawsuit frivolous and ``another publicity stunt.'' The exchange apparently was prompted by a statement that Sloan issued under the headline ``McDonald Sells Mailers Out.'' Sloan said in the statement that McDonald had systematically ``given away work traditionally performed by his own union to the drivers union.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Hear Administration Appeal on Freedom of Information
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on March 19 refused to hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at making it costlier for an organization called the National Security Archive to compile information. The archive is a non-profit organization that collects information on national security and foreign policy and makes it available to the public in various ways. It has filed thousands of FOIA requests for government records. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that gives the archive the same preferential status under the Freedom of Information Act that other news organizations enjoy. The administration claimed the archive should not have the status of a news organization for purposes of FOIA requests. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last year that the archive should be treated as a news media representative under the FOIA because it publishes some of the information it gathers itself. News media representatives that make FOIA requests reimburse the government for the cost of copying the documents, but not for the major additional cost of searching for the records. If the archive did not have the status of a news organization, it would have to reimburse the government for search costs. The archive is headed by Scott Armstrong, a former Washington Post reporter and co-author of ``The Brethren,'' a 1979 book that provided a behind-the-scenes look at the Supreme Court. The organization published a book entitled ``The Chronology: The Documented Day-by-Day Account of the Secret Military Assistance to Iran and the Contras'' and another called ``El Salvador _ The Making of U.S. Policy, 1977-1984.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Switching From Afternoon to Morning
DOC.TEXT: The Southeast Missourian, which has been an afternoon newspaper since its funding in 1904, will convert to morning circulation beginning June 4. The decision to switch follows months of study and an overwhelming national trend away from afternoon deliveries, Publisher Gary Rust said in an article in March 18 editions. Similar-sized daily newspapers in the region _ including those in Carbondale, Ill., Paducah, Ky., and Jonesboro, Ark. _ have made the conversion to morning delivery in recent years, Rust said. The Southeast Missourian, which publishes Monday through Friday and Sunday morning, has a daily circulation of 17,000 and a Sunday circulation of 21,700.
DOC.HEAD: Turner Cautions Against `F' Word
DOC.TEXT: Employees of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. better not use the ``F'' word or their employer will be dipping into their paychecks. The word is ``foreign,'' and TBS Board Chairman and President Ted Turner says using it thwarts his company's policy of promoting greater global understanding. Turner has instituted a company-wide standard requiring the use of the word ``international'' instead of ``foreign'' in all written and verbal references. The company, which owns Cable News Network, has had a policy against use of the word for the past 1{ years, but Turner amended it the week of March 12 to include fines for slipups. ``The word `foreign' implies something unfamiliar and creates a perception of misunderstanding,'' Turner said in a memorandum to employees. ``In contrast, `international' means `among nations' and promotes a sense of unity.'' Employees who use the word ``foreign'' will be warned on the first offense. Future slipups will mean a fine of $50, or $100 for managers. All fines will be donated to the United Nations Children's Fund, the company said.
DOC.HEAD: Clash With Cuba Over U.S. Broadcasts Looms
DOC.TEXT: TV Marti, the Voice of America's television invasion of Cuba, is expected to begin testing this month and Cuban officials are threatening retaliation that could affect U.S. commercial broadcasters. Cuba regards the prospect of U.S. news shows, sitcoms and soap operas as a blatant intrusion on national sovereignty _ or ``tele-aggression,'' as President Fidel Castro calls it. Ramon Sanchez Parodi, a vice foreign minister, says Cuba may curtail travel and telephone communications between Cuba and the United States. Another possibility is that Cuba, with the use of high-powered trnasmitters, will interfere with U.S. radio broadcasts over a huge area west of the Mississippi. Cuban officials argue the proposed station violates U.N. agreements that protect local broadcasting systems from outside interference.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Agrees to Sell Majority Interest in Cleveland TV Station
DOC.TEXT: The National Broadcasting Co. said March 16 it had agreed to sell a majority interest in its Cleveland television station WKYC-TV to Multimedia Inc., which would be making its first major purchase since undertaking a $1.1 billion recapitalization in 1985. Terms of the sale and the size of the stake being sold were not disclosed. Multimedia, which owns four television stations and has interests in newspapers, radio, television programming and cable TV, would assume complete responsibility for managing and operating the station. WKYC-TV serves the nation's 11th-largest TV market and would be Multimedia's biggest TV property.
DOC.HEAD: Pro Basketball Network Formed
DOC.TEXT: The National Basketball Association and PIA Radio Sports will create an NBA Radio Network providing exclusive national radio coverage starting next season. Commissioner David Stern made the announcement March 14 along with Brad Saul, president of the Chicago-based PIA. The four-year agreement calls for a regular-season game of the week, plus coverage of the All-Star game and as many as 31 playoff contests, including all of the conference finals and league finals. The network also will broadcast the draft and lottery. The NBA's current agreement with ABC Radio expires after this season's final round.
DOC.HEAD: ABC's ``World News'' Wins Ratings
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``World News Tonight'' led the news ratings for the ninth consecutive week, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates released March 13. ``NBC Nightly News'' and the ``CBS Evening News'' tied for second place. For the week that ended March 9, the ABC program averaged an 11.5 rating, up 0.4 point from the previous week. NBC's broadcast and CBS's, which has been slumping in the ratings, each averaged 9.7. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Former GOP Media Adviser Assails CBS News President for Andy Rooney Affair
DOC.TEXT: Roger Ailes, President Bush's top media adviser when Bush was running for president, fired several verbal salvoes March 14 at CBS News President David Burke for the latter's short-lived suspension of Andy Rooney. Ailes called the suspension ``outrageous'' and said Burke was ``an ex-image consultant'' whose last job ``that was worth anything was trying to cover up Chappaquidick for Ted Kennedy.'' That was a reference to the controversial 1969 car accident that claimed the life of a young secretary, Mary Jo Kopechne. She was the only passenger in the car driven by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. Burke, a top Kennedy aide at the time of the accident, didn't respond to Ailes' remarks. Ailes' comments were made during a taping of John McLaughlin's talk show, ``McLaughlin,'' on CNBC, the NBC-owned cable service.
DOC.HEAD: Turner NFL Package on TNT
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting and the National Football League agreed March 14 to broadcast eight NFL games each of the next four years on the TNT cable channel. TNT will televise three preseason games each season, along with games the first nine weeks of the regular season in 1990, '92 and '93. It will do eight games in the first eight weeks of 1991. The channel is available to 43 million households.
DOC.HEAD: Tale of Announcer Hired From Billboard a Hoax, Station Admits
DOC.TEXT: A local radio station's program director admitted March 12 that his tale of hiring an unemployed draftsman who advertised his job search on a Boston billboard was a hoax. Ron Valeri, programming director for radio station WAAF, said he and others at the station lied in a bid to outdo a local radio competitor. Valeri said the publicity stunt, which garnered national attention, ran amok. ``We did definitely lose control ... This thing got away from us,'' he said. Valeri and his new employee, Bill Whiteman, told interviewers from various local and national news organizations that the disc jockey was hired because of his eye-catching plea on a Boston billboard: ``Help! I Need A Job!'' Actually, Whiteman was already on the payroll when the billboard went up, Valeri said.
DOC.HEAD: Thieves Tie Up Disc Jockey, Rob Station
DOC.TEXT: Fans of WAVF-FM pitched in with tapes, records and CDs after robbers tied up a disc jockey early March 12 and made off with all the station's music. Announcer Michael L. Green was not hurt in the robbery, though he lost a gold watch and $143, and the station lost 1,500 compact discs and some stereo equipment. The station was off the air for 1{ hours until Green, bound and gagged, knocked the receiver off a telephone and used his nose to dial police, who traced the call. Green said three men stopped him in a parking lot near the station about 4 a.m. as he walked to his car to get some change. They asked him for some station bumper stickers, and when he suggested they return during the day, they forced their way into the station.
DOC.HEAD: Television Photographer Shot While Covering Storm Damage
DOC.TEXT: A television cameraman photographing severe weather was shot and critically wounded March 13. Police arrested four suspects but said they knew of no motive. Bill Merickel, a photographer for Oklahoma City station KWTV-TV, had stopped at an intersection with reporter Dave Balute when someone fired two shots into their van from a car, said Rich Buchanan, a spokesman for the station. Merickel, who was driving, was hit once in the chest. Balute was not hurt. The suspects' car left the scene, and was pursued by a second KWTV van, which contacted police by radio. The four suspects were arrested after a short chase. The shooting happened about 30 miles south of Oklahoma City. Merickel's condition had improved to fair three days after the attack.
DOC.HEAD: Landmark Announces Executive Changes
DOC.TEXT: Landmark Communications on March 13 announced the appointment of Robert D. Benson as president and publisher of The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star. Benson, president and publisher of the Greensboro (N.C.) News & Record, will have responsibility for all operations and departments of the Norfolk newspapers, Landmark president Richard F. Barry III said. Benson will succeed Carl Mangum as president and will take over publishing duties from Barry, who plans to devote full time to his duties as Landmark's chief executive. Barry also announced new posts for Donald Patterson and Frank Batten Jr. Now vice president and business manager of The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star, Patterson will become executive vice president of Landmark with responsibility for overseeing the corporate staff. Batten, director of marketing and associate publisher of the newspapers, will become vice president and associate publisher.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Association Elects New Officers
DOC.TEXT: John R. Hooper of Guy Gannett Publishing Co. in Portland, Maine, was elected president of the New England Newspaper Association on March 15. Other officers elected at the annual winter meeting of the publishers association included Albert K. Sherman Jr. of The Newport (R.I.) Daily News, first vice president; David T. Lucey, of the Meriden (Conn.) Record, second vice president; and Paul Rixon of The Attleboro Sun Chronicle, secretary-treasurer. The association also elected three new members to the board of governors: Richard Feeney, Norwich (Conn.) Bulletin; Peter H. Gamage, Lynn Daily Evening Item, and Robert H. Foster, Foster's Daily Democrat of Dover, N.H.
DOC.HEAD: Hobbs Interim Publisher Named
DOC.TEXT: Maynard Woodhatch, an executive of the Shearman Newspaper Group, was named interim publisher of the Hobbs News-Sun on March 12, replacing George W. Moore. Moore had been publisher since September 1988. Woodhatch, of Lake Charles, La., is assistant to Hugh Shearman, president of the newspaper group of which the News-Sun is a member. Shearman said Woodhatch would serve in the position until a permanent publisher is named. The newspaper group has headquarters in Lake Charles, where Woodhatch is associate publisher of the Lake Charles American Press. Woodhatch, who also is secretary-treasurer of Shearman Newspapers, has been with the Shearman organization for 35 years.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Names New Director of Human Resources
DOC.TEXT: Luis Lewin has been appointed Director of Human Resource Operations for the New York Daily News, the newspaper announced March 15. Lewin formerly held a similar post at the Chicago Tribune. The newspaper also announced that editorial page editor Michael Pakenham is taking a leave of absence for several months to work as executive editor of the Sunday Correspondent, a new British newspaper. The Sunday Correspondent is partly owned by the Tribune Company, which also owns the Daily News. The News said Pakenham would remain ``in overall charge (of the editorial page) through periodic visits.'' Daily direction of the page will be assumed by chief editorial writer Robert W. Laird.
DOC.HEAD: New York Newsday Names New Editors
DOC.TEXT: New York Newsday announced on March 15 that Richard Esposito has been named city editor. He fills the vacancy created last year when James Hairston left to become city editor at the New York Daily News. The newspaper also announced that Joseph Demma, 46, will be Brooklyn-Queens editor, a new position. Esposito has worked as a reporter and served as police bureau chief for the newspaper. Before coming to New York Newsday four years ago, he worked for the New York Post, the Daily News and The Philadelphia Bulletin. Demma started at Newsday in 1965 and has worked as a reporter covering numerous topics as well as serving as investigations editor and Suffolk County editor. He was part of a team of reporters awarded a Pulitzer Prize in 1973 for Newsday's series, ``The Heroin Trail.''
DOC.HEAD: Cox Newspapers Names Successor to Retired VP of Operations
DOC.TEXT: Minor J. ``Buddy'' Ward, senior vice president of operations for Cox Newspapers, has retired and will be succeeded by James A. Cooper, the company announced March 15. Ward, a 37-year Cox employee, formerly was president of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. He was promoted to his division post in 1987. Cooper, 58, joined the Journal-Constitution as a plant manager in 1987 after 15 years at The Washington Post. He was promoted to vice president of operations at the Atlanta papers in 1988 and transferred to the division staff this year. Cox Newspapers, a division of Atlanta-based Cox Enterprises Inc., publishes 18 daily newspapers, several weeklies and a monthly magazine.
DOC.HEAD: Times of London Appoints New Editor
DOC.TEXT: The Times of London appointed award-winning columnist Simon Jenkins as its new editor March 13, and he pledged to reestablish the newspaper as the ``authoritative voice of moderate conservatism.'' Jenkins, a columnist on the Sunday Times, replaces Charles Wilson, who becomes international development director of Rupert Murdoch's News International, publisher of both newspapers. Jenkins was editor of the London Evening Standard from 1976-78, political editor of The Economist weekly from 1979-86, and has been a Sunday Times columnist for the last four years. Wilson became editor of The Times in November 1985 after the death of Charles Douglas-Home.
DOC.HEAD: Peter O'Hara Named NZPA Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Peter O'Hara has been named managing editor of the New Zealand Press Association effective April 1, it was announced Friday. O'Hara, 38, currently editor of NZPA, will succeed Graeme Jenkins, who retires this month as general manager after 36 years with New Zealand's national news agency.

Robert Lamont Chase, who retired after 47 years as a Denver newsman, died March 15 at a retirement home at the age of 85. Chase started his career in the 1920s with the Denver Express, which merged with the Rocky Mountain News in 1926. He wrote a column from 1945 to 1973 and was promoted through the ranks to associate editor of the Rocky Mountain News, from which he retired in 1973. In 1936, Chase and four other reporters and copy editors founded Local 74 of the Denver Newspaper Guild. Chase married reporter Mary Coyle June 7, 1928. She later wrote the Pulitzer Prize-winning play, ``Harvey,'' and died of a heart attack in 1981. Chase is survived by a sister, two sons, 11 grandchildren and several great-grandchildren.

Bob DeHaven, a pioneer broadcaster whose career included 27 years at radio station WCCO, died at his home March 17 of apparent heart failure. He was 81. DeHaven, a native of Anderson, Ind., made his broadcasting debut in Madison, Wis., in 1930 as part of a comedy act known as ``The Flying Filberts,'' which was billed as the only acrobatic act in radio. After working at stations in Milwaukee, Chicago and Tulsa, Okla., DeHaven returned to Minneapolis with station WTCN, and moved to WCCO in 1943. He left the station in 1970, did free-lance work in radio commercials and was a volunteer for more than a dozen years at the Radio Talking Book Network. DeHaven is survived by his wife, Harriet, a son and three daughters.

Tom Harmon, familiar to one generation as a football star and to another as a sports broadcaster, died of a heart attack March 15 at age 70. The father of ``St. Elsewhere'' star Mark Harmon was brought to UCLA Medical Center shortly after winning a golf tournament at the Bel-Air Country Club. Harmon was a triple threat tailback at Michigan who won the Heisman Trophy and The Associated Press Athlete of the Year Award in 1940. He served in the Air Force during World War II and was awarded the Silver Star and the Purple Heart after twice bailing out of crippled planes. He returned from the war to play for the Rams in 1946 and 1947, but his legs had been injured in combat and he was unable to match the football success of his college years. After his playing days ended, Harmon went on to become a prominent sports broadcaster. He also is survived by his wife, Elyse Knox, and their two daughters, Kristin, who was formerly married to the late actor-singer Rick Nelson, and Kelly, an actress and model.

Patricia Ann O'Connell Kiely, a pioneer among the city's television newswomen, died March 18 after a long illness. She was 59. Mrs. Kiely joined KDKA-TV in 1955 as a co-anchor on the station's noon news. When she became pregnant, KDKA launched a campaign called ``KD has a baby,'' which featured almost daily reports on her pregnancy and delivery. In 1967, she joined WPXI-TV, then known as WIIC, on that station's noon broadcast. During her tenure at WPXI from 1967 to 1973, Mrs. Kiely hosted the ``Face to Face'' program, interviewing such newsmakers as George Wallace, George McGovern, Edmund Muskie, Jimmy Hoffa and Jane Fonda. Surviving are her husband, Ed Kiely of Churchill; a daughter, two sons and a brother.

Michael J. Livesey, a widely admired cameraman, photographer and producer for more than three decades, died March 11 of liver and pancreatic cancer. He was 61. Livesey filmed documentaries of American presidents for the United States Information Agency for 15 years starting in 1960. From 1969 to 1979, he was the chief cameraman for ``Camera Three,'' a critically acclaimed arts program that was produced for CBS. He also worked on Walter Cronkite's ``The 20th Century,'' and produced segments for ``60 Minutes,'' on CBS and ``20-20,'' on ABC. Livesey was noted for his photographs of artwork and buildings, which earned him a Peabody Award in 1978. He is survived by his wife, Theresa; children, Jeffrey, Jack, Tara Livesey and Jennifer Livesey Annand, all of Ridgewood; his mother, and a sister.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ Graham A. Martin, a former free-lance journalist who as the last U.S. ambassador to South Vietnam directed the chaotic airlift of Saigon, died March 13 of complications from emphysema. He was 78. Martin was a reporter in Washington before beginning his government career. He worked for the National Recovery Administration, was a colonel in the Army during World War II and joined the foreign service in 1947. After serving in the diplomatic corps in Paris, Washington, Geneva and Bangkok, Martin was assigned as ambassador to Thailand by President Kennedy in 1963. He was sent to Italy by President Nixon in 1969. In April 1975, Martin was in charge of the helicopter airlift from the U.S. Embassy compound that ferried the remaining Americans and about 140,000 Vietnamese to the 7th Fleet in the South China Sea while the city fell to the invading North Vietnamese. Martin is survived by his wife, Dorothy, and two daughters, Nancy M. Lane and Janet M. Tanpemsapya, all of Winston-Salem; a son, Michael Martin, and four grandchildren.

Daniel McGibbeny Jr., retired executive sports editor of the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and a member of the Western Pennsylvania Sports Hall of Fame, died of a heart attack March 15 in his home. He was 74. McGibbeny, whose newspaper career spanned nearly 50 years, retired from the Post-Gazette on Aug. 31, 1980. He joined the Post-Gazette as a copy editor and later became chief copy editor. He was promoted to executive sports editor in the late 1960s. In addition to the Post-Gazette, McGibbeny worked for The Pittsburgh Press, the former Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph, the Monessen Daily Independent, the New Kensington Daily Dispatch and the Hilltop Record. McGibbeny was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 1986. Survivors include his wife, Elva Ferns McGibbeny; a daughter, Patricia Burton of suburban Pittsburgh and three grandchildren.

Walter T. Ridder, whose retirement from the Knight-Ridder, Inc., board of directors last year capped a 50-year newspaper career, died March 17. He was 72. Ridder died at his home in suburban McLean, Va., after a long illness. His began his journalism career with an $18-a-week reporting job at the Hartford (Conn.) Times. He later worked for Ridder newspapers in Duluth and St. Paul, Minn., and served as publisher of the Post-Tribune in Gary, Ind. The Ridder group was founded by his grandfather and included 19 newspapers, radio and television stations at the time it merged with Knight newspapers in 1974. After serving as a war correspondent in Europe during World War II, Ridder directed the information service for the Marshall Plan in Paris and for many years headed the Ridder papers' Washington bureau. Ridder is survived by his wife, Marie, three sisters and a brother, four children and seven grandchildren.

Jerome Schnur, an award-winning producer and director of television shows including ``Beat the Clock,'' ``What's My Line,'' ``I've Got a Secret'' and ``Two For the Money,'' died March 12 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66. Schnur produced ``Tomorrow For Yesterday,'' a CBS science special; ``Michelangelo's Pauline Chapel,'' at the Vatican; ``Light in the Wilderness,'' a Dave Brubeck oratorio; and ``L'Enfance du Christ,'' which played on eight consecutive Christmases on CBS during the 1960's. Schnur was a former board member for WPBT-TV in Miami, where he helped plan its studios and programs. He is survived by his mother, Frances Buschbaum Schnur of Miami Beach, and a sister, Celeste Stone of Houston.

David Teitelbaum, an Emmy-award winning producer of news and documentary programs who worked for NBC for more than three decades, died March 13 of prostate cancer. He was 69. Teitelbaum, a resident of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., died at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He started with NBC in 1954 as a writer for the ``Today'' show and won an Emmy in 1971 for producing a five-part investigation into the welfare system. Teitelbaum was awarded another Emmy for ``The Feet of Dakka,'' a documentary on the war for independence in Bangladesh. As director of operations for NBC News in the Mediterranean from 1972 to 1977, he was responsible for coverage of the 1973 Yom Kippur War in the Middle East and of the Portuguese revolution in 1974. At his retirement in 1986, Teitelbaum was executive producer of a news service NBC News provided to its affiliates. Surviving are his wife, Sylvia, and three sons: Ned, of Englewood Cliffs; Henry, of Brooklyn; and Richard, of Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: Peabody Award Winners Named
DOC.TEXT: Television and radio stations in San Francisco and Charleston, S.C., won Peabody Awards March 15 for their coverage of natural disasters last year, while CBS Radio News and Cable News Network were honored for their reporting of the student uprising in China. The annual awards for distinguished broadcasting were announced by the University of Georgia College of Journalism and Mass Communication. The 27 recipients will be presented the awards April 3 in Atlanta. KCBS-AM and KGO-TV in San Francisco were named as Peabody winners for their reports of last October's earthquake. The Peabody judges called the KCBS coverage ``comprehensive, intelligent and useful,'' while KGO's reports were lauded for ``functioning as an information clearinghouse'' for viewers. WCSC-TV in Charleston covered Hurricane Hugo in a way that provided a ``lifeline for viewers deprived of water, communications and other essential services,'' the judges said. Other winners included broadcasting pioneer J. Leonard Reinsch and veteran ABC newsman David Brinkley for distinguished careers in broadcasting. The 50-year-old awards are named for George Foster Peabody, a Columbus, Ga., native who became a banker and philanthropist in New York. Here is the complete list of winners: _KCBS-AM, San Francisco, for ``Earthquake '89,'' which the judges called ``comprehensive, intelligent and useful coverage of the October 1989 disaster.'' _CBS Radio, New York, for ``China in Crisis,'' described as ``exhaustive coverage of the extraordinary events in China as they unfolded before a shocked world.'' _National Public Radio, Washington, D.C., for Scott Simon's Radio Essays, presented on ``Weekend Edition Saturday,'' described as ``insightful, thought-provoking and evocative commentary on American life.'' _Canadian Broadcasting Corp. in Toronto for ``Lost Innocence: The Children of World War II,'' termed by judges ``a stirring recollection of the horror of war as seen through the eyes of youth.'' _D. Roberts, independent producer, American Public Radio's ``Soundprint'' series, for ``Mei Mei: A Daughter's Song,'' which judges called ``a poignant examination of the cultural gap between a daughter and her foreign-born mother.'' _Texaco Inc. and the Metropolitan Opera Association Inc., honoring a half-century of continuous Saturday afternoon radio broadcasts, the longest continuing sponsorship of a national program in broadcasting history. _WCSC-TV, Charleston, S.C., for providing a ``lifeline for viewers deprived of water, communications and other essential services'' after Hurricane Hugo. _ KGO-TV, San Francisco, for public service after the 1989 earthquake, ``functioning as an information clearinghouse'' for viewers. _ KING-TV, Seattle, for ``Project Home Team,'' which judges called ``an examination of the wrenching problems of the working poor and how their lot can be improved.'' _KRON-TV, San Francisco, for ``I Want to Go Home,'' described by judges as ``a gripping and tragic account of the plight of homeless children in San Francisco.'' _Cable News Network, Atlanta, for coverage of the China crisis, ``a series of thorough, dramatic, courageous and internationally important reports.'' _Central Independent Television, London, for ``Cambodia Year Ten,'' called by the judges ``a passionate and strident examination of the plight of the Asian nation from the barbarous Pol Pot regime to its tenuous present and uncertain future.'' _Music Television (MTV), New York, for ``Decade,'' a look at the 1980s as seen through the eyes of music performers and newsmakers. _CBS Television and Motown-Pangaea Productions, in association with Quintex Entertainment, for the television miniseries ``Lonesome Dove,'' described by the judges as ``a compelling drama of the Old West which proved that the Western is not dead.'' _ABC Television and Black@Marlens Co., in association with New World Television, for ``The Wonder Years,'' which the judges called ``an innovative, humorous and often touching series about adolescence and family life in the tumultuous 1960s.'' _ABC Television and Sacret Inc., in association with Warner Bros. Television, for ``China Beach: Vets,'' an episode which recounted the experience of American nurses in Vietnam ``in compelling, chilling and emotional terms.'' _ABC Television, Lou Rudolph Films, Motown Productions and Allarcom and Fries Entertainment for the miniseries ``Small Sacrifices,'' which judges said is a ``classic example of how exceptional acting, coupled with a great script, can provide television that is powerful and emotionally charged.'' _Beyond International Group, Sydney, Australia, for ``The Great Wall of Iron,'' a behind-the-scenes examination of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, ``completed only weeks before the infamous events in Tianamen Square.'' _HBO, New York, for ``Common Threads: Stories from the Quilt,'' which judges said is a ``stirring elegy to the victims of AIDS which celebrates their lives without exploiting their horrible and untimely deaths.'' _KCNC-TV, Denver, for ``Yellowstone: Four Seasons After Fire,'' an in-depth look at the park after the fire of 1988 and an examination of its recovery. _Public Affairs Television, New York, for ``The Public Mind,'' Bill Moyers' critical look at public opinion formation and change in America and how the media affect basic social institutions. _WLOX-TV, Biloxi, Miss., for ``Did They Die in Vain?'' an examination of Mississippi's progress in race relations during the past 25 years, which the judges said ``demonstrates what a small market television with a capable and dedicated staff can contribute to the understanding of issues that are both complex and important.'' _Film News Now@The American Documentary, New York, for ``Who Killed Vincent Chin?'' called by the judges ``a penetrating examination of a murder in Detroit, revealing the racism, class conflict and media power which permeate modern America.'' _Children's Television Workshop, New York, for ``Sesame Street,'' for what the judges described as ``two decades of innovative and effective education through the medium of television.'' _NBC News, New York, for ``NBC News Special: To Be an American,'' which the judges said ``sparks pride in what this country stands for and which validates the continuing contributions of an able and dedicated newsman, Tom Brokaw.'' _David Brinkley of ABC-TV, a personal award ``attesting to the exceptional contributions he has made to broadcasting during his tenure as one of this country's richest treasures.'' _J. Leonard Reinsch, a pioneer in broadcasting, cable and political communication, ``for a lifetime of outstanding service to his chosen profession.''
DOC.HEAD: Four Named Winners of Science Writing Prizes
DOC.TEXT: Three journalists and a film production team have been awarded $10,000 prizes for their writings about cancer. The prizes, awarded by the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation, went to Donald C. Drake of The Philadelphia Inquirer; Shannon Mililani Brownlee of U.S. News & World Report; Michael Skoler of National Public Radio; and Nippon Hoso Kyokai (NHK), the Japan Broadcasting Corp. Drake was honored for a look at one patient's experience as part of a trial of a new cancer therapy, and a story about two cancer patients who received bone-marrow transplants. Brownlee won in the book and magazine category for an article about genes that upon exposure to a virus or radiation cause normal cells to become cancerous. The prize for broadcasting will be divided between Skoler and NHK. Skoler won for a program on profit-making cancer institutes that conduct expensive and experimental therapies on terminally ill patients who are not eligible for other, more traditional therapies. NHK won for ``Protecting the Living Body _ The Immune System,'' one episode in a series ``The Universe Within.'' Katsuhiko Hayashi is executive producer. Each prize consists of $10,000 _ the largest cash prize in journalism _ and a piece of limited-edition art. This is the first year the awards, known as the International Biomedical Research Science Journalism Prizes, have been presented.

DOC.HEAD: Investigative Reporting Awards Announced
DOC.TEXT: Arson, the blood industry and the effects of local politics on public schools were the topics of winning stories March 16 in the large-newspaper category of a national investigative reporting contest. Investigative Reporters and Editors (IRE), a national organization headquartered at the University of Missouri, announced the winners of its investigative reporting competition: Newspapers over 75,000 circulation _ Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader, series on the effects of local politics on Kentucky's public schools; The Philadelphia Inquirer, series by Gilbert Gaul on the economics, regulation and ethics of the blood industry, and Minneapolis Star Tribune, series by Lou Kilzer and Chris Ison on an arson industry that was linked to firefighters and their chief. Newspapers under 75,000 _ Anchorage Daily News, series by Patti Epler, Richard Mauer, Craig Medred and Stan Jones on the failure of regulators to prevent the Alaskan oil spill; The Texas Lawyer (Dallas), story by Mark Ballard on the ad litem system, and Washington Daily News, series by Betty Gray and Mike Voss examining the local water supply. Magazines _ Florida Trend (St. Petersburg), story by Phillip Longman on the needless destruction of millions of citrus trees; U.S. News & World Report, story by Steven Emerson on corruption, fraud and cost overruns in the Continuity of Government Program. Television, top 20 markets _ KQED-TV, San Francisco, examination of discipline in police brutality cases, and Primetime Live@ABC News, investigation into the downing of Pan Am Flight 103, and WWOR-TV, Secaucus, N.J., series by reporter Joe Collum and producers Gary Scurka and Barbara Gardner on state troopers who target blacks and minorities in their zeal to catch drug dealers. Television, below 20 markets _ WFTV-TV, Orlando, Fla., documentary by Karin Dorsett on how elderly citizens are victimized by the courts and guardianship attorneys, and WTVF-TV, Nashville, Tenn., for series by Tom Gasparoli on school bus drivers with records. Radio _ KTOK, Oklahoma City, for Jerry Bohnen series on a B-1 bomber explosion. Books _ ``Inside Job,'' Mary Fricker, Paul Muolo and Steve Pizzo, investigation into causes of the savings and loan crisis.
DOC.HEAD: NENA Announces Newspaper Awards
DOC.TEXT: The New England Newspaper Association named seven daily newspapers and two weeklies the 1990 ``Newspapers of the Year'' in their respective circulation categories during its annual winter convention March 16. The newspapers were judged on overall appearance, quality of writing and editing, inside content, photos, use of color, reproduction, advertising quality, editorial pages and sports. The Hartford Courant of Hartford, Conn., was named newspaper of the year among papers with a daily circulation of at least 100,000 and a Sunday circulation of 200,000. The Boston Globe and the Christian Science Monitor won merit awards in that category. The Patriot Ledger of Quincy won the top award for Sunday and weekend papers in the 50,000-to-199,999 circulation category. The New Haven Register of New Haven, Conn., and The Sun of Lowell won merit awards. The Middlesex News of Framingham was named newspaper of the year in the Sunday category for papers with a circulation of 49,999 and under. The News was also named ``best newspaper in the contest.'' Greenwich Time of Greenwich, Conn., and The Berkshire Eagle of Pittsfield won merit awards. The Middlesex News also won the top award for papers with a circulation of 35,000 to 59,999, and was praised as ``best of show.'' The Cape Cod Times of Hyannis and The Standard-Times of New Bedford won merit awards. There was no selection for newspaper of the year in the category for papers with a circulation of 60,000 to 150,000. The Patriot Ledger and the New Haven Register won merit awards in the category. The Concord Monitor of Concord, N.H., was named newspaper of the year for dailies with a circulation of 20,000 to 34,999. The Transcript-Telegram of Holyoke and The Sun Chronicle of Attleboro received merit awards. The Journal Tribune of Biddeford-Saco, Maine, was named the top daily among those with a circulation of 12,000 to 19,999. Merit awards went to Greenwich Time and The Daily News of Newburyport. The Manchester Herald of Manchester, Conn., was named newspaper of the year among dailies with a circulation of 11,999 and under. Merit awards went to the Beverly Times of Beverly and The News of Southbridge. For weeklies, the Westford Eagle of Westford won the newspaper of the year award among publications with circulations of 5,000 and under. Merit awards went to The Burlington Times-Union of Burlington and the Georgetown Record of Georgetown. For weeklies 5,001 and up, Old Colony Memorial of Plymouth won newspaper of the year, with merit awards going to The Belmont Citizen-Herald of Belmont and The Narragansett Times of Wakefield, R.I. Judges this year were Tonnie Katz, Managing Editor of the Orange County Register of Santa Ana, Calif.; Sharon Murphy, dean of Marquette University's College of Communications; Brett Alexander, a producer at CBS News and currently a Nieman Fellow at Harvard University; and Norman Lockman, managing editor of The News Journal of Wilmington, Del. The awards were presented by John R. Hooper, vice president of Guy Gannett Publishing Co., of Portland, Maine and NENA's newly elected president.

Tom Brokaw has been proposing a one-hour, two-part ``NBC Nightly News'' to fight off competition from cable, but don't look for it anytime soon: ``No, I think it's fair to say that it's on the back burner,'' the anchor says ... Israel Television began adding Russian subtitles to one of its news shows March 14 to assist the wave of Soviet Jewish immigrants expected this year ... ``Today'' co-host Bryant Gumbel said after his memo that castigated Willard Scott and others on the show became public, he couldn't get hold of the weatherman for a while. Gumbel told Barbara Walters on ``20-20'' that when he finally reached Scott on the telephone ``we shed a lot of tears.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo market's anxiety about a possible interest rate hike and the yen's decline against the dollar sent the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeting to a 14-month low today. The dollar, meanwhile, rose sharply against the yen to a mark a three-year high, fueled by the currency's bullishness in overseas markets and Tokyo's poor performance. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which fell 55.20 points on Friday, plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, today. Its closing of 31,263.24 was the lowest since it closed at 31,170.38 on Jan. 20, 1989. The Nikkei's decline today was the third biggest single-day decline for the index. It plunged 3,836.48, or 14.9 percent, on Oct. 20, 1987, in the worldwide ``Black Monday'' stock market crash, and 1,569.10 points, or 4.50 percent, on Feb. 26.

Secretary of State James A. Baker III is bound for Africa's newest nation, Namibia, where he aims to mix celebration with negotiations to end apartheid in South Africa and to achieve a cease-fire in Angola. In six fast-paced days, Baker will visit three countries, including South Africa _ the first secretary of state to go there since 1978. He will fly to Cape Town on Thursday to show U.S. appreciation for the preliminary steps taken by President F.W. de Klerk and to try to drive him to go faster. To underscore U.S. support for the black movement Baker will go on Friday to Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg, for talks there with Desmond Tutu, the black Anglican archbishop, and other black leaders. Soweto has been the cradle of the anti-apartheid movement. Baker's 25-hour flight to Namibia requires two refueling stops before his arrival in Windhoek, the capital, where world leaders are gathering for independence ceremonies. The country was pried from South Africa's control with the help of U.S. diplomacy that is now shifting its focus to Pretoria, where a white minority government is being urged to dismantle racial segregation.

One of every five House members traveled abroad during the last three months of 1989, visiting at least 60 locations at a cost to taxpayers of about $1 million. Recently released records show that 87 members, including two non-voting delegates, traveled abroad between Oct. 1 and Dec. 31, 1989. Well over 100 staff members also went overseas. The delegations went to some of the finest cities in Europe, to the Third World, and in the case of two House Appropriations Committee staffers, to Antarctica to study research projects. Staffers who travel with members said the workload on a trip can vary with the delegation leader.

Two thieves with a talent for disguise and a taste for Rembrandt and Degas stole 11 paintings valued at hundreds of millions of dollars in a daring theft from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. But experts say the paintings are so priceless, they're worthless. ``People make pilgrimages to see these paintings. Scholars and art lovers know where they belong,'' Constance Lowenthal, executive director of the International Foundation for Art Research, said Sunday. The theft occurred around 1 a.m. Sunday, when two men apparently convinced museum guards they were police, then bound them with tape and made their way to the museum's Dutch room.
