DOC.HEAD: Japanese Public TV Threatened by Dispute Over Reporter's Politics
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese love to complain about their public broadcasting behemoth, NHK, and millions have stopped paying the fees that keep it on the air. A lawsuit has been filed against the network because of alleged political partisanship by one of its prominent reporters. As for non-payment of fees, an NHK spokesman said: ``We don't seek punishment for those who refuse. We just appeal to their honest nature.'' The 66-year-old Japan Broadcasting Corp. _ better known as Nippon Hoso Kyokai, or NHK _ is Japan's only national television network. Monthly fees paid by owners of television sets are supposed to cover its operating costs. NHK has a general-interest channel and another featuring science and cultural programs. It is known for conservative programming and unsmiling announcers who apologize with deep bows even for minor mistakes in subtitles. No advertisements appear on NHK's channels, nor does it mention brand names. The title of a popular song, ``Bright Red Porsche,'' was changed on a variety show to ``Bright Red Car.'' Such programs as documentaries on the Silk Road, China's Yellow River and the human body are acclaimed, but viewers say hours-long live broadcasts of parliamentary debates are stultifying. Critics also say the network is too close to the governing Liberal Democratic Party. ``If NHK were an ordinary company, the Liberal Democrats would be the majority stockholders,'' media critic Masanori Atsuta said, according to Themis magazine. A Cabinet-appointed committee names NHK's chairman and Parliament approves the budget. NHK insists it is independent otherwise, but investigative reporting that could embarrass the government is left to commercial networks. The network has a staff of 15,000 and 93 percent of its budget comes from public fees. It regularly loses money because of the millions who refuse to pay. Daijiro Hashimoto, an NHK reporter and younger brother of Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, is at the focus of the network's latest woes. Hashimoto the reporter took part in his brother's successful campaign for re-election to Parliament in February, prompting allegations that he violated media guidelines of political neutrality. Takehiro Motohashi, spokesman for NHK, said the network ``regretted'' its reporter's actions, but was not taking disciplinary measures. Yokohama lawyer Masayoshi Hamada was sufficiantly angry to bring legal action against the network. His suit claims NHK showed favoritism by lending its name to a political campaign, and thus has no claim to user fees. NHK will not comment on the case, but spokesman Motohashi made the appeal to people's ``honest nature'' after noting that the Broadcast Law requires the 33 million households with television to pay the appropriate fees. Fees are $7.13 a month for a color televisions and $4.70 for black-and-white sets, payable either a year in advance or by monthly automatic bank transfers. Despite an income last year of $2.6 billion, NHK ran a deficit of $167 million because of such costly new ventures as satellite broadcasting, high-definition TV and teletext broadcasting. News reports say the network wants a 28 percent rate increase. To mark households that pay their fees, NHK puts small stickers on front doors. One anti-payment group sends out free stickers saying ``NHK fee refuser.'' ``I paid until about three years ago,'' said Keiko Watanabe, a secretary who likes NHK shows. ``Why should I have to pay for NHK and not others?'' All NHK employees have to take their turn collecting bills ``to impress on us that we survive on public donations,'' an NHK reporter said. Salaries are low. The reporter, who did not want his name revealed, said there is an inside joke that NHK stands for ``Nippon Hakkyu Kyokai'' _ Japan Low-Wage Corp. Someone who is paid $32,000 a year at NHK would earn $47,000 at TV Asahi, a commercial network based in Tokyo. ``In the countryside, everyone feels NHK's the best network around,'' said a reporter from rival TBS. ``Kids there see our TBS van and start shouting, `Look, it's NHK!' It's like God to them.'' Yuko Saito, a housewife in rural Shizuoka prefecture 125 miles southwest of Tokyo, leaves the set on NHK. ``Other networks are pretty silly,'' she said. ``My husband thinks any news besides NHK is dumb, and my mother is glued to NHK all day.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday PMs, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Congresswoman Sees New Aim For U.S. Defenses: Ecosecurity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is another in a series of stories planned in advance of 20th anniversary observances for Earth Day in April.
DOC.TEXT: As she completes a decade in Congress, protecting the environment remains a top priority for Rep. Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island, an activist who made her name fighting against a nuclear power plant in the 1970s. The rest of Congress is catching up, as lawmakers rush to introduce bills to save the rain forest, stop global warming and promote energy efficiency. But Schneider still is a step ahead, promoting the re-structuring of U.S. defense forces to provide for what she calls American ``ecosecurity'' in the face of new environmental threats. The country must prepare to defend itself against threats posed by a growing population in a world with shrinking resources, Schneider says. The threats will arise, she says, as soil erodes and deserts creep into once-fertile regions, triggering famines. ``Hungry people cross borders. You get regional conflict. We need rapid deployment forces for deserts and the tropics,'' says Schneider. Providing ``ecosecurity'' will require a complete reassessment of our national defense strategy, she says. Schneider, a Republican, has been a staunch environmental crusader throughout her career. She has introduced legislation on such disparate environmental issues as global warming, the loss of tropical forests, the destruction of the stratospheric ozone layer, ocean dumping, oil spills and hazardous wastes. Bills she has introduced to ban ocean dumping, encourage energy efficiency by utilities and set energy standards for home appliances have become law. On March 17, the National Wildlife Federation gave her its 1989 National Conservation Achievement Award for Legislation, recognizing her ``outstanding leadership on a variety of conservation and environmental issues.'' She now is lobbying the Environmental Protection Agency to institute a waste-end fee that would encourage industry to recycle its wastes rather than dump them. ``We have the technology to recycle 75 percent of our waste,'' she says. ``The question is, why aren't we doing it?'' As the nation prepares to celebrate the 20th anniversary of Earth Day on April 22, Congress suddenly is brimming with ideas to help the environment, Schneider says. ``There are a dozen different approaches,'' she says. Legislators are considering bills to provide for the planting of trees in cities, encourage energy efficiency, direct the World Bank to promote conservation and double the budget of the United Nations family planning program. ``I think we're going to see more environmental programs focusing on international assistance,'' she says. The focus of legislation in the 1990s will shift from controlling pollution to preventing it through such measures as encouraging energy efficiency, she predicts. ``Pollution prevention pays,'' she says. ``Least-cost energy is our promise for the future, for domestic and foreign policy.'' So-called ``least-cost utility planning'' encourages utilities to choose the most economical alternatives in providing new sources of energy. It turns out, Schneider says, that improving energy efficiency _ freeing wasted energy for new uses _ usually is cheaper than building new power plants. At the same time, boosting efficiency cuts emissions of carbon and sulfur dioxides responsible for global warming and acid rain. ``It's a win-win situation,'' she says. Schneider developed her ideas on ecosecurity when she was asked three weeks ago to speak to a group of New York businessmen on the possible uses of the ``peace dividend'' arising from defense cutbacks as East-West tensions subside. ``I said there's another dynamic we should be thinking of. Eighty-three percent of the world's population growth by 2010 will be in China and the the tropics. The resource base is limited. Certainly a piece of the national security picture for the future must take population into account.'' Environmental organizations have come to the same realization. ``More of the environmental groups are taking on the population issue,'' she says. Schneider made her name in her home state in 1973 as the founder of the Rhode Island Committee on Energy, a group that opposed and eventually halted construction of a nuclear plant in Charlestown, R.I. From 1973 until 1978 she was founder and executive director of the Conservation Law Foundation, formed to represent citizens in environmental disputes. In 1977, she became federal coordinator of the Rhode Island Coastal Zone Management Program. She has traveled to wilderness areas in Madagascar and New Guinea, and has penetrated deeper into the Amazon than any U.S. government official since Theodore Roosevelt. The 1990s, Schneider says, will be the decade of information transfer, the time to get the word out about new energy-efficiency technology developed in the 1970s and 1980s. As part of a public-information campaign, she soon will have her Capitol Hill office outfitted with the latest in energy-efficiency lighting, including compact fluorescent bulbs that screw into ordinary incandescent bulb sockets, providing just as much light using one-fourth the energy. ``My frustration as a member of the science and technology committee for the past 10 years has been to witness the development of these technologies and seeing we do not have a good means, as a government, to get the information out,'' she says. Or a means to remove practical roadblocks, as she found out when she decided to redo her office. ``It took three years to get the architect of the Capitol to approve it,'' she says. ``It's a situation, again, where we have the technology and we haven't transferred it. ``The 1990s are a transfer time,'' she says. ``There are no white hats or black hats. We're all in this environment together.''

DOC.SECOND: PM-Peru-Human Rights, Adv 21, 1st Ld - Writethru, b0196,0932
DOC.NOTE: For Release Wednesday PMs March 21 or Thereafter

Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to INSERT Spanish name Sendero Luminoso in 5th `Human rights' and CORRECT spelling of Cayara in 8th `He was'. Moved originally as March 15 as b0196$ ^Human Rights Violations Climb in Peru's Anti-Guerrilla Fight
DOC.TEXT: Martha Crisostomo was sleeping when eight men in army uniforms, faces hidden by black ski masks, broke down her front door. Her parents and neighbors, helpless, watched the men drag her into the street and fire three bullets into her head and chest. Miss Crisostomo, a 22-year-old public health nurse, was slain in September. She was the last witness to an army massacre of 29 peasants at Cayara village in May 1988. Eight other people who implicated the army in the massacre were killed by soldiers earlier or detained and never seen again, according to human rights organizations. Miss Crisostomo's parents and friends told reporters of her murder. Human rights violatons by security forces have increased dramatically in the campaign against the Sendero Luminoso, or Shining Path, a Maoist group that began an insurgency 10 years ago in the Andes region around this colonial town. More than 18,000 people have died in political violence since 1980. Most have been Indian peasants in the Andes, killed either by rebels who accused them of betraying the struggle or by members of the security forces who suspected them of sympathizing with guerrillas. ``The death of Martha Crisostomo is concrete proof of the outrageous way in which protection has been given to those responsible for killing 29 peasants in Cayara,'' said Carlos Escobar, a former civilian prosecutor whose assignment was to investigate human rights violations in the Ayacucho region. He was fired by the Attorney General's Office when he recommended the Ayacucho military commander and other officers be prosecuted for murder in the Cayara massacre. Escobar also received anonymous death threats. Shining Path guerrillas have extended their operations beyond the Andes, even into Lima, and human rights monitors say the government has begun to tolerate brutal military tactics in a desperate effort to check the insurgency. They say torture, rape, disappearance of suspects and murder of unarmed civilians have become trademarks of army tactics. Sen. Javier Valle Riestra, a member of the governing Aprista Party who is a leading defender of human rights, said the military establishment feels the death of innocent people is a price Peru must pay to eradicate leftist terrorism. ``If 60 people are killed and 40 of them turn out to be Senderistas, the military considers it a successful operation,'' he said. In two detailed reports late last year, the human rights organization Amnesty International said a ``pall of terror'' had settled over much of Peru because of rebel atrocities and brutal actions by government forces. President Alan Garcia and his civilian aides ignored the Amnesty reports. The army routinely refuses comment on accusations of human rights violations, such as the murders of Cayara witnesses. After the Amnesty International reports, however, the Defense Ministry denied any similarity between army conduct and the Shining Path's ``demented acts and criminal methods.'' For three years, the United Nations has listed Peru as leading the world in numbers of disappeared people, ahead even of military-ruled countries. In the seven years since civilian governments began putting the military in charge of insurgency zones in the Andes and the eastern jungles, more than 3,000 people have disappeared after detention. Most human rights violations occur in military-controlled regions, which have expanded to cover one-third of the country. Spanish-speaking soldiers from the coast, wearing black ski masks, patrol the cold Andean heights and sweep into remote hamlets of Quechua-speaking Indian peasants in search of rebels and sympathizers. Community leaders say villagers dread the soldiers' arrival even more than the nocturnal visits of rebel columns. Witnesses to the Cayara massacre told civilian investigators the soldiers first stomped cactus on the bare backs of villagers, demanding they identify rebel supporters, then killed them by bashing their heads in with hammers or slashing their throats with machetes. An army patrol slaughtered 69 peasants in Accomarca village in 1985, including 21 children under age 5. The second lieutenant in command told congressional investigators ``children by the age 3 were potential Senderistas and it was his job to exterminate them,'' said Se, head of the commission. The army said the officer would be given a private military trial. Reporters discovered later he was promoted to first lieutenan. Valle Riestrant and transferred to an army base in Lima, on the coast 235 miles to the northwest. Human rights officials say brutal repression by security forces plays into the hands of the Shining Path. ``The torture, the disappearances, the illegal executions all reinforce the Shining Path's argument that this is an abusive, fascist, genocidal state,'' Diego Garcia-Sayan, director of the independent Andean Commission of Jurists, said in an interview. Lima newspapers n public outrage,'' Enrique Bernales, head of a Senate commission on violence, said of Martha Crisostomo's murder. ``Are we no longer shocked by death?'' he said. ``Peru is definitely a sick country.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Tuesday PMs, March 20, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Director Turns Visit With Young Prosecutor into `Equal Justice' Series
DOC.TEXT: A visit with a college roommate's sister in Houston opened director Thomas Carter's eyes about criminal prosecutors and led to the creation of ABC's ``Equal Justice.'' ``She was a very unlikely assistant district attorney who at 26 or 27 was prosecuting felons,'' said Carter, who has made a career of directing pilots for such series as ``Miami Vice,'' ``St. Elsewhere,'' ``A Year in the Life,'' ``Midnight Caller'' and many more. ``When I looked into it, I found the DA's office was a place where very young lawyers got experience,'' he said. ``We've always had this image in movies and television of prosecutors being tough, older and male. I learned young lawyers spend six or seven years as prosecutors, then move on. The salaries are low, the work is intense, the burnout rate is high. ``These people have such an overwhelming caseload that people fall through the cracks. Our show is about the cracks,'' Carter said of ``Equal Justice.'' Carter, who began directing while starring in ``The White Shadow,'' set the unique visual style for ``Miami Vice.'' He was much in demand as a director but, like a hired gunslinger, always moved on after the pilot. He was looking for a series of his own and found it in ``Equal Justice,'' which debuts Tuesday, March 27, with a two-hour pilot. Carter is the co-creator, executive producer and director, and also played a small role in the movie. The series will be seen beginning Wednesday, March 28, taking over the time slot of ``China Beach,'' which moves to Mondays. ``Equal Justice,'' set in a big-city district attorney's office, stars Cotter Smith, Joe Morton, Jane Kaczmarek, Sarah Jessica Parker, Barry Miller, Debrah Farentino, Lise Cutter, James Wilder, George DiCenzo and Kathleen Lloyd. Carter's co-creators were Christopher Knopf and David A. Simons. Carter is in the forefront of a cadre of young directors who are black, such as Kevin Hooks and Eric Laneuville, who got their start acting in series. ``Race may be a problem for other people, but I don't let it hold me back,'' he said. ``I don't look upon myself as a black director _ I'm a director. Being a director is very personal because you take with you your life and your experiences and your views, and being African-American is an aspect of my character. But it's not the sum of my life. ``I'm interested in so many things that are universal. How the death of a person affects someone else. Love and relationships. I want to explore a variety of themes as well as a variety of visual styles. I think if you could sum up my work at all, you could say it has a sense of romantic realism.'' In the beginning, Carter knew he wanted to do a gritty, urban show about the criminal justice system. He wanted it to have an edge, be fast-paced and have a mixture of humor and dark tragedy. He returned to Houston for more research, then to New York, where he visited all the boroughs, and to Chicago. He also talked to some prosecutors in Los Angeles, although he wanted the story set in an older city. The pilot movie was filmed in Pittsburgh. ``In our show, we don't deal just with the nuts and bolts of the law, but with the politics of it as well,'' said Carter. ``I wanted to do a show that would cause the American public never to look at the law the same again.'' Carter grew up in Texas, where he studied theater at Southwest Texas State University. One of his first roles was as Ray Gun in ``Szysznyk,'' which disappeared before anyone learned how to pronounce it. Next came ``The White Shadow,'' where he got his chance to direct. He found it more challenging than acting and began to direct many episodes of ``Hill Street Blues'' and ``St. Elsewhere.'' ``I was surprised when I directed, because I didn't think I would like it,'' he said. ``I came here to act. I thought if I directed at all it would be much later.''

_greater than Elsewhere in television ... ON THE ROAD: Showtime has introduced a short series called ``Crossroads,'' looking at the talents of people in small towns across the country. Episodes have looked at the Cornerstone Theatre Co. in rural areas of Appalachia and at the annual Cowboy Poetry Gathering in Elko, Nev. One of the three- to six-minute episodes will visit a Washington dance company that features disabled people and senior citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Prostitutes in Mali Teach Customers Dangers of AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Prostitutes have have taken up health education, teaching customers how to protect themselves from catching and spreading AIDS. Under an international program that began last year in this Islamic nation, more than 1,000 prostitutes in Bamako, the capital, have been receiving free condoms and information to pass along on the job. About 350,000 Africans are believed to be infected with the HIV virus. Most cases are in east and central Africa, where one in four hospital beds is filled with a victim of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, for which no cure is known. Health officials hope to slow the spread of AIDS in Mali and other West African countries before it reaches the same catastrophic proportions. ``We have tried to go to countries where HIV prevalence is very low, and you get your programs in place early,'' said Dr. Arlene McKay of Family Health International, based in North Carolina. ``You try to avoid the situation you find in some countries where up to 20 percent of the pregnant women in prenatal clinics are suffering the disease,'' Her non-profit biomedical, research and technical assistance organization is working with risk groups in nine African countries under a contract with the U.S. Agency for International Development. ``You need to get in early and reach the people who are most likely to be practicing high-risk sex,'' she said. It is not easy. ``Officially, prostitutes don't exist in Mali,'' said Dr. Sidi Konore, coordinator of the National AIDS Prevention and Treatment Program. ``The number of people infected with AIDS is growing, and it is clear something must be done'' despite political reluctance, he said. Once a week, a female social worker visits four of Bamako's largest brothels to distribute condoms, provide basic information on sexually transmitted diseases and encourage women to take part. The program has grown significantly since it began with 140 prostitutes, only 11 of whom said they used condoms ``frequently'' with their clients. After three months, condom use was up to 90 percent among the 82 women who continued to participate. Their brothels also benefited by gaining a reputation for safety. Mary Bobbey, 36, went to work at a low mud-brick house in the ramshackle Koura district after her husband left and took their children, her mother got sick and the money ran out. She works in a small room with a dirt floor and corrugated tin door, and said she may have 20 customers on a busy day. ``Not all of them want to use condoms,'' said Mrs. Bobbey, who earns about $46 on a good day. ``It's very dangerous. Out of 20, maybe five will refuse, and if one refuses I can't argue.'' She and other prostitutes are banding together, driven by sisterhood and common sense. Aminata Diakita, feeding her children under a palm tree in the center courtyard, said the the women had decided everyone in the house must participate. ``If there is a woman here who is not participating and she gets sick, then the next day the guy will sleep with one of us and we'll be sick,'' said Ms. Diakita, chosen by the program as the ``team leader'' to help organize the house. ``Besides, if a man says he doesn't want to use one and threatens to go next door, then we can say, `OK, but you'll have to use one there, too'.'' No one knows how many prostitutes in Mali are infected with AIDS, which destroys the immune system and leaves the body vulnerable to fatal disease. Figures on AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases are not released by the government. ``The original idea was to see if prostitutes would change their behavior, and the answer seems to be yes,'' said Kathy Jesencky of Family Health International. ``Clients are starting to accept the idea. We're now going to start working with bar girls and women not in houses,'' she said. ``Using condoms is a habit one develops. The awareness is important and in Mali awareness is increasing.''

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Sunday, March 25, the 84th day of 1990. There are 281 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: Twenty-five years ago, on March 25, 1965, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. led 25,000 marchers to the state capitol in Montgomery, Ala., to protest the denial of voting rights to blacks. On this date: In A.D. 752, Pope Stephen II died, only two days after his election. In 1634, Maryland was founded by English colonists sent by the second Lord Baltimore. In 1865, during the Civil War, Confederate forces captured Fort Stedman in Virginia. In 1911, more than 140 immigrant workers were killed when fire broke out at the Triangle Shirtwaist Company in New York. In 1913, the home of vaudeville, the Palace Theatre, opened in New York City. In 1918, French composer Claude Debussy died in Paris. In 1947, a coal mine explosion in Centralia, Ill., claimed 111 lives. In 1957, the Treaty of Rome established the European Economic Community, also known as the Common Market. In 1964, Britain set aside an acre of land at Runnymede, where the Magna Carta was signed in 1215, as a memorial for the late President Kennedy. In 1975, King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was shot to death by a nephew with a history of mental illness. The nephew was beheaded the following June. In 1987, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled employers may sometimes favor women and members of minority groups over men and whites in hiring and promoting in order to achieve better balance in the work force. In 1988, in New York City's so-called ``preppie murder case,'' Robert E. Chambers Jr. pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in the death of 18-year-old Jennifer Levin. Ten years ago: U.S. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy upset President Carter in the Connecticut and New York Democratic primaries, while on the Republican side, George Bush won Connecticut and Ronald Reagan won in New York. Five years ago: ``Amadeus'' was named best picture of 1984 at the 57th annual Academy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles. The best actor award went to F. Murray Abraham, while Sally Field was named best actress. British journalist Alec Collett was kidnapped in Lebanon. He was murdered in captivity. One year ago: In the wake of the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound, Alaska's chief environmental officer, Dennis Kelso, criticized cleanup efforts as too slow. DOC.HEAD: Cycles of Hope Have Led to Cycles of Frustration and Silence
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Again, an anniversary, Terry Anderson's fifth as a captive. Again, a cycle of hopeful signs and statements about the American hostages in Lebanon. But optimism has proved hollow too often to come easily to the families, colleagues and friends of Anderson and the other seven Americans held captive by militant Moslem factions. Always before, cycles of hope have yielded to cycles of frustration and silence. This time, perhaps, it will be different. Peggy Say, Anderson's sister, thinks so. She is, she says, absolutely convinced that the ceremony held last Friday, across the street from the White House, will be the last before Anderson and other captives finally are freed. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, was seized by Moslem gunmen on March 16, 1985. He has been held longer than any other hostage. His kidnappers identified themselves as members of a group called Islamic Jihad, or holy war. They are aligned with Iran, and two hostages who had been held with Anderson were released after secret Reagan administration arms shipments to the Iranians. The scandal over the arms sales and diversion of the proceeds to support Contra rebels in Nicaragua made the hostage situation part of the major political embarrassment of the Reagan years. President Reagan had, after all, defeated a Democratic president undercut by the Iranian hostage crisis, and had promised that he would not let Americans be taken without swift and sure retribution. There was no way to make good on that when Shiite Moslem factions began seizing American and other foreign hostages amid the unrelenting chaos in Beirut. All told there are now 18 foreign hostages in Lebanon. As he took office, Bush urged the Iranians to help gain freedom for the hostages, saying that goodwill would beget goodwill. At milestones along the way _ anniversaries, birthdays, the release of other hostages, the Bush inauguration to succeed Reagan, the death of Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini _ there have been cycles of heightened public interest, of speculation and sometimes of optimism about the release of hostages. In the latest round, which began about a month ago, a leading Moslem cleric in Beirut said that a way should be found to free the hostages, and Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani was said to have declared that he would like the captives released. But the Moslem leader had said much the same thing more than a year ago, near the fourth anniversary of Anderson's kidnapping. Rafsanjani, as speaker of the Iranian parliament, had offered in 1989 to help gain freedom for the hostages if the United States would work to free Iranians believed to have been captured by Lebanese Christians. But there have been changes along with those similarities. President Bush has put the hostage issue on the administration's public agenda in a way the Reagan White House would not, especially after the Iran-Contra scandal broke. He spent a half hour with Mrs. Say and her husband, David, on Friday. Bush policy does not break with the course set in the Reagan years, but his handling of the problem certainly does. ``I intend to keep open lines of communications with all parties, including Iran, who have influence over hostage takers,'' Bush said in a letter to Mrs. Say. ``Please be assured that your government will take advantage of all legitimate opportunities to obtain the safe release of all of our hostages.'' Bush also said he had been in touch with Syrian President Hafez Assad regarding the hostages. His spokesman said later that was through diplomatic channels, and that there have been other overtures to Middle Eastern leaders on the hostage situation. Jimmy Carter met with Assad last week, and Bush said he had received reports from the former president. Carter said in Damascus that Assad told him Syria was seeking to convince the captors the hostages should be protected and released. Carter said in Damascus on Friday that he thinks there is a better chance of Anderson's release than ever before. He said that stems in part from a growing desire on the part of Iran and the United States to settle their differences. For all the differences in this cycle of hope, there are similarities to those that went before. There are more contacts, and changing circumstances. But there is nothing firm, only an atmosphere, and conjecture. Bush said that he had been confused by all the speculation about a possible break in the hostage situation. ``We are going down every alley, we are trying every avenue to free the hostages, but there is no negotiation going on,'' he said.
Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Live With Rats and Rotting Timbers
DOC.TEXT: Rats run free, broken timbers stab out of the darkness and men stand in mud, breathing bad air, stripped to the waist. That's how it is in a Ukrainian coal mine, 1,500 feet below ground. The men of the Trudovskaya mine say life on the surface isn't much better. Their shoddy housing has no running water and the stores have little to sell. Many die early, killed by accidents, cancer or black-lung disease. They retire at 50, if they live that long. Thousands of miners in the Ukraine, and in the Siberian coal fields of the east, shocked Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Kremlin and the economy last summer with the first industrywide strike. Eight months and countless promises later, the original bread-and-butter demands have become political. After a month of rallies and hunger strikes against the local Communist Party leadership, Ukrainian miners handed the party a stunning setback in elections March 4. ``Look how I live!'' said Nikolai Golik, 36, who has two children. ``Our conditions are not much better than down here in the pit. There is no gas, no hot water. We ain't got a damn indoor toilet.'' Sergei Malchenko, 26, shares his comrade's bitterness. ``Gorbachev is showing off,'' he said. ``He is not doing anything. I didn't go vote because I don't want to play those games. Nothing good will come of it. For 72 years, Communists have been pulling our legs, and finally have mucked it all up. I won't help them. Not me.'' The Trudovskaya mine is one of 21 in this eastern Ukrainian city of 1.2 million people. In it, 3,500 miners work six-hour shifts around the clock to meet a yearly quota of almost 1.5 million tons of hard coal. Andrei Slivka of the Donetsk strike committee, said working conditions have barely changed in his 19 years underground. In the shaft, sections of wall show signs of caving in. Broken timbers protrude in all directions. Muddy water is underfoot everywhere. Poor-quality wood brought in to prop up the shafts breaks easily. Hastily built scaffolding often is flooded and slippery, so miners must jump from board to board. Rats lurk in the flickering light of miners' lamps, waiting for a chance to snatch leftovers from lunch. On the surface, the temperature is 41 degrees Fahrenheit. In the shaft it is 77 degrees. Men dig with shovels, drills and picks. They crouch, squat, crawl to scoop up coal in a narrow tunnel too low for a them to stand straight. Sweat pours down their faces in black streams. There is an alarm system to warn of explosive gas, but miners suspect it doesn't work. An explosion at the Pochenkov mine in same coal basin killed 13 miners and injured more than 20. Boris Grebenyuk, who visited the United States in January with several other Soviet miners, said it would be much easier to work there than in a Donetsk mine. ``We saw humane treatment and a real concern for the workers,'' he said after visiting a mine in West Virginia. Few statistics are available on accidents and occupational illnesses in the nation's largest coal field, known as the Donbass. Yevgeny Mironov, the acting regional Communist Party leader, acknowledged the accident rate was ``unfortunately rather high.'' He blamed ``shortcomings in working conditions'' in the 55 miles of underground tunnels, and carelessness by miners about safety rules. Miners who stopped to talk blamed their problems on the Communist Party apparatus. Donetsk is better off in some ways than many Soviet cities, even though sugar is rationed, the stores have no cheese or fresh meat and fruit is rare in winter. The men sometimes are given meat at the mine, and milk and yogurt are plentiful. Vodka also is plentiful, but there are few clothes, television sets, refrigerators or cars for sale. Most workers live in one-story duplexes, built in the 1940s and 1950s, that need constant repair and have no modern conveniences. As in much of the Soviet Union, there are not enough new apartment buildings and the waiting lists for better housing are long. Sergei Stolika, 62, continues working 12 years beyond the retirement age because he can't get by on a monthly pension of 170 rubles. Nikolai Tsuprik, 27, earns 550 rubles a month, more than twice the pay of the average Soviet worker, but asks: ``What can I do with them? There's nothing to buy in the shops.'' Vladimir Burdo, 50, said: ``I have two daughters. One of them is married and has a child. We all live together in a 48-square-meter flat. You call that life? We need new people in the regional party committee.'' The size of the apartment is equivalent to 500 square feet. The Communist Party district leader, Nikolai Nikandrov, got only about 3,000 votes, or 3.4 percent, in the Ukrainian legislative elections March 4. Two miner candidates got the most votes for the seat. Another loser was Vladimir Ivantsov, party leader at the mine, who supported the men's demands and appeared to have their respect. ``I'm not sorry I lost the elections,'' Ivantsov said. ``People didn't vote against me, but against the apparatus, the system that keeps it afloat.'' Workers want more say in management and greater autonomy for the mines. ``We can't set wholesale prices as we wish,'' Ivantsov said. ``We can't decide ourselves where to sell our production. We can't buy what we really need, even for production development.'' Such problems in the mines make the social problems on the surface all the worse, he said. When miners held rallies and demonstrations to force the regional party leadership out, Ivantsov supported them but stopped short of endorsing a strike. Mironov, the acting regional party leader, said he felt victimized by the mistakes of those who went before him. Voters ``don't want to understand we are quite different'' from previous party leaders, he said, ``but it is our lot to be called to account for the mistakes made before us.'' He rejected demands for his resignation. Yuri Makharov of the city strike committee said he was in no mood for compromise: ``They must resign,'' he said, ``not because they are personally responsible ... but because they are part of the system and we are out to crush that system.''
Sergei Loiko is employed by The Associated Press in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 4 b&w photos. ColorFoto subscribers get 1 35mm slide.)
DOC.TEXT: In a state where not so long ago many rural counties cut the school year to eight months instead of nine, so the children would have more time to work in the cotton fields, education has been moved to the front burner. Mississippi is learning, but the state still has a long way to climb to get out of last place.

Down here at the bottom of America's statistics the burning issue is no longer race. In an evolution as long coming as a magnolia spring, the state has reckoned that the three r's of the schoolhouse, not the fourth `r' of racism, are the key to its future. The alternative is chronic Third Worldism. In this climate of introspection, Jim Crow isn't dead. Just irrelevant. The cost of the state's stubborn, sometimes bloody, past, when race darkened almost any aspect of public policy or private attitudes, is embarrassingly high. The highest illiteracy rate _ a third of its adults _ in the nation. The highest school dropout rate. The lowest score on military entrance tests. Thirty percent of Mississippi's high school graduates don't test high enough to qualify for public college. In 1985-89 less than half of the college freshmen graduated. ``I'm tired of hearing Mississippi this, Mississippi that,'' says Marjorie Vaughan, feisty superintendent of Yazoo County schools. ``I'm tired of hearing that word `bottom.' We have problems, but we're all working on them. Both races.'' Margie Vaughan is right. In a state where James Meredith was shot 24 years ago trying to enroll at Ole Miss, 65 percent of the slim public purse is now spent on education. Integrated education. The Legislature is currently scratching its head over how to raise $382 million to finance a three-year education reform package proposed by Gov. Ray Mabus, a 41-year-old native back home from Harvard law school and a Washington legal firm. This is a legislature that traditionally ``thinks slow and thinks small,'' says Ole Miss history professor David Sansing. But the saliva test for public office in Mississippi today is where you stand on schooling, not segregation. Mabus hoped to pay for a third of his program with a state lottery, which would have been the first in the South. The Senate wouldn't play. H.L. Mencken, after all, coined the term Bible Belt and said the Mississippi state capital at Jackson ``was the buckle.'' ``The defeat of the lottery creates a state of uncertainty for the whole program,'' said a high state official, who would discuss the issue only if granted anonymity. ``The public is ahead of the Legislature on this (more than 60 percent favored the lottery in polls, despite church opposition) but politicians are amazingly good listeners.'' The rest of Mabus's BEST program _ Better Education for Success Tomorrow _would teach adult literacy, go into homes to teach parents and preschoolers rudimentary techniques of knowledge, equalize per-pupil expenditures between poor and rich school districts, free teachers and schools from rote manuals to instruct in accord with local needs, reward successful schools with bonus money to spend as they see fit (except for athletics). BEST is an all-out drive for school betterment all the more remarkable for a state that didn't used to have compulsory education so as to keep whites from having to go to school with blacks. The impetus for reform is simple: economics. To be ignorant in a computer world is to be eyeless in Gaza. ``At every level of planning for our future _ higher employment, higher standards _ the basic need was always education,'' says Olon Ray, Mabus' special assistant for education and a former teacher. ``Our chance for improvement in the state _ in the United States _ lies in our human capital.'' More than a tenth of Americans can't read or write, says the U.S. census. Lack of a high school educated work force costs the nation an estimated $225 billion yearly. Mabus aims to cut the dropout rate, twice the nation's average, in half by the year 2001 and reduce illiteracy by 90 percent. A sobering fact is that three-quarters of Mississippi's projected work force in 2001 is already beyond school age. ``They're all we're going to get, and we need more brains than brawn,'' says Mike Zitterman, manager for Frito-Lay's Mississippi operation. As a result, Frito-Lay has donated a semi-truck equipped with 10 computers to travel the state teaching basic skills to adults. For a change, Mississippi has a first in the nation: a 25 percent tax credit for corporations that teach adult education. Packard Electric in Clinton is spending $300,000 a year to teach its workers. There are almost 50 adult literacy programs in the state, with 40,000 enrollees, says Judy Lipscomb, director of the Governor's Office for Literacy. Mabus is impaled on the horns of a self-made dilemma. He says he takes ``a dim view'' of raising taxes to pay for his ambitious BEST. His predecessor, William Winter, bit a similar bullet. Among the memorabilila and diplomas on the wall of Winter's Jackson law office is a painting of a one-room country school. ``I was the only student from that school ever to graduate from high school,'' he says. Winter's mother was the teacher. More than C-A-T, she taught her son a respect for education. ``In 1952, one in four whites in Mississippi finished high school. One in 40 blacks did,'' he says. To change this dismal record, Winter ran for governor in 1967 on an education reform platform. And lost. Ditto in 1975. He ran a third time in 1979 and won.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
JACKSON, Miss.: and won.
DOC.TEXT: His reform package was finally passed in 1982 _ and paid for with the largest tax increase in Mississippi history while the nation was suffering the worst recession since the Depression. ``Education had developed a substantial constituency,'' Winter says. Kindergarten was made mandatory. Teacher salaries were raised to the regional average. Compulsory school attendance was given teeth. Mrs. Winter's son had changed the terms of political dialogue in Mississippi. ``First Mississippi was a frontier, then before the Civil War a besieged slave society,'' says Dr. Charles Wilson, a professor of southern culture at the University of Mississippi in Oxford, also home of William Faulkner. ``Both societies looked askance at education. ``Nat Turner's rebellion _ he could read _ in 1831 was used as a horrible example. Teaching slaves became illegal. After the war the politically powerful wanted to keep taxes low. Why waste money on inferiors? Landlords didn't want sharecroppers reading the fine print at the company store. Let 'em grow cotton.'' The paradox of an ill-educated state producing Faulkners and Eudora Weltys and Richard Wrights arises from the oral traditions of both the English yeomen and their African slaves, Wilson explains. The traditions and histories of both people were handed down by storytellers. But that is not book learning. ``Then in the 1980s there was some kind of transformation in Mississippi, a consensus that the state was part of the United States, even the world. Economic growth became agreed on as much as race used to be. All the debate now is how to fund education, not if.'' But expiation for centuries of neglect is daunting. ``Illiteracy produces a sense of powerlessness,'' says Wilson. ``It feeds a sense of fatalism. There's a certain security in the status quo however narrow it may be.'' A third of Mississippi adults can't help their children with their homework, read a pill label when they are sick, get their cars fixed on a credit card so it stays in the garage for weeks. Illiteracy means standing in line for government forms, going home to get them read, then going back to stand in line again. It means eating potatoes instead of better foods because their prices are always changing in the supermarket _ all those meaningless numbers. Toward the end it means no solace from the Bible you can't read ... Eyeless in Gaza. To Dr. Merre Dorman in Starkville, the problem _ and the answer _ begins almost at birth. In the home. After considerable arm-wrestling she won grants to begin an outreach program for children 1 to 7 years old. Children deemed ``at risk'' of eventually dropping out of school are identified from welfare rolls and the like. Dorman's paid staff visits the homes weekly to hel the mothers with nutrition at the stove and nutrition of the mind of her children. One of Dorman's staff, Emma Mays, is testing two of the children of Karen Isaacs who is barely in her 20s. Can Lemarcus, 4, catch a ball? Differentiate textures? Later Mrs. Mays will get basic textbooks to teach Karen and Lemarcus habits of basic intelligence. Lemarcus, a bright-looking child, doesn't know he's at risk. Merre Dorman did and did something about it. ``Just talking to PTAs is like preaching to the choir,'' she says. There are countless numbers of such local experiments under way in Mississippi, some financed by foundations, some with computers donated by private corporations. Judy Lipscomb overheard two janitors talking at the University of Southern Mississippi in Hattiesburg about the computer software program they were using in their adult literacy course. (Two hundred and seventy employees at the school have been identified as illiterate.) ``How many janitors do you hear talking about software? Gradually we are taking the stigma out of illiteracy.'' It takes four years on average to teach an adult to read and write, same as for a child. Since Winter's 1982 reform, test scores of Mississippi's 500,000 schoolchildren have risen noticeably, if slightly. (An additional 50,000 remain in the private academies that sprouted when integration became mandatory in 1971.) There are any number of educators in place like Margie Vaughan. ``You can't teach with leaking roofs and trash cans in the halls that need dumping. I'm on probation because my teacher-pupil ratio is too high. I could fix it tomorrow if I had money. That's all it takes. Money. ``I tell my teachers, `Don't talk to me about a child's background. That child is coming to you with nothing. Give him something!''' Behind Margie Vaughan's desk is a stitched sampler: ``If you can read this, thank a teacher.'' One of her kids did once, named a horse for her. She laughs. ``We shall overcome.'' Coming from a white superintendent, that rallying call of the South's blacks did not seem out of place in the context of Mississippi's school reform. Education has always been the silver bullet that could kill bigotry.

DOC.TEXT: Margaret Walker Alexander at 74 is a living time capsule of the agony of black education in Mississippi. Her great-grandfather was a literate freed blacksmith in Georgia who fell in love with a slave while shoeing horses on a plantation. One of their children became a Baptist minister and helped found a Negro college in an abandoned hospital in Natchez that became Jackson State. As a child she knew the insides of one of the 4,000 little white schoolhouses built for blacks in the South by the philanthropy of Sears and Roebuck millionaire Julius Rosenwald. Mrs. Alexander got two degrees from Northwestern, came back to Jackson State to teach and has written poetry, a novel and a biography of black novelist Richard Wright, author of ``Native Son.'' She lives on a street in Jackson that is named for her. ``I've seen three revolutions in my time: the New Deal, civil rights and the electronic age,'' she says. ``My grandparents said education was the most important. My grandchildren say education is not enough. There has to be economic accessibility.''

DOC.TEXT: George Esper, who wrote the following story, spent 10 years covering the Vietnam War for The Associated Press and was there when South Vietnam fell to the communist North on April 30, 1975. He has returned to Vietnam twice, in 1984 and 1989.

On the killing fields of Vietnam, residue of the 10-year war has been mostly bulldozed away, except for an occasional spent shell or a rusted mess kit stuck in the red dirt. But back home in America, a spate of new books and films has kept memories of the divisive war very much alive. Like the men they portray, books about the Vietnam War, fiction or non-fiction, had a tough time being accepted after Saigon fell to the communists. Now 15 years later they pour from the presses by the hundreds. Through them a new generation relives the horrors of the battles at places like the Rock Pile, Dak To, Hamburger Hill, Khe Sanh and Nui Lon Mountain. It was on April 30, 1975, that South Vietnam fell, ending a war in which nearly 3 million Americans fought and 58,000 died. In the late 1970s, an older generation of award-winning books about Vietnam came along. They included Michael Herr's ``Dispatches,'' Tim O'Brien's ``Going After Cacciato,'' Robert Stone's ``Dog Soldiers'' and Philip Caputo's ``A Rumor of War,'' which like some others was initially rejected before being published in 1977. But it wasn't until the 1980s that Vietnam became a popular subject for books and movies. The dedication of the Vietnam Memorial in Washington brought a new respectability to veterans, and a new look at the war. Tom Hebert, a veteran who runs the mail-order Vietnam Bookstore from his home in Burlington, Conn., estimates more than 500 books about the Vietnam War have been published since 1982. His best sellers from the '80s include John DelVecchio's ``The 13th Valley,'' Robert Mason's ``Chickenhawk'' and Neil Sheehan's ``A Bright Shining Lie: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam.'' The passing of time also has brought a breakthrough in movies. After 10 years of trying, a twice-wounded Vietnam veteran, Oliver Stone, brought to the screen ``Platoon,'' the 1987 Academy Award-winning movie that is a semi-autobiographical account of his tour. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' based on paraplegic Ron Kovic's 1976 autobiography of patriotism, anger, guilt and disillusionment in the aftermath of war, was nominated for eight Academy Awards this year. ``The experience of war is still inherently so mysterious and fascinating that we just can't seem to examine enough of it,'' says Michael Norman, a radioman who wrote ``These Good Men,'' one of a recent outpouring of powerful personal accounts of the savagery of the war and a search for its meaning. ``For the men who fought who want to turn war into art, you got to let some time pass,'' says Norman. ``Wordsworth was right. Art is emotion recollected in tranquillity. You can't be tranquil about the war until you let a decent amount of time pass and you think about it.'' Norman traced the lives of 11 comrades with whom he had survived the ``brutal, obscene'' war in an odyssey that took him 50,000 miles in search of what it all meant and what they had become. The realization came to him 16 years later that these men acted at their very best even though he feels sending them to Vietnam in the cause of democracy turned out to be a lie. ``There is no sense to Vietnam when one is sober,'' Rod Kane writes in ``Veterans's Day,'' another recent book. His service as a medic was like being on a car that was out of control, he says. After a while, Vietnam was out of control. Watching his friends die turned Kane into a drunk until he sobered up eight years ago. The new books are filled with metaphors of the senselessness of the war, of American blood spilled in assaults against meaningless hills and mountaintops of no strategic value. News correspondents who were there recall hills like 875 and 1338 that towered thousands of feet above the Dak To Valley and claimed 1,300 American soldiers. Scores of wounded had lain on the hillside for more than two days in great pain before a relief column broke through to rescue them. ``I have always preached a lot about hell but I had never seen it until the last three days,'' the brigade chaplain was moved to say. Many of the American paratroopers at Hamburger Hill had a premonition they were going to die but they were unable to do anything about it. For eight days, the paratroopers assaulted the hill at the cost of 46 men killed and 300 wounded.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
UNDATED: 300 wounded.
DOC.TEXT: At Khe Sanh, the North Vietnamese artillery bombardments reached more than 1,000 rounds on some days. American Marines were at their very best under the worst conditions, dragging bleeding comrades toward bunkers, pleading, ``Corpsman! Corpsman! We've got wounded here,'' withstanding a 77-day siege that inflicted nearly 2,000 casualties, one-third of the entire garrison. In the end, they abandoned it. Jacque Navarra Rhoads, who co-edited the book, ``Nurses in Vietnam: The Forgotten Veterans,'' at age 22 had come straight from nursing school in Albion, N.Y., to tend to the shattered bodies in the monsoons and mud. ``It's really depressing because of the amputations,'' she would say. ``What a waste of men. If I knew what we were fighting for, if the enemy did something to our country, I could see it. I don't know why we're here. So many GIs ask why. I can't answer. I came because they needed medical help. I wanted to appreciate things better back home, like clean sheets, running water and a happy family.'' Another nurse, Edith Knox, was so repelled by the sight of four casualties with amputated legs the first time she made her rounds that she had to leave the emergency room. ``I had never seen anything quite like that,'' she would say. But the most difficult part of her tour was when a youngster would ask her, ``How do I write and tell my wife I don't have a leg anymore?'' Nurse Sharon Lane's medical battalion treated 10,000 patients in nine months. She was so proud of that milestone that she wrote home about it. Four days later, a piece of steel from a North Vietnamese rocket tore through her aorta. She bled to death less than a month before her 26th birthday, the first of eight women killed by hostile fire in Vietnam. Like many veterans, Rod Kane felt lonely and out of place. A war that no one wanted turned him into an outcast, a man who felt he had nothing to offer and was unworthy of returning to society. Some veterans were proud to serve in Vietnam, at least early on. Disillusionment set in during the late 1960s and early 1970s. In 1961, Tom Davis wrote his father: ``I just hope that our little bit will help to ease things in this part of the world. I don't feel too badly about having to be here when I think of all the potential good it will have for this country.'' Three days before his first Christmas away from his wife and 13-month-old daughter in Tennessee, a Viet Cong bullet ripped through his head. He was the first American to die in combat in Vietnam. But as the decade of the '60s neared an end, no one wanted to be the last to die in Vietnam, certainly not the men of ``A'' Company of the 196th Light Infantry Brigade's 3rd Battalion. For five days in August 1969, ``A'' Company had tried to push the North Vietnamese off Nui Lon Mountain, only to be driven back. Finally the men balked. ``I am sorry, sir, but my men refused to go _ we cannot move out,'' the company commander radioed headquarters. ``Repeat that please. Have you told them what it means to disobey orders under fire?'' asked the battalion commander. ``I think they understood,'' the company commander replied. ``But some of them simply had enough _ they are broken. There are boys here who have only 90 days left in Vietnam. They want to go home in once piece ....'' Harry G. Summers Jr., editor of Vietnam Magazine, author of the book ``On Strategy,'' and twice decorated for valor, says there is a very strong statement of patriotism in most of the literature he has seen. ``Not happy about the way it all ended, but certainly proud that they'd served their country and I think that represents the true feeling of most Vietnam vets.'' Michael Norman says war puts a lie to the notion that men fight for a flag and they fight for their country. ``They fight to stand by the man on their right or left, the people that they're close to at the moment. And they fight to survive.'' Sharon Lane was posthumously awarded a galaxy of medals and a memorial statue of her stands in the courtyard of Aultman Hospital in Canton, Ohio, where she went to nursing school. Her mother, Kay Lane, recalls that ``she just thought she was a nobody, you know, just an ordinary person, and everybody tries to make a hero out of her now.''

DOC.TEXT: John Silber's 95-year-old mother once told him, ``Son, your tongue will be your ruin.'' As he seeks the Democratic nomination for governor of Massachusetts, the outspoken president of Boston University has begun to heed those words. Still, this transplanted Texan is not one to shy away from a fight.

John Silber's most distinctive feature is not his deformed right arm, a stump he learned to use as a weapon in schoolyard scraps. What is most physically striking are the furrows that crease his face, especially when he argues. And those furrows are likely to deepen in the coming weeks as this Kant scholar who whipped Boston University into shape goes after the Democratic nomination for governor of Massachusetts. The 63-year-old philosopher-turned-politician, a wiry man who stands just 5-feet-7, will take on anyone in an argument. ``I love it. I love it. It's a sport,'' he says, seated in his spartan campaign office furnished with rented green leather couches, his blue eyes framed by a full head of brown hair. ``It's a participation sport. Some people like fencing, and I like arguing. Obviously I like arguing.'' A transplanted Texan now serving as president of Boston University, Silber is the squeaky wheel in a four-way race for the job a politically weary Gov. Michael Dukakis no longer wants. His competitors at the Democratic Party convention June 1-2 are the lieutenant governor, a former state attorney general and a state lawmaker. In his native Texas they would call John Silber a maverick. Argumentative as a child, combative as a scholar and daring as a university administrator, he is kicking up a dust-storm of controversy. First he complained about the state's welfare largess and Cambodian immigrants in a way some people thought smacked of racism. Then he shared his views on alcoholism in a way critics said trivialized the problem. And he raised hackles when he called Jews racist during an interview in which he recalled his attraction to Judaism as a 21-year-old divinity student at Yale. Silber says he considered converting but decided not to when he discovered ``the racism of Jews is quite phenomenal'' in treating converts as ``second-class.'' It was more than 10 years later, after his father died, that Silber learned his father was Jewish. Silber fought back against the critics. He said he was misquoted, misunderstood and a victim of media distortion. He pointed out his unwavering support for minorities and Israel. But if some in reserved New England call Silber a provocative outsider, that's the way he likes it. He thinks voters like it, too, and that the confrontational style he was weaned on in Texas works here as well. ``It also gets the point across in Massachusetts,'' he says. ``It may not be the style that some reporters like. It may not be the style that some people in universities like. But it's a style that the taxpayers like a very great deal.'' Still, Silber is learning to turn down the fire on the hustings. After the first explosive weeks, he began minding what he said. He seems to have heeded his 95-year-old mother, who he says told him: ``Son, your tongue will be your ruin.'' A wittier, circumspect John Silber demonstrated what he's learned on the campaign trail at a breakfast early in March with 150 members of the Lexington Chamber of Commerce. Since coming to Massachusetts 19 years ago, he began, ``I tried to tell the truth and shame the devil. Now I've heard I have to charm a few people at the same time.'' He cracked a joke about the once-touted Massachusetts economic miracle. ``A miracle is a phenomenon for which there is no rational explanation. We had a Massachusetts mirage.'' The audience loved it. Many said they came out of curiosity to hear the one interesting candidate around. But they were enchanted after he said how he wanted to overhaul the state budget process to tighten spending and efficiency, how he wanted to weed out waste in state operations and ``put an end to amateur hour'' running state agencies, how he was committed to improving education and stimulating the state economy with tax incentives.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
BOSTON: tax incentives.
DOC.TEXT: The son of a German architect and a Texas schoolteacher, Silber is fond of saying he has been a Democrat since age 10. He also voted for Republican Presidents Reagan and Bush. He labels himself both a populist and an elitist. And for a political novice, he has shown a politician's flair in making over Boston University and taking his message of education reform on the road. ``I could be speaking every night in this state, and that was before I announced for governor,'' he says. If you haven't heard him speak, you can read: ``Straight Shooting: What's Wrong With America and How to Fix It,'' published last year by Harper & Row. Silber was educated at Trinity University in his hometown, San Antonio, and at Yale. He has six daughters and a son. He was 44 when he took over Boston University 19 years ago. He had just been fired as dean of arts and sciences at the University of Texas at Austin, following years of discord between him and the Board of Regents over changes made in his department and his criticism of university policies. As the president of Boston University, he transformed an academically uneven, debt-burdened school into a solid institution with 26,000 students, an endowment of $183 million and a budget nearing $500 million. The early years of his term at the university were rough. Silber fought with faculty over politics, labor organizing and tenure. He survived attempted faculty coups and revolts. Students and civil libertarians protested when he ordered the removal of anti-apartheid banners from dormitory windows and he limited overnight dorm visits by members of the opposite sex. Silber wants to govern the state because, he says, he knows a better way and because he thinks public service is an obligation. If it gets any deeper than that, he won't say. ``I think people who can serve and who can afford to take the financial sacrifice necessary to serve, every now and then, ought to do so.'' As president of Boston University, Silber gets $275,000 a year and a house. The governor earns $75,000 and that's it. Massachusetts provides no governor's mansion. ``A lot of people wouldn't give up $200,000,'' Silber says. ``I don't give a fig for money in that sense. Money never gave anybody a meaningful life.'' William Goetzmann, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian at the University of Texas headed the department when Silber was running things there in 1969-70. Goetzmann is no Silber chum, but he respects him. ``I would regard him as a tough person, and yet underneath the sort of tough initial appearance or manner he can also be reasoned with,'' Goetzmann says. Goetzman says Silber reminds him of Michael Dukakis with that ``sort of steely eyed determination.'' ``He puts all his guns on the bar,'' Goetzman says. ``He is a doer.'' Silber has the support of Senate President William Bulger, one of the most powerful people at the statehouse, and former Boston Mayor Kevin White, now a Boston University faculty member. But some political observers don't believe he can win. ``It doesn't look good,'' says Paul Watanabe, a political scientist at the University of Massachusetts in Boston. Silber needs at least 15 percent of the approximately 5,000 state convention delegates to get on the Sept. 18 primary ballot. Ralph Whitehead, a political observer who teaches journalism at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, is more optimistic. Even in the clubby world of Democratic Party politics, Silber should be able to acquire the requisite delegates to make the primary, Whitehead says. And with the campaign expected to be a string of debates, Silber can be expected to shine. ``There's no question that the Democratic state convention is highly unlikely to encourage a Silber candidacy,'' Whitehead says. ``Nevertheless, it might still accept a Silber candidacy. ``I don't count John Silber out.''

DOC.TEXT: After 15 years, director Francis Ford Coppola and actor Al Pacino are back together again to make a third ``Godfather'' movie, a super-secret production being filmed in Rome, Sicily and New York at a cost of $44 million. It is expected to be released around Thanksgiving.
DOC.HEAD: By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to making ``The Godfather, Part III,'' omerta is the word. Silence. The Mafia's code of silence. ``I just know to keep my mouth shut and my script in the safe,'' says Franc D'Ambrosio, who plays Tony Corleone, son of Cosa Nostra chieftain Michael Corleone. When we last saw Michael in ``Godfather, Part II,'' he was having his older brother, Fredo, shot through the head on a fishing boat on Lake Tahoe. Now, 15 years later, director Francis Ford Coppola and most of the cast are back together to make the third chapter of one of the most successful movie sagas of all time. The $44 million production, set in 1979, is being shot in Rome, Sicily and New York and is targeted for release in the United States around Thanksgiving. The basic storyline has leaked out: Michael, played again by Al Pacino, seeks to legitimize the Corleone family by teaming up with a Vatican archbishop who helps him acquire a stake in a European multinational corporation. But the script and the stars, especially Pacino, Diane Keaton and Andy Garcia, are being kept tightly under wraps. The final 12 pages of the script are so secret they were reportedly printed on special paper that can't be photocopied. D'Ambrosio says Pacino, who is made up to look 60 years old, and Keaton, who plays the don's estranged wife, Kay, are so adamant about not being photographed that extras are checked to make sure they're not sneaking cameras onto the set. ``The production assistants are always aware of a flash anywhere,'' says D'Ambrosio, turning to a nervous Coppola aide for instructions on what he can and can't say. Coppola at age 50 has more than his artistic reputation on the line. His financial survival is at stake. A string of box-office flops such as ``One From the Heart,'' ``Rumble Fish'' and ``The Outsiders'' have left him and his Zoetrope studios in economic shambles. In late January, Coppola and Zoetrope Productions filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors, listing assets of $22.2 million and debts of $28.9 million. The move followed protracted litigation over debts owed to Jack Singer, a Canadian real estate developer who lent Coppola $3 million to help him complete ``One From the Heart.'' Coppola hopes to duplicate the success of the first two ``Godfather'' movies, which won the Academy Award for best picture in 1972 and 1974 and together have grossed some $800 million worldwide. Coppola was voted best director, producer and writer for ``Godfather II,'' widely hailed as one of the best film sequels ever made. With Marlon Brando portraying aging boss Vito Corleone, the first ``Godfather'' described the ascendancy of the Italian-American Corleone crime family in New York and Las Vegas. Son Michael murders his father's archenemy in a New York restaurant, hides out in Sicily for more than a year, and returns to the United States to assume power as the new godfather. Part II jumps back and forth between the early years of Vito Corleone, played by Robert De Niro, and the late 1950s when Michael consolidates his power. The film culminates with Michael, feeling betrayed, having his brother murdered. Despite the obvious potential of a third ``Godfather'' installment, Coppola had vowed not to get involved again with the Corleone family. ``If I had to do it, I would just take the story and tell it again, which is what they do on these sequels,'' the director, who declined to be interviewed for this article, is quoted as saying in the recently released book ``Coppola'' by Peter Cowie. ``I'm not really interested in gangsters anymore.'' It took Paramount Pictures 15 years to get the cameras rolling on ``Godfather III.'' Untold numbers of directors, producers, writers and screenplays were considered and rejected. Among the Hollywood heavyweights reportedly interested in the project were Sylvester Stallone and Eddie Murphy. Last year Coppola finally agreed to join forces again with Mario Puzo, whose best-selling novel gave rise to the ``Godfather'' movies, to develop the story for part III. According to the Hollywood trade publication Variety, Coppola's decision probably stemmed in large part from the financial incentives. Paramount made him _ what else? _ an offer he couldn't refuse: some $6 million, plus a share of the gross. (His signing fee for the first Godfather was $125,000.) To perfect the script, Coppola invited actors and crew to his 1,500-acre estate in the Napa Valley near San Francisco. Coppola has reassembled many of the cast and crew of the earlier ``Godfather'' pictures. For three months, they've been headquartered at Rome's Cinecitta studios, a 148-acre complex where most of the interior scenes are being filmed. Behind the camera again are producers Fred Roos and Gray Frederickson, production designer Dean Tavoularis, photography director Gordon Willis and music composer Carmine Coppola, the director's father. On screen, besides Pacino and Keaton, Coppola's sister, Talia Shire, is back as Connie Corleone and Al Martino returns as Johnny Fontane, the crooner in the first ``Godfather.'' But there are also new faces and a new generation of Corleones. The key figure is Garcia, who plays Vincent Mancini, Michael's illegitimate nephew, born of the tryst between Sonny Corleone and a bridesmaid during the wedding party in the first film. Vincent is Michael's apparent heir. Coppola's daughter, Sofia, has the role of Mary Corleone, Michael's daughter. Other newcomers are Bridget Fonda as journalist Grace Madison, Joe Mantegna as gangster Joey Zasa, George Hamilton as arbitrageur B.J. Harrison and Eli Wallach as Don Altobello. Donal Donnelly plays Irish Archbishop Terence Kilday, a Vatican bank official who acts as the intermediary in the Corleone family's new business ventures. The story stems from the real-life scandal involving the Vatican bank's alleged role in the 1982 collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, Italy's largest private bank. D'Ambrosio, a 27-year-old tenor from New York, was a surprise choice for the role of Tony Corleone. He was appearing in Broadway's ``Sweeney Todd'' when he was signed up, beating out more than 1,000 others who auditioned for the part. It is his first movie. ``I call it the Godfather University,'' D'Ambrosio says. ``It's a crash course. I'm learning from the best.''
