DOC.TEXT: In the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York, the village of Saranac Lake was known as ``The City of the Sick,'' a place where tuberculosis sufferers came to take the cure. Modern antibiotics put an end to that, and the town almost died.

Saranac Lake once was a typical one-industry town _ with a difference. Its business was illness. For nearly 70 years, Saranac Lake was synonymous with both a feared disease, tuberculosis, and the sanitarium ``cure,'' medical science's best guess as to how to treat what was once mankind's greatest killer. The TB sufferers have been gone for a generation, but Saranac Lake endures, still proud to be known as the ``City of the Sick.'' Salvation to TB sufferers came in the early 1950s with the development of an effective antibiotic treatment for the disease. But that also dealt an economic blow to this remote Adirondack Mountain village about 270 miles north of New York City. ``It was a disaster for the community,'' says Barbara Parnass of Historic Saranac Lake, a preservation group. ``It wasn't the kind of thing that was dramatic like a fire. But the slow ebbing of the curing industry affected the community very severely.'' In its curing heyday, spitting on Saranac Lake's sidewalks could get you a summons from the police, because the dreaded TB infection was contained in the sputum of a tubercular. It was a place where radios went dead each afternoon, when TB patients were supposed to be resting silently in the open air of their cure porches. ``In some ways, the village had been run by the doctors and the lawyers and the bankers,'' Parnass says. ``They sat on the board of health. They made the rules and regulations. There was a very precise booklet printed up telling everyone how to behave. When the curing collapsed, the doctors retired or they found other places to practice. That left an awful lot of the service industry here with nobody to service.'' Only in recent years has Saranac Lake finally showed signs of snapping out of it. The Tudor-style Will Rogers Hospital, which once cared for show business tuberculars, has just been converted to condominiums. The Trudeau Sanitarium is now a conference center owned by the American Management Association. The nearby Ray Brook Sanitarium is a state prison. And many of the 300 cure cottages, the residential mini-hospitals that made Saranac Lake unique among TB centers, are being restored by private homeowners to their turn-of-the-century grandeur. Parnass says the sudden collapse of the TB industry helped from the viewpoint of historical preservation in Saranac Lake. ``When the plug was pulled, the economic bottom dropped out of the whole village,'' she says. ``The railroad stopped running. There was no money to tear down and put up new houses. In some ways it was good because it held the housing stock where it was.'' Nine out of 10 structures in Saranac Lake, which has about 5,500 residents today, were built before World War II. Parnass' group recently applied to have 187 buildings in the village, including 63 cure cottages, added to the National Register of Historic Places. The village is remembering its legacy in other ways, too. A sign proclaiming Saranac Lake as America's ``Pioneer Health Resort'' still greets visitors. In September, Parnass' group will sponsor the second reunion in Saranac Lake of cure patients, their relatives, doctors, nurses and others involved in the TB industry. About 200 people attended the first reunion in 1987. They are among the dwindling circle of people who remember firsthand the misery and terror generated by tuberculosis. The disease was the ``White Plague,'' the killer that stalked slums and fashionable drawing rooms with equal impunity. Keats, Thoreau and Kafka were just a few of the leading lights of their ages to die from the disease, popularly called ``consumption'' because of the way TB appears to consume the tattered tissue of the lungs of victims stricken with its most common form, pulmonary tuberculosis. What made tuberculosis seem even more terrible was that, for a long time, no one was sure what caused it. Even when a German physician, Dr. Robert Koch, identified the bacterium responsible for TB in 1882, it took researchers another 70 years to find the right antibiotics to effectively attack the infection. Dr. Lee Reichman, speaking for the American Lung Association, compared the fear surrounding TB when it was at its height in the late 19th century and early 20th century as similar to the fear now created by acquired immune deficiency syndrome. In their quest to find some effective treatment for the disease, American doctors began to recommend that tuberculars live in dry climates or in elevated places like the mountains of the American Southwest, the Rockies or the Adirondacks of New York state. It was thought that such an atmosphere would dry out the clogged lungs of TB patients and retard the spread of their infections. Dr. Edward Livingston Trudeau, a tubercular who believed that being in the Adirondacks saved his life, was credited with popularizing the region as a health resort. In 1884, Trudeau established the first U.S. sanitarium for the treatment of TB patients in Saranac Lake. Modeled on German sanitariums of the same era, Trudeau used the tiny, two-patient cottage, later nicknamed ``Little Red,'' to develop a model for treatment that was eventually adopted by most American sanitariums. The main activity at a ``san'' was inactivity. Patients were exposed to fresh air, during the harshest days of winter as well as in sweltering summer heat, by sitting quietly for hours at a time on specially designed lounging chairs. Patients deemed too ill to sit or stand were wheeled onto the porches in their beds. The body temperature and weight of patients was monitored carefully and a great emphasis was placed on proper diet. Saranac Lake took pains to be a happy place, to make tuberculars welcome and to ease their burden. There were picnics, sleigh rides, hay rides and bedside instruction on activities from bookbinding and bird-watching. A winter carnival that began in 1897 as a diversion for TB patients is now billed by village fathers as the oldest of its kind in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 2 b&w photos. ColorFoto subscribers get 1 35mm slide.)
DOC.TEXT: From the Shenandoah Valley of West Virginia ``The Martinsburg Monster'' is keeping an eye on American taxpayers. The ``monster'' is a huge central computer center where the Internal Revenue Service keeps track of its $1 trillion-a-year collections.

The heart of the Internal Revenue Service doesn't beat. It whirls, beeps and blinks at dizzying speeds on dozens of computers and about 330,000 spools of computer tape guarded like a fortress. It has your number. ``This is the one place where it all comes together and where it all goes back out,'' says Gerald Rabe, director of the Martinsburg Computing Center, dubbed ``The Martinsburg Monster.'' ``I would say the computer system we use here is probably second to none in the amount of data processed.'' Row upon row of blue-and-tan computers hum inside a single-story brick building about 80 miles northwest of Washington, sending and retrieving bits of information from the tax returns of more than 140 million individual taxpayers and about 50 million businesses. The magnetic tapes in the master file could circle the Earth at the equator 5{ times, IRS spokesman Charles Koeneke says. Income, interest, deductions and other tabulations from every tax return filed in the United States are stored at the center for an average of five years. Paper returns are sent to federal records centers around the country where they are stored in boxes for an average of seven years before they are burned. ``It depends on what type of taxpayer the individual is,'' Rabe says. ``If you have a criminal case or there is some other problem, those records are kept longer than those of a so-called `good' taxpayer.'' Information gleaned from President Bush's recent tax returns is stored here, among tidbits gleaned from Ronald Reagan's, Donald Trump's and those with more mundane tax histories. ``All taxpayers are created equal in our eyes,'' Rabe says. The computer tapes which make up the IRS master file are locked away in the center's room-size vault kept between 68 and 72 degrees and at 35 percent relative humidity. The vault uses heat generated by the center's dozens of mainframe computers and body heat to keep the nearly constant conditions. The $1 trillion in federal taxes paid in fiscal 1988 paid for the IRS center, and most of the rest of the federal government, according to Frank Keith, an IRS spokesman in Washington. The master file is restricted to a limited number of employees and 10 IRS service centers in Atlanta; Philadelphia; Kansas City, Mo.; Andover, Mass.; Austin, Texas; Holtsville, N.Y.; Covington, Ky.; Fresno, Calif.; Memphis, Tenn.; and Ogden, Utah. The regional centers use the master file to verify returns and to determine whether a tax refund or payment is due. It takes 700 computer programmers, analysts, operators and others working three shifts every day to keep the center operating all year. ``Everyone thinks we're coming up to the busiest time of year for the IRS. That's not true,'' Rabe says. ``We have a work schedule that keeps us busy 52 weeks a year. The business side goes on year-round with the filing of quarterly reports and other programs.'' The people's tax returns are guarded in an accountant's Fort Knox. The low-slung, buff-colored building is surrounded by a 10-foot-high chain-link fence topped with strands of glistening barbed wire. Armed IRS guards patrol the grounds set among apple and peach orchards in the Shenandoah Valley. Three hidden diesel generators stand ready to deliver emergency electricity to the center's computers and air conditioning system in the event of a blackout. Teams of programmers and technicians are on-call 24 hours a day at the center to purge glitches and to keep data from disappearing. Koeneke refused to divulge other backups for the heart of the IRS system that reaches into the pockets of millions of taxpayers each April 15. ``We're probably the best kept secret in town,'' he says. When the center opened in 1961 with five employees, there was little inkling of the explosive growth to come. It had a single IBM computer with less storage capacity than most of today's home computers and 1,700 magnetic tapes to handle an estimated 78 million tax returns. The original 39,000-square-foot center cost $5.3 million in 1961. At the time, many believed it was built in Martinsburg because of West Virginia's critical support of John F. Kennedy over Hubert Humphrey in the state's 1960 Democratic primary for the presidential nomination. Since then, the center has more than tripled in size. It is one of the largest employers in West Virginia's Eastern Panhandle. Before the center opened, tax returns were processed by thousands of clerks who relied on boxes and boxes of records kept around the country. The IRS is now testing a system that accepts electronic tax returns prepared by computer and the storage of data on electronic disks instead of magnetic tape. ``We're just getting into telecommunications,'' says Rabe, who started his IRS career as a computer programmer trainee in 1964. Critics, including members of Congress and the General Accounting Office, have said the IRS needs to replace its aging computer system, a move that could cost as much $11 billion, according to Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., chairman of the Senate finance oversight subcommittee. The GAO puts the cost between $3 billion and $4 billion. Planned improvements will put laptop computers into the hands of revenue agents and tax collectors. An expanded master file operating as a data base available to a number of computer facilities also is in the works, IRS officials say. ``We want to get to the point where banks and gas and electric companies are right now,'' said Rabe. ``If you call us with a question, we want to be able to call up your entire account on the computer screen and answer your questions immediately instead of waiting there to get a response from a service center.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: The word is that ``Elvis'' is not dead, just waiting to make a comeback. The ABC Sunday night television series, which stars Michael St. Gerard as rock 'n' roll singer Elvis Presley, was taken off the air in mid-March after a poor performance in the ratings race. The critically acclaimed show continues in production, however, as the network looks for a new time period. ABC officials say it could return as early as May. ABC had high hopes for ``Elvis,'' which followed ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' on Sunday. But several things happened to derail those hopes. The video show became such a runaway hit that the ratings for ``Elvis,'' by comparison, looked dismal. Even a preview behind top-rated ``Roseanne'' didn't help. Next, Fox Broadcasting scheduled the animated show ``The Simpsons'' against it, and that show creamed ``Elvis.'' Most young viewers watch ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' then switch to Fox for ``The Simpsons.'' The rest of the country watches CBS's ``Murder, She Wrote'' or the NBC movie. In the ratings, ``Elvis' came in only slightly ahead of the Fox also-rans. The decision to pull ``Elvis'' came after ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' finished first in the Nielsen ratings for the week ending March 11, while ``Elvis'' was 45th. ABC felt it had to act because of the enormous drop in viewership. In the overall ratings for the 1989-90 season, ``Elvis'' was in 56th place, halfway through the Nielsen ratings of the 112 shows in prime time _ including those that have been replaced. On the plus side, ``Elvis'' did better than anything else ABC has tried in that Sunday time slot in a long time. Young viewers who control the sets early Sunday night apparently aren't aware of Presley. If they remember him at all, it's from his later, bloated, Las Vegas years. Even St. Gerard, who's 27, concedes he wasn't an Elvis fan. St. Gerard, in an interview before the ABC decision, said that he doesn't pay much attention to the ratings and that ABC executives told him they would stick with the show. ``I do my best and after that it's not in my hands,'' he says. ``I figure anybody cool is going to watch us. It's a quality show. The critical reaction has been overwhelming. We set out to do something respectful of an American legend. I never took this as a joke.'' The show is filmed on authentic locations in Memphis, Tenn., and St. Gerard strives for an interpretation rather than an imitation. He looks remarkably like Presley even without the benefit of makeup and he possesses the singer's early charm and shyness. He lip-syncs to lyrics sung by Ronnie McDowell because the scenes require more flexibility than is found in original Presley recordings. St. Gerard was in Los Angeles for a few days after he began filming ``Elvis'' late last year. He lives in New York, where he played a small role in an ABC Afterschool Special, ``The Accident.'' Regardless of the outcome of ``Elvis,'' St. Gerard seems assured of a booming career. He previously starred in the movie ``Hairspray,'' and now he's reading nine scripts to see what his next picture will be. First, he was returning to Memphis to film four more episodes of ``Elvis.'' ``I'm anxious to get back,'' he says. ``I love the South. I miss it. I miss my friends there. I miss Elvis, too. It's funny. I miss playing the part. ``Elvis was a very complex person. He was naive in some ways, but in other ways he was very focused and determined. He knew how to get his point across. He had a way of handling himself. On stage, he was the king.'' St. Gerard says filming ``Elvis'' in Memphis has been like a homecoming in some respects. Priscilla Presley, Elvis' former wife, is one of the executive producers. Many of Presley's old friends have shown up to help. He plays Presley between ages 19 and 21, when times were still tough and the singer was just beginning to attract attention with his music. Billy Green Bush plays his father and Millie Perkins (``The Diary of Anne Frank'') plays his mother. ``I hope we can take the show up to the time when his mother dies,'' St. Gerard says. ``That was the end of an era. She died in 1958 when he was in the Army. After that, his motivation changed. In the beginning his motivation was to pull his family out of its lower economic strata. He had a lot of drive.'' Elvis Presley has been portrayed on the screen before. Kurt Russell played him in the 1977 ABC movie ``Elvis,'' which beat ``Gone With the Wind'' in the ratings. Don Johnson was Presley in the 1981 NBC movie ``Elvis and the Beauty Queen.'' Dale Midkiff was Presley in the 1988 TV movie ``Elvis and Me,'' based on Priscilla Presley's book. McDowell sang for all the movies.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Since Stephen Lang landed his latest role as a Marine officer in ``A Few Good Men'' on Broadway, he has been obsessively shining his boots. In the play at the Music Box Theater, Lang is Lt. Col. Nathan Jessup, a base commander so gung-ho he's demented. ``When I'm shining my boots, it makes me feel more like a Marine,'' Lang says. ``I've been working on my left boot for months. It will not take a shine. It's recalcitrant.'' Lang arrives at the theater two or three hours before the curtain goes up. ``I'm chronically early,'' he says. ``The deeper I get into a run, the more necessary it is for me to put in the time. ``I enjoy coming in and `Jessuping around' for a while. I'll look in the mirror and try to find him. I lift a couple of weights.'' Lang says some aspects of characters he plays often stick with him off the stage. ``But I keep a pretty sharp lasso on them, too. I haven't been marching the troops at home.'' And he made sure that Harry Black, ``the total wreck of a human being'' he plays in the new film ``Last Exit to Brooklyn,'' stayed at the movie's all-night shoots. ``A Few Good Men'' has been bought _ but not cast _ for a movie. Lang and his wife of 10 years met when she designed his costume for a TV drama. ``I think big families are coming back,'' he says. ``We have a girl, two boys and are expecting a girl.'' His father, Eugene Lang, a company president, told 61 sixth-graders in Harlem in 1981 that if they finished high school, he'd pay their college tuition. He later founded the I Have a Dream Foundation, which now has 130 sponsors in 32 cities backing more than 8,000 children. ``He's a guy who's always looking for outlets for his own creativity and he found it in a really unique way,'' says the younger Lang. About his own profession, Lang says: ``I think I was born to act and I'm very lucky that I just knew that. I don't do it for therapy. I'm less neurotic about acting than I am about most other things.'' In ``A Few Good Men,'' a Marine private has died and two Marines are accused of murder. A lawyer, played by Tom Hulce, suspects Jessup of being behind the death. Jessup is one of the more interesting, complex characters Lang has played. ``He has not turned into an egomaniac,'' Lang says. ``I think he manipulates the power of the office and the power of his personality.'' ``Jessup is a great quoter. The author (Aaron Sorkin) wanted to endow him with a certain arcane elegance, to make him not just a contemporary figure but a larger-than-life figure who can speak with real authority on literature and poetry. ``I think we associate Jessup with a passion. Yeats said the worst are full of a passionate intensity while the best lack all conviction. In that sense you could say Jessup is one of the worst. He is not a skeptic in an age of skepticism and he is not a cynic in an age of cynicism. Neither is he a blind believer. He is a man who has chosen a path for himself, whether we admire that path or not. ``When Jessup goes, he flames out. He is not `seeking treatment.' He says, `This is who I am.''' Lang recently played a different type of soldier, a homeless Vietnam vet, in Steve Tesich's ``Speed of Darkness'' in Chicago. He'll probably repeat it on Broadway. Lang played Happy when Dustin Hoffman starred in ``Death of a Salesman'' on Broadway and was Rosencrantz in an off-Broadway revival of ``Rosencrantz and Gildenstern Are Dead.'' He wants to play Hamlet, having played Horatio to Christopher Walken's Hamlet in 1982. And he'd like to use his ``character singing voice'' in Gilbert and Sullivan, his childhood theatrical love. ``I'd be a good Jack Point in `The Yeomen of the Guard,''' he says. ``If anybody asked me to do it, I'd have a very hard time turning it down.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, March 25, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Greatest Threat to New Government
DOC.TEXT: Noriega is gone, but one-third of Panamanians are out of work and unemployment has become the greatest threat to the new government. ``It has to be resolved or the country will go into a spiral of robberies ... strikes, demonstrations against the government and backlash against the U.S.,'' said Carlos Rodriguez, a Panamanian who is vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce. For now, there seems to be no opposition to President Guillermo Endara's new government. The end of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's corrupt, repressive dictatorship and the lifting of U.S. economic sanctions have brought hope. The government is scratching to keep itself afloat, however, and has nothing to invest in reactivating the economy. It is looking to U.S. aid and private enterprise to do the job. Jorge Heraza, 21, finished high school three years ago with a specialty in commercial accounting, which seemed sensible in an economy that is 70 percent to 80 percent services. He still fills out job applications, and still has no job. The Dec. 20 invasion that ousted Noriega and installed Endara seemed like a good idea, he said, ``but they must follow through. They say they're going to give jobs, but unemployment _ with what has happened, it is worse.'' Government officials say about 33 percent of the work force, estimated at 650,000 people, is unemployed. Looting and vandalism that accompanied the invasion caused about 90 percent of businesses to close, raising the jobless figure from about 20 percent. Before the political crisis began in 1987, about 10 percent of Panamanians did not have jobs. Endara fasted during the first 12 days of March to dramatize Panama's economic problems. He has criticized the slow pace of U.S. aid and of freeing government funds frozen during the Noriega regime. ``People cannot eat democracy,'' the president said. ``There could be popular unrest unless there are some quick solutions. The congressional delay of approval endangers our democracy.'' Of the Bush administration's $1 billion package, Congress has approved $43 million to rebuild the Chorrillo neighborhood, which was destroyed in the invasion, and the start of credit the administration says is worth $500 million. Panamanians say they are well-equipped to use aid effectively. ``Panama is not a basket case like some other countries,'' said Rodriguez, the general manager of Colgate-Palmolive's operations in Panama. ``It has good infrastructure, a good entrepreneurial class.'' With the U.S. dollar as its currency, Panama was a thriving international banking and trade center. That ended with the political crisis created by U.S. indictments of Noriega for drug trafficking, his dismissal of presidents, the closing of banks for nine weeks in 1988 and U.S. economic sanctions. Assets in the cluster of gleaming, modern banking towers plummeted from $40 billion in June 1987 to less than $15 million two years later. On streets that had teemed with visitors buying cameras, electronic equipment, watches and tailored suits, business slowed to a trickle. The gross national product fell 20 percent in 1988 and 7.5 percent more in 1989. Much of the government's revenue was lost to corruption. ``If you stop the corruption, that by itself is income. It was that bad,'' said Guillermo Ford, the second vice president and planning minister. Since the invasion, the government has survived on gradually improving tax revenue and partial release of the $390 million in frozen funds. ``There is a change in mentality'' about taxes, said Willie Cochez, the new mayor of Panama City. ``They know people like President Endara will not steal the money and they decide to pay.'' Officials continue plugging corruption leaks. Kindergartens are $3,000 a month better off since Cochez sent a department head to jail for stealing that much. New officials cut their own salaries, which saves $2.1 million a year. Endara's pay was reduced from $10,000 a month to $7,000. Until Panama pays the $540 million in arrears on its $5.2 billion foreign debt, it will not be eligible for new loans. Rodriguez, the businessman, feels Panamanians may be too optimistic. ``People probably feel the problems are over and they are not,'' he said. ``They probably think it will rebound to pre-1987 in three months and it will not.'' He said unemployment is a ``time bomb against the Endara government or any democratic government.'' Government strategy is to strengthen the private sector by selling state-owned Air Panama, sugar mills and cement and citrus processing plants, Ford said. Some businessmen even suggest that the Panama Canal, to be turned over to Panama at the end of 1999, could be operated as a concession. A major worry in this strategy is reducing the payroll of 150,000 before there are enough new jobs for the people dismissed. Crime has skyrocketed because of unemployment and because so many weapons are in the hands of paramilitary groups set up by Noriega. Police said murders have gone up from four a month to 30. For the long term, Rodriguez said, officials speak of a U.S.-Panama free trade agreement similar to those the United States has with Canada and Israel. Panama has had the Colon free-trade zone for years and it was not seriously affected by the crisis. Officials are promoting establishment of new in-bond plants there, which assemble products for export, and expansion of existing ones. The zone also does a brisk trade in transshipment of goods. International banking could revive, but is considered unlikely to regain its former prominence. Panamanians dismiss concerns that the banks could again become a haven for drug money and say current secrecy laws allow access to information when laundering is suspected. ``The perception in Panama is that the U.S. is delaying approval of the economic recovery package to squeeze out tighter restrictions on banking, tighter restrictions on Cuba-related companies,'' Rodriguez said. Ruben Dario Carles, a former banker and now the government's comptroller, said: ``We cannot sit and wait. We have to deliver the goods. We have to get this thing moving. ``Every unemployed person has a reason to protest and it will be bad if 200,000 protest.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Older Athletes Run For Science
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sunday in penultimate graf is March 25. A version on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Athletes run for many reasons, but members of the Fifty-Plus Runners' Association have found a new one: They run for science. Of course, the members run for all those other reasons, too: keeping fit, losing weight, improving their heart and lungs, dealing with tension or depression, or becoming or staying competitive. Their personal goals dovetail nicely with researchers' desires to learn more about the effects of extended physical activity on older people. ``We see this organization as a role model, a pioneering group. It's a whole new lifestyle for older men and women,'' said Keith Johnsgard, president of Fifty-Plus and a professor at San Jose State University in California. ``They don't have to live the sedentary life that older people do or are expected to.'' Fifty-Plus is not a running club. Sponsored by the Center for Research in Disease Prevention at Stanford University, its goal is to gather a list of highly active seniors for researchers to plumb. Fifty-Plus has 1,600 members. Topics already being studied include how continued physical exercise affects osteoarthritis and osteoporosis. Researchers have found that older runners, male and female, had about 40 percent more bone mineral _ and no more tendencies toward osteoarthritis in their knees _ than seniors who don't exercise. ``Before this, it was generally thought that people who spent a lot of time running would invariably damage their knees,'' said Peter Wood, a biochemist, former Fifty-Plus president and co-author of the study. Wood said good mineral density was important, especially for women, because it helped prevent problems like dowager's hump or osteoporosis. Researchers also have found that Fifty-Plus members consumed 40 percent to 60 percent more calories daily than their sedentary peers _ but had higher levels of the ``good'' cholesterol (high-density lipoprotein cholesterol), which has been associated with a relatively low risk of heart disease. ``When you are eating a good amount, you are more likely to get an adequate supply of nutrients _ and for women a good supply of calcium,'' Wood said. The group's most recent survey found that 85 percent of its members were men. They averaged 59.8 years old, have been running for 13.7 years and covered 26.4 miles per week. Forty-five percent had completed a marathon (26.2 miles) and the vast majority had run at least one 10-kilometer (6.2 miles) race. Fifty-Plus women averaged 58.8 years, had been running for 9.5 years and covered an average of 21.2 miles a week. Fifty-Plus now is looking for a corporate sponsor to help increase its membership and attract a wider group of scientists. ``We'd like to expand membership, and get some really good long-term studies going,'' Johnsgard said. ``Bring in some young, hot-shot epidemiologist who can study us until we're all dead. We are too old to do the really long-term stuff.'' Several members cited the research emphasis as the reason they joined Fifty-Plus. ``The studies attracted me to it,'' said Kent Gartner, 56, a cell biologist at Memphis State University who has been running for 20 years. ``The research they're doing is not only interesting, it's important,'' said Bob Binzer, 67, of Madison, Ind. ``It's inspiring, and you get good advice from the organization.'' Binzer was referring to the association's quarterly newsletter, which summarizes research involving members and publishes health and sports-related articles. ``I really enjoy the newsletter and it's great they're doing this research,'' agreed Betty Brinkmann, 55, of Brighton, Colo. A dietician, she says she often uses information from the newsletter in her own work with cardiovascular rehabilitation patients. Johnsgard, a clinical psychologist, has studied what prompts seniors to begin running and then keep running using Fifty-Plus members. The book that resulted, ``The Exercise Prescription for Depression and Anxiety,'' examines the beneficial effects of continued physical activity on seniors' mental health. The athletes get together once a year _ this year, they'll meet Sunday at Stanford _ for a seminar and business meeting, a generous pasta dinner and an eight-kilometer run. Age-group categories for the race begin at 50 and go up to 100 in five-year intervals, with nearly 400 runners expected. ``It's a gathering of the brothers and the sisters _ a tribal thing,'' Johnsgard said. ``People who exercise regularly in the U.S. are unusual, but people over 50 who exercise are extremely rare. It's like coming home.''
For more information, write Fifty-Plus Runners's Association, P.O. Box D, Stanford, Calif. 94305, 415-723-9790.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Ski Club Open to Slow Skiers But Not Young Ones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The entry requirements are few. ``You have to be an active downhill skier. You must be 70 years of age,'' says Lloyd T. Lambert, founder of the 70-Plus Ski Club. ``You pay $5 for a lifetime membership.'' The claims more than 5,500 members across the country. ``I'm not that speedy any more, but we've got some really, really hot shots,'' said Lambert, 89, who heads the group from his home in Ballston Lake. Senior citizens are staying in shape on the slopes in droves these days, and the trend shows no signs of slowing. With older Americans keener than ever to stay active, skiing is an ideal way to exercise through the winter. ``It's caught on now to where it (membership) has grown 75 percent a year,'' said Bill Vandersluin, 59, spokesman for The Over The Hill Gang, an elderly skiers group based in Aurora, Colo. One member from Los Angeles is living proof ``there's never any shortage of energy'' in the group, said Vandersluin. ``She skis like a demon,'' he said. ``She's 86, and she has no grey hair.'' The Over The Hill Gang, which offers its 2,400 members white water rafting, deep sea fishing and hiking as well as skiing trips, has a minimum membership age of 50. About 6.8 percent of the 18 million to 20 million skiers in the United States are 55 or older, said Chris Stoddard, a spokesman for the United Ski Industries Association. The association is a national trade group for ski areas and ski equipment suppliers. The 70-Plus Ski Club and The Over The Hill Gang hold ski gatherings across the country and provide their members with information about where they can ski for free or at discount rates. Three hundred older skiers descended on the Catskills in New York earlier this month for the 70-Plus Ski Club's annual meeting and races at Hunter Mountain. Lambert got back from a 70-Plus trip to Switzerland last month, but he's off again for more skiing in July, this time to Argentina. Injuries among elderly skiers are few and the accidents they suffer often have little to do with their age, Lambert said. ``These guys on snow boards have run into a few of our members,'' said Lambert. ``One had a broken shoulder, another had broken ribs, and another one was bumped around.'' Injuries on the slopes have been reduced from 7.7 accidents per 1,000 ski visits in the 1950s to 2.5 injuries per 1,000 visits today, according to Stoddard. ``Skiing has an image that you're going to fall and break something,'' he said. ``That image is just not true.'' Stoddard said many older skiers avoid injury because they are usually experienced, and he attributed the overall drop in skiing injuries to improvements in boot bindings and snow making and grooming. Lambert recalls pine toe-strap skies he owned when he first hit the slopes in 1915. ``You couldn't turn or do anything that you could today, because you had nothing to hold your heel in place,'' Lambert said. ``If you wanted to stop you had to fall down or kick the skis off.''
The 70-Plus Ski Club can be reached at 104 East Side Drive, Boston Lake, N.Y., 12019, 518-399-5458. The Over The Hill Gang can be reached at 13791 East Rice Place, Aurora, Colo., 80015, 303-699-6404.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Thurmond: A Senator in His 90s for the '90s?
DOC.TEXT: Once introduced as a ``senator in his 90s for the `90s,'' J. Strom Thurmond is running for re-election and neither his age nor his Dixiecrat past looks like a serious obstacle to a seventh term. ``He has co-opted damn near everybody in South Carolina in one fashion or another,'' said Don Fowler, a Democratic political consultant, trying to explain why his party was having so much trouble finding a candidate to oppose the 87-year-old Republican senator. ``Thurmond has this very unique status in the state where it would be almost an act of discourtesy to run against him, I think that's how some of these people perceive it,'' said Earl Black, a political scientist at the University of South Carolina. ``Regardless of your political views, everyone has great affection for him,'' said Phil Lader, the Democrat contemplating a run against Thurmond. Lader, a 44-year-old businessman, 2 years old in 1948 when Thurmond, then governor of South Carolina, ran for president as a Dixiecrat, a candidacy driven by opposition to integration. ``All the laws of Washington, and all the bayonets of the Army, cannot force the Negro into our homes, our schools, our churches and our places of recreation,'' Thurmond vowed. That was 42 years ago. Times changed and so did Thurmond. Not as fast maybe, but he changed. ``People who live in contemporary times recognize that people change,'' said Theo Mitchell, a state senator planning to challenge Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell in November. Mitchell is black and said that despite Thurmond's segregationist past, the senator ``has support in the black community.'' ``People have done things in bygone eras that they certainly wouldn't do now,'' said Mitchell. ``Attitudes change as well as times.'' Thurmond lobbied to get President Nixon to appoint a black to the federal bench and supported legislation to make Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a national holiday. Those were among the high-profile stands that won Thurmond support among blacks. Equally important are day-to-day constituent services performed by his staff _ locating the lost Social Security check, speeding veterans' benefits. ``People who have problems know that they can get quick responses'' from Thurmond's staff, said Black. Call him beloved. Call him respected and a master of constituent services. But he also is 87 years old. It was Lee Atwater, a Thurmond protege and now Republican Party chairman, who once was introducing the senator at a dinner and joked that Thurmond should use the slogan ``A senator in his 90s for the `90s'' for his next re-election campaign. The audience roared. The senator looked a bit uncertain for a moment and then joined in the laughter. Thurmond was born nine years before Ronald Reagan. He made his Dixiecrat bid for the White House three years before Reagan starred in ``Bedtime for Bonzo.'' This time around, Thurmond already is running campaign commercials on South Carolina television stations. They show the senator bounding up the steps of the U.S. Capitol and doing push-ups in his office. An even bigger part of the legend of eternal youth is the Thurmond family. His wife, Nancy, is a former beauty queen, who married the senator when he was in his 60s and she was not yet 20. They went on to have four children. Lader said he would not directly raise age as an issue. ``It's up to the voters, not me to determine whether a senator who would be in his 90s for most of his term is serving effectively,'' he said. The Senate Democratic campaign committee has been urging Lader to make the run, but he described himself as taking his time about making a decision. Thousands of South Carolinians have received calls from Thurmond during his long career, Lader among them. ``The last call that I got on my way to my wedding 10 years ago, was from Senator Thurmond,'' he recalled. ``He called to wish me well.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Widow Battles Lending Giant for Home
DOC.TEXT: Lennie Williams smiles as she talks of her dead husband and the small home he helped her build 42 years ago. For the moment, at least, the poverty-stricken, 77-year-old widow seems unaware that Transamerica Corp. wants her worn but tidy home because she can't make payments of $499 a month. Mrs. Williams, who supports herself on $438 a month, doesn't remember her husband died 12 years ago, or that she put up the house, in a working-class Phoenix neighborhood, as security for a loan taken out by her former son-in-law in 1987. The Transamerica loan officer who handled the transaction says he doubts Mrs. Williams knew what she was doing. The son-in-law has disappeared. State Rep. Sandra Kennedy, who has known Mrs. Williams for more than 12 years, believes Mrs. Williams was confused in 1987. So does the doctor treating her at the time she signed the loan papers. She couldn't even remember what pills to take, said the doctor, Tali Arik. Alfred Rogers, a Maricopa County Superior Court judge who has heard pretrial testimony in Mrs. Williams' case, says it's likely that Transamerica, which measures profits in the hundreds of millions of dollars, knew or should have known Mrs. Williams was defrauded. Transamerica, which used the slogan ``Our heart is everywhere'' on its latest annual report, is not persuaded. The San Francisco-based financial giant is pressing for trial and demanding Mrs. Williams make payments. The lawsuit was filed by Mrs. Williams and her legal guardian and seeks to block Transamerica Financial Services Inc., a subsidiary, from foreclosing. It also seeks to void her part of the contract and win damages. No trial has been scheduled. The case is the latest in a series involving consumer-loan companies, and comes at a time when the collapse of many thrifts has forced more middle-class borrowers to turn to them. In Arizona alone, ITT Financial Services paid $1.7 million to settle one class-action lawsuit, and Household Finance Corp. paid about $4 million to settle another. Transamerica Financial Services has already offered to pay about $4 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that accuses it of gouging poor and middle-income borrowers. Transamerica officials did not return repeated calls seeking comment on the Williams case. But one of its attorneys, Robert Miles, said the company believes it is entitled to the property. Miles said he could not discuss the case in detail. Arizona Superintendent of Banks William H. Rivoir III said confidentiality laws prohibit him from saying whether his agency is investigating Mrs. Williams' case. Loan-industry lobbyists say this case must be an aberration. However, Bill Morris, director of litigation at Southern Arizona Legal Aid in Tucson and chief architect of the class-action suits, said the situation is believed to occur frequently. After Rogers issued a preliminary injunction blocking Transamerica from foreclosing, the company insisted Mrs. Williams post bond of $499 a month _ $61 more than her monthly income. At a minimum, it said, she should post a $20,000 down payment and pay $425 a month thereafter. The amount was bargained down to $150 a month, without the down payment, after Mrs. Williams' lawyer threatened to take the case to higher courts and set a statewide precedent if successful. Miles said the bond was needed to make sure the case goes to trial quickly. But Doug Erickson, one of Mrs. Williams' lawyers, says he's already agreed to a speedy trial. Before the foreclosure action Mrs. Williams paid $800 and offered to pay an additional $350 a month, with help from relatives. Sworn testimony by the loan officer shows it was Mrs. Williams' son-in-law, William Smith, who wanted the money in the first place. Smith had married Mrs. Williams' daughter Alma but hadn't lived with her for years, said Ms. Kennedy and Rachel Freeman, Mrs. Williams' great-niece and recently appointed legal guardian. Alma died early in 1987. Months later, Smith came around and promised he would help fix Mrs. Williams' home, according to Ms. Freeman. Instead, he allegedly took her to Transamerica, had her co-sign a $32,000 loan and disappeared. Mrs. Williams' attorneys have obtained a judgment against him, but it's of little value since they don't know where he is. The loan officer, Patrick Rajski, said Smith would not have qualified for a loan without the house as security. With an interest rate of nearly 18 percent plus 8 points in prepaid charges, the loan called for total payments of $89,820, or $499 a month over 15 years. Before bringing Mrs. Williams in for the loan-signing, Smith ``said that the least I said to her about the loan the better off it would be,'' Rajski added in sworn testimony before Rogers. ``I felt uneasy about it,'' he testified, adding that he went through with the loan anyway and never told Mrs. Williams she could lose her home. ``I didn't want to bring up the fact that we could foreclose on your home, people don't want to hear this,'' Rajski said. ``When you close a loan, you try to get through with it, you say everything you have to say and no more.'' ``I really don't think that she fully understood,'' said Rajski, who has left Transamerica for another sales job. ``I went over the loan papers,'' he said. ``When she left, was I satisfied that she knew what she was getting into? No.'' Sitting at home last week, Mrs. Williams appeared unaware of the problem. Asked how she spent her days, for example, she replied, ``I work for white people,'' referring to domestic work she has not done for years. ``It was after her heart attack that she just kind of floated away,'' said Ms. Kennedy. ``It hurt my heart when her daughter died, because she got worse.'' Prescription medicine alone consumes about $80 a month of the $438 Mrs. Williams gets from Social Security and a veteran's pension, according to Ms. Freeman, who moved in with her great-aunt and found lawyers to help her after Transamerica threatened foreclosure. The paint is peeling and the cheap carpeting is worn, but the photos and trinkets of a lifetime are all neatly in place, and Ms. Freeman and her son have patched the roof, repaired the water heater and more since moving in to the house, on a 7,500-square-foot lot in south Phoenix. If Transamerica gets its way, Mrs. Williams ``would be put out on the street with nowhere to go,'' Ms. Kennedy says. ``I'm surprised she's made it this far.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Community Looking To Become Retirement Haven
DOC.TEXT: Welcome to Ashley, North Dakota. Retirement haven. Retirement haven? ``I never heard of it before,'' said Katie Sloan, a housing specialist with the American Association of Retired Persons in Washington, D.C. Leaders of Ashley, a farm town of about 1,200 people near the South Dakota border, plan to change that. The town has no luxury condos or sandy beaches. But it has other appeals. ``You can get up at 3 a.m. and go for a walk, and no one cares. You can go for a walk to the park to see the sun rise,'' said Robert Dockter, whose father, Harold Dockter, 69, retired in Ashley. As you drive into Ashley along North Dakota Highway 11, there's the Lake Hoskins Recreation Area, then farm fields with gray grain elevators standing guard along the railroad tracks. Main Street has the McIntosh County Bank, a hardware store, two cafes and City Hall. Leo Geiger, administrator of the Ashley Medical Center, and Bud Overbo, a bank vice president, came up with the plan to advertise Ashley in magazines read by retirees. They thought of attracting retired people about a year ago as a way to increase the population and preserve existing jobs. ``You've got to have doctors, but you can't attract doctors unless you have enough bodies,'' said Geiger, 61, who says he's interested in retiring in Ashley himself. ``Retirees can sell their homes and buy a more moderate home in Ashley. They'd be able to use the interest to live on,'' added City Councilman Myron Schlepp, an insurance salesman. The retirement plan has no organized opposition, though some worry their community will age too much, council members said. People thinking of retiring in Ashley might want to know: _It sits on prairie land, 80 miles from Aberdeen, S.D., the nearest big city. St. Paul, Minn., is 350 miles east. A freight train runs through town once a week during harvest time, once every two or three weeks otherwise. _The average three-bedroom home costs $30,000. _The city has a nine-hole golf course with sand greens, pinochle and gin tournaments, and frequent dances and church and civic group-sponsored social events. _Ashley notes its one full-time police officer, two police vehicles and two jail cells as evidence of a crime-free environment. _The city is the seat of McIntosh County, with a 1.6 percent unemployment rate. The medical center, with 26 hospital beds and 51 nursing home beds, is Ashley's largest employer. The new, not-for-profit Ashley Development Corp. was formed by the business people of Ashley, who hope to get grant money to promote Ashley in retirement magazines, Dockter said. But it may be an uphill battle. ``Every once in a while we do get a call from a community interested in enhancing its tax base,'' Sloan said in Washington. ``But the reality is that most retirees don't move very far.'' Still, the biggest promotional obstacle may be the weather. In January, the National Weather Service says, the average high temperature is 18 degrees, with the average low at 4 below zero.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Last-Minute Tax Tips
DOC.TEXT: Michael Cates is an expert in tax planning and management for the Denver-based College for Financial Planning, a non-profit institution offering financial services and educational programs.

As they agonize over yet another tax season and an April 15 deadline, taxpayers should remember that, with careful planning, many tax-saving ideas are available. Following are three significant tax-saving tips for people over 55 that should be considered when preparing returns. _Sale of a Home: If you sold your home during 1989, there are several options. If the sale resulted in a loss, the loss generally is a non-deductable personal loss. However, a gain on the sale may qualify for special tax treatment. If a taxpayer buys a new principal residence within two years of the date of sale of the old principal residence, the taxpayer will not be required to pay tax on all the gain from the sale. The taxpayer will pay tax on the gain only to the extent that the ``adjusted sales price'' of the old residence exceeds the cost of the new one. The ``adjusted sales price'' equals the selling price of the residence, reduced by sales expenses, such as advertising, commissions and legal fees; and further reduced by expenses for decorating and repairing to help sell the old home. Only expenses for work performed within 90 days before the contract to sell was signed, and paid for within 30 days after the sale, qualify. Capital expenses, such as permanent improvements or replacements, are added to the value of the home. If the cost of the new residence exceeds the adjusted sales price of the old one, no tax is paid on the sale. This is known as a rollover of the gain, or a Section 1034 exchange. This treatment is automatic if a new home is purchased. In this situation, the basis (tax cost) of the new residence will be reduced by the amount of gain postponed. If the taxpayer sells a principal residence but does not replace it, it still may be possible to qualify for special tax treatment. If the taxpayer is 55 or older on the date of the sale, he or she may be able to exclude up to $125,000 of gain on the sale. Also the taxpayer must have used the residence as his or her ``main home'' for at least three years during the five years before the sale. The election to exclude the gain from the sale is available only once in a lifetime and is made on Part 1 of Form 2119. _Standard Deductions and Additional Considerations: The taxpayer is allowed to deduct the greater of the standard deduction or total itemized deductions. The amount of the standard deduction is dependent upon the taxpayer's filing status. Married couples filing jointly are entitled to a $5,200 standard deduction. Single taxpayers are entitled to a $3,100 standard deduction. The standard deduction for heads of households is $4,550, and for married people filing separately, $2,600. In addition, married people who are 65 or older, or blind, are entitled to an additional standard deduction of $600 ($1,200 if both 65 and blind). Single taxpayers who are 65 or older, or blind, are entitled to an additional standard deduction of $750 ($1,500 if both). If the taxpayer was completely blind as of Dec. 31, 1989, a statement should be attached to the tax return describing the condition. If the taxpayer was partially blind, a certified statement from an eye doctor must be attached to the return. The attachment must state that the taxpayer's vision cannot be corrected with glasses or contacts to be better than 20-200 in the better eye, or that the taxpayer's field of vision is 20 degrees or less. _Medicare Surtax: Finally, for taxpayers eligible for Medicare, Congress repealed the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act in December. Because the 1989 tax forms were published before the repeal, lines are included on the form that reflect the supplemental Medicare surtax _ line 54 on Form 1040, and line 23 on Form 1040A. In filling out the return, taxpayers may leave the line blank or fill it in with a zero. If taxpayers already have made payments, through additional estimated tax payments or additional withholdings, they are entitled to a refund. Even if no income tax is owed, a return must be filed to get a refund. A credit for amounts paid through withholding can be claimed by reflecting those amounts on line 56 of Form 1040, or line 25a of Form 1040A. The additions made through estimated tax payments can be shown on line 57 of Form 1040.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, March 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Growing a Tomato Indoors Provides a Rare Thrill
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years that included coverage of World War II from Italy.

Summer or winter, outdoors or in, what is gardening without a tomato? Growing a tomato under lights is easy _ if you you've got space, the right plant and can wait 100 days. My wife kindly let me have space in her area of our fluorescent stand to let me raise my first indoor tomato. Why would anyone want to do this? I can't answer for others, but I got a big sense of accomplishment out of seeing the blossoms come and the fruit set, enlarge and finally redden. I've raised a string bean indoors, but the thrill was nowhere the same. Perhaps it's because of America's special relation to tomatoes, perennially voted our favorte garden vegetable. For 35 years or so, my wife and I have shared a custom-built, four-tiered stand along a wall of our dining room. She has the deep middle shelves for flowers and leafy plants and I occupy the shallower top and bottom tiers for winter salad greens and for starting seeds in spring. We try to keep out of each other's way. Then, a couple of years ago, I saw a newspaper article saying windowsill tomatoes, using sunlight, are easy with certain varieties. Why not under fluorescents, I asked my wife, who, knowing it would mean intrusion on her turf, surprisingly said, ``All right, go ahead.'' I tried two of the recommended varieties, Pixie and Sub-Arctic, both of which had already done well in my outdoor garden. They're small tomatoes, bearing early and abundantly. Sub-Arctic has a particularly interesting past. It's an offspring of international tests, including Soviet trials in Siberia, to develop cold-resistant varieties. Canadians even bred one to fruit on Hudson Bay. In my fluorescent adventure, I was faced with the problem that the tubes are infinitely weaker than sunlight. While I raise tomato seedlings under lights every year, growing plants to fruiting stage was a different challenge. I started both tomoatoes early in January in flats of potting soil, keeping them very close to the lights, an inch or so, so that the newly sprouting seedlings would not get leggy. I kept notes on the progress of each. By Jan. 28, Sub-Arctic was about eight inches tall while Pixie was only three. On Jan. 31, I transplanted one Sub-Arctic and one Pixie into six-inch pots. Sub-Arctic blossomed Feb. 24 and set its first fruit March 8. This turned red the week of April 12 and I ate it April 20, about 100 days after I sowed the seed. Sweet and nice. From then until the end of July, this plant produced a dozen tomatoes, all a deeper red than their outdoor version and sweeter, too, it seemed to me. Sub-Arctic ran away with the show. Pixie grew into a sturdy plant but never blossomed under the lights. Finally I planted it outdoors in June, and it started blossoming almost immediately in the sun, producing its first red fruit July 28. During their indoor careers, I sometimes forgot to water the plants until I noticed they were drooping. Then I rushed to the rescue with a long-nosed watering can, and they picked up right away. I fertilized occasionally with a soluble plant food. Sub-Arctic grew over a couple of feet tall and I tied it to the stand. Its upper reaches meandered along the lights (and my wife's gloxinias) and I had to trim it occasionally. Since then, I've found a variety named Florida Petite that grows only a foot tall out of four-inch pots and requires no sacrifices from my wife. My original experiment needed no unusal skills or horticultural heroics. But in a long gardening career, nothing has quite matched the special pleasure of watching that first red fruit complete its voyage to maturity under my dining room tubes.

Oil prices will likely slide further in the weeks ahead despite OPEC's fresh call for restraints on crude production, analysts said. Ministers of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, hoping to keep the target price of oil at $18 a barrel, wound up a special meeting Saturday by urging its members to be cautious with their output during the second quarter. ``Prices are going to come under a lot of pressure,'' predicted Peter Gignoux, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in London. However, the softening of oil prices will likely have little impact on gasoline prices at the pump.

British industrial conglomerate BTR PLC offered $1.64 billion to acquire Norton Co., the Worchester-based abrasives manufacturer, in an unsolicited tender offer that sent Norton shares skyrocketing. London-based BTR, which has international operations ranging from building materials to sporting goods, offered $75 a share on Friday through a U.S. subsidiary, ER Holdings Inc. Norton stock soared $16.62{ to $74.87{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said its board was reviewing the offer and would inform shareholders of its position on the bid by March 29.

U.S. industrial output rose 0.6 percent in February, the government reported, but the rise reflected a resumption of automobile production and practically no strengthening elsewhere. Thousands of autoworkers, who were laid off in January as manufacturers trimmed bloated inventories, returned to production lines in February and contributed nearly all of the increase in industrial output, the Federal Reserve reported Friday.

Topsy-turvy weather is sending wholesale inflation on a roller-coaster ride so far this year, with prices unchanged in February after a steep increase a month earlier. A sharp drop in energy prices offset increases for other items and held the Labor Department's Producer Price Index steady overall last month, the government said Friday. In another report, housing starts fell 7 percent in February but remained well above the level of the last 11 months of 1989. Analysts said the building pace could not be maintained.

Citicorp said it was reorganizing its commercial real estate division, a move analysts linked to a rise in bad loans because of a downturn in the market nationwide. Under the shift announced Friday, Citicorp is expected to de-emphasize lending to large building projects and concentrate on real estate activities that generate fees for the bank, such as finding investors for projects.

A federal judge ordered Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. to give creditors more information about $260 million in bonuses paid before the firm filed for bankruptcy protection. Lawyers for Drexel agreed Friday to provide details about the firm's 1989 compensation and bonus payments over the weekend to attorneys and accountants for the official committee of unsecured creditors. Creditors have questioned the timing of the payment of $196 million in cash and $64 million in securities to Drexel exceutives in the months prior to the firm's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing Feb. 13.

President Fernando Collor de Mello implemented a sweeping emergency package of economic reforms that include a price freeze, a new national currency, and jail terms for ``economic crimes.'' Business leaders and economists said they fear Collor de Mello's package, announced Friday, would strangle the economy and plunge the country into a deep recession. Brazil has the developing world's largest foreign debt, $114 billion. Inflation is 2,700 percent, and the budget deficit is $31 billion. Millions of people live on the street or in shantytowns.

General Development Corp. has agreed to plead guilty to a felony charge and pay up to $500,000 in fines to settle charges it schemed to inflate home prices at its nine Florida developments. A 16-count federal indictment released Friday said thousands of home buyers lured by slick sales pitches and Florida sunshine fell prey to an elaborate scheme in which General Development allegedly made $850 million on more than 11,000 overpriced homes.

The Federal Trade Commission announced an investigation into the environmental claims of products ranging from trash bags to hairspray, saying it will vigorously pursue deceptive advertising and packaging. Commission Chairwoman Janet Steiger said Friday the FTC staff would join various state officials and a number of companies ``to substantiate ... environmental claims'' in advertising and packaging. No specific companies were targeted.

The stock market climbed sharply to a two-month high Friday, turning the quarterly ``triple witching hour'' to its favor in a busy session. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 45.50 to 2,741.22, its highest close since Jan. 11. The dollar declined against most major foreign currencies. Bond prices rose sharply. Coffee futures prices tumbled; grain futures rose; oil futures were mostly lower; precious metals advanced and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Thumbnails of GM Chairman Smith, Possible Successors
With PM-GM Successor
DOC.TEXT: Here are thumbnail sketches of General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith and the five men believed to be under consideration to succeed him when he retires July 31.

Current position: Chairman and chief executive officer since Jan. 1, 1981. Degrees held: Bachelor's and master's in business administration, both from the University of Michigan. Age: 65 on July 12, 1990. Length of GM employment: 41 years. First GM job: General accounting senior clerk, Detroit Central Office. Background: Rose through financial ranks to election as GM treasurer in March 1970. Other executive positions included vice president in charge of financial staffs and executive vice president.

Current position: Executive vice president of GM's international operations since June 27, 1988. Degrees held: Bachelor's in business administration from the University of Massachusetts, master's of business administration from Boston University. Age: 52 on April 6, 1990. Length of GM employment: 29 years. First GM job: A range of positions at GM's Fisher Body facility in Framingham, Mass., while working on an advanced degree. Background: Began in the financial ranks and rose to comptroller of the corporation in 1980. He then switched to product development work and was named general manager of General Motors of Canada before moving to Europe and becoming president of General Motors Europe in 1987.

Current position: Executive vice president in charge of the Automotive Components Group and the Power Products and Defense Operations Group since June 27, 1988. Degrees held: Bachelor's in economics from Princeton University and master's of business administration from the University of Michigan. Age: 56 on Aug. 22, 1990. Length of GM employment: 32 years. First GM job: Accounting department of GM's Buick-Oldsmobile-Pontiac Division. Background: Nearly entirely in the financial operations, rising to GM's comptroller in 1978. He later was named general manager of the Pontiac Division and was the first president of GM's Saturn Corp. subsidiary in 1985, preparing to launch a new car before Smith retires, and group executive in charge of the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group.

Current position: Chief financial officer and executive vice president in charge of the Finance Group and General Motors Acceptance Corp. since June 27, 1988. Degrees held: Bachelor's in economics from Yale and a master's of business administration from Harvard. Age: 52 on July 7, 1990. Length of GM employment: 24 years. First GM job: In the treasurer's office in New York. Background: Came up through the financial ranks to become GM's treasurer in 1978 and comptroller four years later. In 1984, he became director of GM`s Worldwide Planning Group.

Current position: President and chief operating officer since Sept. 1, 1987. Degrees held: bachelor's from Worchester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts and master's in business administration from Michigan State University. Age: 57 on July 15, 1990. Length of GM employment: 32 years. First GM job: Senior detailer in the Oldsmobile Division's chassis design department. Background: Was promoted through Oldsmobile product development and engineering operations before becoming director of engineering in the Chevrolet Division in 1975. Three years later he was appointed general manager of the Pontiac Division and in 1980 was appointed managing director of Adam Opel AG in West Germany. Two years later, he was named general manager of the Chevrolet Division. In 1986, as an executive vice president, he was put in charge of GM's worldwide Truck & Bus Group and the Overseas Group.

Current position: Executive vice president, operating and public affairs staffs groups since June 27, 1988. Degrees held: bachelor's and master's of business administration, both from Dartmouth. Age: 59 on April 21, 1990. Length of GM employment: 34 years. First GM job: College graduate in training at GM's treasurer's office in New York. Background: Worked in various positions in the treasurer's office and was elected GM's treasurer in 1973. Elected vice president in charge of the financial staff in 1975 and president and general manager of GM of Canada Ltd. in 1978. Three years later, he was reel-ected executive vice president in charge of finance and chief financial officer in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski's Plan Injects New Life in Budget Debate
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Dan Rostenkowski is a comfortable old politician, a powerful House committee chairman with a huge staff, a doting legion of lobbyists and a million bucks in his campaign chest with no challenger in sight. Maybe that's the kind of pol it takes to kick new life into a budget debate which until now has produced only stalemate and fiscal chicanery. The Illinois Democrat, known more for his clout than his daring, last week entered the seemingly hopeless budget struggle with a splash. To eliminate the $100 billion-plus federal deficits, he called on all sides to abandon their long-held positions. His advice includes: President Bush _ Raise income taxes. Democrats _ Cut Social Security. Pentagon _ Reduce spending. Bureaucrats _ Freeze programs. Lobbyists _ The store is closed. It's what some call a ``gore everyone's ox'' strategy _ to the tune of $500 billion over five years. The proposal to freeze Social Security cost-of-living adjustments seems a thumbed nose to the elderly who, offended by Rostenkowski's support of the now-defunct catastrophic health care plan, attacked his car last year. The domestic spending freeze tells fellow Democrats to forget about spending any ``peace dividend'' from defense cuts made in the wake of the Eastern European revolution. By ruling out any tax cut, Rostenkowski rejects an idea popularized in his own party by Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., who suggests cutting Social Security taxes rather than using the revenue to cut the deficit. ``Some within my own party decided they should fight irresponsibility with irresponsibility,'' Rostenkowski said. Rostenkowski began selling the plan this past weekend in speeches before some of the very interest groups who have made his life so comfortable with generous speaking fees and campaign donations. ``The question is whether I can convince you that deficit reduction and a healthy economy are more important for your business than such special incentives'' as tax breaks, he told the Mid-Continent Oil and Gas Association. Rostenkowski's proposal to raise income taxes on the wealthy isn't just a challenge to Bush. It also abandons his own efforts to protect the 1986 tax ``reform'' bill that probably will be cited as the most sweeping achievement in Rostenkowski's three decades in Congress. In an interview, Rostenkowski pushed aside questions seeking a personal agenda in his plan. ``You've got to accept the fact that I'm viewed as the chairman of the committee that has 75 percent of the (deficit-reduction) legislation in its jurisdiction,'' he said. ``I'm supposed to provide some leadership or some cover... I just felt my colleagues would expect this of me,'' he said. Rostenkowski was not too modest to suggest that he might provide some leadership for Bush. ``Many of us felt that President Bush's commitment to no new taxes was only a one-year commitment,'' he said. Distrust is the biggest obstacle to a deficit-reduction plan this year, he said. That distrust has a long history. Many in Congress _ both Democrats and Republicans _ proposed similarly daring plans in the mid-1980s. The Republicans lost control of the Senate after their 1985 budget proposed Social Security cuts, and former House Speaker Jim Wright was vilified for proposing tax increases while Congress was getting a pay increase. Like others before him, Rostenkowski says ``there is the basis for doing something like this if everyone will step forward at the same time.'' So far, Rostenkowski is marching alone. Bush greeted the plan with enough rhetorical warmth to keep it alive but refused to compromise his positions. Loyal House Republicans portrayed it as another example of Democrats wanting to raise taxes. Rostenkowski's Democratic colleagues, meantime, praised him as brave but called his plan unrealistic until Bush changes his tune. Some were distrustful of Rostenkowski's chummy relationship with Bush. ``Everyone is suspicious of the president,'' Rostenkowski said. Without Bush's overt support, Rostenkowski concedes any deficit reduction plan is dead. But he believes the president ``blinked a little bit'' this time. Rumored to be considering retirement, Rostenkowski seems worried about his generation's legacy _ a legacy thus far of debt and a declining standard of living. And he hopes Bush and the senior members of Congress also are worried enough to ``go to Camp David and stamp something out that ... both Republicans and Democrats could accept.'' Where others see only deadlock, Rostenkowski sees potential for compromise and progress. Maybe he thinks he has the right combination of skill, clout and personal security to win _ and maybe just by shaking up a moribund debate, he already has.
Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Lower At Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: will be led after closing
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell at midday Monday following the sharp losses earlier in Tokyo and amid caution ahead of the government's budget statement Tuesday. At about noon local time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 16.6 points at 2,247.3. Midday volume totaled 175 million shares, down from 298.5 million Friday. The overall downturn in the market came after a fairly upbeat week of strong corporate results and institutional buying. Wariness over Britain's budget was dominating the market and probably will prevent investors from taking fresh positions throughout the day and even into early trading Tuesday, dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Sports Daily Plans to Increase Distribution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 22-23 pvs, bgng But the... with 3 new grafs to UPDATE with baseball agreement, edit to conform. Picks up 24th graf, What would...
DOC.TEXT: Nearly seven weeks after The National made a splashy debut, central New Jersey commuters are finding they can sleep in and still get a copy of the daily sports newspaper for their 40-mile train ride to New York. John Giorgianni, owner of the Bottom of the Hill newsstand in suburban New Brunswick, N.J., said he routinely ends up with 30 or more unsold copies these days. In the days after the newspaper's Jan. 31 premiere, late-rising commuters often found the paper was sold out. ``Those first three weeks were phenomenal,'' Giorgianni said. The newspaper's executives say they anticipated a fall-off in circulation after the paper's launch and insist that circulation and ad sales are matching their expectations. They plan to boost distribution by 40 percent soon by making the paper available at more outlets around its first three markets _ New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. But media analysts say it is too soon to say whether The National can survive in the publishing big leagues. They want to see how it handles expansion beyond its current markets and whether it can command a steady readership. Publisher Peter Price said The National is selling about 200,000 of the 250,000 copies it prints every day, matching the target set for the paper. The paper, which costs 50 cents a copy, is distributed Sunday through Friday and plans are to add six to 12 more cities by Dec. 31, when Price hopes a half million copies will be distributed every day. Advertisers have been told The National will start printing a second edition this week with a deadline three hours earlier than normal so papers can be distributed the next morning on newsstands further away from the centers of its three markets. Price confirmed that he hopes to soon begin printing about 75,000 copies a day of the ``twilight edition'' and to increase the regular edition by 25,000 copies, boosting total distribution to 350,000. The twilight edition will enable The National to be available for the morning rush hours in places like eastern Long Island, Atlantic City, N.J., Milwaukee, Springfield, Ill., and Santa Barbara, Calif., Price said. Media analysts say circulation confirmation from independent auditing agencies is not yet available, leaving advertisers to rely on the paper's word and anecdotal evidence of how things have been going. ``They tell us they are meeting or exceeding their circulation guarantees,'' said Andrew White, a spokesman for Philip Morris Inc., which advertises Marlboro and Parliament cigarettes in The National. White said Philip Morris still wants to see if the paper is a truly national publication and whether circulation falls off on certain days of the week. Richard Mader, president of Mader News, a newspaper distributor in Culver City, Calif., said, ``I was originally skeptical that people were going to buy it six days a week.'' ``But the numbers are consistent through the week. There is just a shift to different places on weekends,'' he said. Skeptics argued before The National's launch that people already get enough sports information from their local newspapers and would soon give up trying to wade through a 40- to 48-page sports daily. ``The jury is still out on readership,'' said Joseph Ostrow, worldwide media director for the advertising agency Foote Cone Belding Communications. The amount of advertising in the newspaper has been fairly light, dropping off from double-digits in the first week to an average of four to five pages a day recently. But Price said that too was expected. The paper has had some early editorial gaffes. A cover photo from a college basketball game, for instance, misidentified one of the key players; an item on the University of Miami's Bill Foster was accompanied by a photo of a coach with the same name from Northwestern. The wrong box scores have appeared with game stories. Price said a dozen copy editors were added to the staff when it became evident there were too few to handle the late nights six days a week. He is especially proud of the paper's coverage of the unexpected defeat of heavyweight boxer Mike Tyson late on a Saturday night. One potential threat evaporated late Sunday night when baseball owners and players agreed on a new four-year labor contract, ending a 32-day spring training lockout and averting a strike that threatened the season. Baseball has no widely followed college counterpart, unlike pro football and basketball. Before the settlement, editor-in-chief Frank Deford had said he didn't think readers would want regular coverage of minor league or Japanese baseball as a replacement if there were a major league strike. However, Price had said that if there were a strike the paper could cut back to 32 pages, and insisted the lack of baseball would not be life- threatening. What would kill The National? It remains unclear how much backers of the paper, mainly the Mexican Publisher Emilio Azcarraga, are willing to lose. Price is optimistic. ``We expected the launch would cost us $20-25 million and that is what it has cost us. We are tracking our plan,'' he said.
