DOC.HEAD: Kobe Steel, Texas Instruments To Produce Semiconductors in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Kobe Steel Ltd. and Texas Instruments Inc. of the United States signed an agreement Monday to manufacture advanced semiconductors in Japan. Kobe Steel spokesman Gary Tsuchida said Kobe Steel will own ``a majority interest'' in the venture to be named KTI Semiconductor Ltd. Under an agreement, a plant will be built in Hyogo in western Japan by the end of 1991 at a total cost of $350 million. The venture will be capitalized at $57.9 million. Tsuchida said the venture will manufacture complementary metal oxide semiconductor logic devices, including large-scale integrated circuits and application-specific integrated circuits. The products will be marketed in Japan with TI's brand name, Tsuchida said.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Drops 4.15 percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index plunged more than 1,300 points in massive selling Monday _ its third biggest single-day fall ever _ and closed at a 14-month low. The dollar continued to rise against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which fell 55.20 points last Friday, plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday. Its closing of 31,263.24 was the lowest since it closed at 31,170.38 on Jan. 20, 1989. The only bigger single-day declines were 3,836.48 on Oct. 20, 1987, in the worldwide ``Black Monday'' stock market crash, and 1,569.10 points on Feb. 26 this year. In Monday's early trading, the index initially rose 105 points as investors were encouraged by last Friday's gains on Wall Street, dealers said. But this was followed by a sharp decline in late morning. ``The anxiety about the interest rate hike coupled with the weak yen against the dollar are the main causes of today's fall,'' said Ichitaro Watanabe, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. ``The market as a whole appears very pessimistic about the current situation and I have heard that there was some panic selling.'' He said a sharp fall in index future prices also triggered massive selling on the spot market. Meanwhile, the dollar closed at 153.55 yen, up 1.05 yen from last Friday's close of 152.50 yen. After opening at 152.48 yen, it ranged between 152.35 and 153.80 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar rose against the yen even though the American currency was sold against the West German mark after conservatives' impressive showing Sunday in East Germany's first free elections in 41 years. The conservative alliance led by the Christian Democrats, a sister party of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, won the biggest single bloc of seats. The East German Christian Democrats favor speedy reunification of the German states. Masaaki Tanahashi, a dealer with Mitsui Bank, said that apart from the West German mark's strength against other major currencies, support for the dollar against the yen ``still remains firm.'' But Tanahashi said some market players were waiting to see if Japan's central bank, as speculated, would decide this week to raise its official discount rate from the current 4.25 percent. Japanese media have speculated for weeks that the Bank of Japan would raise its key lending rate, charged for loans to commercial banks, by as much as one percentage point. This would affect other domestic interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Break Down Amid Charges and Counter-Charges

DOC.TEXT: Greyhound and its striking drivers exchanged barbs after negotiations broke down when company officials charged that union leaders failed to negotiate and were ``stepping up the violence.'' Union leaders presented a new contract proposal in talks held in Tucson on Saturday, but the company said it was unacceptable. Negotiations broke off Sunday after only about an hour. A federal mediator said he is disappointed but not surprised that the first negotiations in the 18-day-old Greyhound bus drivers' strike quickly broke off. ``The issues remaining are serious and they are many, and it's not unusual at this stage of negotiations for both sides to remain very firm in their position,'' said Paul F. Stuckenschneider. Greyhound and union officials were less diplomatic. ``There is no way to reach an agreement with people who are trying to break down the company through intimidation, violence and terrorism,'' the company's executive vice president, Anthony Lannie, said in a statement Sunday. ``They had nothing new for us today or yesterday while stepping up the violence,'' Lannie said. ``There were a half-dozen new acts of terrorism yesterday while we were in the meeting.'' In Washington, Jeffrey Nelson, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, said Lannie's statement ``sounds to me like the desperate words of a desperate man. ``We clearly condemn violence and anything we can do to discourage our members we are doing so,'' Nelson said. Unions representing 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out March 2 over wages, job security and grievance procedures. Greyhound operates the only nationwide intercity bus service, and the strike has stranded many smaller communities for which buses are the only public transportation. The company said it has been operating roughly one-third of its buses with replacement and non-striking drivers, with about 400 union drivers joining 1,000 permanent replacements on the job. The union says fewer than 100 of its drivers have crossed the picket lines. Greyhound officials said there have been at least 14 shooting attacks on Greyhound buses, 46 bomb threats and numerous other incidents of vandalism or threats during the walkout. One new report of strike-related violence involved a union vice president accused of striking a driver in Fayetteville, N.C. Ingram, who is also president of a local in Charlotte, denied striking anyone. Steve Scarpino, a Greyhound spokesman in Dallas, said other new complaints involved harassment by pickets in Mobile, Ala., an assault on a driver in Tulsa, Okla. and damaged buses in Tucson and Phoenix. In an earlier incident, driver Edwin J. Ludwigsen, 46, of Spring Lake, N.C., said he was struck on the he!e by a man. o -Bgistratwissmou$a criminalp`ummo(s for William DaniYs,fghom Greyhound said was a union member. In Florida on Sunday, the State Patbol arrested the drivers of tree vehicles that surrounded a New York-to-Miami Greyhound bus on Interstate 95 near Fort Pierce and forced it to slow down. No one on the bus was hurt, Scarpino said. Union officials said their proposal involved a $40 million three-year package that included modest pay increases of 4 percent to 5 percent and the addition of new drivers to the pension plan. A union spokesman said the company has offered a plan that included no guarantee of `ny pay hikes, but would have made raises contingent on$increased profits and ridership. DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts' Bond Rating Lowest In Nation
DOC.TEXT: Another Wall Street credit-rating firm gave Massachusetts the lowest bond rating in the nation today, a move that could make borrowing more expensive for the state. Moody's Investors Service Inc. said the lowered rating reflects Massachusetts' continued inaction in dealing with its fiscal crisis. The rating on its bonds was dropped to Baa from Baa1, although it is still considered investment grade. Standard & Poors Corp., another rating firm, had placed Massachusetts below every other state in the nation last year. S&P re-affirmed its BBB rating last week. Bond ratings give investors a quick reference to determine the degree of risk on an investment. The lower the rating, the higher the risk involved. A low bond rating means the state may have to pay higher interest rates on the money it borrows. Today's announcment coincides with the state's plans to go to market with $360 million in long-term bonds for capital projects sometime this week. George Leung, a Moody's analyst, noted the state's 1990 deficit has grown from an original estimate of $500 million to more than $700 million. ``Extended inaction this fiscal year has reduced confidence that responsible action will be taken to contain this problem,'' Leung said in a statement. Leung also noted that the state's economy has softened. In addition to slowed revenues in fiscal 1990, the state's unemployment rate recently rose to the national average of 5.3 percent in February.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Slip On Brazilian Reforms; Grains Advance
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices were slightly lower today on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely in reaction to Brazilian economic reform plans. Grain futures were mostly higher. The early decline in the soybean market reflected concerns that Brazilian soybean growers will market their newly harvested crops more aggressively as a result of the economic reforms announced last week by Brazil's new president, Fernando Collor de Mello. The package includes a new Brazilian currency with free-floating foreign exchange rates, which some analysts believe could encourage soybean marketings in the world's second-largest soybean-producing nation. Wheat futures were stronger in early trading, led by the March contract amid indications of tighter-than-expected near-term supplies. March grain and soybean contracts expire on Wednesday. Corn futures were higher in sympathy with wheat while oat futures were narrowly mixed. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1\ cents to 4\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.93} a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.49\ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to } cent higher with May at $1.50{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 3 cents lower with March at $5.79{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .25 cent to .48 cent higher with the contract for delivery in April at 77.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .28 cent to .47 cent higher with March at 83 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent lower to .15 cent higher with April at 53.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.15 cents to 1.53 cents higher with May at 52.50 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Drops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT to North Dakota sted North Carolina
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs declined by 15 this week as it continued on its normal first quarter pace to total 908, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The decrease in rig activity conforms to previous first quarters when the count generally is in a decline, according to Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist for Baker Hughes. The year-to-date count, however, remains well ahead of the 1989 tally when 740 rigs were working, Baker Hughes said. Last week, the count rose by 29 to total 923 with Texas heading other oil producing states with a gain of 30. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. This week, Texas saw the largest decline with 15 followed by Oklahoma, 11; Louisiana, two, and New Mexico, Ohio and Pennsylvania, one each. Kansas had the largest increase with six, California and Wyoming had five each, and North Dakota, one. Colorado and Michigan were unchanged from last week.

DOC.HEAD: Kohlberg Kravis Buys 3.9 Percent RJR Nabisco Stake From Drexel
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which continues to sell its securities portfolio as it winds down business, has sold its 3.9 percent stake in RJR Nabisco Inc. to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Ruth Pachman, a spokeswoman for Kohlberg Kravis, said the leveraged buyout firm paid nearly $51 million for the stake. Kohlberg Kravis now holds 58 percent of the food and tobacco company's stock. Drexel was the adviser and lead underwriter for Kohlberg Kravis' $24.53 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco last year. The investment firm acquired the RJR Nabisco stock in the course of underwriting $5 billion in bond sales to finance the buyout. Drexel has been liquidating its securities portfolio since its parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.1 million tons during the week ending March 10, up slightly from the 20 million tons produced the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported Monday. The U.S. coal industry produced 18.7 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Wyoming ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 3.5 million tons produced. Kentucky was second at 3.3 million tons and West Virginia was third at 3 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 200.5 million tons, 6.4 percent ahead of last year's production at this time. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs of Tuesday, March 20
DOC.HEAD: Is A House A Home?
DOC.TEXT: Are Americans buying houses at the expense of their homes? The question is not as foolish as it might seem, especially if you accept the definition of a house as a mere physical structure and a home as a spiritual haven and family environment. Pressured by prices that take a bigger chunk of paychecks than they used to, both husband and wife must work to finance the house, leaving too little time to develop the house as a home. The consequences aren't limited to the immediate family, but are showing up as increased demands on employers and their benefits structure. Some businesses say the situation results in more absences and in stress-related illnesses; although definitive statistical evidence has yet to be developed, the suspicion is that health insurance costs are being driven up. Businesses in areas where good employees are hard to find are either installing or contemplating day-care facilities. Maternal leave time is a standard paragraph in employment contracts. Paternal leave time is growing. In turn, critics of parental leave say it is an important factor in the slow growth of productivity in the American workplace. They are preparing to counter what seems to be growing sentiment in Congress to make it mandatory. The National Federation of Indpendent Business, for example, claims that mandated parental or maternity leave will prove too expensive for smaller companies and may discourage them from hiring potential parents. Whatever the problems or potential problems, housing and real estate people suggest they arise from the fact that houses today often are priced so high that it takes the financial capability of both spouses. Citing a study by the Chicago Title and Trust Co., which provides title insurance on houses, the National Association of Realtors says the great majority of buyers last year were two-income families. The Chicago study indicated that 79.3 percent of all couples buying houses last year relied on two incomes. Among first-time buyers the percentage was 86.8 percent, and even among repeat buyers it was nearly 75 percent. The impact on family life is bound to be the of subject of growing study and controversy. For one thing, various other studies suggest that even today's so-called liberated women often are unable to reduce their load of household chores because men have not been sharing them. That is, women go to work and come home to work. The consequences raise various possibilities, among them that the effect will be felt in the emotional and phsyical health of children, and in the quality of marital relationships. Business is watching the situation carefully, fearful that Congress will force parental leave into the cafeteria of employee benefits. The National Federation says it would make employees wary of hiring young married women. Just as important is the impact dual employment might be having on health care costs. Business in general is trying to reduce its benefits bill, partly by shifting more of the cost to the employees. But while business worries, it is conceivable that the more serious cost to society might have less to do with business and more to do with the home.

DOC.HEAD: No Sunshine for S&Ls in Healthy California, Either
DOC.TEXT: In the late 1980s, Columbia Savings and Loan television ads showed a man in a suit standing high atop a graph. Lines on the chart zigzagged up to demonstrate the company's growth and strength. ``I'd say things are headed in the right direction,'' the pitchman said. If the ads ran now, the guy might have to stand in a junkyard _ a metaphor not only for Columbia, but also for other California S&Ls that diversified away from home-mortgage lending during the deregulated frenzy of the last decade. A third of the state's 21 biggest thrifts are in danger of failing, even in a state economy that is one of the largest and healthiest in the world. Why are so many California thrifts sick? A big reason is bad investments made under deregulation. Columbia's years of success, for example, were built on investments in junk bonds, securities that paid high interest because they funded risky ventures. Many were sold by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond purveyor Michael Milken to his friend and ally, Columbia Chairman Thomas Spiegel. Columbia's heap of junk, far bigger than any other thrift's, has fallen in value by at least $800 million. Because of that, the S&L no longer meets federal standards for capital reserves _ its cash cushion against risk. Spiegel has resigned. Drexel is in bankruptcy court. Milken is indicted. The market for the risky securities he helped pioneer has collapsed. Columbia's new president, Edward Harshfield, is trying to sell the whole $3.5 billion junk bond package. Many observers don't think he can. ``I just have a feeling Columbia may be too far gone,'' said Bert Ely, an Alexandria, Va.-based financial industry consultant. The No. 2 junk bond investor, San Diego's Imperial Savings and Loan, was seized Feb. 23, the same day regulators took over Huntington Beach-based Mercury Savings. Mercury had many problems, but fell into insolvency partly because of another bugbear for California thrifts _ a risky out-of-state loan. The number of thrifts in California boomed in the early 1980s after federal and state laws were loosened, permitting S&Ls to make a range of investments. Unlike banks, they originally had been allowed only to make loans for houses. California has about 12 percent of the country's population, but 29 percent of the S&L assets. The state hasn't suffered the economic shocks of Texas and other energy states, which could partly blame the skidding oil business for their S&L problems, or Arizona, where thrifts were buried when real estate prices slumped. Analysts, regulators and industry officials instead blame shoddy managers who courted big depositors with high interest rates and made ill-conceived investments well beyond the Golden State's borders. Besides junk bonds, California thrifts put money into duds ranging from stud horses to Yugo cars. Honcho thrift entrepreneurs with little experience used their newfound license to write not just adjustable rate loans, but commercial and industrial loans, loans on vacant land, ``all that goofy stuff,'' California S&L Commissioner William Crawford said. Making matters worse, many conservative lenders followed suit, often trying to recoup losses from early fixed-rate mortgage loans made at low rates. ``A lot of the good monkeys copied the bad monkeys,'' Crawford said. Crawford and Marion Sandler, president of World Savings and Loan Association, said trying to do business outside the state was the biggest problem. ``First, you don't know the territory, and second you're the latest pigeon,'' she said. Many California thrift managers wrongly assumed every market was as good as California, said Alex Sheshunoff, the head of an Austin, Texas-based firm that tracks the thrift industry. ``They thought they had geographical risk diversification,'' Sheshunoff said. ``What they wound up with was a piece of every bad deal no matter where it was.'' Some of the more prominent thrifts that ventured out-of-state include Great American Savings Bank of San Diego, now seeking an investor or buyer after losing $124 million in 1989, largely because of commercial lending in Arizona. Great Western's 1989 profits fell 60 percent because of a $200 million reserve for losses on commercial real-estate loans, most of them outside California. The company is regarded as healthy nonetheless. Irvine-based Lincoln Savings, the notorious thrift that regulators say will cost $2 billion to bail out, lost money on Arizona real estate and junk bonds. It is the biggest S&L collapse so far. Mercury said a soured loan on a hotel in Tulsa, Okla., helped push it into insolvency. With assets of $2.16 billion, it had a negative net worth of $33 million when seized. San Diego's Imperial had assets of $9.7 billion and a negative net worth of $60 million when regulators seized it. Besides big junk bond holdings, Imperial's problems included shaky car loans and backing the importer of the Yugo, a car U.S. drivers shunned. Ely attributes many of the problems to simply too many S&Ls with too few solid franchises. ``There's parallels to the steel industry,'' said Ely. ``What we're doing is trimming away obsolescence. ... It's the same trend you see in any mature industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Reports 26 Percent Rise in Net Income for Latest Qtr
DOC.TEXT: The athletic shoe and apparel giant Nike Inc. said Monday its profit for its third fiscal quarter climbed 29 percent from a year earlier as its revenue jumped 21 percent. Nike said its profit totaled $63.1 million, or $1.67 per share, for its third quarter ended Feb. 28, up from $48.8 million, or $1.30 per share, a year earlier. Revenue for the most recent three-month period increased to $577.9 million from $464.7 million a year earlier. Revenue for the company's domestic footwear operations increased 21 percent, domestic apparel revenues grew 21 percent and foreign revenues increased 43 percent. Orders for footwear scheduled for delivery in the United States during the March through July period are 30 percent higher in units and 47 percent higher in dollars compared with the same period last year, the company said. For the nine months ended Feb. 28, Nike earned $175.7 million, or $4.65 a share, up 34.5 percent from $130.6 million, or $3.48 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the nine months rose to $1.63 billion from $1.30 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Unions Team with Biggest Shareholder To Replace Directors, Buy Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, Company spokeswoman... to UPDATE with company response
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s unions and biggest shareholder today announced a joint effort to replace directors of the airline company and buy it for more than $3.8 billion. The offer, which included a no-strike commitment, shattered a lull in the prolonged takeover maneuvering for the parent of United Airlines and was about 40 percent less than a debt-financed deal that collapsed five months ago. That collapse touched off a major tumble in the stock market and raised the first big doubts about the future of the corporate takeover craze of the 1980s. Coniston Partners, a New York takeover firm that has invested in UAL and long demanded changes to boost the stock price, disclosed details of the joint plan with the pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions of the Chicago-based airline, the second largest in the country behind American Airlines. It said they plan to lobby for shareholder proxy votes in favor of electing a new slate of directors at the UAL April 26 meeting, and the directors will attempt to force the company to agree to the takeover proposal. Stockholders will receive $150 in cash and $25 in securities, as well as non-voting common stock amounting to 25 percent of the total in the company, the proposal stated. The unions would own the remaining 75 percent. Based on UAL's 21.8 million shares outstanding, the offer would be worth about $3.8 billion. UAL was trading at about $142.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange before the announcement, then shot up to $150 by midday. The shares have traded as low as $121. Stephen M. Wolf, chairman of the company, said in a statement that the board of directors was prepared to consider the Coniston-union proposal and would meet promptly to discuss it as well as other unspecified alternatives. It was unclear how Coniston and the unions intended to finance the takeover. But their announcement said new labor agreements would be negotiated that would include no-strike commitments and ``result in substantial labor cost savings.'' The collapse of a debt-financed $300-a-share offer for UAL on Oct. 13 is considered one of the major events in the era of corporate takeovers because it instilled deep skepticism about whether such deals would continue. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 190 points that day. The subsequent collapse of the junk-bond market practically stopped all takeover deals because it eliminated the major source of financing. Takeovers for airlines in particular are now considered riskier because of uncertainty about the economy and the overall health of the airline industry. UAL has attracted widespread interest because the unions have been leading an effort to take control and play a crucial role in any takeover's chances of success. The machinists balked at the original takeover proposal and contributed to its downfall.

DOC.HEAD: Holmes a Court Buys 4.18 Percent of Lloyd Webber's Company
DOC.TEXT: The entertainment company Really Useful Group PLC confirmed Monday that Australian investor Robert Holmes a Court had purchased a 4.18 percent stake, threatening British composer Andrew Lloyd Webbers' plan to take the company private. The stake was acquired by Holmes a Court's Heytesbury (U.K.) Ltd. last week, Really Useful said. Webber, who is a director of the companmy, is offering 233 pence, or $3.75, a share, for the company's stock. He already contols 82.5 percent of its 33.2 million shares. The bid values the entire company at 77.4 million pounds, or $125 million. Webber has said he wants to be free to switch his attention from musicals to movies without worrying about how that would affect the company's stock price. The company's principal activity is to develop and exploit the copyrights it owns in Webber's musicals, including ``Phantom of the Opera'' and ``Cats.'' If Holmes a Court acquires more than 5 percent of Really Useful, Webber's plan would be blocked because, under British law, the composer can force remaining shareholders to sell their shares to him only if he gains control of more than 95 percent of the company. Holmes a Court controls a company that operates theaters, the Stoll Moss Theaters Ltd. Among the shareholders accepting the composer's offer has been British publisher Robert Maxwell, who held a 14.4 percent stake.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed in Europe, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar was mixed against the major currencies in Europe Monday as traders concentrated on the West German mark. Gold prices rose by as much as $2 an ounce. Foreign exchange dealers said there was active buying of West German marks after the support for conservative parties in Sunday's general election in East Germany. They said a new East German government, backed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, is likely to take quick steps toward monetary union, free-market reforms and unification of Germany. However, the dollar gained against the Japanese yen because of disappointment that Japan showed no sign of raising its interest rates. The British pound declined on the eve of Tuesday's national budget speech by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major, who is not expected to present measures that can revive Britain's economy. Large tax concessions would fuel inflation, which has been running at 7.7 percent since November; 2.5 percent higher than the average in the 12-nation European Economic Community. One British pound cost $1.6110 in London late Monday, cheaper for buyers than Friday's late $1.6235. The closing price of gold in London, the major market, was $402.45 bid a troy ounce, up from $400.50. The Zurich closing bid price was $402.50, up from $401. DOC.HEAD: Blue Arrow Posts 19 Percent Profit Drop
DOC.TEXT: Blue Arrow PLC, the employment services company, on Monday posted a 19 percent drop in earnings for its fiscal first quarter, when interest charges rose sharply. Blue Arrow said its earnings in the three months ended Jan. 31 came to 5 million pounds, the equivalent of $8.1 million, compared with 6.2 million pounds in the same period a year ago. Earnings per share fell to 0.7 pence from 0.9 pence. Sales increased 22 percent to 436.5 million pounds from 357.4 million pounds. Interest and related financial charges rose 13 percent to 5.52 million pounds. Blue Arrow, of Britain, plans to reincorporate itself in the United States as Manpower Inc., by June. Shareholders, 65 percent of whom are U.S. investors, are to vote on the name change March 27. Blue Arrow acquired the larger Manpower, of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Economic Miracle Soured by Inflation, Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: The government presents its budget Tuesday against a background of inflation and high interest rates that are threatening Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's prospects for re-election. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major is not expected to produce any radical changes in his speech to Parliament outlining the fiscal year ending March 1991. But he is expected to try and boost confidence in his existing tight monetary policy, which has squeezed consumers and raised fears of recession. Base interest rates have risen to 15 percent, sending home loan costs soaring, while an unpopular new property tax that takes effect next month will raise many homeowners' bills by a third. Inflation is 7.7 percent, already the highest among the major industrialized nations, and is forecast to rise to 9 percent. The pound has weakened and the nation's 1989 trade deficit was $34 billion. A tight budget likely will worsen Mrs. Thatcher's standing, while economists fear it won't be tight enough to wring out stubborn inflation. Raising taxes would curb consumers' ability to spend. ``My view is that we need a very tight budget indeed,'' said Keith Skeoch, chief economist at the London investment firm James Capel and Co. The spring budget statement outlines the government's revenue raising plans and is a principal platform for announcing economic policies and forecasts. The government details its spending plans in an autumn statement. Last November, Major said spending would reach 179 billion pounds, the equivalent of $288 billion, in the coming year. Critics say the economy overheated because of the 1988 tax cuts, devised by then-chancellor Nigel Lawson. Lawson eliminated four of six tax brackets, cutting the basic rate from 27 percent to 25 percent and the top rate from 60 percent to 40 percent. The cuts partly were aimed at preventing a recession after the 1987 global stock market crash. But since then, the government has pushed up interest rates 11 times to double their decade-low 7.5 percent of June 1988. The hikes are intended to curb inflation, which has more than doubled to 7.7 percent since January 1988. There are fears that high interest rates might topple Britain into a recession after eight straight years of economic growth. Major says Britain's economic growth should slow to 1.25 percent from 2 percent last year. These are setbacks for the Conservative government which took credit for curing the ``British disease'' of high interest rates and inflation. Now, Mrs. Thatcher, who must call an election by mid-1992, faces doubts about her economic stewardship. The strategy ``has patently failed to work. We've gone to a situation where a recession is almost necessary to slow inflation,'' Skeoch said. Gavyn Davies, a British economist with Goldman Sachs International, said, ``I think it's working, yes... ``But it no longer looks like a Thatcher economic miracle.'' Just last week, the government reported that retail sales rose 2.4 percent in February to an all-time high of $15 billion, despite the higher interest rates. Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party, claimed Mrs. Thatcher's policies ``are failing to manage demand, they are increasing inflation, they are decreasing manufacturing investment and they are clobbering every homebuyer in the country because of mortgage rates.'' But the government said such economic figures can be erratic, that the retail sales growth was slower than last year's 4 percent, and that economic indicators point to a slowdown. Mrs. Thatcher told Parliament the high interest rates are working _ but declined to give assurances that they won't go any higher. Pessimists fear the government again will raise interest rates to prop up the pound, whose fall is worsening inflation prospects. Sterling is trading at about $1.61, compared with $1.87 in December 1988. The foreign exchange and stock markets have been jittery over the economy, Mrs. Thatcher's declining popularity in opinion polls and violent protests against the new property tax. However, there are bright spots. Unemployment has fallen to 5.6 percent in February from a peak of 11.5 percent in June 1986. The government has a budget surplus of $15.5 billion for the first 11 months of its current fiscal year. The strikes that plagued British industry in the 1970s virtually have disappeared. Former Conservative Party Chairman Norman Tebbit told reporters last week that interest rates almost certainly will fall by the end of 1990, because the government will have to ease the pressure as the next election approaches.

DOC.HEAD: Hudson Elected Chief Executive
DOC.TEXT: The United States Shoe Corp. reported Monday that Bannus B. Hudson, president of its LensCrafters Optical division since 1987, has been elected its chief executive officer. He succeeds Philip G. Barach, CEO since 1968. Barach will continue as chairman of the board of U.S. Shoe. Hudson, 44, was elected president and chief operating officer of U.S. Shoe earlier this year. U.S. Shoe, which has about 45,000 employees, reported sales last year of about $2.6 billion. ``The basic goals of U.S. Shoe will remain much the same as they have in the past,'' Hudson said. ``I want to do everything possible to ensure continuation of the dedication and standard of excellence that Phil Barach brought during his many years of service as CEO of U.S. Shoe.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Surge On Fund Buying; Grains Rally
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed sharply higher Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid heavy buying by speculative funds. Grain futures also advanced, reflecting tightness in near-term wheat supplies. The soybean market opened lower on expectations that sweeping economic reforms announced last week in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer, would stimulate farmer sales of soybeans there. But analysts saw no significant increase in Brazilian sales over the weekend or on Monday, said Steve Freed, a grain-market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Meanwhile, analysts said Memphis-based Sparks Commodities Inc. released an estimate of the Brazilian soybean crop pegging production at 19.5 million metric tons instead of the 20.5 million that many analysts had been using in their projections. The lower estimate sparked new buying, which boosted prices in afternoon trading. At the close, wheat futures were 2{ cents to 9\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.98} a bushel; corn was 3 cents to 3{ cents higher with March at $2.51 a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2{ cents higher with March at $1.48{ a bushel; soybeans were 6 cents to 8{ cents higher with March at $5.90 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Command Says Talks Off on Selling Three Texas Radio Properties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 new grafs with additional details.
DOC.TEXT: Command Communications Inc. said Monday talks have ended on previously announced plans to sell radio stations in Houston and Dallas and a Texas-wide radio network for $86.5 million to Evergreen Media Corp. Command said the decision reflects ``the continued strong performance of the properties and the brightening prospects for the Texas economy.'' The New York-based company said it had ``secured additional sources'' of both equity and bank financing and now plans to make acquisitions in Texas and other markets. Scott K. Ginsburg, president and chief executive of Evergreen Media, of Irving, Texas, said he was disappointed that Command and its principals ``have had a change of heart about this transaction.'' Command signed an agreement in January to sell KRLD-AM of Dallas and The Texas State Radio Networks to Evergreen Media for $58.5 million. Under a separate deal, Evergreen would have acquired KODA-FM in Houston for $28 million from The Sillerman Companies, a New York-based investor in Command and other broadcast properties. At that time, Command's president and chief executive, Carl C. Brazell Jr., said in a news release that the purchase price ``gives us an opportunity to increase shareholder value.'' Ginsburg had said in January the deal would give Evergreen, which owns an FM radio station in Dallas and five stations in four other cities, a dominant position in Dallas while moving it further along on its strategic growth plan. But in announcing Monday that the negotiations had ended, Brazell was quoted as saying, ``In the final analysis, we just couldn't part with such a strong regional franchise.'' In a separate news release, Ginsburg said the January agreement called for Evergreen to finance the $28 million KODA purchase while Command was to put in place $58.5 million in assumable debt related to the other transaction. Both companies were to contribute working capital to the KRLD-Texas State Radio Networks entity, Ginsburg said. He said Evergreen received financial commitments from lenders and investors for the KODA purchase, but was unable to receive assurances of Command's ability to secure the required assumable debt related to the purchase of the Houston station and the radio networks. ``Be it financing problems or a new business agenda for Command Communications, it's now apparent that it will not be possible for Evergreen Media to proceed with these tranasctions,'' Ginsburg said. KRLD-AM is an all-news station, KODA-FM has a soft adult contemporary format and The Texas State Radio Networks provides agribusiness and Spanish-language programming and Dallas Cowboys football for stations across Texas. Brazell and Robert F.X. Sillerman formed Command Communications in late 1988. In a telephone interview, Sillerman said it had become more difficult to finance the transaction over the past six months, while at the same time media prices have fallen. ``As a result, we are more interested in acquiring than selling,'' he said. He said The Sillerman Companies last week transferred its right to buy KODA for $28 million to Command. In addition to the two Texas radio stations and the radio networks, Sillerman said Command owns KJQY-FM radio in San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: BP Cuts 1,150 Jobs at London Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: British Petroleum Co. PLC said Monday it was cutting 1,150 jobs, or nearly half the staff, at its London headquarters as part of a reorganization designed to lower costs and make the oil giant more flexible. About 900 people will be laid off and the rest will be transferred, said a spokesman, who was not identified in accordance with British practice. The cuts, mainly affecting staff running administrative, computing and information services, represent a 46 percent reduction in the 2,500 staff currently employed at the company's headquarters. BP employs 118,000 people worldwide. The job cuts are part of BP's ``Project 1990'' to reduce the organization's complexity and cut expenses, BP said. BP Chairman Robert Horton said: ``As we enter the 1990s we expect the pace of change in global business to quicken. ... Corporations which achieve the greatest success will be those which are prepared and able to respond rapidly, flexibly and imaginatively.'' The company said it is simplifying management by removing layers of managers, replacing departments with flexible teams, reducing the number of boards and committees, and contracting out certain services. The announcement follows a reduction of 1,700 jobs, or 17 percent, in BP's exploration and production activities worldwide in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,871,000 net tons during the week ending March 17, 1990, down 2 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 83.5 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 2,050,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 20,082,000 net tons, 6.5 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses). North East Coast 208,000 tons (233,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 304,000 tons (309,000 tons); Lake Erie 157,000 tons (167,000 tons); Detroit 160,000 tons (154,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 485,000 tons (491,000 tons); Southern 259,000 tons (257,000 tons); Western 102,000 tons (102,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Announces Discounts for `Favorite Calling Areas'
DOC.TEXT: AT&T announced Monday its customers will soon be able to call their favorite out-of-state phone number at a reduced rate. The Selectsaver program allows people to pick the area code of their choice and direct-dial it repeatedly for $1.90 a month plus per-minute charges, said spokeswoman Lynn Newman. Evening, night and weekend calls will cost about 12 cents per minute, an average 23 percent less than the regular price. Day calls will cost about 20 cents, a nearly 13 percent savings over regular cost, said Ms. Newman. Customers will also receive a 5 percent discount on all other direct-dialed out-of-state calls, Ms. Newman said. The program should begin May 3 and will be available depending on the billing used by local telephone companies, Ms. Newman said.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Recalls 60,000 1990-Model Tempo, Topaz Cars
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Monday recalled about 60,000 1990-model Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz compact cars to replace an engine cooling fan. The company said in a news release that some fans on the cars equipped with 2.3-liter engines may rub against the fan shroud and overheat. If the fan doesn't work, the engine could overheat. Owners will be contacted by mail and repairs will be performed for free, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar turned in a mixed performance against other major currencies Monday in trading dominated by the West German mark. Gold prices posted minor gains in domestic and overseas dealings. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $400.80 for a troy ounce of gold as of 4 p.m. EST, up 80 cents from Friday's late bid. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for March delivery settled at $400.70 a troy ounce, $1.10 higher than Friday. Currency dealers said the support for conservative parties in Sunday's general election in East Germany sparked interest in buying West German marks. The new East German government, backed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, was considered likely to take quick steps toward monetary union, free-market reforms and unification of Germany. As trading ended in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6860 West German marks, down from 1.6980 marks Friday. The dollar gained against the Japanese yen, however, as dealers grew impatient waiting for the Tokyo government to raise the country's key interest rates, which has been expected for weeks. A Japanese news report late in U.S. trading saying increases could be enacted Tuesday failed to have much impact. Confidence in the yen also was shaken by the stock selloff in Tokyo, which knocked 4.15 percent off the Nikkei Stock Average's value. One dollar bought 153.05 Japanese yen late in New York, more than the 152.65 yen late on Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.55 Japanese yen, up from 152.50. In London late Monday the dollar also closed at 153.55. The British pound declined on the eve of Tuesday's national budget speech by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major, who is not expected to present measures that can revive Britain's economy. Dealers reported the Bank of England sold dollars and bought sterling to defend the pound's value. One British pound fetched $1.6135 late in New York, weaker than $1.6190 on Friday. Earlier, in London, a pound cost $1.6110, cheaper for buyers than Friday's late $1.6235. Zlatko Glamuzina, chief currency dealer at the Banco di Sicilia in New York, said dollar trading was quiet and uneventful with most of the buying and selling interest focused on the mark and the yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Friday, included: 1.5085 Swiss francs, down from 1.5095; 5.7025 French francs, down from 5.7360; 1,246.75 Italian lire, down from 1,253.00; and 1.18225 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18285. Selected dollar rates late in Europe compared with Friday's rates, were: 1.6829 West German marks, down from 1.6945; 1.5085 Swiss francs, up from 1.5080; 5.6895 French francs, down from 5.7245; 1.8970 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9077; 1,244.25 Italian lire, down from 1,251.00; and 1.1836 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1802. Gold and silver prices mostly moved modestly higher. The closing bid for a troy ounce of gold in London, the major market, was $402.45, up from $400.50. The Zurich closing bid was $402.50, up from $401. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $401.75 bid, up from $399.75. In New York, silver bullion for March delivery closed at $5.101 a troy ounce, up from Friday's settlement of $5.093. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid $5.13 a troy ounce, unchanged from Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Airlines Announces First Class Fare Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines announced Monday it was cutting first class fares by about 40 percent in an effort to attract more business travelers and was sweetening travel agent commissions for sales of the new, cut-rate tickets. The lower fares, called ``Y-Not fares,'' are good for domestic travel through June 30, carry no penalties, are fully refundable and can be booked up to flight time. ``With the Y-Not fare, you can buy them at anytime and fly at anytime,'' said George Brennan, vice president of marketing for the Miami-based carrier. Some industry analysts expressed surprise at the size of the fare cuts, which put Eastern's first-class tickets about 15 percent below the industry's full coach fares. But they said they did not expect other carriers to immediately match or lower their rates. ``It's a marketing move, a promotional program,'' said Robert Decker, analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago. ``We might see some selective matching by other airlines but I wouldn't expect a widespread move at this point.'' Eastern is reorganizing under bankruptcy court protection from creditors, where it sought protection following a crippling strike by pilots, machinists and flight attendants a year ago. Decker said Eastern's success in emerging from bankruptcy depends on getting business travelers back in significant numbers. ``They're trying to get the business traveler back on and fill up the first class section which is probably flying empty right now,'' Decker said. Eastern claims its 9,000 daily first-class seats are 65 percent full, although Brennan conceded at a New York news conference that many passengers now flying first class on Eastern are frequent flier passengers upgraded from coach. Current industry first class fares between New York and Miami are $437 one-way, while the lowest full-coach fare is $333, according to figures supplied by Eastern. The new ``Y-Not'' fare on that route is $276 one way _ $10 above Eastern's current full-coach fare. Between Chicago and Atlanta, the current first-class, one-way fare is $537, full-coach is $360 and Eastern's Y-Not fare is $298. Eastern passengers with full-coach fare tickets will be able to exchange their tickets for first-class seats for $10 more. Eastern's full-coach fares, the lowest in the industry, are $10 less than the ``Y-Not'' fares. Eastern said it expects the lower fares to generate about $400,000 a day more in net revenue. The fares are good for travel in the United States, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Andrew Geller, analyst with Provident National Bank in Philadelphia, said the increase in travel agent commissions will help Eastern improve relations between the carrier and its travel agents. Standard commissions industrywide amount to about 10 percent. Eastern will boost the commissions on ``Y-Not'' tickets to 15 percent. Many agents have been wary of putting customers on Eastern because of the carrier's financial problems. ``Some travel agents have not been booking on Eastern for fear that in the future clients might get stranded,'' Geller said. ``By doing this, it tries to get around that fear.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Climb As Brazil's Perceieved Output Drops
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose sharply Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk of lower-than-expected Brazilian soybean yields and diminishing fears that Brazil's economic reforms will lead to a flood of soybean marketings. On other commodity markets, coffee, sugar and cocoa futures fell sharply; livestock and meat futures advanced; petroleum futures were mixed; and precious metals were higher. Soybean futures settled 6 cents to 8\ cents higher with March at $5.90 a bushel. The soybean market opened lower on expectations that sweeping economic reforms announced last week in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer, would stimulate farmer sales of soybeans there. Of greatest concern was a plan to replace Brazil's currency, the cruzado novo, with a new currency, the cruzeiro, which would feature free-floating foreign exchange rates. Many experts believe the cruzeiro will be sharply devalued, which would prompt farmers to sell soybeans to obtain dollars or other hard currency. But analysts saw no significant increase in Brazilian sales over the weekend or on Monday, said Steve Freed, a grain market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Meanwhile, analysts said Memphis-based Sparks Commodities Inc. released an estimate of the Brazilian soybean crop pegging production at 19.5 million metric tons instead of the 20.5 million projected last month by the U.S. Agriculture Department. Sparks would not confirm the number. But analysts said indications of lower-than-expected Brazilian soybean yields _ the harvest began about two weeks ago _ have prompted a great deal of speculation that the crop will be smaller than the USDA's estimate. ``The smaller the Brazilian crop, the less it will compete with our beans once we get into the new crop year'' at the beginning of September, said Anne Frick, senior oilseeds analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Wheat futures settled were 2} cents to 9 cents higher with March at $3.98{ a bushel; corn was 3 cents to 3} cents higher with March at $2.51 a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2{ cents higher with March at $1.48{ a bushel. Selling linked to the Brazilian economic reforms dominated the coffee, cocoa and sugar markets. Brazil is a major producer of all three commodities. On New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, coffee futures finished 1.5 cents to 2.67 cents lower with March at 87 cents a pound; sugar settled .02 cent to .26 cent lower with May at 15.87 cents a pound; cocoa futures settled $20 to $36 lower with March at $1,095 a ton. Livestock and meat futures made strong gains on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, largely in reaction to Friday's monthly USDA cattle-on-feed report, which showed more active feedlot marketings than traders had expected. Live cattle futures settled .42 cent to .78 cent higher with April at 78.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .23 cent to .37 cent higher with March at 82.95 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .30 cent higher with April at 53.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .82 cent to .90 cent higher with March at 51.45 cents a pound. Near-month crude-oil futures edged lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concerns about high OPEC production. Gasoline futures also fell while heating oil firmed on indications of tight near-term availability. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 47 cents lower to 5 cents higher with April at $19.60 a barrel; heating oil was .08 cent to .20 cent higher with April at 54.54 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .35 cent to .86 cent lower with April at 56.36 cents a gallon. Precious metal futures firmed slightly on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold settled $1 higher across the board wwith April at $401.90 a troy ounce; Silver was 0.8 cent to 1 cent higher with March at $5.101 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Computer Services President to Become President of Microsoft
DOC.TEXT: Michael R. Hallman, president of Boeing Computer Services, will become president and chief operating officer of Microsoft Corp., the software publishing company said Monday. Hallman, 44, will join Microsoft April 2 and will succeed Jon A. Shirley on June 30, when Shirley retires. Boeing Co., meanwhile, announced that Arthur E. Hitsman, executive vice president of Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, will replace Hallman, while John B. Sheridan will take over Hitsman's job. Sheridan is vice president and general manager of BA&E's Electronic Systems Division. Hallman, who has been president of BCS since November 1987, is responsible for all Boeing computing and communications systems, including the company's outside computer services, which had sales of $360 million in 1989. He managed a staff of 13,000 people. Microsoft employs about 5,000 people and had sales of $803.5 million in fiscal 1989. Hallman, who holds a master's degree in business from Michigan, has more than 23 years of computer experience. Before joining Boeing, he spent 20 years at IBM. Shirley will remain on Microsoft's board of directors and serve as a consultant to the company for strategic projects. Hitsman was named to his current post at Boeing in May 1989, when the former Boeing Aerospace and Boeing Electronics divisions were consolidated. Prior to that, he served as president of Boeing Electronics and vice president and general manager of the Ballistics Systems Division of Boeing Aerospace. Hitsman, who joined Boeing in 1950 as a design engineer, holds a master's degree in mechanical engineering from Oregon State.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. shares rebounded Monday in an impressive afternoon rally, shrugging off a steep decline in the Tokyo stock market to extend their recent advance. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished 14.41 points higher at 2,755.63, after hovering in negative territory most of the day. The blue-chip barometer had been down as much as 28 points earlier in the trading session. Advancing issues edged out declining ones in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 730 up, 700 down and 533 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 142.30 million shares, down from 222.52 million in Friday's session. Analysts said Wall Street was buoyed by positive market sentiment and continued strength in the dollar. The dollar continued to climb against the Japanese yen, as dealers grew impatient waiting for the Tokyo government to raise the country's key interest rates, a move which has been expected for weeks. A Japanese news report late in U.S. trading said rate increases could be made Tuesday. The U.S. currency was quoted late in New York at 153.05 yen, up from 152.65 yen late Friday. In Japan Monday, anxiety about a possible interest rate hike and the yen's decline against the dollar sent the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeting to a 14-month low. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which fell 55.20 points on Friday, plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, Monday. Its closing of 31,263.24 was the lowest since it closed at 31,170.38 on Jan. 20, 1989. The nervousness spilled over to Wall Street Monday morning but later eased. ``Once the selloff was over, the bullishness that was there for the last few weeks continued to be reflected in the market,'' said Rao Chalasani, an investment strategist at Prescott, Ball & Turben in Cleveland, Ohio. On Friday, the Dow Jones average jumped 44.60 to 2,740.32, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. Analysts said some stocks in New York were helped Monday by news that UAL Corp.'s unions and biggest shareholder have mounted a joint effort to install new directors in a shareholder proxy fight and buy the airline company for around $3.8 billion, or more than $175 a share. Five months ago, the collapse of a debt-financed offer for UAL, parent of United Airlines, touched off a major tumble in the stock market and raised the first big doubts about the future of the corporate takeover craze of the 1980s. The Dow average plunged 190 points last Oct. 13, the day the $300-a-share offer collapsed. UAL stock closed Monday at 154{ a share, up 12 from Friday's close. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 170.25 million shares. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, General Electric jumped ~ to 64~, IBM was up ] at 109, Upjohn surged 1] to 39, Boeing advanced 1} to 71{ and Rorer rose 1\ to 67. Phillips Petroleum was down ] at 25\ and Norton slipped [ to 74}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $11.67 billion, or 0.35 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.74 to 188.66. Standard & Poor's industrial index advanced 2.40 to 398.80, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 1.62 to 343.53. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 0.75 to 442.91. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 364.12, down 0.06.

DOC.HEAD: Takeover Investor, Unions In New Bid For UAL
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf with three grafs to UPDATE with closing stock price and add quote from Coniston investor.
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s unions and biggest shareholder announced a $3.8 billion buyout offer Monday for the airline company, a mostly cash deal worth about 40 percent less than a debt-financed effort that collapsed five months ago. UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf _ who helped lead last year's ill-fated buyout deal _ issued a statement saying the board would consider the offer, which shattered a lull in the maneuvering for the parent of United Airlines. The outcome could help determine the shape of takeovers in the tight-money atmosphere that has prevailed since the collapse of the earlier $6.8 billion deal, which contributed to a plunge in the stock market and raised some of the biggest doubts about the future of the corporate merger craze of the 1980s. Airline analysts said financing for the new bid could be a problem. The depression in the junk-bond market and demise of its pioneer Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., formerly a leading source of takeover financing, also could present major obstacles. Coniston Partners, a New York investment firm that owns 11.8 percent of UAL's approximately 21.8 million shares outstanding, disclosed the plan with the United pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions. United is the nation's second-largest airline after American Airlines. Coniston said the group plans to lobby shareholders for their proxy votes in favor of electing a new slate of directors at UAL's annual meeting April 26. If they are successful, the new directors will push for accepting the Coniston-union takeover, which will give UAL's employees _ including nonunion workers _ 75 percent ownership of the company. The plan would pay stockholders $150 in cash and $25 in securities, plus non-voting common stock amounting to 25 percent of the total in the company, for each of their shares. Based on UAL's 21.8 million shares outstanding, the offer would be worth about $3.8 billion. UAL stock rose $12 to $154.50 a share Monday in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. The shares have recently traded as low as $121. Keith Gollust, one of Coniston's three principal partners, said in a telephone interview that they were undertaking the proxy fight because UAL's board was moving too slowly on Coniston's longstanding demand that the company be sold or restructured. ``Our decision to nominate a slate of directors in opposition to the incumbents was based on our disappointment that the board was unable to produce another transaction,'' he said. Wolf's statement said UAL's board would consider the offer carefully and meet to discuss it along with unspecified alternatives for raising the value of UAL shares. No meeting date was announced. It was unclear how Coniston and the unions intended to finance the takeover. They said the deal would include new labor agreements, such as no-strike commitments, and ``result in substantial labor cost savings.'' Airline analyst Kevin Murphy of Morgan Stanley & Co. said the group's ability to obtain financing was the key to their plan. ``It's going to be hard for them to win a proxy fight unless they can show the shareholders they've got some financial clout,'' Murphy said. But Jack Hunter, an airlines analyst with Howe Barnes Investments Inc., said UAL owns about 240 airplanes, more than half of United's fleet, that could be used as collateral to secure a large enough loan for the proposed deal. Hunter estimated the planes are worth $4 billion. He predicted UAL's board would agree to a buyout and avoid a proxy fight. ``I don't think there's going to be a war,'' Hunter said. ``I think the board is ready to get out of this.'' UAL has been in a takeover target since early last August, when Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis offered $4.3 billion for the company. The pilot-management coalition eventually won a deal with its $300 a share, $6.8 billion offer. The Oct. 13 collapse of that offer, which was to be financed largely with borrowed money, was considered one of the major events in the era of corporate takeovers because it helped instill deep skepticism about whether such deals would continue. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 190 points that day. The subsequent slump of the market for high-interest junk bonds widely used to finance buyouts helped curb the takeover frenzy. Airline acquisitions in particular have been considered risky because of uncertainties about the economy and health of the airline industry. In January, the three unions proposed an employee purchase of 75 percent of UAL and the board instructed its advisers to help the unions put together a formal bid. The relationship soured when the union group indicated it planned to dump Wolf. The chairman has taken a hard line in labor negotiations and would have received $76 million in cash and a 10 percent stake in UAL as part of last year's failed bid. Coniston's buyout plan mirrors the firm's attack on UAL predecessor Allegis Corp. in 1987. The firm acquired a stake in Allegis and threatened to mount a takeover if the company did not divest its non-airline businesses, which Coniston believed were hindering corporate earnings and depressing the value of its shareholdings. Allegis ended up selling its Hertz car rental, Westin Hotel Co., and Hilton International chains and renaming itself UAL.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Oil, Gasoline Futures Drop
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices ended mixed Monday in fairly active trading, as crude oil and gasoline continued the downward trend started last week. Crude oil pierced the $20 mark for the first time in more than three months as sellers went on a binge early in the session, analysts said. However, prices recovered from their lows shortly after midday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 47 cents to close at $19.60 a 42-gallon barrel after sinking to $19.44 earlier in the session. The near-term contract last closed under $20 on Nov. 30, when it finished at $19.89. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for April delivery, which dropped 1.11 cents at one point during the session, ended 0.60 cent lower at 56.36 cents a gallon. ``There's just too much gasoline around,'' said Kevin Breslin, energy analyst with United Energy Inc. ``And most of what's out there is premium, the kind everybody wants.'' Meanwhile, the April contract for No. 2 heating oil rose .08 cent to 54.54 a gallon. ``There are a lot of factors affecting prices right now, including the selling trend last week due to high stocks and low demand and crude oil breaking through technical levels,'' said Peter Beutel, energy broker and analyst with Elders Futures Inc. Analysts said demand for crude oil has fallen off sharply due partly to annual refinery maintenance, when refineries slow operations and therefore use less crude oil to make products. Observers also attributed some of the early sell-off to OPEC-related jitters. ``The fact that OPEC didn't do anything was another factor but I wouldn't put it at the top of the list,'' Beutel said. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' monitoring committee concluded a two-day meeting on Saturday after reviewing current market conditions in advance of the full OPEC ministerial conference in May. As expected, the oil ministers adjourned without making any formal decisions on production, despite the recent softening in prices and predictions of a further seasonal erosion in consumption during the second quarter.
