DOC.HEAD: Banks Taking Advantage Of Securities Loophole
DOC.TEXT: Large bank holding companies have moved swiftly to take advantage of a loophole in the legal wall separating banking from the securities industry, according to a congressional report. Bank holding companies, under a regulation passed by the Federal Reserve Board three years ago, started underwriting a limited amount of some previously forbidden securities in the July-September quarter of 1988. In that quarter, four companies underwrote $12.3 billion in securities, the General Accounting Office said in a report to the House Banking oversight subcommittee. By the July-September quarter of 1989, the latest period for which data was available, 13 companies underwrote $68.7 billion, up 90 percent from the previous quarter and 460 percent from a year earlier. Ninety-eight percent of the securities involved were commercial paper, short-term debt issued by large publicly traded companies. The figures also include municipal revenue bonds, mortgage-related securities and other asset-backed securities. The GAO said the bank activity represented about 1.9 percent of the combined markets in those securities. Another eight companies have gotten permission to receive underwriting what are termed ineligible securities but had not started yet. The Fed has also expanded the list of securities covered by the loophole to include corporate debt and is expected to soon approve the first bank underwriting of corporate stock. The GAO, Congress' auditing and investigative agency, said it was too soon to draw any conclusions about the profitability or riskiness of bank holding company affiliates involvement in securities. So far, the Fed has limited the holding companies to deriving no more than 10 percent of their revenue from ineligible securities. That restriction is in place to comply with the 1933 Glass-Steagall Act. The act separated commercial from investment banking in the wake of abuses thought to contribute to a wave of bank failures that followed the 1929 stock market crash. Next year, Congress is expected to reopen debate on whether and how to permit banks to move more broadly into the securities business.

DOC.HEAD: Unum Agrees To Purchase British Insurer
DOC.TEXT: Unum Corp. said it has agreed with London-based Invesco MIM PLC to purchase National Employers Life Assurance Holding Co. Ltd., for $64 million. The British company markets life insurance, mortgages and pension products in addition to permanent health insurance, Unum said Monday in a statement. The deal is subject to approval by the British government. Unum said it is also negotiating the purchase of some $24 million to $33 million of investments held for National Employers Life policyholders by a subsidiary, National Employers Life Permanent Health Insurance. The subsidiary is Britain's market leader in group permanent health insurance, which is similar to long-term disability insurance in the United States, Unum said. Portland-based Unum is a specialty insurance holding company that lists $8.6 billion in assets.

DOC.HEAD: Perkin-Elmer Sells Off Lithography Business
DOC.TEXT: Perkin-Elmer Corp. announced Monday it has sold its electron beam unit to a group of former and current managers backed by the investments of five other companies that either buy the unit's products or supply it with technology. The Electron Beam Technology Division, of Hayward, Calif., was sold to ETEC Inc., bringing together the leaders in the field of electron beam lithography, said Horace G. McDonnell, chairman and chief executive officer of Perkin-Elmer. Electron beam lithography involves etching patterns onto the wafers used in computer technology. The unit makes the machines that use the beam technology to imprint patterns. Perkin-Elmer has a second division that uses optical lithography to write the patterns. The company has been trying to sell both businesses as part of a restructuring announced last year, but it reportedly has had trouble finding an American buyer for the optical business. Reported interest last year by the Nikon Corp. of Japan raised concerns about foreign companies gaining control of critical technology. Recent reports identified Silicon Valley Group Inc. of San Jose, Calif., as a possible buyer, but company spokesman Edward Bloch declined to comment. No sale price was announced for the electron beam unit, which employs 500 in California, Japan and Europe. It will be run by former Perkin-Elmer officers Charles E. Minihan and Thomas Halloran, with equity participation from International Business Machines Corp., Micron Technology Inc., the Du Pont Co., the Grumman Corp. and Zitel Corp. Perkin-Elmer said IBM is investing in its own beam technology, said to have the most advanced capability in the world. The other businesses Perkin-Elmer has sold in the restructuring are the Electro-Optics Division, which built NASA's powerful Hubble space telescope, and a German aerospace unit. The units targeted for sale accounted for 40 percent of the company's 1988 sales.

DOC.HEAD: Heinz Interested in Buying Grey Poupon, A1
DOC.TEXT: H.J. Heinz Co. said Monday it is interested in buying RJR Nabisco's A1 steak sauce and Grey Poupon mustard lines but that no talks on a possible deal have occurred. Heinz is interested in the products although it already produces barbecue sauce under its Heinz 57 label and also manufactures mustard, said Ted Smyth, spokesman for the Pittsburgh-based food maker. On Saturday, Smyth said RJR Nabisco and Heinz were discussing a possible sale and that Heinz Chairman Anthony J. O'Reilly announced the talks in a meeting with Wall Street analysts last week. However, Heinz issued a statement Monday saying the company was not and had not been in talks about Grey Poupon and A1. But Smyth said on Monday that the company was interested in those brands. The investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. paid $24.53 billion last year to take RJR Nabisco private in the largest corporate takeover ever. The firm has been selling selected assets to reduce its debt load. RJR Nabisco already has sold its Del Monte fresh fruit and processed food businesses, some of its foreign operations and its Baby Ruth and Butterfinger candy business.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Tentative Labor Agreement
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Monday approved LTV Steel Co.'s tentative labor agreement with the United Steelworkers of America, allowing the union to begin sending ballots to 13,700 members. The ballots will be counted April 2 at USW headquarters in Pittsburgh. The proposed three-year contract covers LTV employees at 13 plants in Pennsylvania, Indiana, Illinois, Ohio, New York and Minnesota, according to Gary Hubbard, union spokesman. If approved, it will take effect April 15. The agreement, approved by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton I. Lifland in New York, restores past wage and benefit concessions, including an average of $1.59 an hour in wages cuts and the elimination of three holidays and one week of vacation. New wage increases average $1 an hour beginning Jan. 1, 1991 and 50 cents cents an hour beginning Jan. 1, 1992. Other provisions include: _A $500 immediate bonus and a $500 advance on 1990 profit sharing. _A new profit-sharing plan that gives employees 10 percent of company profits. The present plan was capped at the level of employee concessions. _A program to help protect employees against cost-of-living rises. _Elimination of previously scheduled increases in the cost of optional major medical coverage for retirees, with rates to remain at their 1989 levels through 1990. Beginning 1991, the company will pay 50 percent of cost increases. _Elimination of the $16.82 premium now paid for basic health care coverage by both active and retired employees.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Completes Sale of Gulfstream
DOC.TEXT: The $825 million sale of Chrysler Corp.'s Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. subsidiary to an investor group led by Gulfstream Chairman Allen Paulson has been completed, the automaker said Monday. Chrysler put the commercial aircraft maker up for sale in December in order to concentrate on its car and truck business. The nation's No. 3 automaker bought Gulfstream in 1985 for $627 million. In addition to eliminating a non-automotive subsidiary, the sale fattens Chrysler's coffers as the automaker wrestles with profitability. In the fourth quarter of 1989, Chrysler lost $664 million, mainly because of $577 million in write-offs for plant closings. It was the first quarterly loss the automaker suffered since 1982. A group formed by Paulson and the leveraged buyout firm Forstmann Little & Co. bought the Savannah, Ga.-based Gulfstream. Paulson, who founded Gulfstream in 1978, will remain as its chairman and chief executive. Gulfstream was the largest part of Chrysler Technologies Inc., which also included Electrospace Systems Inc. and Chrysler Technologies Airborne Systems Inc. Chrysler spokesman James Kenyon said Monday the other two subsidiaries still were for sale. He had no comment on negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Company Confirms Proxy Loss
DOC.TEXT: XTRA Corp. confirmed Monday it lost a proxy fight with a dissident shareholder group whose nominees were elected to the company's board of directors. XTRA, a trailer leasing company, said it had received the certified results of voting for directors. The dissident group is led by Connecticut investor Robert Gintel. In a statement, XTRA said the nominees of the dissident group, the XTRA Independent Stockholders Committee, each received about 70 percent of votes cast. After conceding defeat, XTRA Chairman Charles Kay said last week the company had reached an agreement with the dissident group for ``an orderly transition.'' Michael Soja, XTRA's vice president of finance and administration, said Monday there would be no announcement yet on changes at the company.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-UAL, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the major developments in the UAL Corp. buyout story: _June 1989: NWA Inc. accepts a $3.65 billion bid for Northwest Airlines from an investor group led by Alfred Checci, stirring takeover interest in airline companies. _August: Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis offers $5.4 billion, or $240 a share, for UAL Corp., the parent of United Airlines. He later sweetens the bid to $6.19 billion, or $275 a share. _Sept. 14: UAL directors accept a $6.75 billion offer, or $300 a share, from United's pilots, management and British Airways PLC. The offer includes labor and wage concessions. _Sept. 15: Davis says he will match the offer and demand no labor concessions. _Oct. 13: The $6.75 billion takeover by pilots, management and British Airways collapses when financing fails. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials falls nearly 200 points. _Oct. 17: Davis withdraws his matching bid for UAL. _Oct. 20: British Airways says it will no longer participate in takeover talks. _Oct. 30: United pilots, without a contract since April 1988, resume talks with the company. _Oct. 31: Machinists union says it won't join Davis in making a new offer for UAL. _Nov. 1: Investor Saul Steinberg tells the government he wants to buy 15 percent to 25 percent of UAL stock. _Nov. 3: The investment group Coniston Partners says it has a 9.7 percent stake in UAL and wants to reduce the size of the board of directors. _Jan. 8, 1990: UAL directors tell financial advisers to consider a recapitalization of the company. _Jan. 24: United's three labor unions say they are willing to buy 75 percent of the stock. Directors say it is not a formal acquisition bid, and they tell their advisers to try to come up with a firm proposal. _March 19: UAL unions and Coniston Partners announce a new $3.8 billion offer.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of Japan: Tokyo Market Decline Has Been Worse Than Expected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 2nd graf pvs to UPDATE with early Tuesday trading; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `The Nikkei's...
DOC.TEXT: As the Tokyo Stock Exchange took one of its worst beatings ever Monday, a senior Bank of Japan official reiterated that the central bank's key concern was inflation _ adding fuel to expectations for higher interest rates. Rattled by a stronger U.S. dollar and speculation that an interest rate hike was imminent, the exchange's Nikkei Stock Average plunged 1,353.20 points on Monday, a 4.15 percent tumble that marked its third biggest daily decline ever. The close at 31,263.24 points was the lowest for the Nikkei Stock Average since Jan. 20, 1989. The decline continued Tuesday. After a short upswing, the Nikkei was down 691.29 points, or 2.21 percent, at 30,571.95 in early trading. It was the first time the index dropped under 31,000, even temporarily, since Jan. 9, 1989. The Nikkei's decline on Monday was at least partly tied to the growing strength of the U.S. dollar against the Japanese yen, which could help fuel inflation in Japan. The Bank of Japan has attempted to stall the dollar's rise in recent months by selling billions of dollars in the currency markets. There also is speculation that the central bank will hike its benchmark discount rate to support the yen and fight inflation. In the stock market on Monday, many investors appeared to be selling shares as though a rate rise were imminent. Keiichi Nishida of Kidder Peabody Securities said: ``Because Monday's drop was not the result of panic selling, there is a widely shared fear in the market that share prices may fall even further until they really hit the bottom. ``But at this point, no one knows where the bottom really is,'' he said. The Bank of Japan official, who spoke to reporters Monday on condition of anonymity, said the stock market's rapid rise last year set the stage for a downward ``correction.'' He also said that if the market was having trouble finding its appropriate level, it is due to political factors and speculation. The official acknowledged that the correction _ which so far this year has cut nearly 20 percent from the Nikkei average _ had been larger than anticipated. But he reiterated that the central bank's primary concerns were elsewhere, particularly in controlling inflation. The Bank of Japan official said that although the central bank can't create specific exchange rate levels, its repeated intervention should influence the market over time. Nevertheless, the dollar continued rising Monday. It closed at a three-year high of 153.55 yen, up 1.05 yen from last Friday's close. Dealers said the Bank of Japan made large-scale interventions Monday to stem the yen's fall. One dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said the central bank bought at least $1 billion worth of yen Monday. The yen's prolonged weakness, coupled with signs of inflation, has convinced many stock and exchange market participants that another discount rate hike is looming. Higher interest rates tend to bolster the yen but depress stock prices. The Bank of Japan official appeared to give credence to the view that the bank will raise its key rate soon. Admitting that the timing of the rate hike is difficult, he said, ``It may be too late to act when the indicators are flashing.'' After several years of stability, the bank raised the discount rate _ its interest on loans to commercial banks _ three times last year, bringing it to 4.25 percent from 2.5 percent. Masaaki Tanahashi, a currency dealer with Mitsui Bank, said some market players were hesitant to buy the yen until the Bank of Japan actually raises the discount rate. The Dai-Ichi Kangyo dealer, who requested anonymity, said: ``I would not be surprised to see the dollar surpass the 154-yen mark before the interest rate hike actually happens.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Japan's Central Bank Raises Discount Rate
DOC.TEXT: Japan's central bank on Tuesday raised its official discount rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent, effective immediately. The decision followed a meeting of the Bank of Japan's special policy board, officials said. The nation's discount rate, the lending rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks, was 4.25 percent following three hikes last year. The rate increase was aimed at containing inflationary pressure building up in Japan despite three interest hikes last year. The jump in the rates was widely rumored for weeks. The central bank action is also expected to help stabilize the jittery Tokyo stock market, and to stem the yen's weakness against the U.S. dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Narrow Losses, Dollar Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with morning Nikkei close, dollar, Bank of Japan discount rate hike
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange was slightly lower at the close of morning trading Tuesday in wide fluctuations following the third-worst drop in its history. The U.S. dollar declined against the Japanese yen. The dollar ended the morning session at 152.90 yen. It opened at 152.70 yen, down 0.85 yen from Monday's close at 153.55 yen, and ranged between 152.45 yen and 153.55 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 156.67 points, or 0.50 percent, ending morning trading at 31,106.57 after wild ups and downs. The Nikkei gained more than 260 points after trading began, then quickly plunged about 700 points. ``The market is gradually recovering,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a dealer with Daiwa Securities Co. He said news reports that the Bank of Japan might raise its official discount rate during lunchtime lent the market some support. ``With the discount rate hike, the market will recover at least temporarily because there is one less factor to worry about,'' Suzuki said. Japan's central bank later raised its official discount rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent, effective immediately. The decision followed a meeting of the Bank of Japan's special policy board. The official discount rate is the interest rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks, and has a strong impact on other interest rates. In its third-largest single-day drop, the Nikkei on Monday fell 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, to 31,263.24, its lowest close since Jan. 20, 1989. Dealers attributed the plunge to a stronger dollar and the looming discount rate hike. Dealers said the index started higher Tuesday as market players bought issues to make up their short, or oversold, positions after the plunge. But they soon began selling shares again due to lingering pessimism following the dollar's continuous surge. In currency dealings, the dollar was moving narrowly around the 153-yen level, traders said. Despite the discount rate rumors, the yen failed to rise as many market players bought the dollar near 152.50 yen. ``Market players did not jump at the yen because they still think that the Bank of Japan may not raise its discount rate despite all these news reports,'' said Masato Hayashi, a Bank of Tokyo trader. But he said dollar-buyers also were cautious in case of the discount rate hike. The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond was up from Monday's close at 86.50. Its yield was quoted at 7.16 percent, down from the previous day's 7.24 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Approve Railroad Sale
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators Monday agreed to allow the sale of most assets of the Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Co. railroad without requiring protection of workers who would lose their jobs. The Interstate Commerce Commission voted 4-1 against requiring more help for workers than the acquirer, Railroad Development Corp., already has promised. Railroad Development, on suburban Green Tree, has said it will offer the jobs it retains to current P&LE employees in order of seniority. It also will credit those rehired with their years of service and negotiate new contracts with their unions. The company told the commission it plans to retain a work force of 150 to 200 rather the the 417 non-management workers currently working. Dan Vogel, president of Local 1427 of the Transport Workers Union at P&LE and a freight car repairman, called the vote unfortunate. ``We have to find out if RDC is willing to negotiate a fair and reasonable agreement,'' he said. Railroad Development is paying $33 million for 146.6 miles of the P&LE line in Ohio and Pennsylvania, more than 2,200 freight cars and locomotives and the rights to use other railroads' tracks in several states.
